LLM_completions.prefix-probing: We will leave Danglars struggling with the demon of hatred, and endeavoring to insinuate in the ear of the shipowner some evil suspicions against his comrade, and follow Dantès, who, after having traversed La Canebière, took the Rue de Noailles, and entering a small house, on the left of the Allées de Meilhan, rapidly ascended four flights of a dark staircase, holding the baluster with one hand, while with the other he repressed the beatings of his heart, and paused before a half-open door, from which he could see the whole of a small room. This room was clean, though poor. A few pieces of furniture, plain and necessary, composed its whole wealth. A wooden table, four chairs, a chest of drawers, and a bed, were all it contained. But on the bed was seated a young woman, whose beauty was so remarkable that it instantly attracted the eye of the young sailor. She was of the Catalans, a race of people of Spanish origin, who inhabit a quarter of the city of Marseilles near the sea, and who preserve with jealous care their ancient customs and the purity of their blood. Mercédès was dressed in a red and black bodice, and a skirt of the same colors; a golden bodkin confined her hair, and her ears were adorned with long, dangling earrings. Her eyes, of the deepest black, sparkled with a fire that seemed to have been kindled in the East; her lips were of a coral red, and her teeth of the purest pearl. She was leaning her elbow on the chest of drawers, and her head on her hand, in an attitude of thoughtful melancholy. At the sound of Dantès' step, she raised her head, and a cry of joy escaped her lips. Dantès rushed into the room, and in an instant Mercédès was in his arms. 'Oh, Edmond! my dear Edmond!' she cried, 'you are safe! you are here! I have been so anxious!' 'My beautiful Mercédès!' said Dantès, pressing her to his heart, 'I am here, and I am happy, since I see you.' 'But you must have traveled with great speed?' 'I did, indeed. The good ship *Pharaon* sailed like a bird. And what is more, Mercédès, I am here to stay. My good employer, M. Morrel, has promised me the command of the *Pharaon* as soon as the present captain retires, and that will be very soon. Think of it, Mercédès, I, a captain at twenty years of age!' 'A captain! Oh, Edmond, that is good news indeed!' 'And with the command, Mercédès, comes a good salary, and a position that will allow me to provide for you and my father as you deserve. We will be rich, Mercédès, or at least, we will be comfortable. No more poverty, no more struggling.' 'That is not what makes me happy, Edmond,' said Mercédès, looking at him with eyes full of love. 'It is seeing you, knowing you are safe, and knowing that you love me.' 'And I love you more than life itself, Mercédès. And now that I am a captain, and can support a wife, there is nothing to prevent our marriage. We will be married as soon as possible, my Mercédès, the day after tomorrow, if you wish.' A blush spread over the cheeks of Mercédès. 'So soon, Edmond?' 'Why delay? We have waited long enough. My father will be happy, too. Where is he?' 'He is not well, Edmond. He has been very anxious about you. He is in his room.' Dantès' brow clouded. 'Not well? What is the matter?' 'He is old, Edmond, and he has suffered. He has been in want.' 'In want?' cried Dantès, his voice trembling with emotion. 'My father in want? While I was away, earning money?' 'Do not blame yourself, Edmond. He would not let me help him much. He is proud.' Dantès rushed towards the door of the adjoining room. He found his father seated in an armchair, pale and thin. At the sight of his son, the old man uttered a cry and stretched out his arms. Dantès threw himself on his knees before him, and buried his head in his father's lap. 'Father! my dear father! What is this? You are ill!' 'No, my son, I am well now that I see you,' said the old man, his voice broken by sobs. 'But you have suffered, father. Mercédès told me.' 'A little, my son, a little. But it is over now. You are here.' 'And I will never leave you again, father. I will take care of you. We will all live together, Mercédès, you, and I. I am a captain now, father, a captain! And I am going to marry Mercédès the day after tomorrow.' The old man looked from his son to Mercédès, his eyes filled with tears of joy. 'A captain! Married! Oh, my son, God has blessed us!' Mercédès knelt beside Dantès, and took the old man's hand. 'We will be a happy family,' she said softly. 'Yes, yes,' murmured the old man, 'a happy family.' Dantès rose and helped his father to his feet

events.title: Caderousse's Insincere Visit and Subtle Undermining
detailed_summary: Caderousse, a tailor and neighbor, enters, with old Dantès assuming he has come to offer genuine congratulations on Edmond's return.
Dantès perceives Caderousse's insincerity but maintains a polite demeanor.
Caderousse makes a point of stating he needs nothing, recalling that he once lent money to Dantès, which was repaid, implying they are even.
Dantès responds that one is never truly quits with those who offer help, as gratitude remains.
Caderousse explains that he met Danglars, who informed him of Dantès' return and directed him to the apartment.
Old Dantès speaks highly of Caderousse's supposed loyalty, a sentiment Caderousse readily affirms, claiming to value honest people.

Caderousse's eyes fix greedily on the money Dantès had placed on the table. Dantès deflects by saying it's his father's purse, emptied to show he wasn't in want, and offers some to Caderousse, who declines.
The conversation shifts to Dantès' standing with M. Morrel. Caderousse criticizes Dantès for refusing Morrel's dinner invitation, suggesting it was ill-advised for someone aspiring to be captain.
Dantès clarifies he declined in order to see his father sooner and trusts M. Morrel understood his reasons.
Caderousse insinuates that flattery is necessary for career advancement, but Dantès expresses his hope to become captain based on merit alone.
Caderousse then brings up Mercédès, prompting Dantès to ask his father's permission to visit her, which the old man gladly gives, blessing his son's anticipated marriage.

Caderousse interjects that Mercédès is not yet Dantès' wife and pointedly mentions that beautiful girls like her have numerous admirers and receive significant offers, subtly attempting to sow doubt in Dantès' mind.
Dantès, though slightly unsettled, reaffirms his unwavering trust in Mercédès' fidelity, whether he becomes captain or not.
Caderousse encourages Dantès to go to Mercédès immediately to share his news and prospects.
Dantès agrees, embraces his father, gives Caderousse a nod, and departs.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “’Tis Caderousse, who has heard of your arrival, and no doubt comes to congratulate you on your fortunate return.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “I will go directly,” was Edmond’s reply; and, embracing his father, and nodding to Caderousse, he left the apartment.

events.text_segment:
“’Tis Caderousse, who has heard of your arrival, and no doubt comes to congratulate you on your fortunate return.”
“Ah, lips that say one thing, while the heart thinks another,” murmured Edmond. “But, never mind, he is a neighbor who has done us a service on a time, so he’s welcome.”
As Edmond paused, the black and bearded head of Caderousse appeared at the door. He was a man of twenty-five or six, and held a piece of cloth, which, being a tailor, he was about to make into a coat-lining.
“What, is it you, Edmond, back again?” said he, with a broad Marseillaise accent, and a grin that displayed his ivory-white teeth.
“Yes, as you see, neighbor Caderousse; and ready to be agreeable to you in any and every way,” replied Dantès, but ill-concealing his coldness under this cloak of civility.
“Thanks—thanks; but, fortunately, I do not want for anything; and it chances that at times there are others who have need of me.” Dantès made a gesture. “I do not allude to you, my boy. No!—no! I lent you money, and you returned it; that’s like good neighbors, and we are quits.”
“We are never quits with those who oblige us,” was Dantès’ reply; “for when we do not owe them money, we owe them gratitude.”
“What’s the use of mentioning that? What is done is done. Let us talk of your happy return, my boy. I had gone on the quay to match a piece of mulberry cloth, when I met friend Danglars. ‘You at Marseilles?’—‘Yes,’ says he.
“‘I thought you were at Smyrna.’—‘I was; but am now back again.’
“‘And where is the dear boy, our little Edmond?’
“‘Why, with his father, no doubt,’ replied Danglars. And so I came,” added Caderousse, “as fast as I could to have the pleasure of shaking hands with a friend.”
“Worthy Caderousse!” said the old man, “he is so much attached to us.”
“Yes, to be sure I am. I love and esteem you, because honest folks are so rare. But it seems you have come back rich, my boy,” continued the tailor, looking askance at the handful of gold and silver which Dantès had thrown on the table.
The young man remarked the greedy glance which shone in the dark eyes of his neighbor. “Eh,” he said, negligently, “this money is not mine. I was expressing to my father my fears that he had wanted many things in my absence, and to convince me he emptied his purse on the table. Come, father” added Dantès, “put this money back in your box—unless neighbor Caderousse wants anything, and in that case it is at his service.”
“No, my boy, no,” said Caderousse. “I am not in any want, thank God, my living is suited to my means. Keep your money—keep it, I say;—one never has too much;—but, at the same time, my boy, I am as much obliged by your offer as if I took advantage of it.”
“It was offered with good will,” said Dantès.
“No doubt, my boy; no doubt. Well, you stand well with M. Morrel I hear,—you insinuating dog, you!”
“M. Morrel has always been exceedingly kind to me,” replied Dantès.
“Then you were wrong to refuse to dine with him.”
“What, did you refuse to dine with him?” said old Dantès; “and did he invite you to dine?”
“Yes, my dear father,” replied Edmond, smiling at his father’s astonishment at the excessive honor paid to his son.
“And why did you refuse, my son?” inquired the old man.
“That I might the sooner see you again, my dear father,” replied the young man. “I was most anxious to see you.”
“But it must have vexed M. Morrel, good, worthy man,” said Caderousse. “And when you are looking forward to be captain, it was wrong to annoy the owner.”
“But I explained to him the cause of my refusal,” replied Dantès, “and I hope he fully understood it.”
“Yes, but to be captain one must do a little flattery to one’s patrons.”
“I hope to be captain without that,” said Dantès.
“So much the better—so much the better! Nothing will give greater pleasure to all your old friends; and I know one down there behind the Saint Nicolas citadel who will not be sorry to hear it.”
“Mercédès?” said the old man.
“Yes, my dear father, and with your permission, now I have seen you, and know you are well and have all you require, I will ask your consent to go and pay a visit to the Catalans.”
“Go, my dear boy,” said old Dantès; “and Heaven bless you in your wife, as it has blessed me in my son!”
“His wife!” said Caderousse; “why, how fast you go on, father Dantès; she is not his wife yet, as it seems to me.”
“No, but according to all probability she soon will be,” replied Edmond.
“Yes—yes,” said Caderousse; “but you were right to return as soon as possible, my boy.”
“And why?”
“Because Mercédès is a very fine girl, and fine girls never lack followers; she particularly has them by dozens.”
“Really?” answered Edmond, with a smile which had in it traces of slight uneasiness.
“Ah, yes,” continued Caderousse, “and capital offers, too; but you know, you will be captain, and who could refuse you then?”
“Meaning to say,” replied Dantès, with a smile which but ill-concealed his trouble, “that if I were not a captain——”
“Eh—eh!” said Caderousse, shaking his head.
“Come, come,” said the sailor, “I have a better opinion than you of women in general, and of Mercédès in particular; and I am certain that, captain or not, she will remain ever faithful to me.”
“So much the better—so much the better,” said Caderousse. “When one is going to be married, there is nothing like implicit confidence; but never mind that, my boy,—go and announce your arrival, and let her know all your hopes and prospects.”
“I will go directly,” was Edmond’s reply; and, embracing his father, and nodding to Caderousse, he left the apartment.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
’Tis Caderousse, who has heard of your arrival, and no doubt comes to congratulate you on your fortunate return.”

“Ah, father,” said Edmond, turning towards the door, “I am not deceived in my foreboding; here is M. Caderousse.”

Caderousse was a man of about five-and-twenty, a tailor by profession, and living in the next apartment to old Dantès. He was one of those men who, having always been poor, are eternally devoured by envy. Not so much, however, of the higher class, as of their equals, when one of these last happens to rise above the others. Caderousse would have been really grieved to see a prince, or even a duke, made a peer of France, but his face became livid, and his eyes were bloodshot, when a neighbor, a mere carpenter, like himself, inherited a legacy, or when a young fellow, like Dantès, hitherto as poor as he, had saved a dowry of a hundred louis to marry a girl who brought him fifty.

Caderousse entered the apartment of old Dantès with a smile, which, notwithstanding the tailor’s desire to render it fawning, was replete with that inward joy which the sight of any misfortune to our worst enemies produces in us. Dantès, who was a shrewd observer, and always on his guard against hypocrites, divined the feeling of the tailor, and his smile immediately disappeared, to be replaced by a serious and cold expression.

Edmond’s father was, on the contrary, a man of the most confiding nature; he saw in the smile of Caderousse nothing but a mark of friendship for his son, and of pleasure at his return. “Come in, Caderousse, come in,” said he, “and you can felicitate Edmond, who has been restored to us, safe and sound, and who will, I hope, never leave us again.”

“With all my heart,” said Caderousse, “and I am very glad to see him, M. Dantès. He has had a capital voyage, it seems.”

“Yes, my friend,” replied Dantès, “God has been very kind to me.”

“As God is to all who are as good as you are,” rejoined Caderousse. “Ah, it is a fine thing to have a good father, who is proud of his son. And it is a fine thing to be lucky, like you, at twenty-one. But I didn’t come to disturb you, I know you must have much to say.”

“No, no, Caderousse; sit down,” said Dantès, motioning to a chair; “and tell me what news there is of the Rue Saint-Ferréol, and the Cannebière, and the Cours Saint-Louis.”

“Why, nothing particular; only the talk is about your speedy promotion, and about the splendid fortune you are about to make, and then, about the pretty girl you are going to marry, who is as beautiful as a queen.”

“She is a worthy girl, Caderousse,” said Dantès, “and one who will render me very happy.”

“That is what you deserve, my boy,” said old Dantès; “for you have been a good son to me, and God will reward you by giving you a good wife.”

“That is all very well,” said Caderousse, “but it is a pity that the marriage cannot take place directly, as you are obliged to go to Paris.”

“Ah, yes,” said Dantès, “that is true.”

“But,” observed Caderousse, “why not get married before you go?”

“Because,” replied Dantès, “everything is not yet arranged; and I wish to be able to leave my wife in a comfortable position.”

“Ah, that is very thoughtful of you,” said Caderousse, with a smile that was more like a grimace. “But you know, my dear fellow, that ‘delays are dangerous,’ and that when a girl is pretty, there are always plenty of suitors.”

“Oh, Mercédès is not a coquette,” said Dantès, with a proud smile; “and I am sure that she will wait for me.”

“So much the better for you,” said Caderousse; “but still, you know, a voyage to Paris is a long voyage, and during that time, who knows what may happen?”

“The only thing that can happen,” said Dantès, “is that I shall be made captain; and in that case, I shall be able to offer Mercédès a position worthy of her.”

“Ah, that is a very good reason,” said Caderousse; “and I hope with all my heart that you will succeed.”

“Thank you, Caderousse,” said Dantès; “and now, as you say, I must leave my father, and go and see Mercédès.”

“Yes, yes, go,” said old Dantès; “and may God bless you, my dear boy, and your wife, and your children.”

Edmond embraced his father, nodded to Caderousse, and left the apartment.

“’Tis Caderousse, who has heard of your arrival, and no doubt comes to congratulate you on your fortunate return.”

The door opened, and a man entered, whose appearance was in perfect keeping with the description given by the innkeeper. He was a man of forty or forty-five, with a coarse, sun-burnt face, and eyes that shifted uneasily. His clothes were ragged and stained, and he walked with the unsteady gait of one who had been drinking heavily. He stopped short on seeing the Abbé Busoni, and his expression changed from one of hopeful anticipation to cautious suspicion.

“Good evening, Father,” he mumbled, pulling awkwardly at his cap. “They told me… they told me a holy man was here, asking about… about old times.”

“Enter, my son,” said the abbé, his voice calm and measured, giving no hint of the tempest raging within him. “You are Caderousse, are you not? The innkeeper spoke of you.”

Caderousse shuffled forward, his eyes darting between the abbé and the table where a bottle of wine stood. “Aye, Father, that’s me. Caderousse. And you are…?”

“I am a humble servant of God, travelling and seeking knowledge,” replied Busoni. “I have heard tales of this region, and of a young man named Edmond Dantès, whose fate was most unfortunate. I understand you knew him?”

At the mention of Edmond’s name, Caderousse’s face clouded over, a mixture of fear and regret crossing his features. He glanced nervously at the innkeeper, who discreetly withdrew, leaving them alone.

“Edmond Dantès?” Caderousse repeated, his voice lower. “Aye, I knew him. A fine lad, he was. Honest, brave… destined for great things, everyone said.” He paused, then added with a sigh, “Until misfortune struck.”

“Misfortune indeed,” said the abbé, leaning forward slightly. “I have heard whispers of betrayal, of enemies who envied his success. Is there truth to these rumours?”

Caderousse hesitated, licking his dry lips. He eyed the wine bottle again. The abbé followed his gaze. “Perhaps a glass of wine would help loosen your tongue, my son? It has been a long day, no doubt.”

Caderousse’s eyes lit up. “Ah, Father, you are too kind!” He eagerly poured himself a generous measure, drank it down in one gulp, and poured another. The wine seemed to embolden him, washing away some of his reticence.

“Betrayal, you say?” he began, wiping his mouth with the back of his hand. “Aye, there was betrayal. Foul betrayal. It was all because of a letter, you see. A letter written to the public prosecutor.”

“A letter?” the abbé prompted, his heart pounding beneath his cassock, though his face remained impassive. “Who wrote this letter, and what did it say?”

events.title: Danglars and Caderousse Scheme Against Dantès
detailed_summary: After Dantès leaves, Caderousse lingers briefly before departing to meet Danglars, who is waiting for him nearby.
Danglars immediately questions Caderousse about his encounter with Dantès, specifically asking if Dantès mentioned his prospects of becoming captain.
Caderousse confirms that Dantès spoke of the captaincy as a certainty, attributing this confidence to a promise from M. Morrel.
Caderousse embellishes his account, portraying Dantès as arrogant and condescending, claiming Dantès offered him patronage and a loan as if he were already a person of high status.
Danglars reacts with doubt, remarking that Dantès is not yet a captain.
Caderousse concurs, expressing that it would be preferable if Dantès did not get the promotion, as he would become unbearable.
Danglars makes a veiled threat, suggesting that if they choose, Dantès will not only fail to become captain but might even find himself in a worse position.
The conversation turns to Dantès' relationship with Mercédès. Danglars inquires if Dantès is still in love with her.
Caderousse affirms Dantès' deep affection for Mercédès but, driven by his dislike of 'upstarts,' hints at impending trouble for Dantès concerning her.

Under pressure from Danglars, Caderousse reveals that he has repeatedly seen Mercédès in the city accompanied by a tall, striking Catalan man whom she calls her cousin, implying a potential romantic rival.
Caderousse confirms that Dantès had just left to visit the Catalans.
Danglars proposes they proceed to La Réserve, a local establishment, to drink and await news of Dantès and Mercédès, with Danglars offering to cover the expense.

They encounter Père Pamphile, who informs them that Dantès passed by only minutes earlier on his way to the Catalans. Assured, Danglars and Caderousse settle down to wait amidst the pleasant spring scenery.

events.text_segment:
Caderousse lingered for a moment, then taking leave of old Dantès, he went downstairs to rejoin Danglars, who awaited him at the corner of the Rue Senac.
“Well,” said Danglars, “did you see him?”
“I have just left him,” answered Caderousse.
“Did he allude to his hope of being captain?”
“He spoke of it as a thing already decided.”
“Indeed!” said Danglars, “he is in too much hurry, it appears to me.”
“Why, it seems M. Morrel has promised him the thing.”
“So that he is quite elated about it?”
“Why, yes, he is actually insolent over the matter—has already offered me his patronage, as if he were a grand personage, and proffered me a loan of money, as though he were a banker.”
“Which you refused?”
“Most assuredly; although I might easily have accepted it, for it was I who put into his hands the first silver he ever earned; but now M. Dantès has no longer any occasion for assistance—he is about to become a captain.”
“Pooh!” said Danglars, “he is not one yet.”
“Ma foi! it will be as well if he is not,” answered Caderousse; “for if he should be, there will be really no speaking to him.”
“If we choose,” replied Danglars, “he will remain what he is; and perhaps become even less than he is.”
“What do you mean?”
“Nothing—I was speaking to myself. And is he still in love with the Catalane?”
“Over head and ears; but, unless I am much mistaken, there will be a storm in that quarter.”
“Explain yourself.”
“Why should I?”
“It is more important than you think, perhaps. You do not like Dantès?”
“I never like upstarts.”
“Then tell me all you know about the Catalane.”
“I know nothing for certain; only I have seen things which induce me to believe, as I told you, that the future captain will find some annoyance in the vicinity of the Vieilles Infirmeries.”
“What have you seen?—come, tell me!”
“Well, every time I have seen Mercédès come into the city she has been accompanied by a tall, strapping, black-eyed Catalan, with a red complexion, brown skin, and fierce air, whom she calls cousin.”
“Really; and you think this cousin pays her attentions?”
“I only suppose so. What else can a strapping chap of twenty-one mean with a fine wench of seventeen?”
“And you say that Dantès has gone to the Catalans?”
“He went before I came down.”
“Let us go the same way; we will stop at La Réserve, and we can drink a glass of La Malgue, whilst we wait for news.”
“Come along,” said Caderousse; “but you pay the score.”
“Of course,” replied Danglars; and going quickly to the designated place, they called for a bottle of wine, and two glasses.
Père Pamphile had seen Dantès pass not ten minutes before; and assured that he was at the Catalans, they sat down under the budding foliage of the planes and sycamores, in the branches of which the birds were singing their welcome to one of the first days of spring.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Caderousse lingered for a moment, then taking leave of old Dantès, he went downstairs to rejoin Danglars, who awaited him at the corner of the Rue Senac. "Well," said Danglars, "did you see him?" "Yes; I have just left him." "Did he allude to his hopes of being captain?" "He spoke of it as a thing decided." "Indeed!" said Danglars, "he is in a great hurry." "How else would you have him?" asked Caderousse; "he is ambition itself." "Then he has been to the ship?" "As I told you, he went the moment he left us." "And has spoken to M. Morrel?" "Doubtless, unless the old man has not returned." "Are you going to La Réserve?" "Yes, I have nothing to do, and am devilish thirsty;" said Caderousse. "Come this way, then," replied Danglars; "we can tell you the news as we go along." "Hold hard!" said Caderousse; "you surely are not going to leave me here on the pavement, are you?" "No, no, my friend," said Danglars, taking his arm; "come along, and we will drink to the health of Captain Dantès." "If that were all, we should drink nothing, for he is not captain yet." "Ah, ha!" said Danglars, "you are right; and if it should happen that he should not become so?" "Well, that would be a pity," said Caderousse; "for he is a good fellow." "Bah!" said Danglars, "he is not such a good fellow as you imagine; and if he should not be appointed captain, it will not be a pity, but a piece of good fortune for everybody." "Really," said Caderousse, "I should have thought, on the contrary, that M. Morrel was a man of his word, and that Dantès was sure of the appointment." "That is what he thinks himself; but I can tell you that he is not so sure as he believes." "Indeed!" said Caderousse; "then you know something?" "I know that the place is not yet given away, and that there are other candidates besides him." "Yes, yes," said Caderousse; "but M. Morrel has promised it to him, and you know M. Morrel is a man who keeps his word." "That is true," said Danglars; "but it is also true that M. Morrel has a partner, and that the partner has a voice in the matter." "Who is this partner?" asked Caderousse. "M. Leclère, the former captain, who is now retired from business." "Ah, yes, I know him; he is a very rich man." "Yes, and he has a son who is a candidate for the place." "Indeed!" said Caderousse; "then it is not so sure as Dantès thinks." "No, indeed; and I can tell you that if we choose, he shall not only not be captain, but he shall be nothing at all." "How so?" asked Caderousse. "Oh, that is our secret," replied Danglars; "but you may be sure that if we choose, he is done for." "Upon my word," said Caderousse, "that would be a pity, for he is a good fellow." "Come, come," said Danglars, "let us go to La Réserve, and we will talk it over there." "Agreed," said Caderousse; and they went towards La Réserve. As they went along, they met Père Pamphile, who was coming from the Catalans. "Well, Père Pamphile," said Danglars, "have you seen Dantès?" "Yes," replied Père Pamphile; "he passed by here just now on his way to the Catalans." "Good," said Danglars; "then we shall have news of him soon." And they went into La Réserve, and sat down at a table in the corner. The day was fine, and the view from the windows was magnificent. The sea was calm, and the sky was blue. The trees were in full leaf, and the flowers were in bloom. It was one of those lovely spring days which make one feel glad to be alive.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Caderousse lingered for a moment, then taking leave of old Dantès, he went downstairs to rejoin Danglars, who awaited him at the corner of the Rue Senac. Danglars was pacing impatiently, his hands clasped behind his back, his brow furrowed. The moment he saw Caderousse emerge, he stopped abruptly. “Well?” he demanded, his voice low and urgent. “What news? How is the old man?”

Caderousse shrugged, a gesture of indifference that ill-suited the gravity of the situation. “As you might expect,” he said. “Distraught. He knows nothing, of course, except that his son has been taken. He thinks it’s a mistake, a misunderstanding.”

“A mistake?” Danglars scoffed, a cruel glint in his eye. “Hardly. The gendarmes don’t make mistakes of that nature. Treason is a serious charge.”

“Treason,” Caderousse repeated, a shiver running down his spine despite the warm Marseille air. “It seems incredible. Edmond? A Bonapartist?”

“He carried a letter,” Danglars stated flatly, watching Caderousse closely. “From the Isle of Elba. To a certain Noirtier, a prominent Bonapartist in Paris. I saw it myself, in his pocketbook, when he asked me to deliver it.”

Caderousse’s eyes widened slightly. “You saw it? And you said nothing?”

“Why should I?” Danglars countered, a sly smile playing on his lips. “It was not my affair. Besides, I had my suspicions about that voyage. He was too eager to please Captain Leclère, too quick to accept that commission. And now… well, the timing is rather unfortunate for him, isn’t it? Just as he was about to be made captain, just as he was about to marry Mercédès.”

He paused, letting the implications sink in. Caderousse shifted uncomfortably. “But… the denunciation? Who could have…?”

Danglars held his gaze, his expression unreadable for a moment, then he gave a short, dry laugh. “Marseille is full of loyal citizens, Caderousse. In times like these, people are quick to report anything that smacks of disloyalty to the King. Perhaps someone overheard him speaking, perhaps someone saw the letter. Who knows? It’s the King’s justice, swift and sure.”

He leaned closer, lowering his voice further. “The important thing now is discretion. We know nothing. We saw nothing. We heard nothing. Edmond was arrested, yes, a great misfortune, but we have no idea why. Do you understand?”

Caderousse nodded slowly, the fear of implication outweighing any lingering sense of unease or guilt. “Yes,” he murmured. “We know nothing.”

“Good,” Danglars said, straightening up. “It is for the best. For all of us. Now, let us go. We have work to do, and the less we are seen loitering here, the better.” He turned and walked away, leaving Caderousse to follow, the weight of their shared secret settling heavily between them in the quiet street.

chapters.chapter_title: VOLUME ONE. Chapter 3. The Catalans

events.title: The Catalan Village: A Secluded Community
detailed_summary: The narrative introduces the village of the Catalans, situated near where two unnamed friends are observing and drinking wine.
This settlement is described as an ancient and mysterious colony that migrated from Spain, eventually establishing itself on a desolate piece of land granted by the commune of Marseilles.
The village originated from a small group of about twelve to fifteen boats, bringing these seafaring people, likened to gypsies, to the shore.
The architecture of the village is characterized as a distinctive and charming blend of Moorish and Spanish influences.
Its inhabitants are the direct descendants of these first settlers, having diligently maintained their ancestral language, unique customs, and traditional clothing over three to four centuries.
They have largely kept to themselves, intermarrying within their community and remaining separate from the broader population of Marseilles.

events.text_segment: Beyond a bare, weather-worn wall, about a hundred paces from the spot where the two friends sat looking and listening as they drank their wine, was the village of the Catalans. Long ago this mysterious colony quitted Spain, and settled on the tongue of land on which it is to this day. Whence it came no one knew, and it spoke an unknown tongue. One of its chiefs, who understood Provençal, begged the commune of Marseilles to give them this bare and barren promontory, where, like the sailors of old, they had run their boats ashore. The request was granted; and three months afterwards, around the twelve or fifteen small vessels which had brought these gypsies of the sea, a small village sprang up. This village, constructed in a singular and picturesque manner, half Moorish, half Spanish, still remains, and is inhabited by descendants of the first comers, who speak the language of their fathers. For three or four centuries they have remained upon this small promontory, on which they had settled like a flight of seabirds, without mixing with the Marseillaise population, intermarrying, and preserving their original customs and the costume of their mother-country as they have preserved its language.

events.title: Mercédès's Firm Rejection of Fernand's Proposal
detailed_summary: The scene shifts to a house within the Catalan village, detailed with its sun-weathered exterior and whitewashed interior.

Inside, Mercédès, a young woman of striking beauty with dark hair and expressive eyes, leans against the wainscot, nervously plucking at heath blossoms. Her bare arms and the tapping of her foot betray a restless impatience.

Fernand, a young man in his early twenties, observes her with a mixture of annoyance and distress. He attempts to communicate his feelings through his gaze, but Mercédès's composed look seems to dominate his.
Fernand initiates a conversation about Easter, questioning if it is an appropriate time for a wedding.
Mercédès responds with slight exasperation, stating she has already answered his question numerous times and implying he is slow to understand.
Fernand implores her to reiterate her refusal, expressing his profound sorrow at losing the hope of marrying her—a dream he has cherished for a decade and which her mother had approved.
Mercédès firmly asserts that she never gave him false encouragement, consistently offering only platonic affection, as her romantic love is for someone else.
Fernand acknowledges her painful honesty but raises the Catalan tradition of marrying within their community.

Mercédès counters that this is merely a custom, not an unbreakable law, and further highlights his uncertain future due to military conscription, her own impoverished state as an orphan, and her reliance on his charitable sharing of his fishing income—a support she accepts due to their family ties and his insistence, but which she keenly feels as charity.
Fernand declares that her poverty is inconsequential to him; he seeks only a virtuous wife and capable homemaker, qualities he sees in her.
Mercédès firmly concludes that a woman cannot be a good wife or maintain her virtue if her heart belongs to another man, reiterating that friendship is the only commitment she can sincerely offer.

events.text_segment:
Our readers will follow us along the only street of this little village, and enter with us one of the houses, which is sunburned to the beautiful dead-leaf color peculiar to the buildings of the country, and within coated with whitewash, like a Spanish posada. A young and beautiful girl, with hair as black as jet, her eyes as velvety as the gazelle’s, was leaning with her back against the wainscot, rubbing in her slender delicately moulded fingers a bunch of heath blossoms, the flowers of which she was picking off and strewing on the floor; her arms, bare to the elbow, brown, and modelled after those of the Arlesian Venus, moved with a kind of restless impatience, and she tapped the earth with her arched and supple foot, so as to display the pure and full shape of her well-turned leg, in its red cotton, gray and blue clocked, stocking. At three paces from her, seated in a chair which he balanced on two legs, leaning his elbow on an old worm-eaten table, was a tall young man of twenty, or two-and-twenty, who was looking at her with an air in which vexation and uneasiness were mingled. He questioned her with his eyes, but the firm and steady gaze of the young girl controlled his look.
“You see, Mercédès,” said the young man, “here is Easter come round again; tell me, is this the moment for a wedding?”
“I have answered you a hundred times, Fernand, and really you must be very stupid to ask me again.”
“Well, repeat it,—repeat it, I beg of you, that I may at last believe it! Tell me for the hundredth time that you refuse my love, which had your mother’s sanction. Make me understand once for all that you are trifling with my happiness, that my life or death are nothing to you. Ah, to have dreamed for ten years of being your husband, Mercédès, and to lose that hope, which was the only stay of my existence!”
“At least it was not I who ever encouraged you in that hope, Fernand,” replied Mercédès; “you cannot reproach me with the slightest coquetry. I have always said to you, ‘I love you as a brother; but do not ask from me more than sisterly affection, for my heart is another’s.’ Is not this true, Fernand?”
“Yes, that is very true, Mercédès,” replied the young man, “Yes, you have been cruelly frank with me; but do you forget that it is among the Catalans a sacred law to intermarry?”
“You mistake, Fernand; it is not a law, but merely a custom, and, I pray of you, do not cite this custom in your favor. You are included in the conscription, Fernand, and are only at liberty on sufferance, liable at any moment to be called upon to take up arms. Once a soldier, what would you do with me, a poor orphan, forlorn, without fortune, with nothing but a half-ruined hut and a few ragged nets, the miserable inheritance left by my father to my mother, and by my mother to me? She has been dead a year, and you know, Fernand, I have subsisted almost entirely on public charity. Sometimes you pretend I am useful to you, and that is an excuse to share with me the produce of your fishing, and I accept it, Fernand, because you are the son of my father’s brother, because we were brought up together, and still more because it would give you so much pain if I refuse. But I feel very deeply that this fish which I go and sell, and with the produce of which I buy the flax I spin,—I feel very keenly, Fernand, that this is charity.”
“And if it were, Mercédès, poor and lone as you are, you suit me as well as the daughter of the first shipowner or the richest banker of Marseilles! What do such as we desire but a good wife and careful housekeeper, and where can I look for these better than in you?”
“Fernand,” answered Mercédès, shaking her head, “a woman becomes a bad manager, and who shall say she will remain an honest woman, when she loves another man better than her husband? Rest content with my friendship, for I say once more that is all I can promise, and I will promise no more than I can bestow.

events.title: Fernand's Accusations and Mercédès's Passionate Defense of Her Absent Love
detailed_summary: Fernand misinterprets Mercédès's consistent rejection as a fear of partaking in his humble life, boasting that her love would inspire him to achieve wealth and success through his fishing or other commercial ventures.
Mercédès firmly dismisses his aspirational talk, reminding him of his obligations as a soldier and advising him to accept his current life as a fisherman and her offer of friendship.
In a desperate bid, Fernand suggests he might become a sailor, adopting the attire he believes she favors, implying this change would be to win her affection.
Mercédès reacts with visible anger, demanding clarification of his insinuation.
Fernand voices his suspicion that she is waiting for a man in sailor's garb, and cruelly suggests this awaited love might prove unfaithful or have perished at sea.

Mercédès, incensed, condemns Fernand's words as wicked, accusing him of trying to exploit jealousy and divine misfortune. She passionately affirms her love for the unnamed man and her unwavering belief in his fidelity, stating that if he fails to return, it will be because he died loving her alone, not because he was inconstant.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I understand,” replied Fernand, “you can endure your own wretchedness patiently, but you are afraid to share mine.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Yes, I will not deny it, I do await, and I do love him of whom you speak; and, if he does not return, instead of accusing him of the inconstancy which you insinuate, I will tell you that he died loving me and me only.”

events.text_segment:
“I understand,” replied Fernand, “you can endure your own wretchedness patiently, but you are afraid to share mine. Well, Mercédès, beloved by you, I would tempt fortune; you would bring me good luck, and I should become rich. I could extend my occupation as a fisherman, might get a place as clerk in a warehouse, and become in time a dealer myself.”
“You could do no such thing, Fernand; you are a soldier, and if you remain at the Catalans it is because there is no war; so remain a fisherman, and contented with my friendship, as I cannot give you more.”
“Well, I will do better, Mercédès. I will be a sailor; instead of the costume of our fathers, which you despise, I will wear a varnished hat, a striped shirt, and a blue jacket, with an anchor on the buttons. Would not that dress please you?”
“What do you mean?” asked Mercédès, with an angry glance,—“what do you mean? I do not understand you?”
“I mean, Mercédès, that you are thus harsh and cruel with me, because you are expecting someone who is thus attired; but perhaps he whom you await is inconstant, or if he is not, the sea is so to him.”
“Fernand,” cried Mercédès, “I believed you were good-hearted, and I was mistaken! Fernand, you are wicked to call to your aid jealousy and the anger of God! Yes, I will not deny it, I do await, and I do love him of whom you speak; and, if he does not return, instead of accusing him of the inconstancy which you insinuate, I will tell you that he died loving me and me only.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“I understand,” replied Fernand, “you can endure your own wretchedness patiently, but you are afraid to share mine. Well, Mercédès, since you are so hard upon me, I will endeavor to become rich, like Edmond, and then you will not have any excuse to make.”

“You would do better,” said Mercédès, “to remain a fisherman, and sing the praises of the sea, and the gift it bestows on the poor, instead of forming wild plans and incurring debts; or, better still, to go and fulfil your engagement with the army, as I have requested you to do, and not to expose yourself thus.”

“If I go away, I shall die,” replied Fernand, “and you will have been the cause of my death. When I am gone, you will perhaps regret me; for though you may not love me, you know that I love you with all the fire of my soul. My father is a Catalan, and in the veins of a Catalan there flows blood as hot as that which courses in the veins of a Spaniard. When I am mad, I become a demon. I cannot work; I cannot rest; I can do nothing. Shall I tell you of what I think? I think the sea is treacherous, and that she will not keep her promises; I think that Edmond is false to you; and that if he is not, it is because the sea has swallowed him up, as it has done others. Oh, that I were the sea, I would give him back to you, Mercédès, that you might see how faithless he is!”

“Fernand,” cried Mercédès, “I had hoped that you were a more honest man, and a more true Catalan. I had thought that you would have been content with the friendship which I offered you, and which is all that I can offer you. Go, Fernand, go; I have told you that I love you as a brother; but I can never love you otherwise. Go, and leave me to wait for Edmond, who is my betrothed, and who will be my husband.”

“You are mistaken, Mercédès,” replied Fernand, with a bitter smile; “he is not your betrothed, and he will never be your husband. He is a sailor, and a sailor has no betrothed, and no wife. He has a ship, and a sea, and a sky, and that is all. He is a bird of passage, who rests for a moment on a branch, and then flies away to another. He is a wave of the sea, which rises and falls, and is lost in the vast ocean. He is a breath of wind, which blows where it lists, and is gone in a moment. He is a dream, which vanishes when you wake. He is a phantom, which disappears when you touch it. He is a shadow, which fades away when the sun shines. He is nothing, Mercédès, nothing.”

“Fernand,” cried Mercédès, with flashing eyes, “you are a wicked man, and you speak wicked words. You are jealous of Edmond, and you wish to make me jealous too. You wish to make me believe that he is false, or that he is dead. But I know that he is true, and I know that he is alive. And if he were dead, I would die too. And if he were false, I would kill him, and then die myself. But he is not false, and he is not dead. He is true, and he is alive, and he will come back to me. And if he does not come back, it will be because he has died loving me alone, and not because he has been false to me.”

“You would do better,” said Mercédès, “to remain a fisherman, and sing the praises of the sea, and the gift it bestows on the poor, instead of forming wild plans and incurring debts; or, better still, to go and fulfil your engagement with the army, as I have requested you to do, and not to expose yourself thus.”

“If I go away, I shall die,” replied Fernand, “and you will have been the cause of my death. When I am gone, you will perhaps regret me; for though you may not love me, you know that I love you with all the fire of my soul. My father is a Catalan, and in the veins of a Catalan there flows blood as hot as that which courses in the veins of a Spaniard. When I am mad, I become a demon. I cannot work; I cannot rest; I can do nothing. Shall I tell you of what I think? I think the sea is treacherous, and that she will not keep her promises; I think that Edmond is false to you; and that if he is not, it is because the sea has swallowed him up, as it has done others. Oh, that I were the sea, I would give him back to you, Mercédès, that you might see how faithless he is!”

“Fernand,” cried Mercédès, “I had hoped that you were a more honest man, and a more true Catalan. I had thought that you would have been content with the friendship which I offered you, and which is all that I can offer you. Go, Fernand, go; I have told you that I love you as a brother; but I can never love you otherwise. Go, and leave me to wait for Edmond, who is my betrothed, and who will be my husband.”

“You are mistaken, Mercédès,” replied Fernand, with a bitter smile; “he is not your betrothed, and he will never be your husband. He is a sailor, and a sailor has no betrothed, and no wife. He has a ship, and a sea, and a sky, and that is all. He is a bird of passage, who rests for a moment on a branch, and then flies away to another. He is a wave of the sea, which rises and falls, and is lost in the vast ocean. He is a breath of wind, which blows where it lists, and is gone in a moment. He is a dream, which vanishes when you wake. He is a phantom, which disappears when you touch it. He is a shadow, which fades away when the sun shines. He is nothing, Mercédès, nothing.”

“Fernand,” cried Mercédès, with flashing eyes, “you are a wicked man, and you speak wicked words. You are jealous of Edmond, and you wish to make me jealous too. You wish to make me believe that he is false, or that he is dead. But I know that he is true, and I know that he is alive. And if he were dead, I would die too. And if he were false, I would kill him, and then die myself. But he is not false, and he is not dead. He is true, and he is alive, and he will come back to me. And if he does not come back, it will be because he has died loving me alone, and not because he has been false to me.”

events.title: Mercédès's Ultimatum to Fernand and Declaration for Edmond Dantès
detailed_summary: Displaying her fury, Mercédès accuses Fernand of harboring vengeful thoughts against her beloved simply because she does not love Fernand.

She warns him that provoking a conflict would irrevocably damage their relationship, resulting in the loss of her friendship if her beloved were defeated, or her friendship turning to hatred if Fernand were victorious.
Mercédès strongly advises Fernand that attacking the man she loves is a misguided strategy for earning her affection.
She implores him to abandon his malevolent intentions and to accept her offer of platonic friendship and sisterly love.
With tears in her eyes, she points out the irony of his earlier comments about the sea's treachery, reminding him that her beloved has been away for four months, a period marked by severe storms.
Fernand remains silent, visibly pained by her tears but offering no comfort, as they are shed for another man.
After pacing restlessly, he confronts Mercédès with intense emotion, his eyes blazing and fists clenched, demanding her absolute, final answer.
Mercédès responds with calm resolve, unequivocally stating her love for Edmond Dantès and her intention to marry no one else.
When Fernand presses her on the endurance of her love for Dantès, she vows it will last as long as she lives.
Visibly defeated, Fernand sighs profoundly, then, with gritted teeth and flared nostrils, poses the hypothetical question of what she would do if Dantès were dead.
Mercédès declares without hesitation that she too would die.
Fernand then challenges her with the possibility of Dantès having forgotten her.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The young girl made a gesture of rage.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “If he has forgotten you——”

events.text_segment:
The young girl made a gesture of rage. “I understand you, Fernand; you would be revenged on him because I do not love you; you would cross your Catalan knife with his dirk. What end would that answer? To lose you my friendship if he were conquered, and see that friendship changed into hate if you were victor. Believe me, to seek a quarrel with a man is a bad method of pleasing the woman who loves that man. No, Fernand, you will not thus give way to evil thoughts. Unable to have me for your wife, you will content yourself with having me for your friend and sister; and besides,” she added, her eyes troubled and moistened with tears, “wait, wait, Fernand; you said just now that the sea was treacherous, and he has been gone four months, and during these four months there have been some terrible storms.”
Fernand made no reply, nor did he attempt to check the tears which flowed down the cheeks of Mercédès, although for each of these tears he would have shed his heart’s blood; but these tears flowed for another. He arose, paced a while up and down the hut, and then, suddenly stopping before Mercédès, with his eyes glowing and his hands clenched,—“Say, Mercédès,” he said, “once for all, is this your final determination?”
“I love Edmond Dantès,” the young girl calmly replied, “and none but Edmond shall ever be my husband.”
“And you will always love him?”
“As long as I live.”
Fernand let fall his head like a defeated man, heaved a sigh that was like a groan, and then suddenly looking her full in the face, with clenched teeth and expanded nostrils, said,—“But if he is dead——”
“If he is dead, I shall die too.”
“If he has forgotten you——”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The young girl made a gesture of rage. “Fernand,” she said, “you are wicked to entertain such a thought. You are jealous of Edmond, and that is why you hate him. Confess it; it is because you are jealous.” “I,” cried Fernand, turning pale—“I jealous of Edmond! Why should I be jealous of him? I do not love you, Mercédès.” “You do not love me? Ah, you have never said that before!” “No, but I say it now. Well, let us suppose I do love you; suppose I am jealous of Edmond; what then? He is fortunate, but every man cannot be as fortunate as he.” “You are wicked, I say, and I detest you, and I will tell Edmond how ungenerous you are.” “You will tell Edmond how ungenerous I am!” cried Fernand, with a forced smile. “Do you suppose he will trouble himself much about that? He is too happy to think of anything but his good fortune.” “Ah,” said Mercédès, “do not make me angry, Fernand; for you do not know how far I can go when I am angry. If you were to attack Edmond, I would—I do not know what I would do—but I would do something.” “You would do something? What would you do? You would not, I suppose, kill me?” “No, but I would kill myself.” Fernand drew back, and a cold perspiration covered his brow. “You are mad, Mercédès,” he said. “No,” replied she, “but I am resolved. If you lay a hand on Edmond, I will kill myself. I swear it by the Holy Virgin!” “Foolish girl!” said Fernand, approaching her. “You are weeping.” “Yes, I am weeping,” said Mercédès, “and you are the cause of my tears. Why do you torment me thus? I love Edmond, and I will marry him. He loves me, and he will marry me. There is nothing to be said against that. Leave me, Fernand; leave me, I implore you.” “But if he should forget you?” said Fernand.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The young girl made a gesture of rage. Her hands clenched into fists, her eyes flashing with a fire that belied her usual composed demeanor. Eugénie Danglars stood before her father, the wealthy banker, her face pale but set in defiance. The news he had just delivered – the finalization of her engagement to Andrea Cavalcanti, a man she despised and suspected of being a scoundrel – felt like a physical blow. She had pleaded, argued, even threatened, but her father remained unmoved, his gaze fixed on the financial advantages of the union. "You cannot do this, Father!" she cried, her voice trembling with suppressed fury. "You are selling me! Selling me to a man I loathe, a man whose very presence makes my skin crawl!" Monsieur Danglars merely shrugged, adjusting his cravat. "Nonsense, Eugénie. He is a prince, a man of title and fortune. This marriage will solidify our position, connect us to the old aristocracy. Your romantic notions are childish." "Childish?" she echoed, a bitter laugh escaping her lips. "Is it childish to wish for a life of my own, to pursue my music, to choose my own path? You speak of position and fortune, but what of my happiness? What of my soul?" Her father's face hardened. "Your happiness lies in obedience and duty. You will marry Cavalcanti. The contracts are signed, the date is set. There is nothing more to discuss." Eugénie felt a wave of despair wash over her, quickly followed by a resurgence of that burning anger. She looked at the man who was supposed to protect her, her father, and saw only a cold, calculating merchant. He saw her not as a daughter, but as a commodity, a pawn in his endless game of wealth and power. The gesture of rage was not enough. It was a silent scream against the gilded cage he was building around her. She turned abruptly, her skirts swirling, and fled the room, leaving her father to his ledgers and his schemes, her mind racing with desperate plans for escape.

events.title: Edmond Dantès's Arrival, Joyful Reunion, and Tense Confrontation
detailed_summary: At the precise moment Fernand questions Dantès's loyalty, a cheerful voice is heard calling Mercédès's name from outside the house.
Overwhelmed with joy and love, Mercédès exclaims that her beloved has not forgotten her and rushes to the door, eagerly greeting Edmond Dantès.
Fernand, aghast and trembling, instinctively recoils, slumping into a nearby chair as if confronted by something terrifying.
Edmond and Mercédès embrace with profound affection, completely absorbed in their reunion and oblivious to their surroundings, their intense happiness creating a private world for them.
Their immense joy is conveyed through fragmented speech, indicative of overwhelming emotion.
Suddenly, Edmond becomes aware of Fernand's somber, pale, and hostile figure lurking in the shadows of the room.
By an almost involuntary movement, Fernand's hand drifts towards the knife he carries at his belt.
Dantès, his expression hardening, acknowledges Fernand's presence with an apology for not noticing him sooner and asks Mercédès for his identity.
Mercédès introduces Fernand as her cherished friend, cousin, and brother—the person she loves most in the world after Edmond—and asks if Edmond recalls him.
Dantès confirms that he remembers Fernand and, while still holding Mercédès's hand, extends his other hand in a friendly gesture towards the Catalan.
Fernand, however, remains unresponsive, silent and visibly shaking.

Edmond then directs his gaze first to the distressed and uneasy Mercédès, and then back to the dark and threatening Fernand. This silent exchange of looks allows Dantès to grasp the underlying tension of the situation, and his own anger begins to flare.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Mercédès!” called a joyous voice from without,—“Mercédès!”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: This look told him all, and his anger waxed hot.

events.text_segment:
“Mercédès!” called a joyous voice from without,—“Mercédès!”
“Ah,” exclaimed the young girl, blushing with delight, and fairly leaping in excess of love, “you see he has not forgotten me, for here he is!” And rushing towards the door, she opened it, saying, “Here, Edmond, here I am!”
Fernand, pale and trembling, drew back, like a traveller at the sight of a serpent, and fell into a chair beside him. Edmond and Mercédès were clasped in each other’s arms. The burning Marseilles sun, which shot into the room through the open door, covered them with a flood of light. At first they saw nothing around them. Their intense happiness isolated them from all the rest of the world, and they only spoke in broken words, which are the tokens of a joy so extreme that they seem rather the expression of sorrow. Suddenly Edmond saw the gloomy, pale, and threatening countenance of Fernand, as it was defined in the shadow. By a movement for which he could scarcely account to himself, the young Catalan placed his hand on the knife at his belt.
“Ah, your pardon,” said Dantès, frowning in his turn; “I did not perceive that there were three of us.” Then, turning to Mercédès, he inquired, “Who is this gentleman?”
“One who will be your best friend, Dantès, for he is my friend, my cousin, my brother; it is Fernand—the man whom, after you, Edmond, I love the best in the world. Do you not remember him?”
“Yes!” said Dantès, and without relinquishing Mercédès’ hand clasped in one of his own, he extended the other to the Catalan with a cordial air. But Fernand, instead of responding to this amiable gesture, remained mute and trembling. Edmond then cast his eyes scrutinizingly at the agitated and embarrassed Mercédès, and then again on the gloomy and menacing Fernand. This look told him all, and his anger waxed hot.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_jailbreak:
```text
“Mercédès!” called a joyous voice from without,—“Mercédès!”

At the sound of this voice, at the name of Mercédès, Fernand shuddered, and started up; but Mercédès, with a smile that made her lips seem of rose, and showed her teeth of pearl, sprang up herself, and opened the door, crying, “Edmond! Edmond!”

There was a rustling of silk and muslin, and with a cry of joy the young woman threw herself into the arms of the young man, who pressed her to his heart with equal rapture.

Fernand, pale and trembling, drew back against the wall, and became almost hidden by the curtain.

The embrace was long and blissful. Edmond and Mercédès were so absorbed in their own happiness that they did not perceive the presence of a third person, and had no idea that they were watched by eyes gleaming with jealousy.

“Oh, Edmond! my beloved Edmond! you are safe? you are here? you have not forgotten me?”

“Mercédès! my beautiful Mercédès! here I am! never to leave you again! Oh, my darling, you are the angel that watched over me!”

“No, no, not I, but my good angel; for I thought you were dead!”

“No, death has not wanted me yet, Mercédès; and you see I am here to keep my promise.”

“Oh, Edmond, how happy we are!”

“Yes, we are indeed,” replied Edmond, his voice half-choked with emotion.

Suddenly, Edmond's eyes fell upon the figure of Fernand, who stood dark and menacing in the shadow. An almost involuntary movement of Fernand's hand towards the knife at his belt did not escape him.

His brow darkened slightly. “Ah, Mercédès,” he said, with a rather constrained smile, “I did not see this gentleman.” Then, turning to Mercédès, he added, “Who is he?”

“He is Fernand, the man I told you of, my cousin, my brother, who loves me so dearly. It is he who has been my support, my comfort, since you left. You remember him, do you not, Edmond?”

“Yes, yes,” said Dantès, his hand still clasped in Mercédès’s, but extending the other towards the Catalan, “I remember him perfectly. Good evening, Fernand.”

Fernand made no reply, and did not offer his hand. He remained silent, motionless, and visibly shaking.

Dantès’s gaze, which had been fixed on Fernand, turned for a moment to the uneasy Mercédès, and then returned to the dark and threatening figure of the Catalan. He understood everything. The blood rushed to his head, and his anger began to rise.
```

events.title: Mercédès's Intervention and Fernand's Despairing Flight
detailed_summary: Edmond expresses his surprise, stating he hadn't anticipated encountering an adversary upon his arrival.

Mercédès, casting a sharp glance at her cousin, vehemently refutes the notion of an enemy in her home. She declares that if she truly believed such a thing, she would take Edmond's arm and depart for Marseilles with him immediately, never to return to the house.
She then delivers a solemn warning directly to Fernand: if any harm or misfortune were to befall Edmond, she would take her own life by leaping from the highest point of the Cape de Morgiou.
At this dire pronouncement, Fernand's face becomes deathly pale.
Mercédès quickly reassures Edmond that he faces no enemy there, only Fernand, whom she describes as her brother and who, she insists, will extend his hand in devoted friendship.
With a commanding and unwavering gaze, Mercédès compels Fernand, who appears almost mesmerized by her intensity, to slowly approach Edmond and offer his hand.
Fernand's deep-seated animosity is momentarily suppressed by the powerful influence Mercédès holds over him.
However, the instant he completes the reluctant handshake, he feels he has reached his limit and abruptly flees from the house.
As he runs away in a frenzy, tearing at his hair, Fernand cries out in profound anguish, questioning who can free him from Dantès and lamenting his own miserable fate.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I did not know, when I came with such haste to you, that I was to meet an enemy here.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Oh,” he exclaimed, running furiously and tearing his hair—“Oh, who will deliver me from this man? Wretched—wretched that I am!”

events.text_segment:
“I did not know, when I came with such haste to you, that I was to meet an enemy here.”
“An enemy!” cried Mercédès, with an angry look at her cousin. “An enemy in my house, do you say, Edmond! If I believed that, I would place my arm under yours and go with you to Marseilles, leaving the house to return to it no more.”
Fernand’s eye darted lightning. “And should any misfortune occur to you, dear Edmond,” she continued with the same calmness which proved to Fernand that the young girl had read the very innermost depths of his sinister thought, “if misfortune should occur to you, I would ascend the highest point of the Cape de Morgiou and cast myself headlong from it.”
Fernand became deadly pale. “But you are deceived, Edmond,” she continued. “You have no enemy here—there is no one but Fernand, my brother, who will grasp your hand as a devoted friend.”
And at these words the young girl fixed her imperious look on the Catalan, who, as if fascinated by it, came slowly towards Edmond, and offered him his hand. His hatred, like a powerless though furious wave, was broken against the strong ascendancy which Mercédès exercised over him. Scarcely, however, had he touched Edmond’s hand when he felt he had done all he could do, and rushed hastily out of the house.
“Oh,” he exclaimed, running furiously and tearing his hair—“Oh, who will deliver me from this man? Wretched—wretched that I am!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
I did not know, when I came with such haste to you, that I was to meet an enemy here.”

An enemy!” cried Mercédès, casting a look at her cousin, which, if he had not been blinded by rage, would have made him drop his eyes. “An enemy here! I have no enemy in the world, Edmond, and if I had, I would not allow him to enter my door. If there is an enemy, it can only be one who would raise his hand against you. If you have an enemy, Edmond, I will not remain here, but will accompany you. If, on the contrary, you are mistaken, and it is my cousin who is the aggressor, I will say to you, ‘Fernand, you are mistaken; this is an honest and brave man, who is my betrothed, and who will be my husband in the sight of God and man.’ Fernand,” continued she, turning towards the young man, who remained silent and motionless, “do you understand? Look at me, and speak!”

Fernand’s lips moved, but no sound came from them. “Well,” said Mercédès, “since you are silent, I will speak. Edmond,” she added, turning to the sailor, “look at this man; he was born in the same village as myself, he has been my brother; he is my cousin, and has grown up with me. He has always loved me, and I have always loved him. But since you came, he has been jealous of you, and has hated you. He is an enemy, you say? No, Edmond, he is not an enemy; he is only a rival. But you know that rivals are sometimes more dangerous than enemies. Fernand,” she said, turning again to her cousin, “you have heard what I have said. You know that I love Edmond, and that I will marry him. You know that I have always looked upon you as a brother, and that I have always loved you as a brother. But you have been jealous of Edmond, and you have hated him. You have been an enemy to him, and you have been an enemy to me. But I forgive you, Fernand, I forgive you. And now, give your hand to Edmond, and let us be friends.”

Fernand remained motionless. His face was pale, and his eyes were fixed on Mercédès. “Fernand,” she said, “do you hear me? Give your hand to Edmond.”

Fernand did not move. “Fernand,” she said, in a voice that was at once soft and commanding, “do you refuse to give your hand to Edmond? Do you refuse to be my brother? Do you refuse to be my friend?”

Fernand’s lips trembled, and he made a step forward. “Fernand,” said Mercédès, “give your hand to Edmond.”

Fernand raised his hand slowly, and extended it towards Edmond. Edmond took it, and shook it heartily. “Now,” said Mercédès, “we are all friends.”

Fernand withdrew his hand, and without saying a word, rushed out of the house, and disappeared. He ran like a madman, tearing his hair, and crying out, “Who will deliver me from this man? Who will deliver me from this man?”

events.title: Fernand's Public Humiliation and Taunting by Caderousse and Danglars
detailed_summary: As Fernand flees, distraught, he is hailed by Caderousse and Danglars, who are seated and drinking under an arbor.
Looking dazed, Fernand approaches them and slowly sits down. Caderousse jests about his frantic pace, asking if he intended to jump into the sea.
Fernand emits a groan and buries his face in his hands. Caderousse, with characteristic bluntness, remarks that Fernand has the appearance of a spurned lover and lets out a coarse laugh.
Danglars interjects with feigned commiseration, implying Fernand was unprepared for Dantès's sudden reappearance.

Caderousse then elaborates on Fernand's situation for Danglars: Fernand's love for Mercédès, who in turn loves Edmond Dantès, the recently returned mate of the Pharaon, suggesting Fernand has been rejected.
Fernand defensively asserts that Mercédès has the right to love anyone she chooses.

Caderousse continues to mock Fernand, alluding to the pride of Catalans who supposedly don't tolerate rivals and mentioning that Fernand, in particular, was reputed to be fearsome in his vengeance. Fernand responds dejectedly that a lover is never fearsome.
Danglars subtly probes Fernand's despair, suggesting he might have entertained hopes of Dantès being dead or having forgotten Mercédès.

Caderousse, increasingly affected by wine, insinuates that Fernand is not alone in his displeasure at Dantès's 'fortunate arrival,' casting a significant look towards Danglars. Danglars concurs, adding that Dantès's return might bring him misfortune.
Caderousse confidently states that Dantès will marry Mercédès and, moreover, will become captain of the Pharaon. The mention of Dantès's captaincy visibly unnerves Danglars.
Danglars then proposes a toast to 'Captain Edmond Dantès, husband of the beautiful Catalane!' Caderousse empties his glass, while Fernand violently smashes his own on the ground.
At that moment, Caderousse catches sight of Edmond and Mercédès walking arm-in-arm and embracing in the near distance, excitedly pointing them out to Fernand.
Danglars meticulously observes the anguish etched on Fernand's face as Fernand quietly confirms the couple's identity.
Caderousse shouts out to the lovers, inquiring about their wedding date, since Fernand refuses to disclose it.
Danglars makes a show of trying to silence the boisterous Caderousse, while simultaneously goading Fernand by highlighting his apparent inaction.

Stung by the taunts and his own emotions, Fernand rises as if to confront Dantès. However, a glance from Mercédès in their direction reminds him of her earlier threat to end her life if Edmond were harmed, and he collapses back onto his seat, defeated.
Danglars surveys the scene: Caderousse, now coarse and muddled by alcohol, and Fernand, consumed by his unrequited love and despair.
