You are coming to join us? Excellent!” he exclaimed. Danglars managed a strained smile. “Alas, Edmond, we were just… on an errand.” Caderousse grunted in agreement. Just as Dantès was about to inquire further, a sudden commotion arose at the end of the street. A detachment of gendarmes, led by a sergeant, was rapidly approaching. The festive mood instantly evaporated, replaced by a ripple of apprehension. The gendarmes stopped directly before the wedding party. The sergeant, a stern-faced man, looked around, his eyes scanning the faces. “Which of you is called Edmond Dantès?” he demanded in a loud, official voice. A stunned silence fell over the group. Dantès, though bewildered, stepped forward. “I am he,” he replied, his voice steady but questioning. The sergeant nodded curtly. “Edmond Dantès, I arrest you in the name of the law.” Mercédès gasped, her hand flying to her mouth. Old Dantès cried out, “Arrest? My son? For what crime?” The young girls huddled together, frightened. Fernand’s smile widened almost imperceptibly. Danglars and Caderousse exchanged another glance, this one filled with triumph. “There must be some mistake!” Mercédès cried, clinging to Dantès’ arm. “Edmond has done nothing wrong!” The sergeant remained impassive. “We have orders. He is accused of treason.” Treason! The word struck like a thunderbolt. Dantès himself paled slightly, though his eyes flashed with indignation. “Treason? This is impossible! I am a loyal Frenchman!” “You will have the opportunity to explain yourself,” the sergeant said, gesturing to two gendarmes. “Come with us.” They moved to take Dantès by the arms. Mercédès threw herself between them and her betrothed. “No! You cannot take him! He is innocent!” Her pleas were ignored. Dantès gently but firmly disengaged himself from her grasp. “Mercédès, my love, do not despair. This is a misunderstanding. I will clear my name and return to you.” He kissed her forehead, then turned to his father. “Father, do not worry. I will be back soon.” Old Dantès could only look on, tears streaming down his face. Danglars and Caderousse watched, feigning shock and concern, muttering condolences. Fernand stood slightly apart, a picture of false sympathy, his eyes gleaming with malicious satisfaction. Dantès was led away, the gendarmes flanking him. He cast one last look back at Mercédès, whose heartbroken cries echoed in the street, and at his father, who seemed to shrink before his eyes. The joyous procession had dissolved into a scene of utter desolation, the bright promise of the morning shattered by the dark hand of betrayal.

events.title: Joyful Feast Interrupted by Dantès' Startling Wedding Plans
detailed_summary: Upon seeing the bridal party, M. Morrel came down to greet them, reaffirming to the assembled soldiers and sailors his promise that Dantès would succeed Captain Leclere.
Edmond respectfully had Mercédès take M. Morrel's arm, who then led her and the guests up the stairs to the feasting chamber.
Mercédès requested her father-in-law to sit on her right and gestured for Fernand, whom she called a brother, to sit on her left; this gesture visibly tormented Fernand, making him turn ghastly pale.
Meanwhile, Dantès seated M. Morrel to his right and Danglars to his left, and the other guests found their places.
The feast commenced with a variety of seafood delicacies.
Old Dantès, holding a glass of wine, remarked on the unexpected silence for such a happy gathering.
Caderousse commented that being about to marry doesn't always equate to happiness.
Dantès explained his quietness as being due to overwhelming happiness, which can sometimes feel oppressive like sorrow.
Danglars observed Fernand, who was clearly affected by every remark.
Danglars asked Edmond if he feared some impending trouble, noting he should be the happiest man alive.
Dantès admitted this very happiness alarmed him, believing perfect felicity is unnatural and often guarded by challenges, and expressed wonder at being worthy of Mercédès.
Caderousse jokingly reminded Dantès that Mercédès was not yet his wife.
The bride blushed, while Fernand grew increasingly restless and perspired heavily.
Dantès, unperturbed, pulled out his watch and announced that Mercédès would be his wife in an hour and a half.
This news caused general surprise, except for old Dantès who laughed delightedly. Mercédès looked pleased, while Fernand gripped his knife convulsively.
Danglars, paling, questioned how this was possible.
Dantès explained that M. Morrel's influence had removed all obstacles, allowing them to waive the usual waiting period, and the Mayor would marry them at half-past two.

events.text_segment:
As soon as the bridal party came in sight of La Réserve, M. Morrel descended and came forth to meet it, followed by the soldiers and sailors there assembled, to whom he had repeated the promise already given, that Dantès should be the successor to the late Captain Leclere. Edmond, at the approach of his patron, respectfully placed the arm of his affianced bride within that of M. Morrel, who, forthwith conducting her up the flight of wooden steps leading to the chamber in which the feast was prepared, was gayly followed by the guests, beneath whose heavy tread the slight structure creaked and groaned for the space of several minutes.
“Father,” said Mercédès, stopping when she had reached the centre of the table, “sit, I pray you, on my right hand; on my left I will place him who has ever been as a brother to me,” pointing with a soft and gentle smile to Fernand; but her words and look seemed to inflict the direst torture on him, for his lips became ghastly pale, and even beneath the dark hue of his complexion the blood might be seen retreating as though some sudden pang drove it back to the heart.
During this time, Dantès, at the opposite side of the table, had been occupied in similarly placing his most honored guests. M. Morrel was seated at his right hand, Danglars at his left; while, at a sign from Edmond, the rest of the company ranged themselves as they found it most agreeable.
Then they began to pass around the dusky, piquant, Arlesian sausages, and lobsters in their dazzling red cuirasses, prawns of large size and brilliant color, the echinus with its prickly outside and dainty morsel within, the clovis, esteemed by the epicures of the South as more than rivalling the exquisite flavor of the oyster, North. All the delicacies, in fact, that are cast up by the wash of waters on the sandy beach, and styled by the grateful fishermen “fruits of the sea.”
“A pretty silence truly!” said the old father of the bridegroom, as he carried to his lips a glass of wine of the hue and brightness of the topaz, and which had just been placed before Mercédès herself. “Now, would anybody think that this room contained a happy, merry party, who desire nothing better than to laugh and dance the hours away?”
“Ah,” sighed Caderousse, “a man cannot always feel happy because he is about to be married.”
“The truth is,” replied Dantès, “that I am too happy for noisy mirth; if that is what you meant by your observation, my worthy friend, you are right; joy takes a strange effect at times, it seems to oppress us almost the same as sorrow.”
Danglars looked towards Fernand, whose excitable nature received and betrayed each fresh impression.
“Why, what ails you?” asked he of Edmond. “Do you fear any approaching evil? I should say that you were the happiest man alive at this instant.”
“And that is the very thing that alarms me,” returned Dantès. “Man does not appear to me to be intended to enjoy felicity so unmixed; happiness is like the enchanted palaces we read of in our childhood, where fierce, fiery dragons defend the entrance and approach; and monsters of all shapes and kinds, requiring to be overcome ere victory is ours. I own that I am lost in wonder to find myself promoted to an honor of which I feel myself unworthy—that of being the husband of Mercédès.”
“Nay, nay!” cried Caderousse, smiling, “you have not attained that honor yet. Mercédès is not yet your wife. Just assume the tone and manner of a husband, and see how she will remind you that your hour is not yet come!”
The bride blushed, while Fernand, restless and uneasy, seemed to start at every fresh sound, and from time to time wiped away the large drops of perspiration that gathered on his brow.
“Well, never mind that, neighbor Caderousse; it is not worthwhile to contradict me for such a trifle as that. ’Tis true that Mercédès is not actually my wife; but,” added he, drawing out his watch, “in an hour and a half she will be.”
A general exclamation of surprise ran round the table, with the exception of the elder Dantès, whose laugh displayed the still perfect beauty of his large white teeth. Mercédès looked pleased and gratified, while Fernand grasped the handle of his knife with a convulsive clutch.
“In an hour?” inquired Danglars, turning pale. “How is that, my friend?”
“Why, thus it is,” replied Dantès. “Thanks to the influence of M. Morrel, to whom, next to my father, I owe every blessing I enjoy, every difficulty has been removed. We have purchased permission to waive the usual delay; and at half-past two o’clock the Mayor of Marseilles will be waiting for us at the city hall. Now, as a quarter-past one has already struck, I do not consider I have asserted too much in saying, that, in another hour and thirty minutes Mercédès will have become Madame Dantès.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: As soon as the bridal party came in sight of La Réserve, M. Morrel descended and came forth to meet it, followed by the soldiers and sailors there assembled, to whom he had repeated the promise already given, that Dantès should be the successor to the late Captain Leclere. Edmond, radiant with joy, respectfully requested Mercédès to take M. Morrel’s arm, and the latter, repeating to the bride the same words he had used to the bridegroom, conducted her to the dining-room on the first floor, the windows of which looked out upon the sea. The apartment was spacious and airy, and was soon filled with the friends from the Allées de Meilhan, with whom Dantès was intimately acquainted, and the sailors of the Pharaon, his comrades, who had been invited in a body. In a very short time, the room was full of guests, and a joyous tumult reigned, in the midst of which Caderousse, drunk, or nearly so, was distinguishing himself by shouting at the top of his voice. Old Dantès was seated at the right of the bride, and Fernand, pale and trembling, at her left; and Mercédès, who divined by the instinct of woman all the sorrow that Fernand endured, made room for him by her side. Dantès took his place between M. Morrel and Danglars. The rest of the guests ranged themselves as they pleased. In an instant, all were seated. “Well, Edmond,” said M. Morrel, taking the hand of the young man, “to-day you are king of a feast, at which your friends, your betrothed, and your father are assembled. This is a noble day for me, who am happy to call you my friend.” “Ah, M. Morrel,” replied Dantès, “if I have come to any command, it is to you, next to my father and Mercédès, that I owe it.” “No, Edmond, you owe it only to yourself; and the proof is, that in my eyes you are as worthy of it as the brave Captain Leclere was.” “Ah,” said Danglars, “Captain Leclere was a brave man, but a careless one. I say this without any wish to injure his memory.” “In truth,” added Caderousse, who was beginning to feel the effects of the wine, “Captain Leclere was not a bad man, but he was not a sailor; and I, who have been a sailor these twenty years, can tell you that.” “Hold your tongue, Caderousse,” said Dantès, smiling; “you are drunk.” “No,” replied Caderousse, “I am not drunk; but if I were, it would be with joy at seeing my friend Edmond become a captain.” “We will drink to his health,” said M. Morrel. And the health of Edmond was drunk with enthusiasm. “And now,” said Danglars, “let us talk of business.” “No,” said Dantès, “let us talk of happiness. This is a day of happiness, and we will not mar it by talking of business.” “As you please,” said Danglars; “but you know that I am a man of business, and that I like to talk of business.” “Well, then,” said Dantès, “let us talk of business, since you wish it.” “The Pharaon,” said Danglars, “will sail in a fortnight. We must find a captain.” “I have found one,” said M. Dantès. “You?” said Danglars, surprised. “Yes, I,” replied Dantès. “And who is he?” asked Danglars. “It is I,” replied Dantès. “You?” cried Danglars, turning pale. “Yes, I,” repeated Dantès. “M. Morrel has promised me the command.” “Ah,” said Danglars, “I congratulate you.” “Thank you,” replied Dantès. “And now,” said M. Morrel, “let us think of the marriage.” “Ah,” said Caderousse, “the marriage! That is what we are here for.” “Yes,” said Dantès, “and I hope that in an hour and a half Mercédès will be my wife.” This news caused general surprise, except for old Dantès, who laughed delightedly. Mercédès looked pleased, while Fernand gripped his knife convulsively. Danglars, paling, questioned how this was possible. Dantès explained that M. Morrel’s influence had removed all obstacles, allowing them to waive the usual waiting period, and the Mayor would marry them at half-past two.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: As soon as the bridal party came in sight of La Réserve, M. Morrel descended and came forth to meet it, followed by the soldiers and sailors there assembled, to whom he had repeated the promise already given, that Dantès should be the successor to the late Captain Leclere. Edmond, radiant with joy, respectfully requested Mercédès to take M. Morrel’s arm, and the latter, repeating to the bride the same words he had used to the bridegroom, conducted her to the dining-room on the first floor, the windows of which looked out upon the sea. The apartment was spacious and airy, and was soon filled with the friends from the Allées de Meilhan, with whom Dantès was intimately acquainted, and the sailors of the Pharaon, his comrades, who had been invited in a body. In a very short time, the room was full of guests, and a joyous tumult reigned, in the midst of which Caderousse, drunk, or nearly so, was distinguishing himself by shouting at the top of his voice. Old Dantès was seated at the right of the bride, and Fernand, pale and trembling, at her left; and Mercédès, who divined by the instinct of woman all the sorrow that Fernand endured, made room for him by her side, saying, “You, Fernand, my brother, will be on my left.” This gesture, this mark of consideration, which in the eyes of the guests appeared only an amiable attention, was on the part of Mercédès a sublime piece of charity, and on the part of Fernand a terrible torment, for it reminded him that Mercédès considered him as a brother, and that she was about to separate herself from him by an abyss. Dantès took his place between M. Morrel and Danglars. The rest of the guests ranged themselves as they pleased. In an instant, all were seated. The feast commenced. It was a repast worthy of the occasion, and the guests did honour to it. There were all sorts of fish, from the largest to the smallest, dressed in a hundred different ways; there were lobsters, crabs, oysters, and other shell-fish, of which the abundance and variety proved that the sea was determined to do honour to the marriage of one of its children. Old Dantès, holding a glass of wine in his hand, and which he had not yet tasted, turned to Mercédès, and said, with a smile, “It is a fine day, my child, and I am very happy; but it seems to me that we are very silent for a wedding-feast.” “It is true,” said Caderousse, “we are very silent. But what would you have? When a man is about to marry, he is not always gay.” “That is true,” said Dantès; “but when he is about to marry Mercédès, he is too happy to be gay; he is absorbed in his happiness.” “Ah, my friend,” said Danglars, looking at Fernand, who was devouring Mercédès with his eyes, “you are right; you are too happy to be gay. But you should be gay, nevertheless. You are the happiest man in the world.” “And yet,” said Edmond, “I am not gay. There are times when I think that I am too happy.” “Indeed,” said Danglars, “you are too happy?” “Yes,” replied Edmond; “it seems to me that happiness like mine is not natural, and that it must be paid for by some great misfortune. I am like a man who has built his house on the side of a volcano; he is always afraid that the volcano will erupt.” “That is a foolish idea,” said M. Morrel. “You are too happy, my friend, and you are afraid of being too happy. That is all.” “No,” said Edmond, “it is not that. I am afraid of losing Mercédès. I am afraid that something will happen to separate us.” “That is a foolish idea,” said M. Morrel. “Nothing will happen to separate you. You love each other, and you are about to be married. That is all.” “Yes,” said Edmond, “that is all. But it seems to me that it is too much.” “Come, come,” said Caderousse, “do not be so melancholy. You are going to be married, and that is all that you should think of.” “You are right, Caderousse,” said Edmond. “I am going to be married, and I will think of nothing else.” “That is right,” said Caderousse. “And when are you going to be married?” “In an hour and a half,” replied Edmond, pulling out his watch. This news caused general surprise, except for old Dantès, who laughed delightedly. Mercédès looked pleased, while Fernand gripped his knife convulsively. Danglars, paling, questioned how this was possible. Dantès explained that M. Morrel’s influence had removed all obstacles, allowing them to waive the usual waiting period, and the Mayor would marry them at half-past two.

events.title: Rising Revelry, Conspirators' Unease, and the Knock of Fate
detailed_summary: Fernand reacted physically to Dantès' announcement, nearly collapsing and groaning, though it went unnoticed amidst the guests' congratulations.
Old Dantès commended the swift wedding arrangements, typical of a sailor.
Danglars, in a hesitant voice, inquired about formalities like the contract.
Dantès laughingly explained that since neither he nor Mercédès had any fortune, the paperwork was simple and inexpensive, a joke that drew more applause.
Danglars remarked that the betrothal feast had unexpectedly become the wedding dinner.
Dantès corrected him, stating he would leave for Paris the next morning for a short trip and would host the true marriage feast upon his return by the second of March.
This promise of future celebration heightened the guests' merriment, making it difficult for old Dantès to propose a toast amidst the noise.
Dantès acknowledged his father's eagerness with a grateful look, while Mercédès subtly gestured to Edmond about the time.
A boisterous, informal atmosphere filled the room, with guests mingling freely and everyone talking at once.
Fernand's pallor seemed to affect Danglars. Fernand himself appeared to be in agony, leaving the table early to pace silently at the far end of the salon, avoiding the joyful noise.
Caderousse approached Fernand just as Danglars, whom Fernand seemed eager to avoid, joined them.
Caderousse, influenced by Dantès' kindness and wine, told Danglars it would have been a pity to proceed with their previous day's malicious plan against Dantès.
Danglars dismissed the idea of harm, claiming he initially worried about Fernand but was reassured by Fernand's composure as an attendant.
Caderousse observed Fernand's ghastly pallor.
Danglars remarked on the significant sacrifice Fernand made, given Mercédès' beauty, and called Dantès a lucky man.
Mercédès' sweet voice interjected, noting it was two o'clock and they were expected soon.
Dantès eagerly agreed, and the entire party rose with cheers.

At that moment, Danglars, who had been watching Fernand intently, saw him stagger against a seat near a window. Simultaneously, indistinct sounds from the stairs—marching soldiers, clanking swords, and a murmur of voices—grew louder, silencing the wedding party with a sudden, deathlike stillness born of curiosity and apprehension.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Fernand closed his eyes, a burning sensation passed across his brow, and he was compelled to support himself by the table to prevent his falling from his chair; but in spite of all his efforts, he could not refrain from uttering a deep groan, which, however, was lost amid the noisy felicitations of the company.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: At the same instant his ear caught a sort of indistinct sound on the stairs, followed by the measured tread of soldiery, with the clanking of swords and military accoutrements; then came a hum and buzz as of many voices, so as to deaden even the noisy mirth of the bridal party, among whom a vague feeling of curiosity and apprehension quelled every disposition to talk, and almost instantaneously the most deathlike stillness prevailed.

events.text_segment:
Fernand closed his eyes, a burning sensation passed across his brow, and he was compelled to support himself by the table to prevent his falling from his chair; but in spite of all his efforts, he could not refrain from uttering a deep groan, which, however, was lost amid the noisy felicitations of the company.
“Upon my word,” cried the old man, “you make short work of this kind of affair. Arrived here only yesterday morning, and married today at three o’clock! Commend me to a sailor for going the quick way to work!”
“But,” asked Danglars, in a timid tone, “how did you manage about the other formalities—the contract—the settlement?”
“The contract,” answered Dantès, laughingly, “it didn’t take long to fix that. Mercédès has no fortune; I have none to settle on her. So, you see, our papers were quickly written out, and certainly do not come very expensive.” This joke elicited a fresh burst of applause.
“So that what we presumed to be merely the betrothal feast turns out to be the actual wedding dinner!” said Danglars.
“No, no,” answered Dantès; “don’t imagine I am going to put you off in that shabby manner. Tomorrow morning I start for Paris; four days to go, and the same to return, with one day to discharge the commission entrusted to me, is all the time I shall be absent. I shall be back here by the first of March, and on the second I give my real marriage feast.”
This prospect of fresh festivity redoubled the hilarity of the guests to such a degree, that the elder Dantès, who, at the commencement of the repast, had commented upon the silence that prevailed, now found it difficult, amid the general din of voices, to obtain a moment’s tranquillity in which to drink to the health and prosperity of the bride and bridegroom.
Dantès, perceiving the affectionate eagerness of his father, responded by a look of grateful pleasure; while Mercédès glanced at the clock and made an expressive gesture to Edmond.
Around the table reigned that noisy hilarity which usually prevails at such a time among people sufficiently free from the demands of social position not to feel the trammels of etiquette. Such as at the commencement of the repast had not been able to seat themselves according to their inclination rose unceremoniously, and sought out more agreeable companions. Everybody talked at once, without waiting for a reply and each one seemed to be contented with expressing his or her own thoughts.
Fernand’s paleness appeared to have communicated itself to Danglars. As for Fernand himself, he seemed to be enduring the tortures of the damned; unable to rest, he was among the first to quit the table, and, as though seeking to avoid the hilarious mirth that rose in such deafening sounds, he continued, in utter silence, to pace the farther end of the salon.
Caderousse approached him just as Danglars, whom Fernand seemed most anxious to avoid, had joined him in a corner of the room.
“Upon my word,” said Caderousse, from whose mind the friendly treatment of Dantès, united with the effect of the excellent wine he had partaken of, had effaced every feeling of envy or jealousy at Dantès’ good fortune,—“upon my word, Dantès is a downright good fellow, and when I see him sitting there beside his pretty wife that is so soon to be. I cannot help thinking it would have been a great pity to have served him that trick you were planning yesterday.”
“Oh, there was no harm meant,” answered Danglars; “at first I certainly did feel somewhat uneasy as to what Fernand might be tempted to do; but when I saw how completely he had mastered his feelings, even so far as to become one of his rival’s attendants, I knew there was no further cause for apprehension.” Caderousse looked full at Fernand—he was ghastly pale.
“Certainly,” continued Danglars, “the sacrifice was no trifling one, when the beauty of the bride is concerned. Upon my soul, that future captain of mine is a lucky dog! Gad! I only wish he would let me take his place.”
“Shall we not set forth?” asked the sweet, silvery voice of Mercédès; “two o’clock has just struck, and you know we are expected in a quarter of an hour.”
“To be sure!—to be sure!” cried Dantès, eagerly quitting the table; “let us go directly!”
His words were re-echoed by the whole party, with vociferous cheers.
At this moment Danglars, who had been incessantly observing every change in Fernand’s look and manner, saw him stagger and fall back, with an almost convulsive spasm, against a seat placed near one of the open windows. At the same instant his ear caught a sort of indistinct sound on the stairs, followed by the measured tread of soldiery, with the clanking of swords and military accoutrements; then came a hum and buzz as of many voices, so as to deaden even the noisy mirth of the bridal party, among whom a vague feeling of curiosity and apprehension quelled every disposition to talk, and almost instantaneously the most deathlike stillness prevailed.

To make a fortune, to enter the service, to marry a beautiful girl, and all in a few hours! It is miraculous.” “Ah, father,” said Edmond, smiling, “I have been a long time wishing for it.” “So,” said Danglars, in a hesitating tone, “the formalities will be proceeded with?” “Yes,” replied Dantès, “as soon as possible.” “And the contract?” said Danglars; “there must be one, I suppose?” “Certainly, there must,” said Dantès; “and it shall be drawn up and signed this very evening.” “Then,” said Danglars, “the betrothal feast may be considered the marriage feast?” “No,” said Dantès; “not exactly. I must go to Paris.” “To Paris! Really, to Paris?” said Danglars. “Yes, I am compelled to go on a journey for the service of the ship.” “And when will you be back?” asked Mercédès, anxiously. “By the 2nd of March, at the latest, my dear Mercédès.” “Oh, yes,” said old Dantès; “and we will have the wedding then, and a grand one it shall be!” “So be it,” said Dantès; “my worthy father. So then, the 2nd of March. I promise you.” This promise of a wedding feast in the future only increased the merriment of the guests, and it was with difficulty that old Dantès could propose the health of the bride and bridegroom, so much were the company absorbed in anticipations of the feast. Dantès saw the eagerness of his father, and the grateful look which Mercédès cast upon him, and felt himself supreme in happiness. The boisterous mirth of the company, who with the liberty of old friends made themselves quite at home, seemed to increase every moment; and whilst Caderousse, with a voice hoarse with wine, sang a drinking song, and the old father, with a beaming countenance, acknowledged the felicitations of his friends, Mercédès, with a smile full of perfect happiness, met the congratulatory glances of the women. Fernand alone sat in silent agony. He had yielded to the entreaties of Mercédès that he would remain, and in a corner of the room, with his arms crossed, and his head bowed down, he had remained since the announcement of the wedding, a prey to the most bitter reflections. He was roused from them by the voice of Caderousse, who, with a glass in his hand, and somewhat unsteady in his gait, approached him. “Well, Fernand,” said he, “why don’t you drink the health of the bride and bridegroom?” Fernand looked up, but did not answer. “Come, come,” said Caderousse, “don’t be downhearted; it is all for the best.” “Yes,” said Danglars, who had followed Caderousse, “it is all for the best. What would you have? It is fate.” “Fate!” cried Fernand, with a bitter laugh. “Yes, fate,” said Danglars; “and a lucky fate too, for Edmond. He is a lucky fellow.” “And Mercédès is a beautiful girl,” said Caderousse; “and she will make him a good wife.” “Yes,” said Danglars; “and she is rich too, or will be, which is the same thing.” “Rich!” said Fernand; “Mercédès rich! What do you mean?” “Why, her father is dead,” said Danglars, “and she has inherited all his property.” “Indeed!” said Fernand, with a start. “Yes,” said Danglars; “and it is a good deal too.” “So much the better,” said Caderousse; “it is a good match for Edmond.” “Yes,” said Danglars; “and he deserves it. He is a brave fellow.” “And he is a good fellow too,” said Caderousse; “and he has been very kind to me.” “Ah, yes,” said Danglars; “he is a good fellow. But come, let us drink to his health.” “To his health!” said Caderousse; “and to his happiness!” “To his happiness!” repeated Danglars. They drank, and then Caderousse, turning to Fernand, said, “Come, Fernand, drink with us.” Fernand took the glass which Caderousse offered him, and raised it to his lips, but his hand trembled so violently that he spilled the wine. “Never mind,” said Caderousse; “it is a good omen.” “Yes,” said Danglars; “it is a good omen. But come, let us go and join the others.” They left Fernand to his reflections, and went to join the rest of the company. Mercédès had just risen, and was about to leave the room, when Danglars approached her. “Mademoiselle Mercédès,” said he, “allow me to congratulate you.” “Thank you, monsieur,” said Mercédès. “You are a lucky woman,” said Danglars. “I think so,” said Mercédès, with a smile. “And Edmond is a lucky fellow,” said Danglars. “He is indeed,” said Mercédès. “But come,” said she, “it is time for us to go.” “Yes,” said Dantès; “it is time.” And the whole party rose, and were about to leave the room, when a loud noise

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Fernand closed his eyes, a burning sensation passed across his brow, and he was compelled to support himself by the table to prevent his falling from his chair; but in spite of all his efforts, he could not refrain from uttering a deep groan, which, however, was lost amid the noisy felicitations of the company. The Count of Monte Cristo had just concluded a brief, almost casual, anecdote concerning his time in the East, delivered with such effortless charm and profound knowledge that it had captivated every guest. Now, as the polite applause and murmurs of admiration subsided, Fernand opened his eyes, fixing them upon the man who sat opposite him, the man who was the source of his sudden, paralyzing terror. It was he. There was no longer any doubt. The features, refined by time and travel, the piercing gaze, the calm, almost unnerving self-possession – it was Edmond Dantès. Resurrected from the grave of the Château d’If, returned from the oblivion to which Fernand himself had consigned him. A cold sweat broke out on Fernand’s forehead, mingling with the burning sensation. How was this possible? He had seen the letter, signed by Danglars and himself, denouncing Dantès as a Bonapartist agent. He knew Dantès had been arrested on his wedding day. He had heard nothing of him since, save the vague rumors that prisoners at the Château d’If simply vanished. And now, here he was, not a broken, vengeful spectre, but a man of immense wealth, influence, and chilling composure, hosting them all in his opulent Parisian mansion. The irony was a bitter poison in Fernand’s throat. He, the Comte de Morcerf, peer of France, husband of Mercédès, father of Albert, owed his entire life, his title, his fortune, to the destruction of this man. And this man was now looking at him, not with overt hatred, but with an unnerving, almost scientific curiosity, as if observing a specimen under a microscope. Fernand forced himself to breathe, to unclench his hands which had tightened into fists on his knees beneath the table. He glanced around the table, seeking some sign that others saw what he saw, felt what he felt. But the other guests were still buzzing with admiration for the Count, discussing his travels, his collections, his enigmatic past. They saw only the fascinating, wealthy host, the man who had taken Paris by storm. They did not see the ghost of a sailor from Marseille. His eyes fell upon Mercédès, seated further down the table, her face pale and drawn, her gaze fixed on the Count with an intensity that mirrored his own terror, yet held a deeper, more profound sorrow. She knew too. Of course, she knew. The recognition in her eyes was unmistakable, a silent scream across the table that only the three of them could hear. Her distress amplified Fernand’s own. If Mercédès, who had loved Dantès so deeply, was so visibly affected, what hope did he, the betrayer, have? He tried to catch her eye, to send a silent plea for composure, for denial, but she seemed lost in her own private agony. The Count’s voice cut through the air, calm and measured, addressing the table generally but his eyes seemed to linger on Fernand for a fraction of a second longer than on anyone else. “Monsieur le Comte de Morcerf,” the Count said, his tone polite, almost deferential, “you have travelled extensively, I believe? Particularly in Spain and Algeria?” The question was innocuous, yet it struck Fernand like a physical blow. His military campaigns, his rise to power, were built on foundations he preferred not to examine too closely, particularly the circumstances surrounding the death of Ali Pasha and the acquisition of his fortune – events that had occurred after Dantès’s imprisonment. Was this a coincidence? Or did the Count know? Fernand’s mind raced. He managed a stiff nod. “Yes, Monsieur le Comte. I have.” His voice sounded strained

events.title: Dantès' Shocking Arrest and the Shattering of Joy
detailed_summary: As the ominous sounds approached, three knocks landed on the door, causing consternation among the guests.
A loud voice from outside demanded entry in the name of the law.
The door opened to reveal a magistrate in his official scarf, accompanied by four soldiers and a corporal, transforming unease into extreme dread.
M. Morrel, recognizing the magistrate, asked the reason for the unexpected visit, suggesting a mistake.
The magistrate assured reparation if it was a mistake but stated he had an arrest order to fulfill and asked who among them was Edmond Dantès.
All eyes turned to Dantès, who, despite his agitation, stepped forward with dignity and identified himself.
The magistrate declared, “Edmond Dantès, I arrest you in the name of the law!”
Edmond, slightly paling, asked for the reason.
The magistrate stated he could not disclose the reason then but it would be revealed at the preliminary examination.
M. Morrel recognized the futility of resistance against an officer of the law.

Old Dantès, however, sprang forward, pleading so movingly that even the officer was touched. The officer kindly suggested his son likely neglected a minor cargo registration and would probably be released soon after providing required information.
Caderousse, frowning, asked Danglars, who feigned surprise, for an explanation.
Danglars claimed to be equally bewildered.
Caderousse then looked for Fernand, but he had vanished.
The events of the previous night returned to Caderousse's mind with clarity, the current catastrophe seeming to strip away the haze of intoxication.
In a hoarse voice, Caderousse accused Danglars, suggesting this arrest was part of their concerted trick from the day before and wished double evil upon its projectors.
Danglars denied involvement, reminding Caderousse he had torn up the paper.
Caderousse retorted that Danglars had merely thrown it aside, and he had seen it.
Danglars angrily told Caderousse to be quiet, calling him a drunken fool.
Caderousse asked for Fernand’s whereabouts.
Danglars disclaimed knowledge, suggesting Fernand was looking after his own affairs, and urged Caderousse to see what could be done for their friends.
Meanwhile, Dantès, after cheerfully shaking hands with his friends, surrendered to the officer, reassuring everyone it was a small mistake to be cleared up, possibly without even going to prison.
Danglars approached, echoing that it was certainly just a mistake.
Dantès was led down the staircase by the magistrate, followed by soldiers.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The sounds drew nearer.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Dantès descended the staircase, preceded by the magistrate, and followed by the soldiers.

events.text_segment:
The sounds drew nearer. Three blows were struck upon the panel of the door. The company looked at each other in consternation.
“I demand admittance,” said a loud voice outside the room, “in the name of the law!” As no attempt was made to prevent it, the door was opened, and a magistrate, wearing his official scarf, presented himself, followed by four soldiers and a corporal. Uneasiness now yielded to the most extreme dread on the part of those present.
“May I venture to inquire the reason of this unexpected visit?” said M. Morrel, addressing the magistrate, whom he evidently knew; “there is doubtless some mistake easily explained.”
“If it be so,” replied the magistrate, “rely upon every reparation being made; meanwhile, I am the bearer of an order of arrest, and although I most reluctantly perform the task assigned me, it must, nevertheless, be fulfilled. Who among the persons here assembled answers to the name of Edmond Dantès?”
Every eye was turned towards the young man who, spite of the agitation he could not but feel, advanced with dignity, and said, in a firm voice:
“I am he; what is your pleasure with me?”
“Edmond Dantès,” replied the magistrate, “I arrest you in the name of the law!”
“Me!” repeated Edmond, slightly changing color, “and wherefore, I pray?”
“I cannot inform you, but you will be duly acquainted with the reasons that have rendered such a step necessary at the preliminary examination.”
M. Morrel felt that further resistance or remonstrance was useless. He saw before him an officer delegated to enforce the law, and perfectly well knew that it would be as unavailing to seek pity from a magistrate decked with his official scarf, as to address a petition to some cold marble effigy. Old Dantès, however, sprang forward. There are situations which the heart of a father or a mother cannot be made to understand. He prayed and supplicated in terms so moving, that even the officer was touched, and, although firm in his duty, he kindly said, “My worthy friend, let me beg of you to calm your apprehensions. Your son has probably neglected some prescribed form or attention in registering his cargo, and it is more than probable he will be set at liberty directly he has given the information required, whether touching the health of his crew, or the value of his freight.”
“What is the meaning of all this?” inquired Caderousse, frowningly, of Danglars, who had assumed an air of utter surprise.
“How can I tell you?” replied he; “I am, like yourself, utterly bewildered at all that is going on, and cannot in the least make out what it is about.” Caderousse then looked around for Fernand, but he had disappeared.
The scene of the previous night now came back to his mind with startling clearness. The painful catastrophe he had just witnessed appeared effectually to have rent away the veil which the intoxication of the evening before had raised between himself and his memory.
“So, so,” said he, in a hoarse and choking voice, to Danglars, “this, then, I suppose, is a part of the trick you were concerting yesterday? All I can say is, that if it be so, ’tis an ill turn, and well deserves to bring double evil on those who have projected it.”
“Nonsense,” returned Danglars, “I tell you again I have nothing whatever to do with it; besides, you know very well that I tore the paper to pieces.”
“No, you did not!” answered Caderousse, “you merely threw it by—I saw it lying in a corner.”
“Hold your tongue, you fool!—what should you know about it?—why, you were drunk!”
“Where is Fernand?” inquired Caderousse.
“How do I know?” replied Danglars; “gone, as every prudent man ought to be, to look after his own affairs, most likely. Never mind where he is, let you and I go and see what is to be done for our poor friends.”
During this conversation, Dantès, after having exchanged a cheerful shake of the hand with all his sympathizing friends, had surrendered himself to the officer sent to arrest him, merely saying, “Make yourselves quite easy, my good fellows, there is some little mistake to clear up, that’s all, depend upon it; and very likely I may not have to go so far as the prison to effect that.”
“Oh, to be sure!” responded Danglars, who had now approached the group, “nothing more than a mistake, I feel quite certain.”
Dantès descended the staircase, preceded by the magistrate, and followed by the soldiers.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The sounds drew nearer. Three knocks were heard at the door, and the guests looked at each other in consternation. “Is there any one who is not at home?” asked M. Morrel. “There is no one,” replied Caderousse; “we are all here.” In spite of this assurance, the knocks were repeated, and with greater energy. “It seems to be a summons for some one,” said Mercédès, turning pale. “For some one amongst us,” added Danglars. “Open the door,” said M. Morrel; “it is some mistake.” The door was opened, and they saw a magistrate, wearing his official scarf, preceded by four soldiers and a corporal. A murmur of affright ran through the company. “What is the matter?” asked M. Morrel, advancing to meet the magistrate. “Whom do you want, sir? I am M. Morrel, owner of the Pharaon.” “It is not you I want, sir,” replied the magistrate, with civility; “but I have an order to arrest Edmond Dantès, mate of your vessel.” All eyes were turned towards Edmond, who, notwithstanding the agitation he must have experienced, advanced, and with a firm voice, said, “I am he, sir. What do you want with me?” “Edmond Dantès,” said the magistrate, “I arrest you in the name of the law!” A pallor spread itself over the young man’s cheeks, and he slightly trembled. “In the name of the law?” he said. “To what crime is this arrest owing?” “That you will learn at your examination.” M. Morrel saw that resistance was useless. Old Dantès tore his hair, and the women sobbed aloud. A soldier touched Edmond’s arm. “My father!” said he, “and you, Mercédès, do not be alarmed; it is probably some mistake concerning the cargo, and it will be cleared up.” “No, no,” said the old man; “they can only arrest honest people for debt.” “I am not in debt, father. M. Morrel, be kind enough to hasten the examination, and release me from this unpleasant business.” “We will do all that is possible,” said M. Morrel; “compose yourself.” “I will take care of the father, Mercédès,” said Caderousse. “Be calm,” said Mercédès to Edmond. “I will be calm,” replied the young man; “it is only an unpleasant formality.” During this time Danglars had approached Caderousse. “Well,” said Caderousse, “did I not tell you so? He is arrested.” “Yes, and on the wedding-day!” said Danglars. “It is a fatal day for him.” “But why is he arrested?” asked Caderousse. “I do not know,” replied Danglars. “But,” said Caderousse, looking around, “where is Fernand?” “He has disappeared,” said Danglars, becoming pale. “Ah, ah,” said Caderousse, “I begin to understand.” “Understand what?” “Understand that it is a blow aimed at Edmond, through Fernand and you. I saw you both with the Gascon yesterday.” “Hold your tongue, drunkard!” said Danglars; “you are talking nonsense. Do you forget that I tore up the paper?” “No, I do not forget,” said Caderousse; “but you did not tear it up until it was copied. Give me back my glass, I have need of it.” “Go home and sober yourself,” said Danglars. “I will not go home,” said Caderousse; “I will stay here and see what becomes of this poor Edmond. Where is Fernand? I do not see him.” “He is probably gone to see what he can do for him,” said Danglars, with a forced smile. “You are a villain!” replied Caderousse. “You know very well where he is.” “No,” replied Danglars; “I swear to you that I do not.” “Swear to me by your hope of salvation.” “I swear by my hope of salvation.” “Villain!” repeated Caderousse, who could find no other word. “You are a villain!” Edmond, meanwhile, had shaken hands with all his friends, and said to them, with a smile, “Do not forget me, my friends, for I shall soon return.” “Be assured we shall not forget you,” replied M. Morrel. “And we,” said Caderousse and Danglars. “Hold! you have forgotten one,” said Edmond. “Who?” “Mercédès.” “Ah, no,” said Caderousse, “we have not forgotten Mercédès. You are right, Edmond, we have not forgotten her.” The magistrate made a sign, and Edmond descended the staircase, preceded by the corporal, and followed by the four soldiers.

events.title: Grief, Lingering Suspicions, and M. Morrel's Devastating News
detailed_summary: A carriage took Dantès, two soldiers, and the magistrate towards Marseilles.
Mercédès cried out a farewell from the balcony, a sound like a sob of a broken heart.
Dantès leaned from the coach, calling goodbye to Mercédès and promising they would soon meet again, before the vehicle disappeared.
M. Morrel announced he would hurry to Marseilles to get news and instructed everyone to wait.
The remaining guests urged him to go and return quickly.
A long, fearful silence fell upon those left behind after Morrel's departure.
Old Dantès and Mercédès, initially absorbed in their individual grief, eventually rushed into each other's arms in a shared burst of emotion.

Fernand reappeared, shakily poured and drank water, then sat at the first empty seat, which happened to be next to where Mercédès had nearly fainted after old Dantès' embrace. Fernand instinctively moved his chair back.
Caderousse, who had been watching Fernand, whispered to Danglars his certainty that Fernand was the cause of the misery.
Danglars disagreed, calling Fernand too stupid for such a scheme, and hoped the blame would fall on the true perpetrator.
Caderousse pointed out that those who aided and abetted were also culpable.
Danglars evasively replied that one isn't responsible for every stray arrow.
Caderousse countered that one is responsible if the arrow deliberately hits someone.
Meanwhile, guests discussed the arrest in various ways.
One guest asked Danglars for his opinion on the event.
Danglars suggested Dantès might have been caught with a minor contraband item.
Another questioned how this could happen without Danglars' knowledge as supercargo.
Danglars claimed he only knew what he was told about the ship's cargo (cotton from Alexandria and Smyrna) and requested not to be asked for more details.
Old Dantès then recalled his son mentioning a small case of coffee and tobacco he had brought for him.
Danglars seized on this, exclaiming that customs officials must have found these 'hidden treasures' during their absence.
Mercédès ignored this explanation, her grief erupting into hysterical sobbing.
Old Dantès tried to comfort her, saying there was still hope.
Danglars and a faint Fernand echoed the word 'hope,' the latter with apparent difficulty.
A lookout on the balcony shouted that M. Morrel was returning, sparking hope for Dantès' release.
Mercédès and old Dantès rushed to meet Morrel, who appeared very pale.
In response to urgent questions, Morrel gravely stated the situation was more serious than expected.
Mercédès sobbed that Dantès was innocent.
Morrel agreed with her belief but revealed Dantès was charged with being an agent of the Bonapartist faction, a very serious accusation at that time.

events.text_segment:
A carriage awaited him at the door; he got in, followed by two soldiers and the magistrate, and the vehicle drove off towards Marseilles.
“Adieu, adieu, dearest Edmond!” cried Mercédès, stretching out her arms to him from the balcony.
The prisoner heard the cry, which sounded like the sob of a broken heart, and leaning from the coach he called out, “Good-bye, Mercédès—we shall soon meet again!” Then the vehicle disappeared round one of the turnings of Fort Saint Nicholas.
“Wait for me here, all of you!” cried M. Morrel; “I will take the first conveyance I find, and hurry to Marseilles, whence I will bring you word how all is going on.”
“That’s right!” exclaimed a multitude of voices, “go, and return as quickly as you can!”
This second departure was followed by a long and fearful state of terrified silence on the part of those who were left behind. The old father and Mercédès remained for some time apart, each absorbed in grief; but at length the two poor victims of the same blow raised their eyes, and with a simultaneous burst of feeling rushed into each other’s arms.
Meanwhile Fernand made his appearance, poured out for himself a glass of water with a trembling hand; then hastily swallowing it, went to sit down at the first vacant place, and this was, by mere chance, placed next to the seat on which poor Mercédès had fallen half fainting, when released from the warm and affectionate embrace of old Dantès. Instinctively Fernand drew back his chair.
“He is the cause of all this misery—I am quite sure of it,” whispered Caderousse, who had never taken his eyes off Fernand, to Danglars.
“I don’t think so,” answered the other; “he’s too stupid to imagine such a scheme. I only hope the mischief will fall upon the head of whoever wrought it.”
“You don’t mention those who aided and abetted the deed,” said Caderousse.
“Surely,” answered Danglars, “one cannot be held responsible for every chance arrow shot into the air.”
“You can, indeed, when the arrow lights point downward on somebody’s head.”
Meantime the subject of the arrest was being canvassed in every different form.
“What think you, Danglars,” said one of the party, turning towards him, “of this event?”
“Why,” replied he, “I think it just possible Dantès may have been detected with some trifling article on board ship considered here as contraband.”
“But how could he have done so without your knowledge, Danglars, since you are the ship’s supercargo?”
“Why, as for that, I could only know what I was told respecting the merchandise with which the vessel was laden. I know she was loaded with cotton, and that she took in her freight at Alexandria from Pastret’s warehouse, and at Smyrna from Pascal’s; that is all I was obliged to know, and I beg I may not be asked for any further particulars.”
“Now I recollect,” said the afflicted old father; “my poor boy told me yesterday he had got a small case of coffee, and another of tobacco for me!”
“There, you see,” exclaimed Danglars. “Now the mischief is out; depend upon it the custom-house people went rummaging about the ship in our absence, and discovered poor Dantès’ hidden treasures.”
Mercédès, however, paid no heed to this explanation of her lover’s arrest. Her grief, which she had hitherto tried to restrain, now burst out in a violent fit of hysterical sobbing.
“Come, come,” said the old man, “be comforted, my poor child; there is still hope!”
“Hope!” repeated Danglars.
“Hope!” faintly murmured Fernand, but the word seemed to die away on his pale agitated lips, and a convulsive spasm passed over his countenance.
“Good news! good news!” shouted forth one of the party stationed in the balcony on the lookout. “Here comes M. Morrel back. No doubt, now, we shall hear that our friend is released!”
Mercédès and the old man rushed to meet the shipowner and greeted him at the door. He was very pale.
“What news?” exclaimed a general burst of voices.
“Alas, my friends,” replied M. Morrel, with a mournful shake of his head, “the thing has assumed a more serious aspect than I expected.”
“Oh, indeed—indeed, sir, he is innocent!” sobbed forth Mercédès.
“That I believe!” answered M. Morrel; “but still he is charged——”
“With what?” inquired the elder Dantès.
“With being an agent of the Bonapartist faction!” Many of our readers may be able to recollect how formidable such an accusation became in the period at which our story is dated.

'Yes,' replied Danglars, 'the blow is struck.' 'By whom, think you?' 'By Fernand. Who else could it be?' 'I do not know; but I am not so sure.' 'Why not? Who had any interest in removing Dantès? 'He is afraid,' said Danglars. 'Of what?' 'Of being found out.' 'That is possible. But if he is found out, he is lost.' 'Not so sure. He has friends.' 'Who?' 'You, for instance.' 'I? 'You are a coward,' said Caderousse. 'No, I am prudent. And you?' 'I am an honest man.' 'Indeed? Then why did you not denounce him?' 'Because I did not know that he was guilty.' 'And now that you know it?' 'I do not know it. I only suspect it.' 'And you will do nothing?' 'What can I do? I am a poor devil, as I told you.' 'You can speak.' 'To whom?' 'To the magistrate.' 'And ruin myself? No, thank you.' 'You are a coward,' repeated Caderousse. 'Perhaps. But I am not a fool.' 'Nor I,' said Caderousse. 'But I am an honest man, and I will not allow an innocent man to be ruined.' 'You are very scrupulous all at once,' said Danglars. 'What has happened to you?' 'Nothing. But I do not like injustice.' 'And you think that Dantès is innocent?' 'I am sure of it.' 'And you think that Fernand is guilty?' 'I am sure of it.' 'Then denounce him.' 'I will.' 'When?' 'When I have proof.' Meanwhile, the guests were discussing the event in various ways. Some said that Dantès had been arrested for smuggling; others, that he had been concerned in some political plot; others, again, that he had been guilty of some crime which had hitherto escaped detection. 'What do you think of it, M. Danglars?' asked one of the guests. 'I think,' replied Danglars, 'that M. Dantès has been arrested for some trifling offence, such as smuggling, or something of that sort.' 'But,' said another, 'how could that be, without your knowledge, M. Danglars? You are the supercargo, and you ought to know everything that passes on board.' 'I know,' replied Danglars, 'what I am bound to know, that is to say, that the ship is laden with cotton from Alexandria and Smyrna, and with a few cases of opium for the Sultan. As for the rest, I know nothing.' 'But,' said old Dantès, 'my son told me that he had brought me a small case of coffee and tobacco.' 'Ah, yes,' said Danglars, 'I remember now. He did mention something of the kind. But I did not pay much attention to it.' 'And you think,' said the guest who had first spoken, 'that it is for that trifle that he has been arrested?' 'It is probable,' replied Danglars. 'The customs officers are very strict just now. And besides, they may have found something else on board.' simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.refinement_prompt:
IMPROVEMENT GUIDANCE:
1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- The completion invents several extended dialogues and exchanges between Caderousse and Danglars that do not exist in the original, including lengthy debates about guilt, honesty, and prudence. These invented conversations replace the original, more concise exchanges and alter the tone and focus of the scene.
- The completion omits the return and report of M. Morrel, which is a significant event in the latter part of the passage. The original includes his return, the group's reaction, and the revelation of the accusation against Dantès, none of which are present in the completion.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The completion lacks the direct farewell exchange between Edmond and Mercédès, including the emotional gestures and spoken words as the carriage departs.
- The description of the fearful silence and the emotional aftermath among those left behind is abbreviated and lacks the specific sequence of reactions, such as the simultaneous embrace between Mercédès and the elder Dantès.
- The completion does not include the group’s anticipation and lookout for M. Morrel’s return, nor the announcement of his arrival.
- The explanation of the specific charge against Dantès and the historical context of its seriousness is missing.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- Early in the passage, the completion inaccurately describes Mercédès’ reaction and omits the prisoner’s response from the carriage, altering the emotional dynamic of the scene.
- The sequence of events is disrupted: the invented dialogue between Caderousse and Danglars is placed where, in the original, a more concise and thematically different exchange occurs.
- The completion introduces incorrect details about the ship’s cargo, mentioning items not present in the original, and omits the specific references to the actual goods discussed.
- The completion attributes certain lines and actions to the wrong characters, such as having Caderousse and Danglars discuss their own honesty and intentions at length, which is not present in the original.
- The completion ends abruptly, cutting off Mercédès’ reaction and omitting the concluding developments, including the group’s response to M. Morrel’s news and the final revelation about the accusation.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: A carriage awaited him at the door; he got in, followed by two soldiers and the magistrate, and the vehicle drove off towards Marseilles. The silence inside the carriage was heavy, broken only by the rhythmic clatter of the horses' hooves on the road and the occasional jingle of the soldiers' equipment. Dantès sat between the two guards, the magistrate opposite him, his face impassive. Edmond felt a cold knot tightening in his stomach. He looked out of the window, watching the familiar streets of the Allées de Meilhan disappear behind them, then the houses giving way to the open road. The sun, which had shone so brightly on his betrothal feast just hours ago, now seemed distant and indifferent. He tried to speak, to ask questions, to demand an explanation, but the words caught in his throat. The magistrate offered no information, merely observing him with a detached gaze that chilled Dantès more than the cool air entering through the open window. The soldiers remained silent, their presence a constant, unyielding reminder of his captivity. He was a prisoner, though he could not fathom why. What crime could he possibly have committed? His mind raced, replaying the events of the day: the arrival in port, the visit to his father, the joyous reunion with Mercédès, the betrothal feast. Nothing seemed out of place, nothing that could warrant this sudden, brutal separation from his life. Yet, here he was, being driven away, his future stolen in an instant. The carriage continued its journey, leaving the city behind. Soon, the landscape changed, becoming more rugged, the road winding closer to the coast. Dantès' heart leaped when he caught the first glimpse of the sea, his beloved element. But the sight brought no comfort; instead, it emphasized his plight. The sea, usually a path to freedom and adventure, was now a barrier, separating him from everything he held dear. The carriage stopped near a small cove. A boat was waiting, manned by two sailors. The magistrate and the soldiers disembarked, motioning for Dantès to follow. He stepped out onto the shingle, the sound of the waves a mournful dirge. He looked back towards the distant city, a lump forming in his throat. This was not a journey he had ever anticipated. He was led into the boat, the soldiers taking their places on either side of him. The sailors pushed off, and the boat began to move across the water. As they pulled away from the shore, Dantès saw it – a dark, formidable shape rising from the sea, silhouetted against the pale sky. The Château d'If. Its reputation preceded it; a fortress prison, a place from which few returned. A shiver ran down his spine. Was this where they were taking him? The boat approached the island, the walls of the fortress looming larger and larger, their stone faces grim and unwelcoming. There were no windows visible from the sea, only battlements and the narrow slit of a gate. The boat docked at a small landing stage carved into the rock. Dantès was ordered out, his legs stiff from the carriage ride and the shock. He was led through a heavy, iron-studded gate that creaked ominously as it swung open. Inside, the air was cold and damp, smelling of stone and decay. They walked through narrow, echoing corridors, the sound of their footsteps amplified in the oppressive silence. They passed guards standing stiffly at intervals, their faces expressionless. Finally, they reached a door, heavier and more forbidding than the others. The magistrate nodded to the soldiers. One of them produced a large, rusty key. The lock groaned as the key turned. The door swung inward, revealing a small, dark chamber. It was bare save for a stone bench and a pile of straw in one corner. The air was thick and stagnant. "In here," the magistrate said, his voice flat. Dantès hesitated for a moment, his eyes wide with disbelief and terror. This couldn't be happening. This was a nightmare. But the soldiers were behind him, their hands on his arms, urging him forward. He stumbled into the cell. The door slammed shut behind him with a deafening clang that reverberated through the stone walls and through his very soul. The sound of the bolt sliding home was the final, crushing blow.

events.title: Caderousse's Moral Conflict and Danglars' Self-Preserving Manipulation
detailed_summary: Mercédès cried out in despair, and old Dantès collapsed into a chair upon hearing the charge.
Caderousse whispered to Danglars that he had been deceived and the 'trick' had been played, declaring he would not let an old man and an innocent girl suffer and would tell them everything.
Danglars fiercely silenced Caderousse, warning for his safety and questioning Dantès' innocence, pointing out the ship's stop at Elba.
He suggested that if compromising documents were found on Dantès, anyone supporting him might be deemed an accomplice.
Caderousse, driven by selfish instinct, recognized the force of this argument. His gaze on Danglars shifted from doubt to caution, and generosity gave way.
He proposed they wait and see what happens.
Danglars readily agreed, stating that if Dantès were innocent, he'd be freed, and if guilty, it was unwise to get involved in a conspiracy.
Caderousse expressed his inability to stay longer.
Danglars, pleased by Caderousse's compliance, agreed they should leave and let events unfold.
Following their departure, Fernand, now positioning himself as Mercédès' friend and protector, escorted her home. Other friends took Dantès' nearly catatonic father to the Allées de Meilhan.

events.text_segment:
A despairing cry escaped the pale lips of Mercédès; the old man sank into a chair.
“Ah, Danglars!” whispered Caderousse, “you have deceived me—the trick you spoke of last night has been played; but I cannot suffer a poor old man or an innocent girl to die of grief through your fault. I am determined to tell them all about it.”
“Be silent, you simpleton!” cried Danglars, grasping him by the arm, “or I will not answer even for your own safety. Who can tell whether Dantès be innocent or guilty? The vessel did touch at Elba, where he quitted it, and passed a whole day in the island. Now, should any letters or other documents of a compromising character be found upon him, will it not be taken for granted that all who uphold him are his accomplices?”
With the rapid instinct of selfishness, Caderousse readily perceived the solidity of this mode of reasoning; he gazed, doubtfully, wistfully, on Danglars, and then caution supplanted generosity.
“Suppose we wait a while, and see what comes of it,” said he, casting a bewildered look on his companion.
“To be sure!” answered Danglars. “Let us wait, by all means. If he be innocent, of course he will be set at liberty; if guilty, why, it is no use involving ourselves in a conspiracy.”
“Let us go, then. I cannot stay here any longer.”
“With all my heart!” replied Danglars, pleased to find the other so tractable. “Let us take ourselves out of the way, and leave things for the present to take their course.”
After their departure, Fernand, who had now again become the friend and protector of Mercédès, led the girl to her home, while some friends of Dantès conducted his father, nearly lifeless, to the Allées de Meilhan.

But are you sure he is guilty?” “Sure as that you are a living man. The proofs were found upon him, or will be found.” He stopped, and then added, in a low voice, as if speaking to himself, “And among them, perhaps, the letter from the Isle of Elba.” “You did not, then, denounce him, Danglars?” asked Caderousse, uneasily. “No,” replied Danglars; “but I was with the officer who did.” “But why was he arrested just as he was going to be married?” asked Caderousse. “Because,” said Danglars, “the order came just at that moment. But do not make yourself uneasy, if he is innocent, he will be set at liberty.” “Oh, yes, if he is innocent,” said Caderousse; “but if he is not?” “If he is not, it is another affair, and we must let justice take its course,” replied Danglars. “But,” said Caderousse, “can we not do something for him? Can we not speak in his favour?” “That would be the surest way to ruin him and ourselves too. No, no, let us not stir in the matter. If he is innocent, he has no need of us; if he is guilty, we should only compromise ourselves by trying to serve him.” “You are right,” said Caderousse; “let us wait and see.” “Yes,” said Danglars, “let us wait and see. And now, as there is nothing more to be done here, let us go.” “Yes, let us go,” said Caderousse. They went out together. Fernand, who had been standing apart, approached Mercédès, and offered to escort her home. She accepted his offer, and they went out together. The other friends took the old man, who was almost in a state of catalepsy, to the Allées de Meilhan.

events.title: Danglars' Calculated Ascent to Command of the Pharaon
detailed_summary: News of Edmond's arrest as a Bonapartist agent spread quickly through Marseilles.
M. Morrel, on his way to seek more information from M. de Villefort, encountered Danglars and Caderousse and expressed his disbelief about the accusation.
Danglars reminded Morrel that he had previously voiced suspicion about Dantès anchoring at Elba.
When Morrel asked if he had shared these suspicions with others, Danglars denied it.

In a low voice, Danglars insinuated he kept quiet to protect Morrel, whose uncle was a known Bonapartist sympathizer, and thus Morrel himself was suspected of Napoleonic leanings. Divulging his fears, Danglars claimed, could have harmed both Edmond and Morrel.
He added that while a subordinate should inform the shipowner of occurrences, some matters are best concealed from others.
M. Morrel commended Danglars as a worthy fellow, revealing he had already considered Danglars' interests should Dantès have become captain.
Danglars feigned surprise at Morrel's kindness.
Morrel shared that he had asked Dantès about Danglars and whether Dantès would mind keeping him on, acknowledging a perceived coolness between them.
When Danglars inquired about Dantès' reply, Morrel recounted that Dantès admitted to possibly causing offense but stated that anyone trusted by the shipowners would also have his preference.
Danglars muttered
The hypocrite!
under his breath.
Caderousse interjected that no one could deny Dantès was noble-hearted.
M. Morrel then pointed out that the Pharaon was without a captain.
Danglars responded that since the port stay was for three months, they could hope for Dantès' release within that time.

When Morrel pressed about the interim, Danglars offered his services, stating he was as capable as any captain and that his temporary command would simplify matters upon Dantès' return, allowing them both to resume their posts.

Morrel thanked Danglars, agreeing it would resolve difficulties, and authorized him to take command of the Pharaon and oversee the unloading of its cargo, emphasizing that private misfortunes shouldn't hinder business.
Danglars assured Morrel on that score and asked if they would be allowed to see Dantès.

Morrel promised to inform them after speaking with M. de Villefort, whom he hoped to sway in Edmond's favor, despite Villefort being a staunch royalist and king's attorney, hoping he was fundamentally a decent man.
Danglars expressed doubt, noting Villefort's reported ambition as a negative factor.

events.text_segment:
The rumor of Edmond’s arrest as a Bonapartist agent was not slow in circulating throughout the city.
“Could you ever have credited such a thing, my dear Danglars?” asked M. Morrel, as, on his return to the port for the purpose of gleaning fresh tidings of Dantès, from M. de Villefort, the assistant procureur, he overtook his supercargo and Caderousse. “Could you have believed such a thing possible?”
“Why, you know I told you,” replied Danglars, “that I considered the circumstance of his having anchored at the Island of Elba as a very suspicious circumstance.”
“And did you mention these suspicions to any person beside myself?”
“Certainly not!” returned Danglars. Then added in a low whisper, “You understand that, on account of your uncle, M. Policar Morrel, who served under the other government, and who does not altogether conceal what he thinks on the subject, you are strongly suspected of regretting the abdication of Napoleon. I should have feared to injure both Edmond and yourself, had I divulged my own apprehensions to a soul. I am too well aware that though a subordinate, like myself, is bound to acquaint the shipowner with everything that occurs, there are many things he ought most carefully to conceal from all else.”
“’Tis well, Danglars—’tis well!” replied M. Morrel. “You are a worthy fellow; and I had already thought of your interests in the event of poor Edmond having become captain of the Pharaon.”
“Is it possible you were so kind?”
“Yes, indeed; I had previously inquired of Dantès what was his opinion of you, and if he should have any reluctance to continue you in your post, for somehow I have perceived a sort of coolness between you.”
“And what was his reply?”
“That he certainly did think he had given you offence in an affair which he merely referred to without entering into particulars, but that whoever possessed the good opinion and confidence of the ship’s owners would have his preference also.”
“The hypocrite!” murmured Danglars.
“Poor Dantès!” said Caderousse. “No one can deny his being a noble-hearted young fellow.”
“But meanwhile,” continued M. Morrel, “here is the Pharaon without a captain.”
“Oh,” replied Danglars, “since we cannot leave this port for the next three months, let us hope that ere the expiration of that period Dantès will be set at liberty.”
“No doubt; but in the meantime?”
“I am entirely at your service, M. Morrel,” answered Danglars. “You know that I am as capable of managing a ship as the most experienced captain in the service; and it will be so far advantageous to you to accept my services, that upon Edmond’s release from prison no further change will be requisite on board the Pharaon than for Dantès and myself each to resume our respective posts.”
“Thanks, Danglars—that will smooth over all difficulties. I fully authorize you at once to assume the command of the Pharaon, and look carefully to the unloading of her freight. Private misfortunes must never be allowed to interfere with business.”
“Be easy on that score, M. Morrel; but do you think we shall be permitted to see our poor Edmond?”
“I will let you know that directly I have seen M. de Villefort, whom I shall endeavor to interest in Edmond’s favor. I am aware he is a furious royalist; but, in spite of that, and of his being king’s attorney, he is a man like ourselves, and I fancy not a bad sort of one.”
“Perhaps not,” replied Danglars; “but I hear that he is ambitious, and that’s rather against him.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The rumor of Edmond’s arrest as a Bonapartist agent was not slow in circulating throughout the city. M. Morrel himself, on his way to the Palais de Justice to make inquiries, met Danglars and Caderousse. “Ah, M. Morrel!” cried Caderousse, “you have heard the news?” “Alas! yes,” replied Morrel, “and I am come to ascertain the truth of this frightful report.” “But it is true, nevertheless,” said Danglars; “he has been arrested as a Bonapartist agent.” “Impossible!” said M. Morrel; “Edmond is the most honest young man on earth, and I am sure he is no more a Bonapartist than I am a Royalist.” Danglars smiled. “Do you think so?” said he. “By my honor, I do not know a more estimable young man than Edmond Dantès,” said Morrel. “Do you, Danglars?” “Oh, yes,” replied Danglars, “when I say he is a Bonapartist, it is merely what he himself said.” “What he himself said?” “Yes, when he showed me the letter from the Isle of Elba, and told me he had a commission from the Grand Marshal, who had given him a letter to carry to a person in Paris.” “Indeed?” “Yes; but as I never like to meddle with politics, I said nothing about it, and I beg you to observe, M. Morrel, that I have not spoken of it even to my partner, Caderousse.” “The devil!” cried Caderousse, “you have not been so discreet, Danglars, for you told me, and added that you had your fears that when Edmond returned the first thing he would do would be to get himself made captain in my place.” “It is true,” said Danglars, “I did say so; but I said it, as I always do say anything, without reflecting, and besides—” “Besides,” said Caderousse, “you added that Dantès was a Bonapartist, and as the Bonapartists had a good chance of coming back, he would not only be captain, but would be admiral too, and then he would get you a good berth.” “I tell you,” replied Danglars, “that I had forgotten all about it; and I am even astonished that I ever remembered anything about it.” “Well, well,” said Morrel, “it is a very serious matter.” “Yes, it is,” said Danglars, “and I am afraid it will be a long time before we see him again. If he is a Bonapartist, and they find a letter from the Isle of Elba upon him, he is lost.” “But the Pharaon?” inquired Morrel. “Ah, the Pharaon!” said Danglars. “She is without a captain, and I am afraid we shall be obliged to lay her up.” “Not at all,” said Morrel; “I will take the command of her myself.” “You, M. Morrel?” “Yes; I will take the command of her myself. I am not afraid of the sea, and I will take her to sea, and I will bring her back again.” “But you are not a sailor, M. Morrel.” “I am a sailor, nevertheless. I have been to sea, and I know how to navigate a ship.” “But you are not a captain.” “I am a captain, nevertheless. I have commanded a ship, and I know how to command a ship.” “But you are not a captain in the merchant service.” “I am a captain in the merchant service, nevertheless. I have commanded a ship in the imperial navy, and I know how to command a ship in the imperial navy.” “But you are not a captain in the republican navy.” “I am a captain in the republican navy, nevertheless. I have commanded a ship in the republican navy, and I know how to command a ship in the republican navy.” “But
