events.title: Villefort's Relief, Reflection, and Ruthless Ambition
detailed_summary: The moment Dantès exits and the door closes, Villefort collapses into a chair, nearly fainting from the immense stress and relief.

He murmurs to himself, expressing his profound relief that the chief prosecutor (procureur du roi) was not present in Marseilles, as the discovery of the letter addressed to his father would have undoubtedly led to his own ruin and the destruction of all his ambitious hopes.
He reflects with frustration on how his father's controversial past continuously casts a shadow over his own career and successes.
Suddenly, a new thought illuminates his expression. A calculating smile forms on his lips, and his previously haggard eyes become fixed in deep contemplation.
He arrives at a decisive conclusion: the very letter that threatened to destroy him can, in fact, be leveraged to build his fortune and advance his career.
With this newfound, ruthless resolve, he declares, "Now to the work I have in hand."
After confirming that Dantès has indeed been taken away, Villefort, the deputy procureur, quickly departs for the residence of his fiancée, his mind now set on executing his opportunistic plan.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Hardly had the door closed when Villefort threw himself half-fainting into a chair.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And after having assured himself that the prisoner was gone, the deputy procureur hastened to the house of his betrothed.

events.text_segment:
Hardly had the door closed when Villefort threw himself half-fainting into a chair.
“Alas, alas,” murmured he, “if the procureur himself had been at Marseilles I should have been ruined. This accursed letter would have destroyed all my hopes. Oh, my father, must your past career always interfere with my successes?” Suddenly a light passed over his face, a smile played round his set mouth, and his haggard eyes were fixed in thought.
“This will do,” said he, “and from this letter, which might have ruined me, I will make my fortune. Now to the work I have in hand.” And after having assured himself that the prisoner was gone, the deputy procureur hastened to the house of his betrothed.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Hardly had the door closed when Villefort threw himself half-fainting into a chair. “Ah,” murmured he, “if the procureur du roi had been at Marseilles, if M. de Salvieux or M. de Fleuriau had been here, I should have been ruined. This accursed letter would have destroyed my prospects for ever. Oh, my father, how many times has your name caused me to tremble! How many times has your career impeded mine! How many times has the name of Noirtier been an obstacle to my advancement!” And he again wiped the large drops of perspiration that rolled down his forehead. Suddenly his brow cleared, a smile played around his mouth, and his haggard eyes were fixed with a searching look. “Certainly,” said he, “I am a fool to be thus terrified. The danger is remote, not imminent. No one knows of the existence of this letter, with the exception of Dantès and myself. His destruction is now as necessary to my future as his liberty would be injurious. I can only hope to advance by walking over his body. Villefort, the ambitious man, can spring from the ruins of Dantès, the sailor. I will be revenged for the trouble this young man has caused me; and at the same time I will remove the obstacle that impedes my onward course. Let me see, let me see,” continued he, with a smile of satisfaction, “and yet the procureur is not here; his deputy would be too much alarmed at the slightest responsibility. I alone am here, and it is for me to strike the blow. The blow from which I recoil will strike me myself. Noirtier, thou art the rock which will split my bark, unless I can cleave thee asunder! Yes, Noirtier, thy son will sever the tie of kindred and cast thee from him.” And as he spoke these words, he shuddered, and dared not look around him. “Nevertheless,” continued he, again smiling, “my father is the son of the Marquis of Noirtier, who was one of the firmest supporters of the old parliament. My father was a Jacobin, and the Jacobinism of ’93 has become the republicanism of 1815; that is to say, the father has followed in the footsteps of the son, and the son has preceded the father. There is but little difference between a man who conspired against Louis XVI. and a man who conspires against Louis XVIII. Save that the former prepared the way for the return of the latter. Had my father continued what he was, a Jacobin, in 1815, he would be shot as a Bonapartist; were he a Royalist, he would be held up as a model of virtue. But he has assumed a tinge of each colour, and is consequently neither. Come, let me consider, this Jaques Allégre, the author of the letter, is armed with one fact only; that is, that the vessel touched at the Isle of Elba, and delivered a letter to a man named Noirtier, and that this man was the father of the procureur du roi of Marseilles. Now, the procureur du roi is not at Marseilles, but at Nîmes. And he is not called Noirtier, but Villefort. So that, you see, the letter is not for the procureur du roi of Marseilles, but for M. Noirtier, at Paris. Besides, fear will render Dantès eloquent, and

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Hardly had the door closed when Villefort threw himself half-fainting into a chair. His face was livid, his hands trembled violently. The air seemed thick, suffocating him. That man, that Count of Monte Cristo, knew! He knew the terrible secret buried in the garden at Auteuil. How could he know? Who was this man? His memory raced back, searching for a face, a name, anything that could explain this impossible knowledge. Could it be? No, it was madness. Dantes was dead, buried in the Chateau d'If. Yet, the Count's eyes, his calm, knowing demeanor, the chilling precision of his words... it was as if the past had risen from its grave, embodied in this mysterious stranger. Villefort felt a cold dread seize him, a premonition of ruin. The ground beneath him seemed to crumble.

chapters.chapter_title: VOLUME ONE. Chapter 8. The Château d’If

events.title: Initial Imprisonment and Lingering Hope
detailed_summary: The police commissary, accompanied by two gendarmes flanking Dantès, navigates through ominous corridors linking the Palais de Justice to the prison.
The prison, a grim structure, overlooks the Accoules clock-tower.
After many turns, Dantès faces a door with an iron wicket; the commissary's triple knock resonates deeply with Dantès' anxiety.
The door opens, Dantès is pushed inside, and it closes loudly, sealing him off from the pure air into the thick, foul atmosphere of confinement.

He is led to a fairly clean but grated and barred cell. Its appearance doesn't immediately distress him, as he clings to the memory of Villefort's seemingly sympathetic words, which he misinterprets as a promise of liberation.
It is four o'clock on March 1st when Dantès enters the cell, and darkness soon falls.
The obscurity heightens his sense of hearing; every slight noise makes him rush to the door, expecting release, only to be met with disappointment as the sounds recede.

Around ten o'clock, as despair begins to consume him, approaching footsteps, the turning of a key, and the opening of his heavy oak door flood his cell with torchlight, momentarily reviving his hopes.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The commissary of police, as he traversed the antechamber, made a sign to two gendarmes, who placed themselves one on Dantès’ right and the other on his left.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: At last, about ten o’clock, and just as Dantès began to despair, steps were heard in the corridor, a key turned in the lock, the bolts creaked, the massy oaken door flew open, and a flood of light from two torches pervaded the apartment.

events.text_segment:
The commissary of police, as he traversed the antechamber, made a sign to two gendarmes, who placed themselves one on Dantès’ right and the other on his left. A door that communicated with the Palais de Justice was opened, and they went through a long range of gloomy corridors, whose appearance might have made even the boldest shudder. The Palais de Justice communicated with the prison,—a sombre edifice, that from its grated windows looks on the clock-tower of the Accoules. After numberless windings, Dantès saw a door with an iron wicket. The commissary took up an iron mallet and knocked thrice, every blow seeming to Dantès as if struck on his heart. The door opened, the two gendarmes gently pushed him forward, and the door closed with a loud sound behind him. The air he inhaled was no longer pure, but thick and mephitic,—he was in prison.
He was conducted to a tolerably neat chamber, but grated and barred, and its appearance, therefore, did not greatly alarm him; besides, the words of Villefort, who seemed to interest himself so much, resounded still in his ears like a promise of freedom. It was four o’clock when Dantès was placed in this chamber. It was, as we have said, the 1st of March, and the prisoner was soon buried in darkness. The obscurity augmented the acuteness of his hearing; at the slightest sound he rose and hastened to the door, convinced they were about to liberate him, but the sound died away, and Dantès sank again into his seat. At last, about ten o’clock, and just as Dantès began to despair, steps were heard in the corridor, a key turned in the lock, the bolts creaked, the massy oaken door flew open, and a flood of light from two torches pervaded the apartment.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The commissary of police, as he traversed the antechamber, made a sign to two gendarmes, who placed themselves one on Dantès’ right and the other on his left. “Take him away,” he said. The gendarmes seized Dantès by the arm. “Oh!” stammered Dantès, “this is not the way to the prison of the Palais de Justice.” “No, it is another prison,” replied the commissary. “But this is not just; I am innocent,” said Dantès. “You will learn that later.” “But where are you taking me?” “Into the prison.” “Which?” “That of the Château d’If.” When they had traversed a long corridor, they came to a staircase that conducted them to a court. It was the court of the Palais de Justice. A carriage was waiting there, into which Dantès was requested to enter. “No,” he said, “I prefer walking. Conduct me to the prison on foot.” “You are wrong,” said the commissary; “we have a long way to go.” “So much the better,” said Dantès; “it will refresh me.” The gendarmes and the commissary looked at each other with astonishment, but as Dantès persisted, the commissary yielded. They set out. They passed through the Rue Dauphine, then the Rue Saint-Laurent, and at length arrived at the port. A boat was waiting there, into which they entered. The two gendarmes were at the bow, the commissary in the stern, and Dantès in the middle. The boat glided rapidly over the waves, and in a few minutes they reached the Château d’If. It is a gloomy structure, which rises from the bosom of the sea, like a phantom of stone. It overlooks the Accoules clock-tower, and seems to be watching the city. As they approached, Dantès felt a cold shudder run through his veins. The boat stopped at the foot of a staircase cut in the rock. The commissary and the gendarmes landed, and Dantès followed them. They ascended the staircase, and passed through a postern gate. A turnkey was waiting for them, who opened a heavy door. They entered a court, and then a corridor. At the end of the corridor was another door, with an iron wicket. The commissary knocked three times. The sound echoed through the corridor, and seemed to strike on Dantès’ heart. The door opened, and he was pushed inside. It closed behind him with a loud noise, and he was left in darkness. He felt the thick, foul atmosphere of confinement, and he shuddered. He was led to a cell, which was fairly clean, but grated and barred. Its appearance did not immediately distress him, for he still clung to the memory of Villefort’s seemingly sympathetic words, which he misinterpreted as a promise of liberation. It was four o’clock on March 1st when Dantès entered the cell, and darkness soon fell. The obscurity heightened his sense of hearing; every slight noise made him rush to the door, expecting release, only to be met with disappointment as the sounds receded. Around ten o’clock, as despair began to consume him, approaching footsteps, the turning of a key, and the opening of his heavy oak door flooded his cell with torchlight, momentarily reviving his hopes.

events.title: Nighttime Transfer and Growing Apprehension
detailed_summary: The torchlight reveals four heavily armed gendarmes, causing Dantès, who had initially stepped forward, to halt at the display of force.
He asks if they are there to fetch him, and a gendarme confirms.
Dantès, still believing in Villefort's intervention, asks if it's by the deputy procureur's orders, which the gendarme affirms, easing Dantès' fears.
Calmly, he positions himself amidst the escort.
A carriage is waiting outside, with a coachman and a police officer on the box.
Dantès confirms the carriage is for him but is urged forward before he can speak further, mounting the steps and finding himself seated between two gendarmes, with two more opposite.
The carriage moves heavily over the cobblestones.
Dantès observes the grated windows of the carriage, realizing he has merely exchanged one prison for another, mobile one, its destination unknown to him.
Through the grating, he identifies familiar streets—Rue Caisserie, Rue Saint-Laurent, Rue Taramis—as they head towards the quay, eventually seeing the lights of the La Consigne guardhouse.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: By the torchlight Dantès saw the glittering sabres and carbines of four gendarmes.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Soon he saw the lights of La Consigne.

events.text_segment:
By the torchlight Dantès saw the glittering sabres and carbines of four gendarmes. He had advanced at first, but stopped at the sight of this display of force.
“Are you come to fetch me?” asked he.
“Yes,” replied a gendarme.
“By the orders of the deputy procureur?”
“I believe so.” The conviction that they came from M. de Villefort relieved all Dantès’ apprehensions; he advanced calmly, and placed himself in the centre of the escort. A carriage waited at the door, the coachman was on the box, and a police officer sat beside him.
“Is this carriage for me?” said Dantès.
“It is for you,” replied a gendarme.
Dantès was about to speak; but feeling himself urged forward, and having neither the power nor the intention to resist, he mounted the steps, and was in an instant seated inside between two gendarmes; the two others took their places opposite, and the carriage rolled heavily over the stones.
The prisoner glanced at the windows—they were grated; he had changed his prison for another that was conveying him he knew not whither. Through the grating, however, Dantès saw they were passing through the Rue Caisserie, and by the Rue Saint-Laurent and the Rue Taramis, to the quay. Soon he saw the lights of La Consigne.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: By the torchlight Dantès saw the glittering sabres and carbines of four gendarmes.  A cold dread seized him, a feeling he had never known, not even in the fiercest tempests at sea.  They stood framed in the doorway, their faces grim and impassive, casting long, dancing shadows into the festive room.  The joyous chatter of the wedding guests died down, replaced by a stunned silence.  Mercédès, her face paling instantly, clutched his arm, her eyes wide with terror.  Old Dantès rose shakily from his chair, his hand trembling.  The leader of the gendarmes stepped forward, his voice flat and official.  “Edmond Dantès?” he asked, though his gaze left no doubt.  Dantès, finding his voice, though it sounded strange and distant, replied, “I am he. What is the meaning of this?”  The gendarme produced a paper. “Edmond Dantès, ship’s mate of the Pharaon, you are arrested by order of the deputy procureur du roi.”  Arrested? On his wedding day? Surrounded by friends and family? It seemed an impossible nightmare.  He looked from the stern faces of the gendarmes to the horrified countenances of his loved ones.  “But why? What have I done?” he stammered, his mind racing, searching for a reason, any reason, for this sudden, brutal intrusion into his happiness.  The gendarme offered no explanation, only a curt gesture towards the door.  The dream was shattered.

events.title: Sea Journey, Fleeting Joy, and Crushing Memories
detailed_summary: The carriage halts, and the police officer gets out, summoning about a dozen soldiers from the guardhouse who form ranks, their muskets glinting in the lamplight.
Dantès silently wonders if such a significant force is truly for him.
The officer opens the locked carriage door, wordlessly answering Dantès' unspoken question as he sees a clear passage formed by the soldiers from the carriage to the port.
Two gendarmes exit first, then Dantès is ordered out, followed by the other two.
They proceed towards a boat tethered near the quay, held by a custom-house officer.
Soldiers observe Dantès with detached curiosity as he is quickly placed in the boat's stern between gendarmes, the officer taking position at the bow.

The boat is pushed off, and four oarsmen propel it swiftly towards the Pilon. A shout from the boat signals for the port's closing chain to be lowered, and they pass into the Frioul, beyond the inner harbor.

Dantès initially feels joy breathing fresh air again, equating it with freedom, but this is short-lived as they pass La Réserve, the site of his happiness that very morning, now alive with sounds of a ball.
He folds his hands, looks skyward, and prays fervently.
The boat continues its journey past landmarks like Tête de Mort and Anse du Pharo, preparing for a maneuver around the battery that Dantès finds baffling.
He asks where they are taking him but is told they are forbidden to explain. Trained in discipline, Dantès refrains from further questioning.
His mind races with vague and wild speculations; the boat seems too small for a long voyage, and no larger vessel is visible. He considers the possibility of being marooned.

The lack of restraints like handcuffs seems a positive sign, and he recalls Villefort's assurance of safety if Noirtier's name remained unmentioned, and how Villefort seemingly destroyed the incriminating letter.
He waits silently, trying to discern their course in the darkness.

They pass the Ile Ratonneau and approach the Point des Catalans, where Mercédès lives. He thinks he can distinguish a female figure on the beach and wonders why Mercédès has no premonition of his proximity.
A single light shines from Mercédès's window, the only visible light, indicating she is awake. He considers shouting out to her but is restrained by pride and concern for his guards' perception.
He remains silent, his gaze fixed on the light as the boat moves on, his thoughts solely on Mercédès until an elevation of land obscures the light.
Dantès then realizes they have reached open sea; while he was lost in thought, the oars were shipped and a sail hoisted, the boat now propelled by the wind.

events.text_segment:
The carriage stopped, the officer descended, approached the guardhouse, a dozen soldiers came out and formed themselves in order; Dantès saw the reflection of their muskets by the light of the lamps on the quay.
“Can all this force be summoned on my account?” thought he.
The officer opened the door, which was locked, and, without speaking a word, answered Dantès’ question; for he saw between the ranks of the soldiers a passage formed from the carriage to the port. The two gendarmes who were opposite to him descended first, then he was ordered to alight and the gendarmes on each side of him followed his example. They advanced towards a boat, which a custom-house officer held by a chain, near the quay.
The soldiers looked at Dantès with an air of stupid curiosity. In an instant he was placed in the stern-sheets of the boat, between the gendarmes, while the officer stationed himself at the bow; a shove sent the boat adrift, and four sturdy oarsmen impelled it rapidly towards the Pilon. At a shout from the boat, the chain that closes the mouth of the port was lowered and in a second they were, as Dantès knew, in the Frioul and outside the inner harbor.
The prisoner’s first feeling was of joy at again breathing the pure air—for air is freedom; but he soon sighed, for he passed before La Réserve, where he had that morning been so happy, and now through the open windows came the laughter and revelry of a ball. Dantès folded his hands, raised his eyes to heaven, and prayed fervently.
The boat continued her voyage. They had passed the Tête de Mort, were now off the Anse du Pharo, and about to double the battery. This manœuvre was incomprehensible to Dantès.
“Whither are you taking me?” asked he.
“You will soon know.”
“But still——”
“We are forbidden to give you any explanation.” Dantès, trained in discipline, knew that nothing would be more absurd than to question subordinates, who were forbidden to reply; and so he remained silent.
The most vague and wild thoughts passed through his mind. The boat they were in could not make a long voyage; there was no vessel at anchor outside the harbor; he thought, perhaps, they were going to leave him on some distant point. He was not bound, nor had they made any attempt to handcuff him; this seemed a good augury. Besides, had not the deputy, who had been so kind to him, told him that provided he did not pronounce the dreaded name of Noirtier, he had nothing to apprehend? Had not Villefort in his presence destroyed the fatal letter, the only proof against him?
He waited silently, striving to pierce through the darkness.
They had left the Ile Ratonneau, where the lighthouse stood, on the right, and were now opposite the Point des Catalans. It seemed to the prisoner that he could distinguish a feminine form on the beach, for it was there Mercédès dwelt. How was it that a presentiment did not warn Mercédès that her lover was within three hundred yards of her?
One light alone was visible; and Dantès saw that it came from Mercédès’ chamber. Mercédès was the only one awake in the whole settlement. A loud cry could be heard by her. But pride restrained him and he did not utter it. What would his guards think if they heard him shout like a madman?
He remained silent, his eyes fixed upon the light; the boat went on, but the prisoner thought only of Mercédès. An intervening elevation of land hid the light. Dantès turned and perceived that they had got out to sea. While he had been absorbed in thought, they had shipped their oars and hoisted sail; the boat was now moving with the wind.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The carriage stopped, the officer descended, approached the guardhouse, a dozen soldiers came out and formed themselves in order; Dantès saw the reflection of their muskets by the light of the lamps on the quay. It was a considerable force, and the young man wondered if such preparations were requisite to take a simple ship’s mate to the Palais de Justice. The officer opened the door, and a voice bade Dantès alight. He did so, and found himself in the midst of a double rank of soldiers. A passage was formed, down which he walked, preceded by two gendarmes, followed by two others; the officer closed the march. They took the way to the port, and Dantès perceived a boat held by a custom-house officer, who was waiting for them on the quay. The soldiers looked at him with the curiosity natural to men to whom a spectacle is a relief, and who do not speculate on the cause, but only contemplate the effect. The boat was painted black, and seemed built for swiftness; it could carry about a dozen men, and was rigged with a single mast. In the stern sheets were two gendarmes, who made room for Dantès between them; the officer placed himself in the bow; the four oarsmen took their places, and in a moment the boat was pushed off from the land. The noise of the oars, as they struck the water with measured time, seemed to Dantès like the beating of a funeral march; and indeed, how little did he imagine that the watery grave was before him! He at first wished to address the officer, but he saw by his countenance that he was not an ordinary agent, and he remained silent, thinking that the moment to speak had not arrived. The boat flew like a bird. In a moment they had passed the Pilon, and were making towards the Pointe des Catalans. Then Dantès saw a light, and that light was from the lamp of a fisherman’s hut. “Ah,” thought he, “it is the hut of old Père Jacquot, who has often taken me fishing with him.” He looked again; the light disappeared. They had passed the Pointe des Catalans. The boat rowed on. Dantès thought that they were going to the Château d’If, and the idea made his blood run cold. But the boat passed the Château d’If, and went on. “Where are we going?” asked Dantès. “You will see,” replied the officer. Dantès was silent. The boat still went on. It passed the Ile Ratonneau, and then the Ile Pomègues. “Where are we going?” asked Dantès again. “To the Château d’If,” replied the officer. Dantès shuddered. The boat stopped. It was alongside a rock. A ladder was lowered. “Go up,” said the officer. Dantès obeyed. He found himself on a platform. A door opened, and he entered a passage. At the end of the passage was a staircase. He went up the staircase. At the top of the staircase was a door. It opened, and he entered a room. In the room was a bed, a table, and a chair. On the table was a lamp. The officer entered after him. “This is your room,” said he. “You will remain here until further orders.” He went out, and the door was locked. Dantès was alone. He looked around him. The room was small and dark. The walls were damp. The air was cold. He sat down on the bed. He buried his face in his hands. He wept. He wept for a long time. When he raised his head, the lamp was burning low. He looked at the door. It was locked. He was a prisoner. He was in the Château d’If. He was in the most terrible prison in France. He was in the tomb. He was dead. He was buried. He was forgotten. He was lost. He was damned. He was in hell

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The carriage stopped, the officer descended, approached the guardhouse, a dozen soldiers came out and formed themselves in order; Dantès saw the reflection of their muskets by the light of the lamps on the quay. His heart, which had been beating with a vague apprehension since he was taken from the Rue du Cours, now seemed to stop entirely. He felt a cold dread creep over him, a premonition of disaster far worse than anything he could have imagined. The officer returned to the carriage door, his face grim and impassive in the flickering light. “Edmond Dantès,” he said, his voice formal and devoid of emotion, “in the name of the law, I arrest you.”

Dantès stared at him, stunned. “Arrest me? On what charge?” he stammered, his voice barely a whisper. The officer offered no explanation, merely gesturing to the soldiers. Two of them stepped forward and opened the carriage door. “Descend, sir,” the officer commanded. Dantès, still reeling from the shock, mechanically obeyed. As he stepped onto the cold, damp stones of the quay, he felt the eyes of the soldiers upon him, their faces indistinct shadows beneath their shakos. He looked back towards the carriage, hoping to see a familiar face, a sign of support, but there was only the empty interior and the impassive driver.

He was led between the two soldiers towards a small boat moored at the quay. The air was heavy with the smell of salt and seaweed, a smell that usually brought him comfort and a sense of belonging, but which now seemed alien and menacing. He glanced back at the city lights, twinkling in the distance, a world of warmth and life from which he was being abruptly severed. He thought of Mercédès, waiting for him, perhaps still celebrating their engagement, unaware of the catastrophe that had befallen him. The thought was a sharp pain in his chest.

They boarded the boat. The officer and a few soldiers followed. The oarsmen pushed off from the quay, and the boat glided silently across the dark water. Dantès watched the lights of Marseille recede, growing smaller and smaller until they were just a faint glow on the horizon. The silence in the boat was broken only by the rhythmic dip of the oars and the gentle lapping of the waves against the hull. He tried to speak, to ask again why he was being arrested, but the words caught in his throat. He felt utterly alone, adrift in a nightmare.

After what seemed an eternity, a dark, imposing shape loomed out of the darkness ahead. As they drew closer, Dantès recognized it with a sickening certainty: the Château d'If. The island fortress, a grim sentinel guarding the entrance to the harbor, a place of legend and fear, where political prisoners and the most dangerous criminals were confined. He had sailed past it countless times, never imagining he would one day be taken inside its forbidding walls. The boat approached a small landing stage at the base of the rock. Soldiers were waiting there, their figures silhouetted against the faint light from the fortress windows high above.

He was helped out of the boat, his legs stiff and unsteady. He stumbled slightly, and a soldier's hand gripped his arm roughly, steadying him. He was led up a steep, narrow path carved into the rock. The air grew colder, heavier. The silence was absolute, broken only by the sound of their footsteps and the distant cry of a seabird. They passed through a heavy, iron-studded gate, which clanged shut behind them with a sound that echoed ominously in the stone passageway. He was inside the Château d'If. The reality of his situation crashed down upon him with crushing force. He was a prisoner, in the most infamous prison in France, with no idea why or for how long. Despair, cold and absolute, began to settle in his soul.

events.title: The Dreadful Revelation of Château d’If
detailed_summary: Overcoming his reluctance, Dantès appeals to the nearest gendarme, addressing him as a fellow Christian and soldier, and asks their destination, identifying himself as Captain Dantès, a loyal Frenchman accused of treason, promising to accept his fate if told.
The gendarme hesitates, exchanges a look with his companion who signals no harm in revealing the truth now.
The gendarme questions Dantès' professed ignorance of their destination, given he is a sailor from Marseilles.
Dantès swears he has no idea.
The gendarme insists it's impossible for him not to know, but Dantès pleads for an answer, appealing past the gendarme's orders by noting the information will soon be obvious anyway.
The gendarme tells him to look around if he isn't blind or new to the harbor.
Dantès stands and sees the imposing, dark rock of the Château d’If looming nearby, a fortress renowned for grim legends, which strikes him as a scaffold.
He cries out in disbelief, questioning why they are going to the Château d’If.
The gendarme smiles at his reaction.
Dantès asserts he cannot be imprisoned there, as it's for political prisoners and he has committed no crime, asking if there are magistrates or judges at the fortress.
The gendarme replies that it only houses a governor, garrison, turnkeys, and thick walls, advising Dantès not to look so surprised.
Dantès grips the gendarme's hand tightly, asking if he truly believes he's being taken to be imprisoned in the Château d’If.
The gendarme confirms it's probable and tells him not to squeeze so hard.
Dantès questions the lack of inquiry or formality.
The gendarme states all formalities are complete and the inquiry made.

Dantès then desperately mentions M. de Villefort's promises, to which the gendarme responds he doesn't know about any promises but confirms their destination is the Château d’If, immediately followed by an alarmed cry for help as he notices Dantès' sudden movement.

events.text_segment:
In spite of his repugnance to address the guards, Dantès turned to the nearest gendarme, and taking his hand,
“Comrade,” said he, “I adjure you, as a Christian and a soldier, to tell me where we are going. I am Captain Dantès, a loyal Frenchman, thought accused of treason; tell me where you are conducting me, and I promise you on my honor I will submit to my fate.”
The gendarme looked irresolutely at his companion, who returned for answer a sign that said, “I see no great harm in telling him now,” and the gendarme replied:
“You are a native of Marseilles, and a sailor, and yet you do not know where you are going?”
“On my honor, I have no idea.”
“Have you no idea whatever?”
“None at all.”
“That is impossible.”
“I swear to you it is true. Tell me, I entreat.”
“But my orders.”
“Your orders do not forbid your telling me what I must know in ten minutes, in half an hour, or an hour. You see I cannot escape, even if I intended.”
“Unless you are blind, or have never been outside the harbor, you must know.”
“I do not.”
“Look round you then.” Dantès rose and looked forward, when he saw rise within a hundred yards of him the black and frowning rock on which stands the Château d’If. This gloomy fortress, which has for more than three hundred years furnished food for so many wild legends, seemed to Dantès like a scaffold to a malefactor.
“The Château d’If?” cried he, “what are we going there for?”
The gendarme smiled.
“I am not going there to be imprisoned,” said Dantès; “it is only used for political prisoners. I have committed no crime. Are there any magistrates or judges at the Château d’If?”
“There are only,” said the gendarme, “a governor, a garrison, turnkeys, and good thick walls. Come, come, do not look so astonished, or you will make me think you are laughing at me in return for my good nature.”
Dantès pressed the gendarme’s hand as though he would crush it.
“You think, then,” said he, “that I am taken to the Château d’If to be imprisoned there?”
“It is probable; but there is no occasion to squeeze so hard.”
“Without any inquiry, without any formality?”
“All the formalities have been gone through; the inquiry is already made.”
“And so, in spite of M. de Villefort’s promises?”
“I do not know what M. de Villefort promised you,” said the gendarme, “but I know we are taking you to the Château d’If. But what are you doing? Help, comrades, help!”

events.title: Desperate Plunge and Violent Subjugation

He falls back, cursing in rage.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: By a rapid movement, which the gendarme’s practiced eye had perceived, Dantès sprang forward to precipitate himself into the sea; but four vigorous arms seized him as his feet quitted the bottom of the boat.

events.text_segment:
By a rapid movement, which the gendarme’s practiced eye had perceived, Dantès sprang forward to precipitate himself into the sea; but four vigorous arms seized him as his feet quitted the bottom of the boat. He fell back cursing with rage.
“Good!” said the gendarme, placing his knee on his chest; “this is the way you keep your word as a sailor! Believe soft-spoken gentlemen again! Hark ye, my friend, I have disobeyed my first order, but I will not disobey the second; and if you move, I will blow your brains out.” And he levelled his carbine at Dantès, who felt the muzzle against his temple.
For a moment the idea of struggling crossed his mind, and of so ending the unexpected evil that had overtaken him. But he bethought him of M. de Villefort’s promise; and, besides, death in a boat from the hand of a gendarme seemed too terrible. He remained motionless, but gnashing his teeth and wringing his hands with fury.

His face was livid, his eyes starting from their sockets, and he foamed at the mouth. He fought with the fury of despair, biting and kicking, but the gendarmes were experienced and strong. They bound his hands and feet with ropes, securing him tightly to the bench. The boat continued its silent journey towards the Château d'If, a dark silhouette against the horizon, a symbol of his shattered hopes. Dantès, exhausted and defeated, could only watch the receding shore, his heart filled with a terrible anguish. The sea, which he had hoped would be his grave, now mocked him with its indifferent waves. His dream of freedom was crushed, replaced by the grim reality of imprisonment.

events.title: Arrival at the Fortress and Disoriented Entry
detailed_summary: The boat abruptly lands with a significant jolt.
A sailor disembarks, and the sound of a rope running through a pulley indicates to Dantès that they are mooring, signifying the journey's end.
His guards seize him by the arms and collar, forcing him to stand and dragging him towards steps leading to the fortress gate, while the police officer follows with a bayonet-fixed musket.

Dantès offers no resistance, feeling as if in a dream. He vaguely perceives soldiers on the embankment, is aware of ascending steps, passing through a door that closes behind him, all as if through a fog.
He doesn't even register the sight of the ocean, the ultimate barrier to freedom for prisoners.
They pause for a moment, during which he attempts to gather his thoughts.
He surveys his surroundings: a courtyard enclosed by high walls. He hears the rhythmic footsteps of sentinels, their musket barrels glinting as they pass a light source.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At this moment the boat came to a landing with a violent shock.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He looked around; he was in a court surrounded by high walls; he heard the measured tread of sentinels, and as they passed before the light he saw the barrels of their muskets shine.

events.text_segment:
At this moment the boat came to a landing with a violent shock. One of the sailors leaped on shore, a cord creaked as it ran through a pulley, and Dantès guessed they were at the end of the voyage, and that they were mooring the boat.
His guards, taking him by the arms and coat-collar, forced him to rise, and dragged him towards the steps that lead to the gate of the fortress, while the police officer carrying a musket with fixed bayonet followed behind.
Dantès made no resistance; he was like a man in a dream; he saw soldiers drawn up on the embankment; he knew vaguely that he was ascending a flight of steps; he was conscious that he passed through a door, and that the door closed behind him; but all this indistinctly as through a mist. He did not even see the ocean, that terrible barrier against freedom, which the prisoners look upon with utter despair.
They halted for a minute, during which he strove to collect his thoughts. He looked around; he was in a court surrounded by high walls; he heard the measured tread of sentinels, and as they passed before the light he saw the barrels of their muskets shine.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: At this moment the boat came to a landing with a violent shock. Dantes, still encased in the sack intended for his watery grave, felt the jolt resonate through his bruised body. He knew this was his one chance. The men who had carried him would likely depart quickly, leaving the 'corpse' to the elements. With a surge of desperate strength, he began to writhe, pushing against the rough canvas, seeking any weakness, any tear. The weight of the cannonball tied to his feet dragged him down, but the sack, perhaps snagged on a rock or the seabed, offered a momentary resistance to the full descent. He clawed and tore, his fingers finding purchase on the coarse material. The salt water filled his mouth and nose, a bitter taste of near-death, but the urgency of survival fueled his efforts. Finally, with a supreme effort, he ripped a hole large enough to thrust his head through. He gasped for air, the cold night wind a shock against his face. Then, working frantically, he managed to free his arms, untying the ropes that bound him. The sack fell away, and he kicked violently, shedding the leaden weight of the cannonball. He rose to the surface, sputtering, alive. The stars, cold and distant, were the first sight of his new world. He was free, but adrift in the vast, dark sea.

events.title: Consignment to a Grim Cell and Abrupt Abandonment
detailed_summary: After a wait of over ten minutes, during which the gendarmes released Dantès, confident he couldn't escape, orders finally arrived.
A voice inquires about the prisoner's location, and the gendarmes respond.
The voice instructs for the prisoner to follow him to his cell.
The gendarmes push Dantès forward.
Dantès follows his guide, an ill-dressed and sullen-looking under-jailer, into a nearly subterranean room with bare, damp walls that seem saturated with sorrow.
A lamp on a stool faintly illuminates the cell, allowing Dantès to see his conductor.
The jailer announces this as Dantès's chamber for the night, explaining that the governor is asleep and might arrange a change the next day.
He mentions the provisions of bread, water, and fresh straw, stating it's all a prisoner could desire, and bids him goodnight.

Before Dantès can speak, or even notice where the bread and water are placed or where the straw is, the jailer departs, taking the lamp and closing the door, leaving Dantès with the haunting image of the dungeon's dripping walls imprinted on his mind.
Dantès finds himself alone, enveloped in darkness and silence, a chilling sensation accompanying his feverish state.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: They waited upwards of ten minutes.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Dantès was alone in darkness and in silence—cold as the shadows that he felt breathe on his burning forehead.

events.text_segment:
They waited upwards of ten minutes. Certain Dantès could not escape, the gendarmes released him. They seemed awaiting orders. The orders came.
“Where is the prisoner?” said a voice.
“Here,” replied the gendarmes.
“Let him follow me; I will take him to his cell.”
“Go!” said the gendarmes, thrusting Dantès forward.
The prisoner followed his guide, who led him into a room almost under ground, whose bare and reeking walls seemed as though impregnated with tears; a lamp placed on a stool illumined the apartment faintly, and showed Dantès the features of his conductor, an under-jailer, ill-clothed, and of sullen appearance.
“Here is your chamber for tonight,” said he. “It is late, and the governor is asleep. Tomorrow, perhaps, he may change you. In the meantime there is bread, water, and fresh straw; and that is all a prisoner can wish for. Goodnight.” And before Dantès could open his mouth—before he had noticed where the jailer placed his bread or the water—before he had glanced towards the corner where the straw was, the jailer disappeared, taking with him the lamp and closing the door, leaving stamped upon the prisoner’s mind the dim reflection of the dripping walls of his dungeon.
Dantès was alone in darkness and in silence—cold as the shadows that he felt breathe on his burning forehead.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: They waited upwards of ten minutes. During this time Dantès was left to himself. The gendarmes, having fulfilled their commission, and being now at ease about their prisoner, stood a little distance off, conversing together and laughing. Dantès saw that they were confident of his not attempting to escape. He was not at all surprised at this. How could he attempt it? He was in a dungeon, and was awaiting the arrival of a jailer, who would no doubt soon appear and conduct him to a cell. Orders arrived at the end of the ten minutes. "Where is the prisoner?" inquired a voice. "Here," replied the gendarmes. "Let him follow me," said the voice. "Go," said the gendarmes, pushing Dantès. Dantès followed his guide, who was an under-jailer, ill-dressed and of sullen appearance. He held in his hand a lamp, the light of which, as they passed through the corridors, scarcely pierced the gloom. They arrived at a nearly subterranean room, the bare, damp walls of which seemed saturated with the sorrow that had been there for ages. A lamp placed on a stool in a corner faintly illuminated the cell, and enabled Dantès to see his conductor, who was no other than the under-jailer. "Here is your chamber for to-night," said he. "It is late, and the governor is asleep. To-morrow, perhaps, he will sanction your removal. In the meantime, here are bread and water, and fresh straw; that is all a prisoner can desire. Good-night." And, before Dantès could open his mouth, before he could think of asking where the bread and water were, before he could see where the straw was, the under-jailer took up his lamp and departed, leaving the dungeon to darkness, and closing the door, which shut with a loud noise. For a moment Dantès remained motionless, and listening to the sound of the retiring footsteps; but when the sound died away, and he felt himself alone, the darkness and the silence were fearful. Then the chilling sensation of the damp struck to his heart, and with the damp the fever.

events.title: The First Agonizing Night and Morning of Despair
detailed_summary: At daybreak, the jailer returns with instructions that Dantès is to remain in his current cell.
He discovers Dantès in the exact same position as the night before, seemingly transfixed, his eyes swollen from crying.
Dantès had spent the entire night standing, without sleep.
The jailer approaches, but Dantès seems oblivious until the jailer touches his shoulder, startling him.
When asked if he slept, Dantès replies uncertainly.
The jailer, surprised by his state, then inquires if he is hungry, to which Dantès again responds with

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: With the first dawn of day the jailer returned, with orders to leave Dantès where he was.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: All his emotion then burst forth; he cast himself on the ground, weeping bitterly, and asking himself what crime he had committed that he was thus punished.

events.text_segment:
With the first dawn of day the jailer returned, with orders to leave Dantès where he was. He found the prisoner in the same position, as if fixed there, his eyes swollen with weeping. He had passed the night standing, and without sleep. The jailer advanced; Dantès appeared not to perceive him. He touched him on the shoulder. Edmond started.
“Have you not slept?” said the jailer.
“I do not know,” replied Dantès. The jailer stared.
“Are you hungry?” continued he.
“I do not know.”
“Do you wish for anything?”
“I wish to see the governor.”
The jailer shrugged his shoulders and left the chamber.
Dantès followed him with his eyes, and stretched forth his hands towards the open door; but the door closed. All his emotion then burst forth; he cast himself on the ground, weeping bitterly, and asking himself what crime he had committed that he was thus punished.

'He is gone,' he murmured, 'and I am alone again. Alone! alone!' And he threw himself on the ground, and burst into tears. 'Oh, my God!' he cried, 'I am abandoned by all the world! I am lost! I am lost!'

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: With the first dawn of day the jailer returned, with orders to leave Dantès where he was. This news, or rather lack of change, plunged Edmond into deeper despair. He had hoped for an interrogation, a trial, anything that might break the suffocating monotony and injustice of his confinement. But no, he was simply to remain, forgotten in the darkness. The hours crawled by, marked only by the faint sounds from outside and the gnawing emptiness in his stomach. He received no food, no water. His throat was parched, his body weak. He lay on the cold stone floor, his mind a whirl of confusion and anguish. Why was he here? Who had betrayed him? The questions echoed unanswered in the silent cell. It was not until late in the day that the heavy door creaked open again. This time, the jailer entered with two assistants. They roughly ordered him to stand, indicating he was to be moved. A flicker of hope, however faint, ignited within him. Perhaps this was the beginning of the end of his ordeal.

events.title: Torment of Regret and Futile Pleas to the Jailer
detailed_summary: Dantès spends the day in extreme distress, barely eating and pacing his cell incessantly, much like a caged animal.

A particular thought torments him: his passivity during the journey, where he believes he missed multiple opportunities to escape by jumping into the sea and swimming to safety, relying on his renowned swimming skills.
He imagines reaching Spain or Italy, where Mercédès and his father could have joined him, confident in his ability to find work as a skilled seaman, fluent in Italian and Spanish.
Instead, he is confined in the Château d’If, ignorant of his loved ones' fate, all because he trusted Villefort's deceptive promises.
The agonizing regret drives him to throw himself violently onto his straw bed.
The following morning, the jailer returns at the same hour and asks if Dantès is more reasonable, but Dantès remains silent.
The jailer offers his assistance, and Dantès reiterates his desire to see the governor.
The jailer repeats that it is impossible, as it's against prison regulations for prisoners even to ask.
When Dantès asks what is permitted, the jailer lists better food (at a cost), books, and permission to walk.
Dantès dismisses these, insisting only on seeing the governor.
The jailer warns that if Dantès persists with this demand, he will stop bringing him food.
Edmond defiantly states that he will then die of hunger.
Recognizing Dantès's willingness to die, and considering the financial loss (as each prisoner generated income for him), the jailer adopts a more conciliatory tone.
He explains that while Dantès's request is impossible, good behavior might eventually lead to an opportunity to walk about, where he might encounter the governor, whose choice it would be to respond.
Dantès asks how long he would have to wait, and the jailer suggests a timeframe of a month, six months, or even a year.
Dantès declares this too long and insists on seeing the governor immediately.
The jailer cautions him against fixating on the impossible, warning that such brooding could lead to madness within two weeks.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The day passed thus; he scarcely tasted food, but walked round and round the cell like a wild beast in its cage.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Ah,” said the jailer, “do not always brood over what is impossible, or you will be mad in a fortnight.”

events.text_segment:
The day passed thus; he scarcely tasted food, but walked round and round the cell like a wild beast in its cage. One thought in particular tormented him: namely, that during his journey hither he had sat so still, whereas he might, a dozen times, have plunged into the sea, and, thanks to his powers of swimming, for which he was famous, have gained the shore, concealed himself until the arrival of a Genoese or Spanish vessel, escaped to Spain or Italy, where Mercédès and his father could have joined him. He had no fears as to how he should live—good seamen are welcome everywhere. He spoke Italian like a Tuscan, and Spanish like a Castilian; he would have been free, and happy with Mercédès and his father, whereas he was now confined in the Château d’If, that impregnable fortress, ignorant of the future destiny of his father and Mercédès; and all this because he had trusted to Villefort’s promise. The thought was maddening, and Dantès threw himself furiously down on his straw. The next morning at the same hour, the jailer came again.
“Well,” said the jailer, “are you more reasonable today?” Dantès made no reply.
“Come, cheer up; is there anything that I can do for you?”
“I wish to see the governor.”
“I have already told you it was impossible.”
“Why so?”
“Because it is against prison rules, and prisoners must not even ask for it.”
“What is allowed, then?”
“Better fare, if you pay for it, books, and leave to walk about.”
“I do not want books, I am satisfied with my food, and do not care to walk about; but I wish to see the governor.”
“If you worry me by repeating the same thing, I will not bring you any more to eat.”
“Well, then,” said Edmond, “if you do not, I shall die of hunger—that is all.”
The jailer saw by his tone he would be happy to die; and as every prisoner is worth ten sous a day to his jailer, he replied in a more subdued tone.
“What you ask is impossible; but if you are very well behaved you will be allowed to walk about, and some day you will meet the governor, and if he chooses to reply, that is his affair.”
“But,” asked Dantès, “how long shall I have to wait?”
“Ah, a month—six months—a year.”
“It is too long a time. I wish to see him at once.”
“Ah,” said the jailer, “do not always brood over what is impossible, or you will be mad in a fortnight.”

events.title: The Abbé's Story, a Rejected Bribe, and a Desperate Threat
detailed_summary: Dantès questions the jailer's prediction of madness.
The jailer affirms it, citing the example of an abbé who previously occupied the same cell and went mad from persistently offering the governor a million francs for his freedom.
Dantès inquires how long ago the abbé left the cell, and the jailer replies it was two years.
When Dantès asks if the abbé was liberated, the jailer clarifies that he was moved to a dungeon.
Dantès declares that he is not an abbé nor is he mad, though he acknowledges he might become so, but asserts his current sanity.

He proposes a different offer to the jailer: not a million francs, which he doesn't possess, but one hundred crowns if the jailer, on his next trip to Marseilles, would find a young woman named Mercédès at the Catalans and deliver two lines from him.
The jailer refuses, explaining that if caught, he would lose his job, which pays two thousand francs a year, making the three hundred francs offered a foolish risk.
Dantès then issues a stark warning: if the jailer refuses to even inform Mercédès of his presence, he will ambush the jailer upon entry and kill him with the stool.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “You think so?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Well,” said Dantès, “mark this; if you refuse at least to tell Mercédès I am here, I will some day hide myself behind the door, and when you enter I will dash out your brains with this stool.”

events.text_segment:
“You think so?”
“Yes; we have an instance here; it was by always offering a million of francs to the governor for his liberty that an abbé became mad, who was in this chamber before you.”
“How long has he left it?”
“Two years.”
“Was he liberated, then?”
“No; he was put in a dungeon.”
“Listen!” said Dantès. “I am not an abbé, I am not mad; perhaps I shall be, but at present, unfortunately, I am not. I will make you another offer.”
“What is that?”
“I do not offer you a million, because I have it not; but I will give you a hundred crowns if, the first time you go to Marseilles, you will seek out a young girl named Mercédès, at the Catalans, and give her two lines from me.”
“If I took them, and were detected, I should lose my place, which is worth two thousand francs a year; so that I should be a great fool to run such a risk for three hundred.”
“Well,” said Dantès, “mark this; if you refuse at least to tell Mercédès I am here, I will some day hide myself behind the door, and when you enter I will dash out your brains with this stool.”

events.title: Accusation of Madness and Descent into the Dungeon
detailed_summary: The jailer exclaims at the threat, backing away defensively, and asserts that Dantès is definitely going mad, comparing his behavior to that of the previous abbé occupant and predicting a similar descent into madness requiring restraint.
He ominously adds that, fortunately, the prison has dungeons for such cases.
Dantès menacingly swings the stool around his head.
The jailer, feigning conciliation, agrees to Dantès's demand, stating he will send word to the governor.
Dantès, as if truly mad, drops the stool and sits on it. The jailer quickly exits.
The jailer returns almost immediately with a corporal and four soldiers.
He announces that by the governor's orders, the prisoner is to be conducted to the tier beneath.
The corporal confirms this means the dungeon, and the jailer affirms, stating they must place

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Threats!” cried the jailer, retreating and putting himself on the defensive; “you are certainly going mad. The abbé began like you, and in three days you will be like him, mad enough to tie up; but, fortunately, there are dungeons here.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The jailer was right; Dantès wanted but little of being utterly mad.

events.text_segment:
“Threats!” cried the jailer, retreating and putting himself on the defensive; “you are certainly going mad. The abbé began like you, and in three days you will be like him, mad enough to tie up; but, fortunately, there are dungeons here.”
Dantès whirled the stool round his head.
“All right, all right,” said the jailer; “all right, since you will have it so. I will send word to the governor.”
“Very well,” returned Dantès, dropping the stool and sitting on it as if he were in reality mad. The jailer went out, and returned in an instant with a corporal and four soldiers.
“By the governor’s orders,” said he, “conduct the prisoner to the tier beneath.”
“To the dungeon, then,” said the corporal.
“Yes; we must put the madman with the madmen.” The soldiers seized Dantès, who followed passively.
He descended fifteen steps, and the door of a dungeon was opened, and he was thrust in. The door closed, and Dantès advanced with outstretched hands until he touched the wall; he then sat down in the corner until his eyes became accustomed to the darkness. The jailer was right; Dantès wanted but little of being utterly mad.

I have heard of them, but I did not believe there were any real ones left; I did not think that the government ever put people in dungeons now. Ah, dungeons, it is well to know that!” And he swung the stool round his head. “Come, come,” said the jailer, “calm yourself, and I will send word to the governor.” “Good!” said Dantès, suddenly dropping the stool, and sitting on it; “do so.” The jailer went out, and returned in an instant with a corporal and four soldiers. “By the governor’s orders,” said he, “conduct the prisoner to the tier beneath.” “To the dungeon, then,” said the corporal. “Yes, to the dungeon,” said the jailer; “and put him in the one where the Abbé Faria was, and to which the governor referred.”

They left him in darkness and in silence. Dantès felt the wall, which was damp and rough, and sat down in the corner. The next day the jailer came with bread and water, and to examine the cell. Dantès was seated in the same place, with his head resting on his knees. He did not move at the sound of the door, nor even when the jailer spoke to him. He was not mad, but he was in despair.

chapters.chapter_title: VOLUME ONE. Chapter 9. The Evening of the Betrothal

events.title: Villefort's Urgent Warning and Ambitious Request
detailed_summary: Villefort returns to Madame de Saint-Méran's residence, where the guests he left at dinner are now having coffee in the salon.
His arrival prompts a flurry of questions from the guests, speculating about political crises or the return of Napoleon.
Villefort apologizes to his future mother-in-law, the Marquise, for his abrupt departure and requests a private conversation with the Marquis.
Noticing Villefort's grave demeanor, the Marquis senses the seriousness of the matter.
Villefort informs him that the issue is so critical he must leave for Paris for a few days, causing his fiancée, Renée, to cry out in distress.
He vaguely mentions that the destination is an official secret but offers to have a friend going to Paris undertake any commissions.
Alone with the Marquis in the library, Villefort emphasizes the extreme importance of his trip to Paris.
He inquires about the Marquis's financial holdings and strongly advises him to sell all his assets, which are in funds, to prevent losing everything.
The Marquis, alarmed, agrees and writes a letter to his broker, instructing him to sell immediately.
Villefort then requests a second letter, this one for the King, to gain direct access without the usual formalities that would cause delays.
He explains that reaching the King first with his news is crucial for his own advancement, as he wishes to claim full credit for the information, bypassing the Keeper of the Seals.
The Marquis agrees to have M. de Salvieux compose the letter of introduction for Villefort.
Villefort states he must depart within fifteen minutes and asks the Marquis to have his coachman ready and to convey his regrets to the Marquise and Renée.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Villefort had, as we have said, hastened back to Madame de Saint-Méran’s in the Place du Grand Cours, and on entering the house found that the guests whom he had left at table were taking coffee in the salon.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I shall be gone only a few moments.

events.text_segment:
Villefort had, as we have said, hastened back to Madame de Saint-Méran’s in the Place du Grand Cours, and on entering the house found that the guests whom he had left at table were taking coffee in the salon. Renée was, with all the rest of the company, anxiously awaiting him, and his entrance was followed by a general exclamation.
“Well, Decapitator, Guardian of the State, Royalist, Brutus, what is the matter?” said one. “Speak out.”
“Are we threatened with a fresh Reign of Terror?” asked another.
“Has the Corsican ogre broken loose?” cried a third.
“Marquise,” said Villefort, approaching his future mother-in-law, “I request your pardon for thus leaving you. Will the marquis honor me by a few moments’ private conversation?”
“Ah, it is really a serious matter, then?” asked the marquis, remarking the cloud on Villefort’s brow.
“So serious that I must take leave of you for a few days; so,” added he, turning to Renée, “judge for yourself if it be not important.”
“You are going to leave us?” cried Renée, unable to hide her emotion at this unexpected announcement.
“Alas,” returned Villefort, “I must!”
“Where, then, are you going?” asked the marquise.
“That, madame, is an official secret; but if you have any commissions for Paris, a friend of mine is going there tonight, and will with pleasure undertake them.” The guests looked at each other.
“You wish to speak to me alone?” said the marquis.
“Yes, let us go to the library, please.” The marquis took his arm, and they left the salon.
“Well,” asked he, as soon as they were by themselves, “tell me what it is?”
“An affair of the greatest importance, that demands my immediate presence in Paris. Now, excuse the indiscretion, marquis, but have you any landed property?”
“All my fortune is in the funds; seven or eight hundred thousand francs.”
“Then sell out—sell out, marquis, or you will lose it all.”
“But how can I sell out here?”
“You have a broker, have you not?”
“Yes.”
“Then give me a letter to him, and tell him to sell out without an instant’s delay, perhaps even now I shall arrive too late.”
“The deuce you say!” replied the marquis, “let us lose no time, then!”
And, sitting down, he wrote a letter to his broker, ordering him to sell out at the market price.
“Now, then,” said Villefort, placing the letter in his pocketbook, “I must have another!”
“To whom?”
“To the king.”
“To the king?”
“Yes.”
“I dare not write to his majesty.”
“I do not ask you to write to his majesty, but ask M. de Salvieux to do so. I want a letter that will enable me to reach the king’s presence without all the formalities of demanding an audience; that would occasion a loss of precious time.”
“But address yourself to the keeper of the seals; he has the right of entry at the Tuileries, and can procure you audience at any hour of the day or night.”
“Doubtless; but there is no occasion to divide the honors of my discovery with him. The keeper would leave me in the background, and take all the glory to himself. I tell you, marquis, my fortune is made if I only reach the Tuileries the first, for the king will not forget the service I do him.”
“In that case go and get ready. I will call Salvieux and make him write the letter.”
“Be as quick as possible, I must be on the road in a quarter of an hour.”
“Tell your coachman to stop at the door.”
“You will present my excuses to the marquise and Mademoiselle Renée, whom I leave on such a day with great regret.”
“You will find them both here, and can make your farewells in person.”
“A thousand thanks—and now for the letter.”
The marquis rang, a servant entered.
“Say to the Comte de Salvieux that I would like to see him.”
“Now, then, go,” said the marquis.
“I shall be gone only a few moments.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Villefort had, as we have said, hastened back to Madame de Saint-Méran’s in the Place du Grand Cours, and on entering the house found that the guests whom he had left at table were taking coffee in the salon. A murmur of surprise accompanied the entrance of the young man, who was thus returning to the house of his affianced wife at so unusual an hour. He was in deep mourning, and the paleness of his face and the contraction of his features showed that he had undergone some very serious event. The Marquise, who was at one end of the salon, perceived him as he entered, and seeing his disturbed look, cried out, “Good heavens, M. de Villefort, what is the matter? Is the king dead, or is there another revolution?” And all the guests arose and surrounded Villefort, inquiring with anxiety the cause of his sudden return. Renée, pale and motionless, was leaning on the arm of her mother; she questioned him with her eyes, but could not utter a word. Villefort’s look was fixed on her, and there was in it that dark expression which at times crossed his countenance and almost transformed him. “Pardon me, madame,” said he, addressing the Marquise, “for thus breaking in upon you; but I had a most important communication to make to M. le Marquis.” “Go, then, my dear Villefort,” said M. de Saint-Méran; “I am at your service.” And he took the arm of Villefort, and they passed into the library. As soon as they were alone, “Marquis,” said Villefort, “excuse my abruptness; but I must leave you in an hour.” “To leave us!” cried M. de Saint-Méran, “to leave us when we expected to keep you for a week at least? This is another proof of the instability of human affairs. Renée will not be pleased with you.” “Alas, my dear marquis,” said Villefort, “that is the least of my troubles. A great misfortune has happened, or rather, I should say, a great danger threatens us. I am obliged to go to Paris immediately.” “To Paris! Immediately!” said M. de Saint-Méran. “But the wedding, the contract?” “Do not let us think of that now, marquis,” said Villefort; “I tell you that a great danger threatens us. Perhaps it is already too late. What I have to tell you is a secret of state, a secret of the most vital importance. I cannot tell you more here. I must go to Paris, and that without losing a moment.
