LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Villefort had, as we have said, hastened back to Madame de Saint-Méran’s in the Place du Grand Cours, and on entering the house found that the guests whom he had left at table were taking coffee in the salon. His face was so pale, his eyes so wild, and his whole demeanor so agitated, that a general exclamation of surprise and alarm greeted him. Madame de Saint-Méran, seated on a sofa, rose with difficulty, her hand pressed to her side. The doctor, M. d’Avrigny, who was among the guests, immediately approached Villefort.

“Good heavens, M. de Villefort!” cried Madame de Saint-Méran. “What has happened? You look as though you have seen a ghost!”

Villefort could scarcely speak. He leaned against the doorframe, his breath coming in short, sharp gasps. “A misfortune, madame… a terrible misfortune…”

The guests gathered around him, their faces reflecting the general anxiety. M. d’Avrigny took his arm. “Compose yourself, M. de Villefort. Tell us what has occurred.”

“My father… M. Noirtier…” Villefort stammered, then stopped, unable to articulate the full horror of the scene he had just witnessed at the Rue du Faubourg Saint-Honoré.

Just as he was about to force the words out, a piercing shriek echoed from the floor above. It was followed by a commotion of hurried footsteps and frightened cries. Madame de Saint-Méran, already frail, swayed and would have fallen had not M. d’Avrigny caught her.

“What is that?” she gasped, her eyes wide with terror.

Before anyone could answer, a servant rushed into the salon, his face ashen. “Madame! Madame is taken ill! Quickly, M. le Docteur!”

M. d’Avrigny needed no second bidding. He released Madame de Saint-Méran into the care of her husband, the Marquis, and hurried towards the stairs, followed by Villefort and several others. They found Madame de Saint-Méran’s mother, the Marquise, lying on a couch, writhing in pain. Her face was contorted, her lips blue, and a cold sweat beaded on her forehead.

M. d’Avrigny immediately began his examination. He asked rapid questions of the servants and the Marquise’s lady’s maid, who stood by, weeping hysterically. The symptoms were alarming: sudden, violent spasms, intense pain in the stomach, difficulty breathing. It was clear this was no ordinary illness.

Villefort, forgetting his own distress for a moment, watched the doctor with a growing sense of dread. The Marquise, who had been in perfect health only moments before, was clearly dying.

M. d’Avrigny administered what remedies he could, but they seemed to have little effect. The Marquise’s condition worsened rapidly. She clutched at her throat, her eyes fixed and staring. In a final, desperate effort, she tried to speak, but only an inarticulate gurgle escaped her lips.

A few minutes later, with a final, convulsive shudder, the Marquise de Saint-Méran breathed her last. A profound silence fell over the room, broken only by the sobs of the servants and the low moan of the Marquis.

M. d’Avrigny stood up, his face grave. He looked from the deceased to the assembled family and guests. “This is most extraordinary,” he murmured, more to himself than to them. “The suddenness… the violence of the symptoms…”

Villefort, his mind reeling from the double shock of his father’s condition and now the death of his prospective mother-in-law, felt a cold hand grip his heart. Two deaths in such quick succession, both under strange circumstances. The Marquis de Saint-Méran, overcome with grief, knelt beside his wife’s body, burying his face in his hands.

M. d’Avrigny, ever the professional, began to give instructions for the necessary arrangements. But his eyes held a look of deep suspicion. He had seen such symptoms before, or read of them in medical texts. They pointed to one terrible conclusion,

events.title: Mercédès's Plea and Villefort's Torment of Conscience
detailed_summary: Villefort leaves the Marquis's rooms, initially rushing but then slowing his pace to avoid causing public alarm.
Near his own door, he encounters a figure in the shadows, Mercédès, who has come seeking information about Dantès.
Villefort recognizes Mercédès, noting her beauty and dignified bearing, and feels as though he is the one being judged as she inquires about her fiancé.
He harshly informs her that Dantès is a significant criminal and that he can offer no assistance.
Mercédès bursts into tears and implores Villefort to tell her Dantès's location, or at least if he is alive or dead.
Villefort claims ignorance, stating Dantès is no longer under his authority, pushes past her, and closes his door, attempting to shut out his guilt.
However, remorse deeply affects him; he enters his salon with a sigh resembling a sob and collapses into a chair.
He experiences the initial pangs of what he foresees as unending torture, haunted by the image of the innocent Dantès, whom he sacrificed for his ambition and his father's past.
This remorse is new to him; unlike previous cases where he condemned guilty men, he knows Dantès is innocent, making him an executioner, not a judge.
A profound sense of apprehension, previously unknown to him, arises within him.
He reflects that if Renée or Mercédès had interceded at that very moment, pleading for mercy, he might have ordered Dantès's release.
No such intervention occurs; instead, his valet enters to announce that his travelling carriage is prepared.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Villefort hastily quitted the apartment, but reflecting that the sight of the deputy procureur running through the streets would be enough to throw the whole city into confusion, he resumed his ordinary pace.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: If at this moment the sweet voice of Renée had sounded in his ears pleading for mercy, or the fair Mercédès had entered and said, “In the name of God, I conjure you to restore me my affianced husband,” his cold and trembling hands would have signed his release; but no voice broke the stillness of the chamber, and the door was opened only by Villefort’s valet, who came to tell him that the travelling carriage was in readiness.

events.text_segment:
Villefort hastily quitted the apartment, but reflecting that the sight of the deputy procureur running through the streets would be enough to throw the whole city into confusion, he resumed his ordinary pace. At his door he perceived a figure in the shadow that seemed to wait for him. It was Mercédès, who, hearing no news of her lover, had come unobserved to inquire after him.
As Villefort drew near, she advanced and stood before him. Dantès had spoken of Mercédès, and Villefort instantly recognized her. Her beauty and high bearing surprised him, and when she inquired what had become of her lover, it seemed to him that she was the judge, and he the accused.
“The young man you speak of,” said Villefort abruptly, “is a great criminal, and I can do nothing for him, mademoiselle.” Mercédès burst into tears, and, as Villefort strove to pass her, again addressed him.
“But, at least, tell me where he is, that I may know whether he is alive or dead,” said she.
“I do not know; he is no longer in my hands,” replied Villefort.
And desirous of putting an end to the interview, he pushed by her, and closed the door, as if to exclude the pain he felt. But remorse is not thus banished; like Virgil’s wounded hero, he carried the arrow in his wound, and, arrived at the salon, Villefort uttered a sigh that was almost a sob, and sank into a chair.
Then the first pangs of an unending torture seized upon his heart. The man he sacrificed to his ambition, that innocent victim immolated on the altar of his father’s faults, appeared to him pale and threatening, leading his affianced bride by the hand, and bringing with him remorse, not such as the ancients figured, furious and terrible, but that slow and consuming agony whose pangs are intensified from hour to hour up to the very moment of death. Then he had a moment’s hesitation. He had frequently called for capital punishment on criminals, and owing to his irresistible eloquence they had been condemned, and yet the slightest shadow of remorse had never clouded Villefort’s brow, because they were guilty; at least, he believed so; but here was an innocent man whose happiness he had destroyed. In this case he was not the judge, but the executioner.
As he thus reflected, he felt the sensation we have described, and which had hitherto been unknown to him, arise in his bosom, and fill him with vague apprehensions. It is thus that a wounded man trembles instinctively at the approach of the finger to his wound until it be healed, but Villefort’s was one of those that never close, or if they do, only close to reopen more agonizing than ever. If at this moment the sweet voice of Renée had sounded in his ears pleading for mercy, or the fair Mercédès had entered and said, “In the name of God, I conjure you to restore me my affianced husband,” his cold and trembling hands would have signed his release; but no voice broke the stillness of the chamber, and the door was opened only by Villefort’s valet, who came to tell him that the travelling carriage was in readiness.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Villefort hastily quitted the apartment, but reflecting that the sight of the deputy procureur running through the streets would be enough to throw the whole city into confusion, he resumed his ordinary pace. As he reached the corner of the Rue des Conseils, a woman, who seemed to have been waiting for him, advanced from the shadows of a doorway, and held out her arms to stop him. Villefort felt a chill run through him at this sudden apparition, and endeavoured to pass on, but the woman, whose face was covered with a veil, and whom he could not distinguish in the darkness, stepped in front of him. “Monsieur de Villefort,” said she, in a low voice. “You wish to speak to me?” said the young man. “Yes,” she replied; “but if it be a crime, it is you who have committed it—not I.” Villefort drew back, but the woman, who had followed him, and had again stopped him, said, “Monsieur de Villefort, you are the deputy procureur.” “You are mistaken, madame,” replied Villefort; “I am not the person you take me for.” “No,” said the woman, with a mournful smile, “I am not mistaken; you are Monsieur de Villefort, the deputy procureur, and you are going to marry Mademoiselle de Saint-Méran, and your father is the Count Noirtier.” “Silence, madame! silence!” cried Villefort; “do not utter that name.” “Why should I be silent?” said the woman; “why should I not speak of him? Is he not my betrothed?” “Your betrothed!” cried Villefort, starting back. “Yes,” said she; “and I ask you what you have done with him?” “With whom?” “With Edmond Dantès, who was to be my husband in a week, and who is now, perhaps, dead or a prisoner.” “Edmond Dantès,” repeated Villefort, almost mechanically; “he is a great criminal, and I can do nothing for him.” “A great criminal!” cried Mercédès; “Monsieur de Villefort, you know that he is innocent; you know that he is a good and noble young man.” “I know nothing about it, madame,” said Villefort; “I only know that he has been arrested, and that he is in prison.” “But where is he? where is he?” cried Mercédès; “tell me, I implore you, where he is, and I will bless you.” “I do not know,” said Villefort; “he is no longer under my authority.” “But he is alive? he is alive?” cried Mercédès. “I do not know,” said Villefort; “I have no information about him.” Mercédès uttered a cry, and fell on her knees. “Oh, Monsieur de Villefort,” said she, “have pity on me! tell me if he is alive.” “I can tell you nothing, madame,” said Villefort; “I must go; I am expected.” He made a movement to pass, but Mercédès, who had risen, held him back. “Monsieur de Villefort,” said she, “you are a man of honor, you are a Christian; tell me, on your soul, if Edmond Dantès is alive.” “I do not know,” said Villefort, in a voice that was almost inaudible; “I do not know.” He pushed her gently aside, and hurried on. Mercédès fell back on the pavement, and burst into tears. Villefort entered his house, and threw himself into a chair, overcome by emotion. He felt that he had committed a great crime, and that he was a miserable wretch. He thought of Mercédès, of her beauty, of her grief, and he felt a pang of remorse. He had sacrificed an innocent man to his ambition, to his father’s past, and he knew that he should never be happy again. He was no longer a judge, but an executioner. A cold sweat covered his brow, and he felt a profound sense of apprehension, a feeling he had never experienced before. He thought that if Renée or Mercédès had at that moment entered, and said, “Save him!” he would have ordered Dantès to be set at liberty. But no one came, and the valet entered to announce that the carriage was ready.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.refinement_prompt:
IMPROVEMENT GUIDANCE:
1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- The completion invents a significant portion of dialogue and interaction between Villefort and Mercédès that does not exist in the original, including a veiled identity, references to Villefort's family, and Mercédès falling to her knees. These invented scenes and exchanges alter the tone and structure of the encounter.
- The completion omits the original's introspective and metaphorical description of Villefort's remorse, particularly the extended comparison to a wounded hero and the nature of his internal suffering.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The completion lacks the original's detailed depiction of Villefort's internal emotional progression after the encounter, including the specific imagery and metaphors used to describe his remorse and psychological torment.
- The nuanced shift from Villefort's professional detachment to his personal anguish is not fully developed; the completion summarizes his feelings rather than following the original's gradual, layered introspection.
- The completion does not include the original's reflection on Villefort's past actions as a prosecutor and the contrast between his previous lack of remorse and his current suffering.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The sequence of events is altered: the completion introduces invented locations and actions (such as a specific street corner and Mercédès veiled in darkness) that are not present in the original.
- The dialogue is expanded and dramatized beyond what is in the source, including invented lines and emotional outbursts not found in the original passage.
- The completion attributes certain thoughts and feelings to Villefort in a more direct and explicit manner, rather than following the original's more subtle and metaphorical approach.
- The ending condenses and simplifies the transition to the valet's entrance, omitting the original's detailed lead-up and emotional context.

events.title: Villefort's Resolute Departure and Renée's Selfish Grief
detailed_summary: Reacting to his valet's news, Villefort jumps up from his chair.
He quickly gathers all the gold from his desk drawer and puts it in his pocket.
He stands still for a moment, pressing his hand to his head and muttering, before his servant places his cloak on him.
He then rushes into his carriage, instructing the driver to take him to M. de Saint-Méran's house.
The narrator comments that this action definitively sealed Dantès's unfortunate fate.
Upon arriving at the Saint-Méran residence, Villefort finds the Marquise and Renée awaiting him.
He is momentarily startled by Renée, half-expecting her to plead for Dantès again.
However, Renée's distress is revealed to be purely personal; she is upset about Villefort's departure just as they were about to be married.
Her love for Villefort is paramount, and far from sympathizing with Dantès, she resents him for being the cause of her separation from her fiancé.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Villefort rose, or rather sprang, from his chair, hastily opened one of the drawers of his desk, emptied all the gold it contained into his pocket, stood motionless an instant, his hand pressed to his head, muttered a few inarticulate sounds, and then, perceiving that his servant had placed his cloak on his shoulders, he sprang into the carriage, ordering the postilions to drive to M. de Saint-Méran’s.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She loved Villefort, and he left her at the moment he was about to become her husband. Villefort knew not when he should return, and Renée, far from pleading for Dantès, hated the man whose crime separated her from her lover.

events.text_segment:
Villefort rose, or rather sprang, from his chair, hastily opened one of the drawers of his desk, emptied all the gold it contained into his pocket, stood motionless an instant, his hand pressed to his head, muttered a few inarticulate sounds, and then, perceiving that his servant had placed his cloak on his shoulders, he sprang into the carriage, ordering the postilions to drive to M. de Saint-Méran’s. The hapless Dantès was doomed.
As the marquis had promised, Villefort found the marquise and Renée in waiting. He started when he saw Renée, for he fancied she was again about to plead for Dantès. Alas, her emotions were wholly personal: she was thinking only of Villefort’s departure.
She loved Villefort, and he left her at the moment he was about to become her husband. Villefort knew not when he should return, and Renée, far from pleading for Dantès, hated the man whose crime separated her from her lover.

events.title: The Aftermath for Dantès's Acquaintances
detailed_summary: The narrative shifts to Mercédès, who, after her encounter with Villefort, met Fernand.
She returned to her home in the Catalans district and collapsed onto her couch in despair.
Fernand remained by her side, kneeling and kissing her hand, though she was unresponsive to his presence or affection.
She spent the night in this state, oblivious to the lamp burning out or the arrival of dawn, her grief solely focused on Edmond.
She eventually acknowledges Fernand's presence, who confirms he has been with her since the previous day.
M. Morrel had made earnest efforts to assist Dantès after learning of his imprisonment.
He visited all his influential contacts in the city, but was consistently rebuffed as rumors circulated that Dantès was a Bonapartist agent.
Given the political climate where Napoleon's return was deemed impossible, Morrel's efforts were futile, and he returned home in despair, convinced the situation was grave and beyond help.
Caderousse was also agitated and uneasy but, unlike Morrel, did not try to help Dantès.
Instead, he attempted to drown his thoughts and anxieties with two bottles of black currant brandy.

However, he failed to achieve forgetfulness, becoming too intoxicated to get more alcohol but not enough to erase the troubling events from his mind, sitting amidst empty bottles and imagined apparitions.
Danglars, in stark contrast, was the only one who felt content and pleased.
He had successfully eliminated a rival and secured his own position on the ship Pharaon.
Described as a calculating individual who prioritized his own gains over human life, valuing figures and sums, Danglars went to bed at his usual time and slept soundly.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Meanwhile what of Mercédès?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He went to bed at his usual hour, and slept in peace.

events.text_segment:
Meanwhile what of Mercédès? She had met Fernand at the corner of the Rue de la Loge; she had returned to the Catalans, and had despairingly cast herself on her couch. Fernand, kneeling by her side, took her hand, and covered it with kisses that Mercédès did not even feel. She passed the night thus. The lamp went out for want of oil, but she paid no heed to the darkness, and dawn came, but she knew not that it was day. Grief had made her blind to all but one object—that was Edmond.
“Ah, you are there,” said she, at length, turning towards Fernand.
“I have not quitted you since yesterday,” returned Fernand sorrowfully.
M. Morrel had not readily given up the fight. He had learned that Dantès had been taken to prison, and he had gone to all his friends, and the influential persons of the city; but the report was already in circulation that Dantès was arrested as a Bonapartist agent; and as the most sanguine looked upon any attempt of Napoleon to remount the throne as impossible, he met with nothing but refusal, and had returned home in despair, declaring that the matter was serious and that nothing more could be done.
Caderousse was equally restless and uneasy, but instead of seeking, like M. Morrel, to aid Dantès, he had shut himself up with two bottles of black currant brandy, in the hope of drowning reflection. But he did not succeed, and became too intoxicated to fetch any more drink, and yet not so intoxicated as to forget what had happened. With his elbows on the table he sat between the two empty bottles, while spectres danced in the light of the unsnuffed candle—spectres such as Hoffmann strews over his punch-drenched pages, like black, fantastic dust.
Danglars alone was content and joyous—he had got rid of an enemy and made his own situation on the Pharaon secure. Danglars was one of those men born with a pen behind the ear, and an inkstand in place of a heart. Everything with him was multiplication or subtraction. The life of a man was to him of far less value than a numeral, especially when, by taking it away, he could increase the sum total of his own desires. He went to bed at his usual hour, and slept in peace.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Meanwhile what of Mercédès? She had returned with Fernand to the Catalans, and, overcome with grief, had thrown herself on her couch. Fernand, kneeling by her side, took her hand, and covered it with kisses; but she did not perceive him, or if she did, she gave no indication of his presence. She passed the night thus. The lamp was extinguished for want of oil, and she had not noticed it; the dawn came, and she had not seen it. Grief had blindfolded her. At length, about ten in the morning, she arose, her eyes red and swollen, and she saw Fernand, who was still kneeling where she had left him. "Rise, Fernand," she said, "and leave me." Fernand was crushed by this cold reception. "Oh, Mercédès," said he, "do not say to me, 'Leave me.' You know that I would willingly die for you." "You would die for me?" she asked. "Yes, and you know it. You know that from my infancy I have loved you." "You love me, do you say?" she said, with a strange smile. "But if you love me, why did you not help me?" "Help you? How? I would have defended you with my life." "You would have defended me with your life, and yet my Edmond is in prison, and you do nothing!" "But I have done all I could, Mercédès. I have been to Marseilles; I have seen M. Morrel; I have seen the mayor; I have been to the governor. I have done all that is possible, but the hand of God is there." "The hand of God is there!" said Mercédès, with a shudder. "Then it is indeed a misfortune!" "But you do not know what has happened," continued Fernand. "They say that Edmond is a Bonapartist agent, and that he has been arrested for treason." Mercédès uttered a cry, and fell back on the couch. Fernand, seeing her so pale and lifeless, thought she was going to die, and rushed out to call for help. But Mercédès recovered, and when Fernand returned, she was sitting up, her eyes fixed and staring. "Edmond a Bonapartist agent!" she repeated. "It is impossible! It is a calumny!" "I fear it is true, Mercédès," said Fernand. "M. Morrel himself told me that he had seen the papers, and that the proof was overwhelming." Mercédès clasped her hands, and raised her eyes to heaven. "Oh, God," she said, "have pity on me!" Meanwhile, M. Morrel, who had gone to the city as soon as he heard of Dantès' arrest, had used all his influence to obtain his release. He had seen the mayor, the procureur du roi, the governor of the prison, and all the officials who had any authority in such matters. But he had met with nothing but coldness and indifference. The rumor that Dantès was a Bonapartist agent had spread like wildfire, and in the political climate of the time, when the return of Napoleon was considered impossible, such an accusation was enough to ruin a man. M. Morrel returned home in despair. He was convinced that the situation was grave, and that there was nothing more to be done. Caderousse, too, was agitated and uneasy, but he did not try to help Dantès. Instead, he went to the inn and ordered two bottles of black currant brandy, with which he hoped to drown his thoughts and anxieties. But he failed to achieve forgetfulness. He became too intoxicated to get more alcohol, but not enough to erase the troubling events from his mind. He sat amidst the empty bottles, seeing imaginary apparitions and hearing phantom voices. Danglars, in stark contrast, was the only one who felt content and pleased. He had successfully eliminated a rival and secured his own position on the ship Pharaon. Described as a calculating individual who prioritized his own gains over human life, valuing figures and sums, Danglars went to bed at his usual time and slept soundly, dreaming of the future and the fortune that awaited him.

events.title: Final Farewells and Lingering Despair
detailed_summary: After receiving the letter from M. de Salvieux, Villefort takes his leave.
He embraces his fiancée Renée, kisses the hand of the Marquise de Saint-Méran, and shakes hands with the Marquis.
Following these farewells, he departs for Paris, taking the road through Aix.
The narrative then briefly focuses on Old Dantès, Edmond's father, who is depicted as being consumed by anxiety and on the verge of death due to uncertainty about his son's fate.
The chapter concludes with an ominous remark from the narrator, stating that the reader is well aware of what has befallen Edmond, implying his grim situation is established.

Villefort, after having received M. de Salvieux’s letter, embraced Renée, kissed the marquise’s hand, and shaken that of the marquis, started for Paris along the Aix road. He left them, and the narrative turns briefly to another, far less fortunate household. Old Dantès, Edmond's father, was consumed by a gnawing anxiety, his life ebbing away, brought to the very brink of death by the agonizing uncertainty surrounding his son's fate. But the reader, alas, is already well aware of what has befallen Edmond, and knows how grim his situation truly is.

chapters.chapter_title: VOLUME ONE. Chapter 10. The King’s Closet at the Tuileries

events.title: The King's Complacency Challenged by Blacas's Anxieties
detailed_summary: The narrative shifts to King Louis XVIII's private study in the Tuileries, a room historically favored by Napoleon and himself.
The King is depicted casually annotating a volume of Horace at his Hartwell desk, while listening to M. de Blacas, a man of aristocratic bearing, who appears exceedingly troubled.
The King responds to Blacas's unease with a jest about visions of kine, implying that scarcity is not a concern under his prudent reign.
Blacas clarifies that his fear pertains to a different kind of threat, specifically a 'storm brewing in the south,' suggesting political unrest.

Louis XVIII dismisses this concern light-heartedly, asserting that the weather (and by implication, the political climate) in the south is actually very fine, showcasing his penchant for witty remarks.

M. de Blacas earnestly requests the King to dispatch trusted individuals to Languedoc, Provence, and Dauphiné to gather reliable information about the sentiment in these provinces, if only to calm his loyal servant's fears.
The King responds with a Latin quotation ('Canimus surdis,' meaning 'we sing to the deaf'), continuing his annotations, signaling his current disinterest in Blacas's worries.

Blacas, attempting to navigate the King's mood, laughingly acknowledges the King's confidence in French loyalty but reiterates his own dread of a 'desperate attempt,' hinting at Bonaparte or his faction.
The King complains that Blacas's alarms are disrupting his scholarly work on Horace.
Blacas counters that the King's sense of security is, in turn, disrupting his sleep.

After asking Blacas to wait while he finishes a particularly delightful note on Horace, the King, with an air of having a new thought (though merely commenting on another's idea), finally agrees to hear Blacas out.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Go on, my dear duke, go on—I listen.”

events.text_segment:
We will leave Villefort on the road to Paris, travelling—thanks to trebled fees—with all speed, and passing through two or three apartments, enter at the Tuileries the little room with the arched window, so well known as having been the favorite closet of Napoleon and Louis XVIII., and now of Louis Philippe.
There, seated before a walnut table he had brought with him from Hartwell, and to which, from one of those fancies not uncommon to great people, he was particularly attached, the king, Louis XVIII., was carelessly listening to a man of fifty or fifty-two years of age, with gray hair, aristocratic bearing, and exceedingly gentlemanly attire, and meanwhile making a marginal note in a volume of Gryphius’s rather inaccurate, but much sought-after, edition of Horace—a work which was much indebted to the sagacious observations of the philosophical monarch.
“You say, sir——” said the king.
“That I am exceedingly disquieted, sire.”
“Really, have you had a vision of the seven fat kine and the seven lean kine?”
“No, sire, for that would only betoken for us seven years of plenty and seven years of scarcity; and with a king as full of foresight as your majesty, scarcity is not a thing to be feared.”
“Then of what other scourge are you afraid, my dear Blacas?”
“Sire, I have every reason to believe that a storm is brewing in the south.”
“Well, my dear duke,” replied Louis XVIII., “I think you are wrongly informed, and know positively that, on the contrary, it is very fine weather in that direction.” Man of ability as he was, Louis XVIII. liked a pleasant jest.
“Sire,” continued M. de Blacas, “if it only be to reassure a faithful servant, will your majesty send into Languedoc, Provence, and Dauphiné, trusty men, who will bring you back a faithful report as to the feeling in these three provinces?”
“Canimus surdis,” replied the king, continuing the annotations in his Horace.
“Sire,” replied the courtier, laughing, in order that he might seem to comprehend the quotation, “your majesty may be perfectly right in relying on the good feeling of France, but I fear I am not altogether wrong in dreading some desperate attempt.”
“By whom?”
“By Bonaparte, or, at least, by his adherents.”
“My dear Blacas,” said the king, “you with your alarms prevent me from working.”
“And you, sire, prevent me from sleeping with your security.”
“Wait, my dear sir, wait a moment; for I have such a delightful note on the Pastor quum traheret—wait, and I will listen to you afterwards.”
There was a brief pause, during which Louis XVIII. wrote, in a hand as small as possible, another note on the margin of his Horace, and then looking at the duke with the air of a man who thinks he has an idea of his own, while he is only commenting upon the idea of another, said:
“Go on, my dear duke, go on—I listen.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: We will leave Villefort on the road to Paris, travelling—thanks to trebled fees—with all speed, and passing through two or three apartments, enter at the Tuileries the little room with the arched window, so well known as having been the favorite closet of Napoleon and Louis XVIII., and now of Louis Philippe. There, seated in an armchair, with his feet on the fender, was Louis XVIII., who had just finished reading a report of the minister of police, and was writing, or rather making a note, on the margin of a volume of Horace, with a gold pen. Close to him stood M. de Blacas, who was listening with an air of profound uneasiness to the King’s observations. M. de Blacas was a man of high birth, and of remarkably stiff and formal manners, which were supposed to be indicative of great aristocracy, and was in reality nothing more than the politeness of the courtier. Louis XVIII. was a king of learning and taste, and maintained a correspondence with the celebrated M. Robert de Lamennais, who was then neither an abbé nor an apostate. He was an elegant Latin scholar, and composed Greek verses, which he would occasionally quote with great aplomb in his conversation. He had been compelled to abandon the throne of his ancestors, and to fly from France; and during his exile he had cultivated literature and the arts, and had acquired a taste for them which he retained even after his restoration to power. He was a man of considerable ability, but he was indolent and fond of ease, and was more inclined to trust to the wisdom of his ministers than to his own judgment. He was a great admirer of Horace, and was fond of quoting him. At the moment we are describing, he was engaged in writing a note on the margin of a volume of Horace, and was listening to M. de Blacas with an air of profound uneasiness. “What is the matter, my dear duke?” he inquired, looking up from his book. “You look as if you had seen a vision of kine, and that the seven lean kine had devoured the seven fat kine. Is that what is troubling you?” “Sire,” replied M. de Blacas, “I am not troubled by any such vision. I am troubled by a very different kind of vision, and one which is much more likely to be realized.” “Indeed,” said the King, “and what may that be?” “Sire,” replied M. de Blacas, “I fear that a storm is brewing in the south.” “A storm in the south?” repeated the King, with a smile. “Why, my dear duke, the weather in the south is remarkably fine at this time of the year. I have just received a report from the minister of police, and he assures me that everything is perfectly quiet in that quarter.” “Sire,” said M. de Blacas, “the minister of police may be mistaken. I have received information from other sources, and I am convinced that there is a storm brewing in the south.” “Indeed,” said the King, “and what is the nature of this storm?” “Sire,” replied M. de Blacas, “I fear that it is a political storm.” “A political storm?” repeated the King, with a laugh. “Why, my dear duke, there is no such thing as a political storm in France. We have a charter, and we have a constitution, and we have a representative government. We are a free people, and we are a happy people. There is no room for a political storm in France.” “Sire,” said M. de Blacas, “I hope that you are right, but I fear that you are mistaken. I have received information from other sources, and I am convinced that there is a political storm brewing in the south.” “Indeed,” said the King, “and what is the nature of this political storm?” “Sire,” replied M. de Blacas, “I fear that it is a storm which will sweep away the throne of your ancestors.” “Indeed,” said the King, with a smile. “And who is to raise this storm?” “Sire,” replied M. de Blacas, “I fear that it is the man who has already once swept away the throne of your ancestors.” “Indeed,” said the King, “and who may that be?” “Sire,” replied M. de Blacas, “it is the man who is now an exile in the island of Elba.” “Indeed,” said the King, “and what is he doing there?” “Sire,” replied M. de Blacas, “he is watching his opportunity.” “Indeed,” said the King, “and what is he waiting for?” “Sire,” replied M. de Blacas, “he is waiting for the moment when he can return to France.” “Indeed,” said the King, “and what will he do when he returns to France?” “Sire,” replied M. de Blacas, “he will sweep away the throne of your ancestors.” “Indeed,” said the King, with a smile. “And how will he do that?” “Sire,” replied M. de Blacas, “he will do it by raising a storm in the south.” “Indeed,” said the King, “and how will he raise this storm?” “Sire,” replied M. de Blacas, “he will do it by means of his adherents, who are very numerous in the south.” “Indeed,” said the simple_agent_extraction_refined_0.text: We will leave Villefort on the road to Paris, travelling—thanks to trebled fees—with all speed, and passing through two or three apartments, enter at the Tuileries the little room with the arched window, so well known as having been the favorite closet of Napoleon and Louis XVIII., and now of Louis Philippe. There, seated in an armchair, with his feet on the fender, was Louis XVIII., who had just finished reading a report of the minister of police, and was writing, or rather making a note, on the margin of a volume of Horace, with a gold pen. Close to him stood M. de Blacas, who was listening with an air of profound uneasiness to the King’s observations. M. de Blacas was a man of high birth, and of remarkably stiff and formal manners, which were supposed to be indicative of great aristocracy, and was in reality nothing more than the politeness of the courtier. Louis XVIII. was a king of learning and taste, and maintained a correspondence with the celebrated M. Robert de Lamennais, who was then neither an abbé nor an apostate. He was an elegant Latin scholar, and composed Greek verses, which he would occasionally quote with great aplomb in his conversation. He had been compelled to abandon the throne of his ancestors, and to fly from France; and during his exile he had cultivated literature and the arts, and had acquired a taste for them which he retained even after his restoration to power. He was a man of considerable ability, but he was indolent and fond of ease, and was more inclined to trust to the wisdom of his ministers than to his own judgment. He was a great admirer of Horace, and was fond of quoting him. At the moment we are describing, he was engaged in writing a note on the margin of a volume of Horace, and was listening to M. de Blacas with an air of profound uneasiness. “What is the matter, my dear duke?” he inquired, looking up from his book. “You look as if you had seen a vision of kine, and that the seven lean kine had devoured the seven fat kine. Is that what is troubling you?” “Sire,” replied M. de Blacas, “I am not troubled by any such vision. I am troubled by a very different kind of vision, and one which is much more likely to be realized.” “Indeed,” said the King, “and what may that be?” “Sire,” replied M. de Blacas, “I fear that a storm is brewing in the south.” “A storm in the south?” repeated the King, with a smile. “Why, my dear duke, the weather in the south is remarkably fine at this time of the year. I have just received a report from the minister of police, and he assures me that everything is perfectly quiet in that quarter.” “Sire,” said M. de Blacas, “the minister of police may be mistaken. I have received information from other sources, and I am convinced that there is a storm brewing in the south.” “Indeed,” said the King, “and what is the nature of this storm?” “Sire,” replied M. de Blacas, “I fear that it is a political storm.” “A political storm?” repeated the King, with a laugh. “Why, my dear duke, there is no such thing as a political storm in France. We have a charter, and we have a constitution, and we have a representative government. We are a free people, and we are a happy people. There is no room for a political storm in France.” “Sire,” said M. de Blacas, “I hope that you are right, but I fear that you are mistaken. I have received information from other sources, and I am convinced that there is a political storm brewing in the south.” “Indeed,” said the King, “and what is the nature of this political storm?” “Sire,” replied M. de Blacas, “I fear that it is a storm which will sweep away the throne of your ancestors.” “Indeed,” said the King, with a smile. “And who is to raise this storm?” “Sire,” replied M. de Blacas, “I fear that it is the man who has already once swept away the throne of your ancestors.” “Indeed,” said the King, “and who may that be?” “Sire,” replied M. de Blacas, “it is the man who events.title: Minister Dandré's Reassuring but Misleading Intelligence on Napoleon
detailed_summary: Blacas reveals that his concerns are not based on unfounded rumors but on information from a trustworthy individual tasked with monitoring the south, who has urgently traveled to warn of a significant threat to the King.
The King, still absorbed in his Horace, quotes another Latin phrase ('Mala ducis avi domum') and, after asking Blacas if he wants to drop the subject, directs him towards yesterday's police report.
Just then, M. Dandré, the Minister of Police, is announced and enters the room.

Louis XVIII, with a barely concealed smile, instructs Baron Dandré to share the latest news about Bonaparte with the Duke de Blacas, encouraging full disclosure of any serious developments and mockingly refers to Elba as a volcano poised for war.
M. Dandré, leaning respectfully on a chair, begins by asking if the King has read yesterday's report.
The King confirms he has but instructs Dandré to relay its contents to Blacas, specifically regarding the 'usurper's' activities on Elba.
Dandré informs the Duke that recent intelligence from Elba should be satisfactory to all loyal servants: Bonaparte is reportedly 'mortally wearied' and spends his days observing his miners.
The King interjects that Bonaparte also 'scratches himself for amusement,' alluding to a skin condition, prurigo, that afflicts him.

The Minister of Police further adds that they are almost certain Napoleon will soon descend into insanity, citing behaviors like frequent weeping, boisterous laughter, and spending hours flinging stones into the sea, appearing overjoyed when they skip multiple times.
Louis XVIII jests that such actions might be signs of wisdom rather than madness, referencing Plutarch's account of Scipio Africanus.

M. de Blacas remains visibly troubled, caught between the King's confident demeanor and the Minister's seemingly factual, yet to him insufficient, report, especially given the partial information he possessed from Villefort.
The King then prompts Dandré to elaborate on the 'usurper's conversion,' a notion that puzzles Blacas.

Dandré, with utmost gravity, explains that Napoleon recently held a military review, dismissed some old veterans who wished to return to France, and personally exhorted them to 'serve the good king,' assuring these were Napoleon's precise words.
Triumphantly, the King pauses his work on Horace to ask Blacas for his reaction to this seemingly definitive piece of news.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Well, Blacas, what think you of this?” inquired the king triumphantly, and pausing for a moment from the voluminous scholiast before him.

events.text_segment:
“Sire,” said Blacas, who had for a moment the hope of sacrificing Villefort to his own profit, “I am compelled to tell you that these are not mere rumors destitute of foundation which thus disquiet me; but a serious-minded man, deserving all my confidence, and charged by me to watch over the south” (the duke hesitated as he pronounced these words), “has arrived by post to tell me that a great peril threatens the king, and so I hastened to you, sire.”
“Mala ducis avi domum,” continued Louis XVIII., still annotating.
“Does your majesty wish me to drop the subject?”
“By no means, my dear duke; but just stretch out your hand.”
“Which?”
“Whichever you please—there to the left.”
“Here, sire?”
“I tell you to the left, and you are looking to the right; I mean on my left—yes, there. You will find yesterday’s report of the minister of police. But here is M. Dandré himself;” and M. Dandré, announced by the chamberlain-in-waiting, entered.
“Come in,” said Louis XVIII., with repressed smile, “come in, Baron, and tell the duke all you know—the latest news of M. de Bonaparte; do not conceal anything, however serious,—let us see, the Island of Elba is a volcano, and we may expect to have issuing thence flaming and bristling war—bella, horrida bella.”
M. Dandré leaned very respectfully on the back of a chair with his two hands, and said:
“Has your majesty perused yesterday’s report?”
“Yes, yes; but tell the duke himself, who cannot find anything, what the report contains—give him the particulars of what the usurper is doing in his islet.”
“Monsieur,” said the baron to the duke, “all the servants of his majesty must approve of the latest intelligence which we have from the Island of Elba. Bonaparte——”
M. Dandré looked at Louis XVIII., who, employed in writing a note, did not even raise his head. “Bonaparte,” continued the baron, “is mortally wearied, and passes whole days in watching his miners at work at Porto-Longone.”
“And scratches himself for amusement,” added the king.
“Scratches himself?” inquired the duke, “what does your majesty mean?”
“Yes, indeed, my dear duke. Did you forget that this great man, this hero, this demigod, is attacked with a malady of the skin which worries him to death, prurigo?”
“And, moreover, my dear duke,” continued the minister of police, “we are almost assured that, in a very short time, the usurper will be insane.”
“Insane?”
“Raving mad; his head becomes weaker. Sometimes he weeps bitterly, sometimes laughs boisterously, at other time he passes hours on the seashore, flinging stones in the water and when the flint makes ‘duck-and-drake’ five or six times, he appears as delighted as if he had gained another Marengo or Austerlitz. Now, you must agree that these are indubitable symptoms of insanity.”
“Or of wisdom, my dear baron—or of wisdom,” said Louis XVIII., laughing; “the greatest captains of antiquity amused themselves by casting pebbles into the ocean—see Plutarch’s life of Scipio Africanus.”
M. de Blacas pondered deeply between the confident monarch and the truthful minister. Villefort, who did not choose to reveal the whole secret, lest another should reap all the benefit of the disclosure, had yet communicated enough to cause him the greatest uneasiness.
“Well, well, Dandré,” said Louis XVIII., “Blacas is not yet convinced; let us proceed, therefore, to the usurper’s conversion.” The minister of police bowed.
“The usurper’s conversion!” murmured the duke, looking at the king and Dandré, who spoke alternately, like Virgil’s shepherds. “The usurper converted!”
“Decidedly, my dear duke.”
“In what way converted?”
“To good principles. Tell him all about it, baron.”
“Why, this is the way of it,” said the minister, with the gravest air in the world: “Napoleon lately had a review, and as two or three of his old veterans expressed a desire to return to France, he gave them their dismissal, and exhorted them to ‘serve the good king.’ These were his own words, of that I am certain.”
“Well, Blacas, what think you of this?” inquired the king triumphantly, and pausing for a moment from the voluminous scholiast before him.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: “Sire,” said Blacas, who had for a moment the hope of sacrificing Villefort to his own profit, “I am compelled to tell you that these are not mere rumors destitute of foundation which thus disquiet me; but a serious-minded man, deserving all my confidence, and charged by me to watch over the south” (the duke hesitated as he pronounced these words), “has arrived by post to tell me that a great peril threatens the king, and so I hastened to you, sire.”“Mala ducis avi domum,” murmured Louis XVIII., without raising his eyes. “Does your fear relate to the interior or exterior?”“To the interior, sire; and concerns the island of Elba.”“I told you, duke, that you were unnecessarily alarmed. Bonaparte, while at Porto-Ferrajo, is more really a prisoner than if he were in the dungeons of Vincennes. The island of Elba is surrounded by cruisers, some French, and others English; besides,” added the king, laughing, “I am informed that the usurper is mortally weary, and passes his time in drilling his grenadiers, and cultivating his potatoes.”“So much the better, sire,” said the minister; “but I must own that I have no great faith in this pretended weariness and this agricultural employment.”“To the point, duke; what is it that alarms you? I like to look my dangers in the face, not from bravado, but from prudence. Let us see, what is the matter?”“An agent whom I had at Naples, and who has followed Bonaparte to the island of Elba, has just arrived to inform me that the usurper has left Porto-Ferrajo on board a brig named the *Inconstant*, with four hundred men of the Old Guard, two thousand muskets, and a park of artillery.”“Well, well,” said Louis XVIII., “continue.”“The brig was accompanied by two war-brigs, the *Zéphyr* and the *Melpomène*, and a schooner, the *Epervier*.”“Oh, yes, I know all that,” said the king; “and the report states that the vessels were seen on the 28th of February off Cape San-Martin, which is in the Mediterranean.”“Yes, sire, and the report adds that the brig *Inconstant* steered for the Gulf of Juan, and that the schooner *Epervier* and the two war-brigs accompanied her.”“Well, duke,” said the king, smiling, “is that all? You see, I am as well informed as you are.”“No, sire, that is not all,” replied Blacas, with a faltering voice; “the report adds that the brig *Inconstant* anchored in the Gulf of Juan on the 1st of March, and that the men of the Old Guard landed with the usurper.”“Ah, indeed!” said the king, this time with a visible emotion; “where is that report?”“Here it is, sire,” said Blacas, presenting a paper to Louis XVIII.The king took the paper, and read it with attention. When he had finished, he returned it to Blacas. “That is very serious,” said he. “But what do you think of it?”“I think, sire, that the usurper is mad, and that he will be taken before he has gone ten leagues.”“That is also my opinion,” said the king. “He has neither money, nor troops, nor partisans. He is a madman who is going to his ruin.”“So much the better, sire,” said Blacas; “but we must take precautions.”“Of course,” said the king. “Give orders to the minister of war to send troops to the south. Let the garrisons be reinforced. Let the gendarmerie be on the alert. Let the prefects watch over the public mind. Let the police redouble their activity.”“All that has been done, sire,” said Blacas. “But I think we should also send a special commissioner to the south, a man of energy, who can take prompt and decisive measures.”“That is a good idea,” said the king. “Whom do you propose?”“M. de Villefort, sire. He is a young man of great merit, who has already rendered important services to the government.”“M. de Villefort,” said the king. “Yes, I know him. He is the son of the Girondin Noirtier, is he not?”“Yes, sire; but he has entirely renounced the errors of his father. He is a royalist, and a fervent one.”“Very well,” said the king. “Send for M. de Villefort. I will speak to him myself.”Just then, M. Dandré, the minister of police, was announced. “Come in, Dandré,” said the king. “Come and tell the duke the news from the island of Elba. The usurper has left Porto-Ferrajo.”M. Dandré entered, and bowed to the king and the duke. “Has your majesty read the report?” said he.“Yes, yes, Dandré,” said the king; “but tell the duke what you think of it.”“I think, sire,” said Dandré, leaning respectfully on the back of a chair, “that the usurper is lost. events.title: Blacas Persists for His Messenger, Revealed as Villefort, Piquing Royal Interest
detailed_summary: Blacas expresses his profound doubt, stating that either the Minister of Police is mistaken or he himself is, diplomatically suggesting the error is likely his own given the Minister's responsibilities. He strongly advises the King to personally question his informant.

The King consents to receive Blacas's messenger but cautions against expecting him to be too easily convinced. He asks Dandré about any reports more recent than February 20th, as it is currently March 3rd.
Dandré replies he is expecting an update hourly, which might have arrived since he left his office.
Louis XVIII facetiously tells Dandré to go check, and if no new report exists, to fabricate one, laughing at this common practice.

Dandré clarifies that invention is unnecessary due to the daily influx of detailed, albeit often opportunistic, denunciations from individuals hoping for rewards. He then departs to seek new information.
Blacas announces his intention to retrieve his messenger.

The King detains Blacas, humorously suggesting a new coat of arms for him an eagle with prey, bearing the motto 'Tenax' (Tenacious) due to his persistence. He then tries to engage Blacas in a discussion about a passage in Horace concerning a stag fleeing a wolf.
Impatiently, Blacas compares his messenger, who traveled 220 leagues in under three days, to the swiftly fleeing stag.
The King remarks on the arduousness of such a journey when the telegraph could transmit messages much faster and effortlessly.

Blacas passionately advocates for his messenger, emphasizing the ardor and distance traveled to deliver vital information, and beseeches the King to receive him graciously, mentioning M. de Salvieux's recommendation.
The mention of M. de Salvieux, the King's brother's chamberlain, captures the King's attention. He asks if Salvieux spoke of the conspiracy.
Blacas clarifies that Salvieux did not mention a conspiracy but strongly recommended a M. de Villefort and requested he be presented to the King.
Upon hearing the name 'M. de Villefort' and that he comes from Marseilles, the King's demeanor changes, showing signs of uneasiness.
The King reveals he knows Villefort as an intelligent and ambitious man, and crucially, as the son of Noirtier, a known Girondin and senator.

When Blacas expresses surprise at the King employing the son of such a figure, Louis XVIII explains that Villefort's ambition is so potent he would sacrifice anyone, even his father, to achieve his goals.
Convinced, the King decisively orders Blacas to bring Villefort in without delay.

The Duke, his royalist zeal reinvigorated, hurries away. Left alone, Louis XVIII mutters a Latin phrase from Horace: 'Justum et tenacem propositi virum' ('The man who is just and resolute in his purpose').

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I say, sire, that the minister of police is greatly deceived or I am; and as it is impossible it can be the minister of police as he has the guardianship of the safety and honor of your majesty, it is probable that I am in error. However, sire, if I might advise, your majesty will interrogate the person of whom I spoke to you, and I will urge your majesty to do him this honor.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Justum et tenacem propositi virum.”

events.text_segment:
“I say, sire, that the minister of police is greatly deceived or I am; and as it is impossible it can be the minister of police as he has the guardianship of the safety and honor of your majesty, it is probable that I am in error. However, sire, if I might advise, your majesty will interrogate the person of whom I spoke to you, and I will urge your majesty to do him this honor.”
“Most willingly, duke; under your auspices I will receive any person you please, but you must not expect me to be too confiding. Baron, have you any report more recent than this, dated the 20th February, and this is the 3rd of March?”
“No, sire, but I am hourly expecting one; it may have arrived since I left my office.”
“Go thither, and if there be none—well, well,” continued Louis XVIII., “make one; that is the usual way, is it not?” and the king laughed facetiously.
“Oh, sire,” replied the minister, “we have no occasion to invent any; every day our desks are loaded with most circumstantial denunciations, coming from hosts of people who hope for some return for services which they seek to render, but cannot; they trust to fortune, and rely upon some unexpected event in some way to justify their predictions.”
“Well, sir, go,” said Louis XVIII., “and remember that I am waiting for you.”
“I will but go and return, sire; I shall be back in ten minutes.”
“And I, sire,” said M. de Blacas, “will go and find my messenger.”
“Wait, sir, wait,” said Louis XVIII. “Really, M. de Blacas, I must change your armorial bearings; I will give you an eagle with outstretched wings, holding in its claws a prey which tries in vain to escape, and bearing this device—Tenax.”
“Sire, I listen,” said De Blacas, biting his nails with impatience.
“I wish to consult you on this passage, ‘Molli fugiens anhelitu,’ you know it refers to a stag flying from a wolf. Are you not a sportsman and a great wolf-hunter? Well, then, what do you think of the molli anhelitu?”
“Admirable, sire; but my messenger is like the stag you refer to, for he has posted two hundred and twenty leagues in scarcely three days.”
“Which is undergoing great fatigue and anxiety, my dear duke, when we have a telegraph which transmits messages in three or four hours, and that without getting in the least out of breath.”
“Ah, sire, you recompense but badly this poor young man, who has come so far, and with so much ardor, to give your majesty useful information. If only for the sake of M. de Salvieux, who recommends him to me, I entreat your majesty to receive him graciously.”
“M. de Salvieux, my brother’s chamberlain?”
“Yes, sire.”
“He is at Marseilles.”
“And writes me thence.”
“Does he speak to you of this conspiracy?”
“No; but strongly recommends M. de Villefort, and begs me to present him to your majesty.”
“M. de Villefort!” cried the king, “is the messenger’s name M. de Villefort?”
“Yes, sire.”
“And he comes from Marseilles?”
“In person.”
“Why did you not mention his name at once?” replied the king, betraying some uneasiness.
“Sire, I thought his name was unknown to your majesty.”
“No, no, Blacas; he is a man of strong and elevated understanding, ambitious, too, and, pardieu! you know his father’s name!”
“His father?”
“Yes, Noirtier.”
“Noirtier the Girondin?—Noirtier the senator?”
“He himself.”
“And your majesty has employed the son of such a man?”
“Blacas, my friend, you have but limited comprehension. I told you Villefort was ambitious, and to attain this ambition Villefort would sacrifice everything, even his father.”
“Then, sire, may I present him?”
“This instant, duke! Where is he?”
“Waiting below, in my carriage.”
“Seek him at once.”
“I hasten to do so.”
The duke left the royal presence with the speed of a young man; his really sincere royalism made him youthful again. Louis XVIII. remained alone, and turning his eyes on his half-opened Horace, muttered:
“Justum et tenacem propositi virum.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
I say, sire, that the minister of police is greatly deceived or I am; and as it is impossible it can be the minister of police as he has the guardianship of the safety and honor of your majesty, it is probable that I am in error. However, sire, if I might advise, your majesty will interrogate the person of whom I spoke to you, and I will urge your majesty to do him this honor.”
“Blacas,” said the king, “you are falling into the error of all who are too ardent in the serving of their master: you are compromising me with the minister of police, who does not, perhaps, deserve to be compromised. Dandré is a clever man who holds his appointment from M. de Talleyrand, and that, you know, is of itself a recommendation. He is now at the end of the telegraph wire, and receives news of every event as soon as it occurs. How could he have no information of what you communicate to me, unless his agents are traitors or he is an imbecile? In the one case he should be dismissed, in the other he should resign. But, Blacas, you know Dandré is neither a traitor nor an imbecile; I ask you, then, how it is that he has not been apprised of this conspiracy?”
“Sire,” returned the duke respectfully, “M. Dandré is not to blame; he receives information of what is passing, but he does not, perhaps, attach the same importance as your majesty does to the information he receives.”
“Indeed,” said Louis XVIII., with a sarcastic smile, “and what is your information, duke? Let us see, do you know anything of the Island of Elba, of a certain Bonaparte, of a certain landing on the coast of Italy?”
“Sire, be patient, and you shall hear,” replied M. de Blacas, and he related to the king the conversation he had overheard between the two members of the committee, and the details furnished by the agent, whom M. de Salvieux recommended to his notice.
“‘_Hum_,’ said the king, ‘_hum_.’ ”
“The thing appears serious to me,” said the duke.
“Serious, Blacas? I should think not,” replied Louis XVIII., still smiling. “The minister of police is a Argus; besides, are there not gendarmes, watchmen, and custom-house officers, who surround the whole coast from Antibes to La Vendée? If Bonaparte landed, he would be caught between three lines of soldiers; and we should then have a laugh at this Bonaparte, who has become corpulent, as M. de Talleyrand says, and whose body-guard is composed of four old fellows and a dozen schoolboys.”
“Sire,” replied Blacas, “the report is that a landing has taken place.”
“Do not disturb yourself,” replied Louis XVIII.; “it is a false alarm.”
“Sire,” said the duke, “let us not despise it; it is better to be too prudent than too confident. The minister of police may be right in not attaching importance to it, but he may also be wrong.”
“Come, Blacas, speak frankly,” said the king. “Do you really believe this news?”
“Sire,” replied the duke, “I believe it so firmly, that I have ordered a special courier to be ready to set out for Marseilles.”
“Indeed,” said the king, “and what for?”
“To ascertain the truth of the report.”
“Very well,” said the king, “do so. But do not be uneasy, Blacas; I repeat, it is a false alarm.”

events.title: Villefort's Urgent Report of Napoleon's Impending Return and Conspiracy
detailed_summary: M. de Blacas quickly returns with Villefort but faces an obstacle in the antechamber: M. de Brezé objects to Villefort's travel-worn and uncourtly attire.
Blacas invokes the King's direct order to override M. de Brezé's protests concerning courtly protocol, and Villefort is introduced into the King's presence.
The King, remaining in the same position, acknowledges Villefort and bids him to enter.
Villefort bows, advances a few steps, and then waits for the King to address him.
Louis XVIII states that the Duc de Blacas has informed him that Villefort possesses interesting information.
Villefort affirms the gravity of his news and expresses his belief that the King will also find it highly important, hoping his rapid journey means the situation, though urgent, is not beyond remedy.

The King, visibly affected by the seriousness conveyed by both Blacas and Villefort, instructs Villefort to speak comprehensively and to begin his account from the start, emphasizing his preference for order.
After a discreet and tactful apology for any potential lack of clarity in his speech due to his anxiety, Villefort, reassured by the King's benign expression, commences his report.

He explains he has traveled to Paris with maximum speed to inform the King of a critical discovery made during his duties: not a minor, common plot, but a true conspiracy, a 'storm' that directly threatens the King's throne.

Villefort reveals that the 'usurper' (Napoleon) is equipping three ships and is involved in a project that, while perhaps seeming mad, is potentially terrible. He asserts that Napoleon will have already departed Elba, heading for an unknown destination, but certainly aiming for a landing at Naples, on the Tuscan coast, or possibly on the shores of France, reminding the King of Napoleon's sustained connections with these regions.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: M. de Blacas returned as speedily as he had departed, but in the antechamber he was forced to appeal to the king’s authority.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Your majesty is well aware that the sovereign of the Island of Elba has maintained his relations with Italy and France?”

events.text_segment:
M. de Blacas returned as speedily as he had departed, but in the antechamber he was forced to appeal to the king’s authority. Villefort’s dusty garb, his costume, which was not of courtly cut, excited the susceptibility of M. de Brezé, who was all astonishment at finding that this young man had the audacity to enter before the king in such attire. The duke, however, overcame all difficulties with a word—his majesty’s order; and, in spite of the protestations which the master of ceremonies made for the honor of his office and principles, Villefort was introduced.
The king was seated in the same place where the duke had left him. On opening the door, Villefort found himself facing him, and the young magistrate’s first impulse was to pause.
“Come in, M. de Villefort,” said the king, “come in.”
Villefort bowed, and advancing a few steps, waited until the king should interrogate him.
“M. de Villefort,” said Louis XVIII., “the Duc de Blacas assures me you have some interesting information to communicate.”
“Sire, the duke is right, and I believe your majesty will think it equally important.”
“In the first place, and before everything else, sir, is the news as bad in your opinion as I am asked to believe?”
“Sire, I believe it to be most urgent, but I hope, by the speed I have used, that it is not irreparable.”
“Speak as fully as you please, sir,” said the king, who began to give way to the emotion which had showed itself in Blacas’s face and affected Villefort’s voice. “Speak, sir, and pray begin at the beginning; I like order in everything.”
“Sire,” said Villefort, “I will render a faithful report to your majesty, but I must entreat your forgiveness if my anxiety leads to some obscurity in my language.” A glance at the king after this discreet and subtle exordium, assured Villefort of the benignity of his august auditor, and he went on:
“Sire, I have come as rapidly to Paris as possible, to inform your majesty that I have discovered, in the exercise of my duties, not a commonplace and insignificant plot, such as is every day got up in the lower ranks of the people and in the army, but an actual conspiracy—a storm which menaces no less than your majesty’s throne. Sire, the usurper is arming three ships, he meditates some project, which, however mad, is yet, perhaps, terrible. At this moment he will have left Elba, to go whither I know not, but assuredly to attempt a landing either at Naples, or on the coast of Tuscany, or perhaps on the shores of France. Your majesty is well aware that the sovereign of the Island of Elba has maintained his relations with Italy and France?”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: M. de Blacas returned as speedily as he had departed, but in the antechamber he was forced to appeal to the king’s authority. M. de Brezé, the grand master of the ceremonies, was on the point of refusing admittance to M. de Villefort, who had followed the minister, and who was dressed in travelling garb. The grand master of the ceremonies, in all his rigid aristocracy, was as inflexible as the Duc d’Antin had formerly been, at the court of Louis XIV., with regard to the admission of Racine, and stood on the most stringent etiquette. But the king’s order, formally delivered, bade him to make way, and M. de Brezé bowed, in obedience. In a moment Villefort found himself in the presence of Louis XVIII. The king was seated in an arm-chair, with a table before him, on which were laid, it must be understood, not papers of state, but two open volumes, which the king perused with apparent delight, and with his usual smile, a smile which, since 1814, had rarely quitted his lips. Near the king, standing with one hand resting on the back of his chair, was M. de Blacas, who had followed Villefort. At the sight of Villefort, Louis XVIII. closed the two volumes, and, putting a paper-knife in the place, turned towards the young man, saying, “M. de Villefort, M. le Duc de Blacas assures me you have some interesting intelligence to communicate.” “Sire,” replied Villefort, “I think it will be highly interesting, and I therefore hastened to your majesty.” “Speak, monsieur,” said the king, “but first tell me how, with such a dress, you came to enter the Tuileries, which is, I believe, generally closed to travellers and couriers. M. de Brezé is usually so strict.” “Sire, my dress is a proof of the haste with which I have travelled, and of my ardent desire to lay my news before your majesty; and I must beg your majesty to excuse it, and to look only to the importance of the communication which I have to make.” “Do not apologize for your dress, monsieur,” said the king, “but continue your relation. You have travelled, then?” “I have come from Marseilles, sire, with the greatest possible speed.” “A long journey, and in dangerous times,” said the king, smiling, “which you have accomplished, it appears, without accident.” “Sire, I am proud to have incurred danger in your majesty’s service.” “Tell me, besides the fatigue, what dangers have you incurred, monsieur?” “I know not, sire, but I have a commission which I received at the same time as the order to come to Paris.” “From whom?” “From M. le Marquis de Saint-Méran, who desired me to pass his compliments to your majesty, and to say that he is honored to be your majesty’s knight; and that he is making preparations which your majesty will learn at a fitting opportunity.” “A worthy nobleman,” said the king, “a truly worthy nobleman. I am grateful to him for his remembrance.” And he half turned from Villefort to M. de Blacas, adding, “M. de Saint-Méran was almost the only one of his order who remained faithful to us in our exile. He is a most estimable man, and his daughter, whom I saw when she was quite a child, is, I am told, a most beautiful woman.” “Your majesty is correctly informed,” said Villefort, “the marquis’s daughter is a great beauty.” “Ah, then, monsieur,” replied the king, with a most gracious smile, “you are not insensible to the charms of the fair sex, it seems. Let us not detain you from the important communication you have to make to us. Come, come, monsieur, go on, I am listening.” “Sire,” said Villefort, “I have come to inform your majesty of a fact of the utmost importance, which has occurred in the department over which I hold jurisdiction.” “Indeed,” said the king; “what is it?” “A conspiracy, sire, a real conspiracy, which threatens your majesty’s throne.” “A conspiracy,” said Louis XVIII., with a smile, “are you quite sure, monsieur? Conspiracies have become so common nowadays, that they have ceased to alarm us.” “Sire,” said Villefort, “this is not a conspiracy like that of the Rue Saint-Nicaise, or like that of General Malet; this is a plot which may have terrible consequences.” “Indeed,” said the king, his brow contracting; “I am listening, monsieur.” “Here is the information, sire, which I have obtained, and which I have hastened to lay

The ushers, accustomed to the measured pace of courtly life and the strict adherence to protocol, were reluctant to grant immediate passage to a man whose haste seemed almost indecorous. "His Majesty is engaged, M. le Comte," one of them stated, blocking the way with a polite but firm gesture. "You must wait your turn." Blacas, however, was in no mood for ceremony. The fate of the monarchy, perhaps of France itself, hung in the balance. "My turn?" he exclaimed, his voice sharp with impatience. "Do you know what news I carry? His vehemence, coupled with the mention of the King's name and the obvious distress on his face, finally swayed the ushers.
