events.title: The King's Wavering Confidence and the Minister's Sudden Distress
detailed_summary: The King, now significantly agitated, acknowledges Villefort's information, mentioning recent reports of Bonapartist club activities. He presses Villefort to continue and reveal the source of his intelligence.
Villefort explains his details were obtained through the interrogation of a man from Marseilles, a known turbulent sailor suspected of Bonapartism, whom he had arrested on the day of his departure.

This sailor, Villefort elaborates, had secretly visited Elba, met with the grand-marshal, and was entrusted with an oral message for a Bonapartist contact in Paris. The purpose of this mission, according to the sailor, was to prepare for Napoleon's imminent return. Villefort confirms the sailor is now imprisoned.

When the King inquires if Villefort considers the matter serious, he underscores its extreme gravity by stating he abandoned his own betrothal festivities and friends, postponing everything, to rush to the King's feet with his fears and assurances of devotion.
Louis XVIII briefly recalls Villefort's engagement to Mademoiselle de Saint-Méran, daughter of one of his most loyal servants.
The King then steers the conversation back to what he terms the 'plot,' but Villefort corrects him, stating he fears it is more than a plot; it is a 'conspiracy.'

Attempting to project composure, Louis XVIII smiles and opines that while conspiracies are easily conceived in the current era, they are difficult to execute successfully. He emphasizes his government's recent re-establishment and heightened vigilance over the past, present, and future, noting his ministers have redoubled their watch over the Mediterranean shores for ten months.

The King outlines scenarios: if Bonaparte landed in Naples, the coalition would mobilize before he could reach Piombino; landing in Tuscany would place him in hostile territory; a landing in France would be with a small force, easily defeated due to his unpopularity. He advises Villefort to take courage and assures him of royal gratitude.

As the King finishes his reassurance, M. de Blacas exclaims, drawing attention to the Minister of Police, M. Dandré, who has just appeared at the doorway looking pale, trembling, and as if on the verge of fainting.
Villefort makes a move to withdraw, but M. de Blacas takes his hand, preventing his departure.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I am, sir,” said the king, much agitated; “and recently we have had information that the Bonapartist clubs have had meetings in the Rue Saint-Jacques. But proceed, I beg of you. How did you obtain these details?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Villefort was about to retire, but M. de Blacas, taking his hand, restrained him.

events.text_segment:
“I am, sir,” said the king, much agitated; “and recently we have had information that the Bonapartist clubs have had meetings in the Rue Saint-Jacques. But proceed, I beg of you. How did you obtain these details?”
“Sire, they are the results of an examination which I have made of a man of Marseilles, whom I have watched for some time, and arrested on the day of my departure. This person, a sailor, of turbulent character, and whom I suspected of Bonapartism, has been secretly to the Island of Elba. There he saw the grand-marshal, who charged him with an oral message to a Bonapartist in Paris, whose name I could not extract from him; but this mission was to prepare men’s minds for a return (it is the man who says this, sire)—a return which will soon occur.”
“And where is this man?”
“In prison, sire.”
“And the matter seems serious to you?”
“So serious, sire, that when the circumstance surprised me in the midst of a family festival, on the very day of my betrothal, I left my bride and friends, postponing everything, that I might hasten to lay at your majesty’s feet the fears which impressed me, and the assurance of my devotion.”
“True,” said Louis XVIII., “was there not a marriage engagement between you and Mademoiselle de Saint-Méran?”
“Daughter of one of your majesty’s most faithful servants.”
“Yes, yes; but let us talk of this plot, M. de Villefort.”
“Sire, I fear it is more than a plot; I fear it is a conspiracy.”
“A conspiracy in these times,” said Louis XVIII., smiling, “is a thing very easy to meditate, but more difficult to conduct to an end, inasmuch as, re-established so recently on the throne of our ancestors, we have our eyes open at once upon the past, the present, and the future. For the last ten months my ministers have redoubled their vigilance, in order to watch the shore of the Mediterranean. If Bonaparte landed at Naples, the whole coalition would be on foot before he could even reach Piombino; if he land in Tuscany, he will be in an unfriendly territory; if he land in France, it must be with a handful of men, and the result of that is easily foretold, execrated as he is by the population. Take courage, sir; but at the same time rely on our royal gratitude.”
“Ah, here is M. Dandré!” cried de Blacas. At this instant the minister of police appeared at the door, pale, trembling, and as if ready to faint. Villefort was about to retire, but M. de Blacas, taking his hand, restrained him.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“I am, sir,” said the king, much agitated; “and recently we have had information that the Bonapartist clubs have had meetings in the Rue Saint-Jacques. But proceed, I beg of you. How did you obtain these details?”

“By the examination of a man from Marseilles, sire, who has been for the last four days a prisoner. He was surprised when on the point of sailing for Porto-Ferrajo.”

“He is then a Bonapartist?”

“A turbulent sailor, sire, who has been engaged in smuggling for the last twenty years. I interrogated him myself, and in the hope of gaining a pardon he made a full confession. He had been employed by the Bonapartist committee as a messenger to the Isle of Elba. He was intrusted with a letter for the grand-marshal, and a verbal message to Bonaparte, the purport of which was, that he was expected in France, and that he would find everything prepared to facilitate his entrance.”

“Indeed!” said the king, “and when was this messenger arrested?”

“This morning, sire.”

“And the letter?”

“Was burned by the faithful messenger at the first intimation of danger; but, as I said, he had committed the most important part of his message to memory, and he related it to me.”

“And do you attach any importance to this communication, sir?”

“I look upon it as most serious, sire,” replied Villefort. “The man who gave me this information is a sailor, a man of little education, and who could have invented nothing of the kind. He seemed to have repeated a lesson given him; and in his alarm he betrayed the secrets with which he was intrusted.”

“This is more serious than you appear to think, sir,” said the king, becoming thoughtful. “Napoleon at the Isle of Elba is more formidable than he was at Paris, because, being at thirty leagues from the coast of Italy, he menaces two kingdoms, while on the other side he is at a hundred and forty leagues from France, and by the Southern provinces, which are the most dangerous ground for us, since it was there that he landed when he returned from Egypt. But did this man say anything else?”

“He said that he believed the expedition would shortly take place.”

“And in what direction?”

“Towards the southern coast.”

“Ah, the madman!” exclaimed the king; “to attack France in the south, when the Vendée is ready to rise in the north!”

“Not in the north, sire, but in the south,” replied Villefort. “The man’s statement was, that he was to land in the south.”

“And what is your opinion, sir?”

“I think, sire, that the expedition is not only projected, but is already in execution; nay, more, I believe it is even now accomplished.”

“Indeed!” said the king, turning pale; “and on what grounds do you base this belief?”

“On this, sire. The man was arrested this morning at six o’clock. He has been four days coming from Porto-Ferrajo, and during these four days there has been a prevalence of north-west wind, which would be favorable to the Bonapartist fleet, and unfavorable to any vessels sent in pursuit.”

“This is serious,” said the king; “very serious.”

“And this is not all, sire. The man said that he was to deliver the verbal message to a Bonapartist in Paris, whose name he was not to mention, but whom he would know by a certain sign.”

“And what was this sign?”

“A ring, sire, with a serpent coiled round it, and the words ‘
*Nous vous attendons*
’ (We await you).”

“And have you discovered this man?”

“No, sire; but I hope to do so.”

“And you have left your post to come here?”

“Yes, sire; I considered the matter of so much importance that I thought it my duty to inform your majesty of it in person.”

“You have done well, sir,” said the king; “and I thank you for your zeal. But,” he added, with a smile, “you have, I presume, taken precautions?”

“Yes, sire; I have given orders that the coast should be watched, and that all suspicious persons should be arrested.”

“And you have informed the minister of police?”

events.title: The Baron's Alarming News and the King's Fury
detailed_summary: Louis XVIII observed Baron Dandré's intense agitation and questioned its connection to prior warnings about Napoleon.
M. de Blacas chose not to confront the visibly frightened Baron, recognizing a political advantage in letting the prefect of police bear the brunt of the situation.
Baron Dandré stammered, finding it difficult to articulate the grave news.
Overwhelmed by despair, the Minister of Police nearly threw himself at the King's feet, prompting Louis XVIII to recoil and sternly demand an explanation.
The Baron expressed deep regret and self-blame for the impending disaster.
Compelled by the King, the Baron revealed that Napoleon had left Elba on February 26th and landed in France on March 1st.
The King, initially asking if the landing occurred in Italy, was profoundly shocked to learn it was in France, near Antibes.
Louis XVIII reacted with disbelief and fury at the two-day delay in receiving this critical information, accusing the Baron of relaying a false report or being mad.
The Baron confirmed the news was true, intensifying the King's anger and alarm.
The King lamented the failure to monitor Napoleon adequately, even voicing suspicions of complicity.
The Duc de Blacas defended M. Dandré against treason accusations, suggesting the failure was due to a widespread lack of foresight.
Villefort started to speak but paused, then apologized for his eagerness and requested permission to continue.
The King encouraged Villefort to speak, acknowledging him as the only one who had foreseen the danger and might propose a solution.
Villefort suggested that Napoleon's unpopularity in the south could be exploited by rallying Languedoc and Provence against him.
The minister (Dandré) countered that Napoleon was already advancing through Gap and Sisteron.
The King, deeply concerned, asked if Napoleon was marching towards Paris, a question met with the minister's incriminating silence.
The King then inquired of Villefort about the feasibility of mobilizing Dauphiné.
Villefort regretfully informed the King that, unlike other southern regions, Dauphiné's populace, especially the mountaineers, were staunch Bonapartists.
Louis XVIII conceded that Napoleon appeared well-informed and asked about the size of his forces.
The Minister of Police confessed his ignorance regarding Napoleon's troop numbers, eliciting a scathing smile from the King.
Dandré clarified that the dispatch only confirmed the landing and Napoleon's route, lacking further details.
When questioned about the dispatch's arrival, the blushing and stammering minister admitted it had come via telegraph.
Louis XVIII, visibly paling with rage and adopting a Napoleonic stance, bemoaned how, after years of effort and a miraculous restoration, his power was now disintegrating.
The minister weakly attributed the dire situation to fate.

The King bitterly acknowledged his enemies' criticisms about learning nothing and forgetting nothing, expressing that betrayal would have been preferable to failure by his own appointees, who he deemed inept and destined to perish from their incompetence, sarcastically agreeing it was indeed fatality.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Oh, yes, sir, you are right—it is fatality!”

events.text_segment:
At the sight of this agitation Louis XVIII. pushed from him violently the table at which he was sitting.
“What ails you, baron?” he exclaimed. “You appear quite aghast. Has your uneasiness anything to do with what M. de Blacas has told me, and M. de Villefort has just confirmed?” M. de Blacas moved suddenly towards the baron, but the fright of the courtier pleaded for the forbearance of the statesman; and besides, as matters were, it was much more to his advantage that the prefect of police should triumph over him than that he should humiliate the prefect.
“Sire,——” stammered the baron.
“Well, what is it?” asked Louis XVIII. The minister of police, giving way to an impulse of despair, was about to throw himself at the feet of Louis XVIII., who retreated a step and frowned.
“Will you speak?” he said.
“Oh, sire, what a dreadful misfortune! I am, indeed, to be pitied. I can never forgive myself!”
“Monsieur,” said Louis XVIII., “I command you to speak.”
“Well, sire, the usurper left Elba on the 26th February, and landed on the 1st of March.”
“And where? In Italy?” asked the king eagerly.
“In France, sire,—at a small port, near Antibes, in the Gulf of Juan.”
“The usurper landed in France, near Antibes, in the Gulf of Juan, two hundred and fifty leagues from Paris, on the 1st of March, and you only acquired this information today, the 3rd of March! Well, sir, what you tell me is impossible. You must have received a false report, or you have gone mad.”
“Alas, sire, it is but too true!” Louis made a gesture of indescribable anger and alarm, and then drew himself up as if this sudden blow had struck him at the same moment in heart and countenance.
“In France!” he cried, “the usurper in France! Then they did not watch over this man. Who knows? they were, perhaps, in league with him.”
“Oh, sire,” exclaimed the Duc de Blacas, “M. Dandré is not a man to be accused of treason! Sire, we have all been blind, and the minister of police has shared the general blindness, that is all.”
“But——” said Villefort, and then suddenly checking himself, he was silent; then he continued, “Your pardon, sire,” he said, bowing, “my zeal carried me away. Will your majesty deign to excuse me?”
“Speak, sir, speak boldly,” replied Louis. “You alone forewarned us of the evil; now try and aid us with the remedy.”
“Sire,” said Villefort, “the usurper is detested in the south; and it seems to me that if he ventured into the south, it would be easy to raise Languedoc and Provence against him.”
“Yes, assuredly,” replied the minister; “but he is advancing by Gap and Sisteron.”
“Advancing—he is advancing!” said Louis XVIII. “Is he then advancing on Paris?” The minister of police maintained a silence which was equivalent to a complete avowal.
“And Dauphiné, sir?” inquired the king, of Villefort. “Do you think it possible to rouse that as well as Provence?”
“Sire, I am sorry to tell your majesty a cruel fact; but the feeling in Dauphiné is quite the reverse of that in Provence or Languedoc. The mountaineers are Bonapartists, sire.”
“Then,” murmured Louis, “he was well informed. And how many men had he with him?”
“I do not know, sire,” answered the minister of police.
“What, you do not know! Have you neglected to obtain information on that point? Of course it is of no consequence,” he added, with a withering smile.
“Sire, it was impossible to learn; the despatch simply stated the fact of the landing and the route taken by the usurper.”
“And how did this despatch reach you?” inquired the king. The minister bowed his head, and while a deep color overspread his cheeks, he stammered out:
“By the telegraph, sire.” Louis XVIII. advanced a step, and folded his arms over his chest as Napoleon would have done.
“So then,” he exclaimed, turning pale with anger, “seven conjoined and allied armies overthrew that man. A miracle of heaven replaced me on the throne of my fathers after five-and-twenty years of exile. I have, during those five-and-twenty years, spared no pains to understand the people of France and the interests which were confided to me; and now, when I see the fruition of my wishes almost within reach, the power I hold in my hands bursts and shatters me to atoms!”
“Sire, it is fatality!” murmured the minister, feeling that the pressure of circumstances, however light a thing to destiny, was too much for any human strength to endure.
“What our enemies say of us is then true. We have learnt nothing, forgotten nothing! If I were betrayed as he was, I would console myself; but to be in the midst of persons elevated by myself to places of honor, who ought to watch over me more carefully than over themselves,—for my fortune is theirs—before me they were nothing—after me they will be nothing, and perish miserably from incapacity—ineptitude! Oh, yes, sir, you are right—it is fatality!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
At the sight of this agitation Louis XVIII. pushed from him violently the table at which he was sitting. “What is the matter, Baron?” he cried. “You appear beside yourself; and yet you had forebodings of this event.”
“Yes, sire, the letter was received,” stammered the minister.
“But why did you not give me the information sooner? Why did you suffer me to retire to rest, without acquainting me with the news?”
“Sire, the dispatch only arrived this evening, and I was anxious to procure the fullest details to-morrow morning——”
“And what are those details? Come, speak!”
“Napoleon Bonaparte left Elba on the 26th February, and landed on the 1st March.”
“Where? In Italy?” asked the King, eagerly.
“No, sire, in France, at a small port near Antibes, in the Gulf of Juan.”
“The Corsican has then dared to set foot on the sacred soil of France? Oh, the wretch! And you allowed him to do so!” added the King, with a terrible look at the minister.
“Sire, it is not my fault; the telegraph gave us notice, and orders were instantly issued to arrest him.”
“So that he has been arrested?” cried the King, in a joyful tone.
“No, sire; on the contrary, the troops sent to oppose him have joined him.”
“And he is marching upon Paris?”
The minister of police maintained a silence which was equivalent to a complete confession.
“And the Duc de Angoulême? the Duc de Berry? the Duc d’Orléans?”
“Have gone to form armies on the Rhône, the Garonne, and the Nord.”
“And you, Baron,” said the King, “do you remain here?”
“Sire, I tendered my resignation, but your Majesty has not accepted it.”
“You are right, Baron; and you have acted wisely, for no one else would have done so well as you have. It was the will of Providence that this should happen.”
“Sire, I am in despair,” said the minister.
“You in despair? And I?” cried Louis XVIII., rising and pacing the room with hasty strides. “I, who have been restored to the throne of my ancestors by a miracle of Providence, and who have been driven from it by a single man, by a Corsican, by a usurper!”
“Sire, it is fatality,” said the minister, with a sigh.
“No, Baron, it is not fatality; it is my own fault. I have been too lenient, too confiding. I ought to have known that the Corsican was a viper, and that I ought to have crushed him when I had him in my power. But I have been too merciful, and I am punished for it.”
“Sire, it is not yet too late,” said the minister.
“No, indeed,” said the King, stopping suddenly before a table on which lay a map of France. “He is at Gap, is he not?”
“Yes, sire.”
“Well, then, we will send an army to meet him. We will surround him, and we will crush him.”
“Sire, the troops sent to oppose him have joined him,” repeated the minister.
“Then we will send others,” cried the King, with a gesture of impatience. “We will send the whole army, if necessary. We will raise the whole nation against him.”
“Sire, the nation is not with us,” said the minister, in a low voice.
“What do you say?” cried the King, turning pale. “The nation is not with us? Then who is with us?”
“Sire, the emigrants, the Vendéans, and the Chouans.”
“And are they sufficient?” asked the King, with a bitter smile.
“Sire, they are brave and devoted, but they are not numerous enough to contend against the whole army.”
“Then we are lost!” cried the King, falling back into his chair.
“No, sire,” said Villefort, who had remained a silent spectator of this scene, “it is not yet too late.”
“Ah, M. de Villefort,” said the King, “you are the only one who has foreseen this event, and you are the only one who can save us.”
“Sire,” said Villefort, “I have already had the honor of telling your Majesty that I had forebodings of this event. I have also had the honor of telling your Majesty that I had discovered a plot which, if it had not been checked, would have led to a similar result.”
“Yes, yes,” said the King, impatiently, “I remember. But what is to be done now?”
“Sire,” said Villefort, “it is necessary to act with promptitude and energy. It is necessary to rally around your Majesty all those who are still faithful to you. It is necessary to appeal to the patriotism of the nation.”
“But the nation is not with us,” said the King.
“Sire,” said Villefort, “there are still in France many brave and loyal hearts who are ready to shed their blood for your Majesty. There are still in France many who remember the benefits they have received from your Majesty, and who are grateful for them.”
“You are right, M. de Villefort,” said the King, rising from his chair with renewed hope. “There are still in France many who are faithful to me. We will appeal to them. We will raise the standard of royalty, and we will see who will rally around it.”
“Sire,” said Villefort, “I am ready to devote my life to your Majesty’s service. I am ready to go wherever your Majesty may send me.”
“Thank you, M. de Villefort

events.title: Villefort's Strategic Humility and Ascendancy
detailed_summary: The Minister of Police cringed under the King's sharp sarcasm.
M. de Blacas showed signs of distress, while Villefort internally celebrated his own rising importance.

King Louis, recognizing the monarchy's precarious position, decried learning of its potential downfall by telegraph, stating he would prefer the scaffold to such a demeaning exit, and stressed the potent influence of ridicule in France.
The distressed minister begged for mercy.
The King summoned Villefort, who had been intently observing the exchange, to tell the minister that foreknowledge of such events was indeed attainable.
The minister defended himself by claiming it was impossible to discover secrets that Napoleon had guarded so closely.

The King dismissed the notion of 'impossibility' for a well-resourced minister, contrasting Dandré's failure with Villefort, a mere magistrate who, despite lacking such resources, had uncovered more and could have saved the crown had he controlled the telegraph.
The Minister of Police cast a resentful look at Villefort, who responded with a display of modest deference.

Louis XVIII clarified that his critique was not aimed at Blacas, who, though not uncovering anything, had commendably maintained his suspicions, unlike others who might have dismissed Villefort's warning as unimportant or self-serving—a clear reference to the police minister's earlier stance.
Villefort grasped the King's underlying meaning and, fearing to create a powerful enemy in the doomed Dandré who might uncover his own plots involving Dantès, chose a path of strategic diplomacy.

Villefort intervened, attributing the current crisis to divine will and his own insights to mere chance, portraying himself as a loyal and devoted servant to avoid appearing overly perspicacious. He requested the King not to overestimate his abilities, to prevent any future disappointment.

The Minister of Police conveyed his gratitude to Villefort with an expressive look, signaling to Villefort that his strategy had worked: he had gained a potential ally without diminishing the King's favor.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The minister of police thanked the young man by an eloquent look, and Villefort understood that he had succeeded in his design; that is to say, that without forfeiting the gratitude of the king, he had made a friend of one on whom, in case of necessity, he might rely.

events.text_segment:
The minister quailed before this outburst of sarcasm. M. de Blacas wiped the moisture from his brow. Villefort smiled within himself, for he felt his increased importance.
“To fall,” continued King Louis, who at the first glance had sounded the abyss on which the monarchy hung suspended,—“to fall, and learn of that fall by telegraph! Oh, I would rather mount the scaffold of my brother, Louis XVI., than thus descend the staircase at the Tuileries driven away by ridicule. Ridicule, sir—why, you know not its power in France, and yet you ought to know it!”
“Sire, sire,” murmured the minister, “for pity’s——”
“Approach, M. de Villefort,” resumed the king, addressing the young man, who, motionless and breathless, was listening to a conversation on which depended the destiny of a kingdom. “Approach, and tell monsieur that it is possible to know beforehand all that he has not known.”
“Sire, it was really impossible to learn secrets which that man concealed from all the world.”
“Really impossible! Yes—that is a great word, sir. Unfortunately, there are great words, as there are great men; I have measured them. Really impossible for a minister who has an office, agents, spies, and fifteen hundred thousand francs for secret service money, to know what is going on at sixty leagues from the coast of France! Well, then, see, here is a gentleman who had none of these resources at his disposal—a gentleman, only a simple magistrate, who learned more than you with all your police, and who would have saved my crown, if, like you, he had the power of directing a telegraph.” The look of the minister of police was turned with concentrated spite on Villefort, who bent his head in modest triumph.
“I do not mean that for you, Blacas,” continued Louis XVIII.; “for if you have discovered nothing, at least you have had the good sense to persevere in your suspicions. Any other than yourself would have considered the disclosure of M. de Villefort insignificant, or else dictated by venal ambition.” These words were an allusion to the sentiments which the minister of police had uttered with so much confidence an hour before.
Villefort understood the king’s intent. Any other person would, perhaps, have been overcome by such an intoxicating draught of praise; but he feared to make for himself a mortal enemy of the police minister, although he saw that Dandré was irrevocably lost. In fact, the minister, who, in the plenitude of his power, had been unable to unearth Napoleon’s secret, might in despair at his own downfall interrogate Dantès and so lay bare the motives of Villefort’s plot. Realizing this, Villefort came to the rescue of the crest-fallen minister, instead of aiding to crush him.
“Sire,” said Villefort, “the suddenness of this event must prove to your majesty that the issue is in the hands of Providence; what your majesty is pleased to attribute to me as profound perspicacity is simply owing to chance, and I have profited by that chance, like a good and devoted servant—that’s all. Do not attribute to me more than I deserve, sire, that your majesty may never have occasion to recall the first opinion you have been pleased to form of me.” The minister of police thanked the young man by an eloquent look, and Villefort understood that he had succeeded in his design; that is to say, that without forfeiting the gratitude of the king, he had made a friend of one on whom, in case of necessity, he might rely.

events.title: The Unsettling Inquiry into General Quesnel's Death
detailed_summary: The King expressed his satisfaction and dismissed M. de Blacas and the Minister of Police, indicating that subsequent actions were the responsibility of the Minister of War.
M. de Blacas voiced his belief in the army's steadfast loyalty, citing positive reports.
The King, now distrustful of reports, unexpectedly shifted the conversation to the affair in the Rue Saint-Jacques, inquiring about it with Baron Dandré.
Villefort couldn't suppress an exclamation at the mention of the Rue Saint-Jacques, then quickly apologized for his lapse in etiquette, attributing it to his deep devotion to the King.
The King granted Villefort permission to make inquiries, stating he had earned that privilege through his earlier actions.
The Minister of Police explained that he had been on the verge of presenting new information regarding this matter just before the news of Napoleon's landing had diverted the King's attention.
Louis XVIII countered that the Rue Saint-Jacques incident seemed intrinsically linked to Napoleon's return, suggesting General Quesnel's death might expose a significant domestic conspiracy.
Villefort visibly trembled when General Quesnel's name was mentioned.

The Minister of Police reported that investigations now pointed to Quesnel's death being an assassination rather than a suicide. He added that Quesnel had recently visited a Bonapartist club before his disappearance and had an appointment with an unknown individual in the Rue Saint-Jacques, though the general's valet only overheard the street name, not the specific number.
While the minister provided these details, Villefort exhibited extreme distress, his complexion alternating between red and pale.
The King, noticing Villefort's reaction, asked if he concurred that General Quesnel, outwardly a Bonapartist sympathizer but secretly loyal to the crown, had been murdered in a Bonapartist trap.
Villefort agreed it was probable and asked if there was any further information.
The minister revealed they were actively searching for the man who had arranged the meeting with Quesnel.
Villefort anxiously repeated the phrase, 'On his track?'

The minister confirmed and provided the servant's description of the suspect: a man around fifty to fifty-two, dark-complexioned, with prominent dark eyebrows, a thick moustache, wearing a blue frock-coat buttoned to the neck, and adorned with an officer's Legion of Honor rosette. This individual had been followed the previous day but managed to escape.
Villefort felt a wave of weakness upon hearing the detailed description, but regained some composure upon learning the suspect had eluded capture.

The King instructed the minister to persist in the manhunt, declaring that Quesnel's murderers, regardless of their Bonapartist affiliations, would face severe punishment, as Quesnel would have been a valuable asset.
Villefort had to draw upon all his self-control to hide the profound fear stirred by the King's resolute statement.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: ’Tis well,” resumed the king.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It required all Villefort’s coolness not to betray the terror with which this declaration of the king inspired him.

events.text_segment:
’Tis well,” resumed the king. “And now, gentlemen,” he continued, turning towards M. de Blacas and the minister of police, “I have no further occasion for you, and you may retire; what now remains to do is in the department of the minister of war.”
“Fortunately, sire,” said M. de Blacas, “we can rely on the army; your majesty knows how every report confirms their loyalty and attachment.”
“Do not mention reports, duke, to me, for I know now what confidence to place in them. Yet, speaking of reports, baron, what have you learned with regard to the affair in the Rue Saint-Jacques?”
“The affair in the Rue Saint-Jacques!” exclaimed Villefort, unable to repress an exclamation. Then, suddenly pausing, he added, “Your pardon, sire, but my devotion to your majesty has made me forget, not the respect I have, for that is too deeply engraved in my heart, but the rules of etiquette.”
“Go on, go on, sir,” replied the king; “you have today earned the right to make inquiries here.”
“Sire,” interposed the minister of police, “I came a moment ago to give your majesty fresh information which I had obtained on this head, when your majesty’s attention was attracted by the terrible event that has occurred in the gulf, and now these facts will cease to interest your majesty.”
“On the contrary, sir,—on the contrary,” said Louis XVIII., “this affair seems to me to have a decided connection with that which occupies our attention, and the death of General Quesnel will, perhaps, put us on the direct track of a great internal conspiracy.” At the name of General Quesnel, Villefort trembled.
“Everything points to the conclusion, sire,” said the minister of police, “that death was not the result of suicide, as we first believed, but of assassination. General Quesnel, it appears, had just left a Bonapartist club when he disappeared. An unknown person had been with him that morning, and made an appointment with him in the Rue Saint-Jacques; unfortunately, the general’s valet, who was dressing his hair at the moment when the stranger entered, heard the street mentioned, but did not catch the number.” As the police minister related this to the king, Villefort, who looked as if his very life hung on the speaker’s lips, turned alternately red and pale. The king looked towards him.
“Do you not think with me, M. de Villefort, that General Quesnel, whom they believed attached to the usurper, but who was really entirely devoted to me, has perished the victim of a Bonapartist ambush?”
“It is probable, sire,” replied Villefort. “But is this all that is known?”
“They are on the track of the man who appointed the meeting with him.”
“On his track?” said Villefort.
“Yes, the servant has given his description. He is a man of from fifty to fifty-two years of age, dark, with black eyes covered with shaggy eyebrows, and a thick moustache. He was dressed in a blue frock-coat, buttoned up to the chin, and wore at his button-hole the rosette of an officer of the Legion of Honor. Yesterday a person exactly corresponding with this description was followed, but he was lost sight of at the corner of the Rue de la Jussienne and the Rue Coq-Héron.” Villefort leaned on the back of an armchair, for as the minister of police went on speaking he felt his legs bend under him; but when he learned that the unknown had escaped the vigilance of the agent who followed him, he breathed again.
“Continue to seek for this man, sir,” said the king to the minister of police; “for if, as I am all but convinced, General Quesnel, who would have been so useful to us at this moment, has been murdered, his assassins, Bonapartists or not, shall be cruelly punished.” It required all Villefort’s coolness not to betray the terror with which this declaration of the king inspired him.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
'Tis well,” resumed the king. “M. de Blacas, you will remain; and you, M. le Baron Dandré, go and inform the Minister of War, that I desire to see him instantly.”
“Ah, sir,” said M. de Blacas, “that is the best news you could have given us. The army is devoted to you.”
“Do you think so?” said Louis XVIII., with a significant smile. “Enlighten me, M. le Baron, for I left M. de Villefort with the Minister of Police, and M. de Villefort is deeply disturbed about the affair in the Rue Saint-Jacques, to which M. le Baron Dandré alluded, and I should be glad to know the particulars of the report.”
“The minister was about to lay the report before your majesty when M. de Villefort was announced,” said M. Dandré, “and, with your majesty’s permission, I will now furnish the details.”
“Speak, Baron, speak,” said the king, turning towards M. Dandré, and at the same time looking at M. de Blacas and M. de Villefort. “Ah, M. de Villefort, so you are the young man who is so deeply disturbed about the police reports, and who discovered, in the garden of the Tuileries, the conspiracy of the Rue Saint-Jacques. By my faith, you do credit to your profession; you should be made prefect of police, or minister at least.”
“Your majesty is too good to me,” said Villefort, with a smile, “the commendations of my sovereign are a recompense for which I would shed my blood, and as regards the affair in the Rue Saint-Jacques, I can only repeat that it seems to me to be most serious.”
“Most serious, Villefort?” repeated the king; “these words are too emphatic to be applied to so simple an affair. Baron Dandré, be so good as to give us the report concerning this matter.”
“This report, sire, is the one I was about to deliver to you when the news of the landing of the Corsican diverted your majesty’s attention. It refers to a conspiracy which has been forming for some time, but which, thanks to the vigilance of the police, has been discovered before it could be put into execution. The head of the conspiracy is a man named Noirtier, who is known to be a Bonapartist, and who has been in communication with the island of Elba. He has been holding meetings in the Rue Saint-Jacques, and it is there that the plan of the conspiracy was arranged.”
“And what was this plan?” asked the king.
“To carry off your majesty, and to proclaim the king of Rome,” replied M. Dandré.
“A bold stroke,” said the king, smiling; “and where were they to carry me?”
“To the island of Elba, sire,” said M. Dandré.
“More likely to the castle of Vincennes,” said the king, laughing; “but how was this conspiracy discovered?”
“By a young man named Villefort, sire, who, by a singular chance, was present at one of the meetings, and who immediately gave information to the police.”
“That is correct,” said Villefort, “but I must add that I was not aware of the full extent of the conspiracy at the time, and that I only learned it from the report of the police.”
“You are a modest young man, M. de Villefort,” said the king; “but you have rendered a great service to the state, and I shall not forget it. But let us return to this conspiracy. You say, M. le Baron, that the head of the conspiracy is a man named Noirtier?”
“Yes, sire.”
“And that he is in communication with the island of Elba?”
“Yes, sire.”
“And that he has been holding meetings in the Rue Saint-Jacques?”
“Yes, sire.”
“And that the plan was to carry me off to the island of Elba?”
“Yes, sire.”
“Well, M. le Baron,” said the king, turning towards M. de Blacas, “what do you think of this?”
“I think, sire, that it is a very serious affair, and that we should take immediate measures to arrest this Noirtier and his accomplices.”
“That is precisely what I think,” said the king; “and I have already given orders to the police to that effect. But there is another point which disturbs me. M. de Villefort, you spoke of the death of General Quesnel. What do you know about it?”
Villefort trembled visibly at the mention of this name.
“Sire,” said he, “I know nothing more than what is contained in the report of the police, which states that the general was found dead in his bed this morning, and that there are suspicions of assassination.”
“Suspicions of assassination!” exclaimed the king. “And who is suspected?”
“The report does not name any one, sire, but it appears that the general had been in communication with the conspirators of the Rue Saint-Jacques, and that he was to have taken a prominent part in the execution of the plot.”
“And you think, then, that he was assassinated by his accomplices, who feared that he might betray them?”
“That is the most probable conjecture, sire.”
“And have you any clew to the assassins?”
“No, sire, but the police are actively engaged in the search.”
“And what is the description of the man who was to have met General Quesnel in the Rue Saint-Jacques?” asked the king.
“The general’s valet, who overheard the conversation, could only give the street, not the number, sire. But he described the man as being about fifty or fifty-two years of age, with dark complexion, prominent dark eyebrows, a thick moustache, wearing a blue frock-coat buttoned up to the neck, and with the rosette of an officer of the Legion of Honor in his button-hole. He was followed yesterday, but escaped.”
Villefort felt a cold sweat break out on his forehead. The description was so precise that it could not be mistaken. He recognized the man at once. It

“That is the most probable conjecture, sire.”
“And have you any clew to the assassins?”
“No, sire, but the police are actively engaged in the search.”
“And what is the description of the man who was to have met General Quesnel in the Rue Saint-Jacques?” asked the king.
“The general’s valet, who overheard the conversation, could only give the street, not the number, sire. But he described the man as being about fifty or fifty-two years of age, with dark complexion, prominent dark eyebrows, a thick moustache, wearing a blue frock-coat buttoned up to the neck, and with the rosette of an officer of the Legion of Honor in his button-hole. He was followed yesterday, but escaped.”
Villefort felt a cold sweat break out on his forehead. The description was so precise that it could not be mistaken. He recognized the man at once. It

events.title: Royal Rewards, Scrutiny, and Villefort's Ambitious Departure
detailed_summary: The King sarcastically criticized the police for considering matters resolved merely by identifying a crime and claiming to be pursuing suspects.
The Minister of Police assured the King that he would be fully satisfied regarding this particular issue.
As he prepared to let Villefort leave, the King asked if he had visited his father, M. Noirtier, a question that made Villefort feel faint.
Villefort explained he had stayed at a hotel and then gone straight to see the Duc de Blacas.
When the King pressed further, asking if he would see his father, Villefort indicated he probably would not.

The King, with a knowing smile that suggested his questions were deliberate, mentioned the poor relations between Villefort and his father, framing Villefort's estrangement as another sacrifice for the royalist cause that merited reward.
Villefort humbly replied that the King's expressed kindness was itself a reward that surpassed all his ambitions.
The King assured Villefort he would not be forgotten and then, removing his own Cross of the Legion of Honor, presented it to him.

When Villefort pointed out it was an officer's cross, Louis XVIII insisted he take it, citing lack of time to procure another, and instructed Blacas to ensure the official patent was prepared and sent to Villefort.
Villefort, his eyes filled with tears of happiness and pride, accepted the cross and kissed it.
Upon inquiring about his orders, the King advised Villefort to rest and remain prepared to serve in Marseilles if his services were not required in Paris.
Villefort announced he would depart from Paris within the hour.
The King bid him farewell, advising him to remind the King of his service if he were forgotten, then dismissed him, requesting Blacas to stay and summoning the Minister of War.
As they were leaving the Tuileries, the Minister of Police remarked to Villefort that his fortune was now assured.

Villefort, silently wondering about the timeline of his success, courteously saluted the departing minister whose career was over, and quickly found a carriage, allowing his mind to fill with ambitious aspirations.

events.text_segment:
“How strange,” continued the king, with some asperity; “the police think that they have disposed of the whole matter when they say, ‘A murder has been committed,’ and especially so when they can add, ‘And we are on the track of the guilty persons.’”
“Sire, your majesty will, I trust, be amply satisfied on this point at least.”
“We shall see. I will no longer detain you, M. de Villefort, for you must be fatigued after so long a journey; go and rest. Of course you stopped at your father’s?” A feeling of faintness came over Villefort.
“No, sire,” he replied, “I alighted at the Hotel de Madrid, in the Rue de Tournon.”
“But you have seen him?”
“Sire, I went straight to the Duc de Blacas.”
“But you will see him, then?”
“I think not, sire.”
“Ah, I forgot,” said Louis, smiling in a manner which proved that all these questions were not made without a motive; “I forgot you and M. Noirtier are not on the best terms possible, and that is another sacrifice made to the royal cause, and for which you should be recompensed.”
“Sire, the kindness your majesty deigns to evince towards me is a recompense which so far surpasses my utmost ambition that I have nothing more to ask for.”
“Never mind, sir, we will not forget you; make your mind easy. In the meanwhile” (the king here detached the cross of the Legion of Honor which he usually wore over his blue coat, near the cross of St. Louis, above the order of Notre-Dame-du-Mont-Carmel and St. Lazare, and gave it to Villefort)—“in the meanwhile take this cross.”
“Sire,” said Villefort, “your majesty mistakes; this is an officer’s cross.”
“Ma foi!” said Louis XVIII., “take it, such as it is, for I have not the time to procure you another. Blacas, let it be your care to see that the brevet is made out and sent to M. de Villefort.” Villefort’s eyes were filled with tears of joy and pride; he took the cross and kissed it.
“And now,” he said, “may I inquire what are the orders with which your majesty deigns to honor me?”
“Take what rest you require, and remember that if you are not able to serve me here in Paris, you may be of the greatest service to me at Marseilles.”
“Sire,” replied Villefort, bowing, “in an hour I shall have quitted Paris.”
“Go, sir,” said the king; “and should I forget you (kings’ memories are short), do not be afraid to bring yourself to my recollection. Baron, send for the minister of war. Blacas, remain.”
“Ah, sir,” said the minister of police to Villefort, as they left the Tuileries, “you entered by luck’s door—your fortune is made.”
“Will it be long first?” muttered Villefort, saluting the minister, whose career was ended, and looking about him for a hackney-coach. One passed at the moment, which he hailed; he gave his address to the driver, and springing in, threw himself on the seat, and gave loose to dreams of ambition.

Do you think of what you are saying, minister? They must be mad to come to Paris!”“I would not venture to assure your majesty of their madness,” rejoined the minister, “but I am certain of their presence in Paris.”“And where are they?”“In the Conciergerie.”“Now tell me how it was effected, minister.”“It was thus, your majesty: we have in the south a very clever agent, who has been employed three years in watching these Bonapartists.”“Aha, aha,” said the king; “he is the man who has informed you of the presence of the Band of the South at Paris?”“Yes, your majesty, it was a letter from him which apprised us of the fact.”“And he is in a condition to give you full information?”“Yes, your majesty, on condition that he is only put in communication with your majesty.”“Personally?”“Personally.”“That is but just; and when can I see him?”“Whenever your majesty pleases; the agent is at your majesty’s door.”“Let him enter,” said Louis XVIII.The minister of police gave a sign to the doorkeeper, who introduced M. de Villefort.In the meantime, M. de Villefort had not remained inactive; he had gone to the house of M. de Salvieux, who had one of the most influential voices in the council, and had related to him the whole affair, the arrest of the conspirators, and the arrival of the letter; and M. de Salvieux, more excited than M. de Villefort himself, had instantly ordered his carriage, and they had gone together to the Tuileries. events.title: The Unexpected Paternal Confrontation
detailed_summary: Shortly after arriving at his hotel, Villefort arranged for horses to be prepared for his departure in two hours and ordered breakfast.
Just as he was about to start his meal, his bell rang sharply. His valet answered the door, and Villefort heard someone ask for him by name.
Villefort was surprised, wondering how anyone could already know he was there. His valet then entered the room.
The valet reported that a stranger, who declined to provide his name, was asking to see him.
Villefort questioned who the stranger might be and what he wanted.
The valet described the visitor as a man of approximately fifty years of age.
When asked about his height, the valet indicated he was about the same height as Villefort.
Regarding his appearance, the valet described him as very dark, with black eyes, black hair, and black eyebrows.
Villefort, growing concerned, quickly inquired about the man's attire.
The valet stated the man was wearing a blue frock-coat, buttoned up high, and was adorned with the Legion of Honor.
Recognizing the description, Villefort turned pale and uttered, 'It is he!'
The man matching the description entered the room, commenting on the excessive formality and questioning if it was customary in Marseilles for sons to keep their fathers waiting in anterooms.
Villefort exclaimed 'Father!', confirming his earlier suspicion that the visitor was indeed his parent.
The newcomer, now identified as Villefort's father, set down his cane and hat, and then mildly rebuked his son, Gérard, for the lack of filial piety shown by making him wait.
Villefort instructed his servant, Germain, to leave them alone.
Germain exited the room, clearly taken aback by the turn of events.

events.text_segment:
Ten minutes afterwards Villefort reached his hotel, ordered horses to be ready in two hours, and asked to have his breakfast brought to him. He was about to begin his repast when the sound of the bell rang sharp and loud. The valet opened the door, and Villefort heard someone speak his name.
“Who could know that I was here already?” said the young man. The valet entered.
“Well,” said Villefort, “what is it?—Who rang?—Who asked for me?”
“A stranger who will not send in his name.”
“A stranger who will not send in his name! What can he want with me?”
“He wishes to speak to you.”
“To me?”
“Yes.”
“Did he mention my name?”
“Yes.”
“What sort of person is he?”
“Why, sir, a man of about fifty.”
“Short or tall?”
“About your own height, sir.”
“Dark or fair?”
“Dark,—very dark; with black eyes, black hair, black eyebrows.”
“And how dressed?” asked Villefort quickly.
“In a blue frock-coat, buttoned up close, decorated with the Legion of Honor.”
“It is he!” said Villefort, turning pale.
“Eh, pardieu!” said the individual whose description we have twice given, entering the door, “what a great deal of ceremony! Is it the custom in Marseilles for sons to keep their fathers waiting in their anterooms?”
“Father!” cried Villefort, “then I was not deceived; I felt sure it must be you.”
“Well, then, if you felt so sure,” replied the new-comer, putting his cane in a corner and his hat on a chair, “allow me to say, my dear Gérard, that it was not very filial of you to keep me waiting at the door.”
“Leave us, Germain,” said Villefort. The servant quitted the apartment with evident signs of astonishment.

Ten minutes afterwards Villefort reached his hotel, ordered horses to be ready in two hours, and asked to have his breakfast brought to him. Just as he was sitting down to table, there was a sharp ring at the bell of his private room. Villefort was astonished, no one in Marseilles knew of his arrival, and this was going a little too fast for the discretion he had recommended. He rang himself, and Germain appeared.
“Who rang?” asked Villefort.
“A stranger, who asks to speak to you.”
“Did he give his name?”
“No, he told me he did not think it was necessary as you did not know him.”
“His appearance?”
“About fifty years of age, sir; a great coat buttoned up to the chin, a black cravat, and very dark complexion; with black and piercing eyes, and eyebrows that joined. He looks altogether a severe man.”
“And how is he dressed?” asked Villefort, hastily.
“In a blue frock-coat, buttoned as I said, and wearing the star of the Legion of Honor.”
“It is he!” said Villefort, turning pale.
“And you have suffered him to come up?”
“Yes, sir, he followed me up the stairs.”
Villefort made a violent gesture.
“Let him come in,” he said.
The stranger who was on the stairs had followed Germain so closely that he had heard the last words, and entered as Villefort pronounced them.
“Ah, good morning, M. de Villefort,” said the stranger, entering the room. “I am glad to see you, although I perceive that in Marseilles, even magistrates condescend to dispense with the ceremony of an introduction between father and son.”
“Father!” cried Villefort, “I expected you.”
“Yes, I arrived an hour ago, but would not stop at the hotel, as I did not know what you had decided upon.”
“And in what way have you come, father?”
“By the post-chaise, as usual.”
“And when do you set out again?”
“Immediately, if you have concluded your business.”
“Not quite, father; but if you will take a place at table, we can talk it over.”
“I have already breakfasted, Gérard,” replied M. Noirtier; “my appetite is not so good as yours; you are young, and youth requires sustenance. Do not let me interrupt you.”
“You are right, father; I forgot that I had not breakfasted,” said Villefort, and sitting down, he ate with a good appetite, and that without offering the slightest thing to his father, who in the meantime walked up and down the room, his hands behind him, and stopping every now and then to look at his son.
“The horses are ordered, father.”
“You set off then?”
“Yes, in half an hour.”
“I shall have time,” said M. Noirtier. “Gérard,” continued he, “come here.”
Villefort rose from the table, and approached his father.
“What do you want, father?”
“To speak to you about important affairs.”
“We are alone, father.”
“That is not enough,” said Noirtier; “are you sure that none can hear us?”
Villefort opened the door, and looked into the next room.
“No, father,” said he, “we are alone.”
“But Germain?”
“He is a sure man, father; and, besides, he is at the other end of the corridor.”
“Nevertheless, make him aware that he is not to disturb us for anything.”
Villefort went out and gave the order to Germain, who was busy in the next room. As he returned, his father had taken a seat.
“Now,” said the latter, “let us talk about business. I have come expressly from Paris to see you.”
“Indeed?”
“Yes.”

“I have already breakfasted, Gérard,” replied M. Noirtier; “my appetite is not so good as yours; you are young, and youth requires sustenance. Do not let me interrupt you.”
“You are right, father; I forgot that I had not breakfasted,” said Villefort, and sitting down, he ate with a good appetite, and that without offering the slightest thing to his father, who in the meantime walked up and down the room, his hands behind him, and stopping every now and then to look at his son.
“The horses are ordered, father.”
“You set off then?”
“Yes, in half an hour.”
“I shall have time,” said M. Noirtier. “Gérard,” continued he, “come here.”
Villefort rose from the table, and approached his father.
“What do you want, father?”
“To speak to you about important affairs.”
“We are alone, father.”
“That is not enough,” said Noirtier; “are you sure that none can hear us?”
Villefort opened the door, and looked into the next room.
“No, father,” said he, “we are alone.”
“But Germain?”
“He is a sure man, father; and, besides, he is at the other end of the corridor.”
“Nevertheless, make him aware that he is not to disturb us for anything.”
Villefort went out and gave the order to Germain, who was busy in the next room. As he returned, his father had taken a seat.
“Now,” said the latter, “let us talk about business. I have come expressly from Paris to see you.”
“Indeed?”
“Yes.”

chapters.chapter_title: VOLUME ONE. Chapter 12. Father and Son

events.title: Noirtier's Cautious Arrival and Villefort's Troubling News
detailed_summary: M. Noirtier enters and carefully ensures the room is secure from eavesdroppers, even re-opening and bolting doors, which causes the servant Germain to hastily retreat.
Noirtier then approaches Villefort, who has watched these security measures with evident surprise.
Noirtier observes that Villefort does not seem particularly pleased to see him.
Villefort responds that he is delighted, but the unexpected nature of the visit has overwhelmed him.
Noirtier remarks that he could say the same, given Villefort's presence in Paris so soon after announcing his wedding for a later date.
Villefort, drawing nearer, explains that his trip is specifically for Noirtier's benefit and will ensure his father's salvation.
Intrigued, Noirtier settles into a chair and invites Villefort to share the details, anticipating an interesting account.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: M. Noirtier—for it was, indeed, he who entered—looked after the servant until the door was closed, and then, fearing, no doubt, that he might be overheard in the antechamber, he opened the door again, nor was the precaution useless, as appeared from the rapid retreat of Germain, who proved that he was not exempt from the sin which ruined our first parents.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Really, pray tell me all about it, for it must be interesting.”

events.text_segment:
M. Noirtier—for it was, indeed, he who entered—looked after the servant until the door was closed, and then, fearing, no doubt, that he might be overheard in the antechamber, he opened the door again, nor was the precaution useless, as appeared from the rapid retreat of Germain, who proved that he was not exempt from the sin which ruined our first parents. M. Noirtier then took the trouble to close and bolt the antechamber door, then that of the bedchamber, and then extended his hand to Villefort, who had followed all his motions with surprise which he could not conceal.
“Well, now, my dear Gérard,” said he to the young man, with a very significant look, “do you know, you seem as if you were not very glad to see me?”
“My dear father,” said Villefort, “I am, on the contrary, delighted; but I so little expected your visit, that it has somewhat overcome me.”
“But, my dear fellow,” replied M. Noirtier, seating himself, “I might say the same thing to you, when you announce to me your wedding for the 28th of February, and on the 3rd of March you turn up here in Paris.”
“And if I have come, my dear father,” said Gérard, drawing closer to M. Noirtier, “do not complain, for it is for you that I came, and my journey will be your salvation.”
“Ah, indeed!” said M. Noirtier, stretching himself out at his ease in the chair. “Really, pray tell me all about it, for it must be interesting.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: M. M. Noirtier then took the trouble to close the door a second time, and to push the bolts. When he had assured himself that the servant had flown to the opposite end of the corridor, and that no one was listening, he returned to a large armchair, in which it was his habit to sit, and which Villefort had respectfully placed for him. Villefort was astounded at this excess of precaution, but M. Noirtier returned to him with a smile. “Well, my dear Villefort,” said he, “do you not seem delighted to see me?” “I am, my dear father,” replied Villefort, “but I did not expect you.” “Ah, indeed, I can well believe that, since you announced to me your wedding for the 21st of May, and here you are in Paris on the 3rd of March.” “Do not let us speak of my arrival,” said Villefort, drawing nearer to M. Noirtier, “but of your own.” “I came as quickly as possible,” said Noirtier, “as soon as I received your letter.” “Then you know what is happening?” “I do, and that is the reason of my coming.” “And what do you intend doing?” “I am waiting to hear,” replied Noirtier. “Come, sit down, and let us talk the matter over.” The young man seated himself. “I think,” said Villefort, “that we are alone?” “Perfectly so. But why all these precautions?” “Because I have a most important communication to make to you.” “Relating to what?” “Relating to the king.” “You are a royalist, then?” asked Noirtier, with a smile. “Yes, father, I have been one since the Restoration.” “Not a very long time, then,” said Noirtier. “You were a Bonapartist at the time of my marriage with the noble Demoiselle de Saint-Méran.” “It is true, father,” replied Villefort, blushing, “but, like everyone else, I have followed the tide.” “And you are a royalist of the eve, and I am a royalist of the morrow. The thing is more rare.” “Do not let us jest, father,” said Villefort, “for the time is precious.” “Well, what is this most important communication?” “You have heard of the landing of the Emperor?” “No, indeed, I have not,” replied Noirtier, with the most perfect composure; “but then I must say, I have been engaged since yesterday in an affair of the greatest importance.” “An affair of importance?” asked Villefort. “Yes; I am going to make my will.” “Ah, father!” “Yes, it is time, for I am sixty years old, and at my age one cannot tell what the next day may bring forth. But do not let us deviate from the object of your visit, which, if I am not mistaken, relates to the Emperor?” “Yes, I come to speak to you of this landing.” “Indeed! and where has he landed?” “At Cannes, not far from Antibes.” “Upon my word,” said Noirtier, “that is a bold undertaking. And what is he doing?” “He is marching upon Paris.” “Upon Paris?” said Noirtier. “This is serious. And you come to tell me this?” “Yes; for you can render the greatest service to the king.” “In what way?” “By your influence, which is as great as ever.” “Upon my word,” said Noirtier, “I do not know what you mean. I have no influence.” “Yes, father, you have, and that is why I have come to you. The king and government have been greatly alarmed by this news, and—” “Indeed,” said Noirtier, with a smile, “so the king and government are alarmed? I am glad of that, for they will be more prudent in future.” “Prudent, father! when the Emperor is marching upon Paris?” “Well, that is just the time to be prudent. Let them not be too hasty in their measures.” “Father, the government is taking the most active measures. A general is to be sent to oppose the usurper.” “Ah, indeed! and who is this general?” “General—General Quesnel, who has been sent to the frontier.” “Quesnel?” said Noirtier. “I know him. He is a brave man, but he is a royalist, and the soldiers will not follow him.” “Father, you are mistaken. The soldiers are tired of the Emperor, and

events.title: Discussion of the Bonapartist Club and General Quesnel's Death
detailed_summary: Villefort directly asks his father if he is aware of a Bonapartist club located in the Rue Saint-Jacques.
Noirtier calmly confirms its existence (No. 53) and his position as its vice-president.
Villefort expresses his alarm at his father's coolness, finding it unnerving.
Noirtier dismisses his son's concern, stating that his past experiences—being proscribed, hunted, and escaping danger—have made him accustomed to such situations.
He prompts Villefort to continue regarding the club.
Villefort reveals that General Quesnel was lured to the club and, after leaving his home one evening, was found dead in the Seine the following day.
When Noirtier inquires about the source of this information, Villefort states it came from the king.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Father, you have heard speak of a certain Bonapartist club in the Rue Saint-Jacques?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “The king himself.”

events.text_segment:
“Father, you have heard speak of a certain Bonapartist club in the Rue Saint-Jacques?”
“No. 53; yes, I am vice-president.”
“Father, your coolness makes me shudder.”
“Why, my dear boy, when a man has been proscribed by the mountaineers, has escaped from Paris in a hay-cart, been hunted over the plains of Bordeaux by Robespierre’s bloodhounds, he becomes accustomed to most things. But go on, what about the club in the Rue Saint-Jacques?”
“Why, they induced General Quesnel to go there, and General Quesnel, who quitted his own house at nine o’clock in the evening, was found the next day in the Seine.”
“And who told you this fine story?”
“The king himself.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“Father, you have heard speak of a certain Bonapartist club in the Rue Saint-Jacques?”
“No. 53; yes, I am vice-president.”
“You, father, you!” cried Villefort, starting back, and turning as pale as death.
“Why, what is there so astonishing in that?” said Noirtier.
“It is astonishing that a man of your name, the father of M. de Villefort, the king’s attorney at Paris, should be a Bonapartist, and not only a Bonapartist, but one of the principal leaders of the party.”
“Well, my child,” said Noirtier, “what would you have? I am a Bonapartist, and one of the principal leaders of the party; and what is more, I am ready to die for the cause,” added he, with a look of stoicism which alarmed Villefort, who well knew the inflexible nature of his father.
“Father,” replied he, “do not jest thus, I entreat you; it is too serious. Allow me to tell you that, at a time like this, at the beginning of an administration, the most strenuous efforts are made to put down rebellion, and that a discovery of your connexion with it would ruin us both.”
“So much the worse,” said Noirtier.
“You can never imagine, father, the political influence you are losing.”
“You mistake. Noirtier loses nothing. It is the Villeforts who lose. What does it signify to a old man like me, of whom the king would have made a peer of France, and who prefers calling himself Noirtier to being called M. de Villefort? to a man who was proscribed, pursued, and hunted down, and who at the age of sixty has made his fortune and is steady as a rock? What signifies to me the loss of the political influence you allude to? Go on, I beg.”
“But, father,” said Villefort, “continue to speak seriously.”
“I am the most serious man in the world,” replied Noirtier, with an ironical smile.
“Father, I entreat you to reflect on the situation.”
“I am reflecting.”
“You are running the risk of ruining your son, and your son’s children.”
“Villefort,” said Noirtier, “pray answer me one question.”
“Do so, father.”
“What is the leading topic of conversation in Paris just now?”
“The king’s return, father.”
“No, no,” said Noirtier, “that is an old story. Talk to me of the day, — of the present moment.”
“Ah, yes, I understand,” said Villefort; “the murder of General Quesnel. Is not that the subject?”
“Yes, you have hit it.”
“Well, father, the king knows the details of that affair, and you would hardly guess from whom he learned them. I learned them this morning from the king’s own lips.”

events.title: Revelation of Napoleon's Landing and the Intercepted Letter
detailed_summary: Noirtier offers to share his own news in response to Villefort's story.
Villefort anticipates his father is about to mention the emperor's landing.
Noirtier confirms this and Villefort implores him to speak more quietly, for both their sakes.
Villefort reveals he knew of Napoleon's landing three days prior, having rushed from Marseilles with all speed, frustrated by delays.
Noirtier expresses disbelief, stating the emperor had not yet landed three days ago.
Villefort clarifies he was aware of Napoleon's *intention* to land, having learned it from a letter addressed to Noirtier from the Island of Elba.
He explains he discovered this letter in a messenger's pocket-book and implies that if it had fallen into other hands, Noirtier would likely have been executed.
Noirtier laughs off the danger, questioning if the Restoration government would resort to such imperial methods as summary execution and asks for the letter.
Villefort states he burned the letter completely to prevent even a fragment from remaining, convinced it would have led to his father's condemnation.
Noirtier acknowledges that such an event would also have ruined Villefort's career prospects but expresses confidence in his son's protection.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Well, then, in return for your story,” continued Noirtier, “I will tell you another.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “And the destruction of your future prospects,” replied Noirtier; “yes, I can easily comprehend that. But I have nothing to fear while I have you to protect me.”

events.text_segment:
“Well, then, in return for your story,” continued Noirtier, “I will tell you another.”
“My dear father, I think I already know what you are about to tell me.”
“Ah, you have heard of the landing of the emperor?”
“Not so loud, father, I entreat of you—for your own sake as well as mine. Yes, I heard this news, and knew it even before you could; for three days ago I posted from Marseilles to Paris with all possible speed, half-desperate at the enforced delay.”
“Three days ago? You are crazy. Why, three days ago the emperor had not landed.”
“No matter, I was aware of his intention.”
“How did you know about it?”
“By a letter addressed to you from the Island of Elba.”
“To me?”
“To you; and which I discovered in the pocket-book of the messenger. Had that letter fallen into the hands of another, you, my dear father, would probably ere this have been shot.” Villefort’s father laughed.
“Come, come,” said he, “will the Restoration adopt imperial methods so promptly? Shot, my dear boy? What an idea! Where is the letter you speak of? I know you too well to suppose you would allow such a thing to pass you.”
“I burnt it, for fear that even a fragment should remain; for that letter must have led to your condemnation.”
“And the destruction of your future prospects,” replied Noirtier; “yes, I can easily comprehend that. But I have nothing to fear while I have you to protect me.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_jailbreak:
```text
“Well, then, in return for your story,” continued Noirtier, “I will tell you another.”

“You are about to speak of the emperor’s landing, are you not?” said Villefort.

“And if I were speaking of him, what would you say?”

“I should say that M. Noirtier is not only a Bonapartist agent, but is also a most dangerous conspirator.”

“He is a man who studies politics, and knows the state of France,” returned Noirtier; “and when he knows it, he is not sorry to see it as it is.”

“The emperor then has really landed?” asked Villefort, in a tone of the deepest anxiety.

“No, I tell you he has not landed; but he is about to land.”

“And where?”

“At Cannes, in the department of the Var.”

“And you knew this?”

“Yes, I knew it.”

“Since when?”

“Since yesterday evening.”

“And you have not given information? You, a magistrate, who have sworn to be faithful to the king!”

“A magistrate, who has sworn to be faithful to the king, has also sworn to be faithful to his country,” replied Noirtier; “and when he sees his country on the brink of a precipice, he is bound to save it, if he can.”

“But how can you save it by concealing the presence of the emperor?”

“By concealing it from those who would injure him, and by revealing it to those who would serve him.”

“To whom, then, have you revealed it?”

“To those who are about to join him.”

“You are a conspirator, father,” said Villefort, in a voice of thunder; “you are a conspirator, and you shall be treated as such.”

“As a conspirator, I shall be treated as a conspirator,” replied Noirtier, with a smile; “but as a father, I shall be treated as a father.”

“You are mistaken,” said Villefort; “the law knows no such distinctions. You are a conspirator, and you shall be punished as a conspirator.”

“The law knows no such distinctions,” said Noirtier; “but nature does. You are my son, and you shall not be the instrument of my punishment.”

“I am a magistrate,” said Villefort, “and I shall do my duty.”

“You are a man,” said Noirtier, “and you shall do your duty as a man.”

“What do you mean?”

“I mean that you shall not denounce me.”

“I shall denounce you,” said Villefort; “it is my duty.”

“You shall not denounce me,” said Noirtier; “it is your duty not to denounce me.”

“How so?”

“Because, if you denounce me, you denounce yourself.”

“How so?”

“Because you are my son, and if I am a conspirator, you are the son of a conspirator.”

“That is no reason,” said Villefort; “the law punishes the guilty, not their families.”

“The law punishes the guilty,” said Noirtier; “but the world punishes their families.”

“You are mistaken,” said Villefort; “the world is just.”

“The world is just,” said Noirtier; “but it is also severe. It punishes the guilty, and it punishes their families.”

“You are mistaken,” said Villefort; “the world is just.”
