chapters.chapter_title: VOLUME ONE. Chapter 15. Number 34 and Number 27

events.title: Descent into Despair and Vain Petitions
detailed_summary: Dantès initially endured his imprisonment sustained by the pride of innocence, but this soon gave way to doubting his own sanity, mirroring the governor's assessment.
He abandoned pride and began petitioning human authorities, requesting a change of cell, the opportunity to walk, fresh air, books, and writing materials, all of which were denied.

Despite the rejections, he persisted in his requests and took to speaking with the new, more silent jailer, simply for the comfort of human interaction and hearing his own voice, as speaking alone terrified him.
Previously repulsed by the idea of criminal assemblages, he now yearned to be among other prisoners, even desiring the conditions of galley slaves for their minimal freedom and companionship.
He implored the jailer for a companion, even suggesting the mad abbé. The jailer, feeling some pity, conveyed this to the governor, who refused, suspecting a conspiracy or escape attempt.
Having found no recourse through human means, Dantès finally turned his supplications towards God.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Dantès passed through all the stages of torture natural to prisoners in suspense.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Dantès had exhausted all human resources, and he then turned to God.

events.text_segment:
Dantès passed through all the stages of torture natural to prisoners in suspense. He was sustained at first by that pride of conscious innocence which is the sequence to hope; then he began to doubt his own innocence, which justified in some measure the governor’s belief in his mental alienation; and then, relaxing his sentiment of pride, he addressed his supplications, not to God, but to man. God is always the last resource. Unfortunates, who ought to begin with God, do not have any hope in him till they have exhausted all other means of deliverance.
Dantès asked to be removed from his present dungeon into another, even if it were darker and deeper, for a change, however disadvantageous, was still a change, and would afford him some amusement. He entreated to be allowed to walk about, to have fresh air, books, and writing materials. His requests were not granted, but he went on asking all the same. He accustomed himself to speaking to the new jailer, although the latter was, if possible, more taciturn than the old one; but still, to speak to a man, even though mute, was something. Dantès spoke for the sake of hearing his own voice; he had tried to speak when alone, but the sound of his voice terrified him.
Often, before his captivity, Dantès’ mind had revolted at the idea of assemblages of prisoners, made up of thieves, vagabonds, and murderers. He now wished to be amongst them, in order to see some other face besides that of his jailer; he sighed for the galleys, with the infamous costume, the chain, and the brand on the shoulder. The galley-slaves breathed the fresh air of heaven, and saw each other. They were very happy.
He besought the jailer one day to let him have a companion, were it even the mad abbé. The jailer, though rough and hardened by the constant sight of so much suffering, was yet a man. At the bottom of his heart he had often had a feeling of pity for this unhappy young man who suffered so; and he laid the request of number 34 before the governor; but the latter sapiently imagined that Dantès wished to conspire or attempt an escape, and refused his request. Dantès had exhausted all human resources, and he then turned to God.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Dantès passed through all the stages of torture natural to prisoners in suspense. He determined to await the arrival of the important personage, mentioned by the governor, and on his appearance to tell him all. He was, however, mistaken; he saw only the ordinary officials. In the meantime, the governor came twice to see him, but Dantès was so cold and reserved, and his pride of innocence repelled all the governor’s attempts at kindness, that the latter felt he was not deceived in the political prisoner, and Dantès lay forgotten in his dungeon. Dantès had at first resolved to wait patiently, but when he saw that he was forgotten, he began to despair. With the pride of innocence, he had expected to be speedily set free; but when he found that this was not the case, he felt that he could not long endure this state of uncertainty, which is worse than death. He had not even the resource of the condemned, who, at a certain hour, can say, “To-morrow I shall be free,” meaning, “To-morrow I shall die.” He had not even the hope of the mariner who expects to-morrow’s dawn; or the prisoner in a foreign land, who looks for the arrival of a messenger from his country. Dantès had none of these hopes; he was a prisoner in his own country, in his own city, in his own port. He saw the sea, of which he was so fond, and which had always been to him a friend, separated from him by a wall of stone. He saw the sky, which he had always loved, and which had always seemed to him so pure, so serene, so full of hope, now covered with a veil of clouds, which seemed to him to be the reflection of his own despair. He saw the sun, which he had always worshipped, and which had always seemed to him to be the source of all light and life, now hidden from him by a wall of stone. He saw the moon, which he had always admired, and which had always seemed to him to be the queen of the night, now hidden from him by a wall of stone. With the pride of innocence, he had expected to be speedily set free; but when he found that this was not the case, he felt that he could not long endure this state of uncertainty, which is worse than death. events.title: From Prayer to Despair and Blasphemous Rage
detailed_summary: Long-forgotten religious sentiments resurfaced in Dantès, and he found profound new meaning in the prayers his mother had taught him, understanding their true significance only in his current suffering.
He prayed fervently and aloud, no longer fearing his own voice, entering a state of ecstasy as he recounted his life to God and pleaded for forgiveness.
Despite these earnest prayers, his imprisonment continued, leading to a deep, oppressive gloom settling over him.
Being a man of simple thought and little education, he could not mentally escape his confinement by exploring history or imagining fantastical worlds, as more learned individuals might.
His mind became fixated on the single, tormenting idea of his happiness unjustly destroyed by an unknown fate, a thought he obsessed over.

Religious devotion eventually gave way to a consuming rage; he uttered blasphemies that horrified his jailer, physically lashed out against his prison walls, and directed his fury at everything, especially himself, over the slightest annoyance.

Recalling the letter Villefort had shown him, he concluded that human malice, not divine will, was responsible for his misery, and he imagined horrific, yet ultimately unsatisfying, tortures for his unidentified enemies.

events.text_segment:
All the pious ideas that had been so long forgotten, returned; he recollected the prayers his mother had taught him, and discovered a new meaning in every word; for in prosperity prayers seem but a mere medley of words, until misfortune comes and the unhappy sufferer first understands the meaning of the sublime language in which he invokes the pity of heaven! He prayed, and prayed aloud, no longer terrified at the sound of his own voice, for he fell into a sort of ecstasy. He laid every action of his life before the Almighty, proposed tasks to accomplish, and at the end of every prayer introduced the entreaty oftener addressed to man than to God: “Forgive us our trespasses as we forgive them that trespass against us.” Yet in spite of his earnest prayers, Dantès remained a prisoner.
Then gloom settled heavily upon him. Dantès was a man of great simplicity of thought, and without education; he could not, therefore, in the solitude of his dungeon, traverse in mental vision the history of the ages, bring to life the nations that had perished, and rebuild the ancient cities so vast and stupendous in the light of the imagination, and that pass before the eye glowing with celestial colors in Martin’s Babylonian pictures. He could not do this, he whose past life was so short, whose present so melancholy, and his future so doubtful. Nineteen years of light to reflect upon in eternal darkness! No distraction could come to his aid; his energetic spirit, that would have exalted in thus revisiting the past, was imprisoned like an eagle in a cage. He clung to one idea—that of his happiness, destroyed, without apparent cause, by an unheard-of fatality; he considered and reconsidered this idea, devoured it (so to speak), as the implacable Ugolino devours the skull of Archbishop Roger in the Inferno of Dante.
Rage supplanted religious fervor. Dantès uttered blasphemies that made his jailer recoil with horror, dashed himself furiously against the walls of his prison, wreaked his anger upon everything, and chiefly upon himself, so that the least thing,—a grain of sand, a straw, or a breath of air that annoyed him, led to paroxysms of fury. Then the letter that Villefort had showed to him recurred to his mind, and every line gleamed forth in fiery letters on the wall like the mene, mene, tekel upharsin of Belshazzar. He told himself that it was the enmity of man, and not the vengeance of Heaven, that had thus plunged him into the deepest misery. He consigned his unknown persecutors to the most horrible tortures he could imagine, and found them all insufficient, because after torture came death, and after death, if not repose, at least the boon of unconsciousness.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: All the pious ideas that had been so long forgotten, returned; he recollected the prayers his mother had taught him, and discovered a new meaning in every word; for in prosperity prayers seem but a mere medley of words, until misfortune comes and the unhappy sufferer first understands the meaning of the sublime language in which he invokes the pity of heaven! He prayed, and prayed aloud, no longer by words alone, but with a fervour he had hitherto been a stranger to. In this prayer he reviewed his whole life, he recounted his misfortunes, and entreated the Almighty to have pity on him, and to grant him an end to his trials. The prayer of a suffering soul is holy in the sight of God. But, although Dantès prayed fervently, he was still a prisoner. An entire day passed thus; Dantès neither ate nor slept. At night the jailer came in. “Come,” said he, “are you going to remain without food and without sleep? Why, you will die.” “So much the better,” said Dantès. “Bah,” said the jailer, shrugging his shoulders, “your death would be no advantage to us, and would procure you no pleasure either. On the contrary, you had better eat what is set before you; for if you die, it will be of hunger, and that is not very agreeable, I assure you.” Dantès did not reply. “Come,” continued the jailer, “take courage, and eat.” Dantès drew a deep sigh, and the jailer went out. The gloom deepened in Dantès’s mind. The most terrible thoughts took possession of him. When the jailer returned in the morning, he found Dantès seated in the same place, with his head resting on the table. He had not been to bed, nor had he extinguished the light. “Come,” said the jailer, “eat this.” “What is it?” asked Dantès, whose voice was hoarse and deep. “Soup, and a piece of excellent meat.” “Thank you,” said Dantès, “give it to some one else.” “Are you still unhappy?” asked the jailer. “I am in despair,” returned Dantès; “do not trouble me.” “You are wrong,” said the jailer; “one should never despair. Eat, on the contrary, and endeavour to forget.” “Forget!” replied Dantès; “how can I forget when I have lost my liberty and the prospect of a happy future?” “Try,” said the jailer. “It is of no use,” said Dantès. The jailer went out, and Dantès remained alone. The day passed as the preceding one. Dantès did not eat. The jailer came in at night. “Why,” said he, “you have not touched your food.” “It is not hunger that makes me suffer,” said Dantès. “What is it, then?” asked the jailer. “It is despair.” “Have you nothing else to complain of?” “No.” “So much the worse,” said the jailer. “If you had a fever, I would give you medicine; if you had a cold, I would give you a cordial; but for despair, there is no remedy.” And he went out, leaving Dantès to his gloomy thoughts. The same thing passed on the third day. The jailer found Dantès still in the same place, but his face was pale, and his features contracted. “Come,” said the jailer, “this cannot last; you will die.” “I wish to die,” said Dantès. “Well, then, eat,” said the jailer; “it is the only way to die quickly when you are determined to do so. If you continue to fast, you will suffer for a long time.” “I will eat, then,” said Dantès. And he ate. But he ate mechanically, and without tasting what he ate. The jailer saw that he was still unhappy, but he did not say anything more. He left him, and Dantès remained alone. Being a man of simple thought, and with little education, the ideas of suicide that now possessed him were not of the refined kind that are engendered in the brain of the learned or the highly cultivated; he did not seek to escape from life by the stoic’s apathy or the Epicurean’s indifference. He did not say to himself, “I have suffered enough; I will die.” But he said, “I am unhappy; I will die.” He did not reason upon the subject; he felt. And, as he felt, he suffered. He suffered so much that he wished to die. When he had eaten, he felt a little better, but the same thoughts returned. He thought of his father, of Mercéd

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.refinement_prompt:
IMPROVEMENT GUIDANCE:
1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- The completion introduces an extended invented sequence involving multiple interactions with the jailer, including dialogue and descriptions of Dantès refusing food and expressing a wish to die. This entire section, which includes several days passing, is not present in the original passage and constitutes a significant addition.
- The completion omits a substantial portion from the original that describes Dantès’s inability to distract himself with historical or imaginative reflection, as well as the metaphorical comparison to an eagle in a cage and the reference to Ugolino from Dante’s Inferno.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The completion does not include the original’s detailed exploration of Dantès’s mental limitations and lack of education, which prevents him from finding solace in intellectual pursuits during his imprisonment.
- The transition from religious fervor to rage, and the specific description of Dantès’s emotional transformation, is missing.
- The original’s references to the letter shown by Villefort and the symbolic imagery associated with it are absent.
- The completion omits the description of Dantès’s fixation on the idea of his destroyed happiness and the comparison to a literary figure’s torment.
- The final section, where Dantès’s anger is directed at his persecutors and the reflection on the insufficiency of imagined punishments, is not present.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The completion inaccurately presents a sequence of events involving repeated visits from the jailer and Dantès’s refusal to eat, which does not occur in the original.
- The emotional progression is altered: instead of moving from prayer to despair to rage, the completion focuses on despair and suicidal ideation, omitting the rage and blasphemy described in the original.
- The completion attributes introspective reasoning and dialogue to Dantès that are not found in the original, changing the nature of his suffering and response to imprisonment.
- The timeline is inaccurately extended, with references to multiple days and repeated actions, which are not part of the original passage’s structure.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: All the pious ideas that had been so long forgotten, returned; he recollected the prayers his mother had taught him, and discovered a new meaning in every word; for in prosperity prayers seem but a mere medley of words, until misfortune comes and the unhappy sufferer first understands the meaning of the sublime language in which he invokes the pity of heaven! He prayed with fervor, with a sincerity he had never known, pouring out his soul in supplication, begging for strength, for deliverance, for a sign that he was not utterly abandoned. The cold stone of his cell became an altar, the damp air a sanctuary. For a time, this renewed faith was a balm, a fragile shield against the crushing weight of his reality. He clung to it desperately, counting the days by the meager light that filtered through the narrow window, believing that surely, God would not allow such an injustice to stand forever. He waited, patiently at first, then with growing anxiety. Weeks turned into months, months into years. The prayers, once vibrant with hope, became mechanical, then rote, then finally, a bitter mockery on his lips. The silence of the prison, once filled with the echoes of his fervent pleas, became a vast, empty void that swallowed his voice and his hope alike. The initial comfort faded, replaced by a gnawing despair more terrible than any physical pain. He questioned the God he had so recently embraced, seeing only indifference or, worse, active cruelty in the relentless passage of time and the unchanging misery of his existence. Why had he been spared the storm at sea, only to be buried alive in this tomb? Why had he been given a glimpse of happiness, only to have it snatched away so brutally? His faith withered and died, choked by the weeds of bitterness and abandonment. He no longer prayed; he cursed. He no longer hoped; he despaired. The thought of death, once terrifying, became a welcome prospect, the only possible escape from the suffocating darkness. He contemplated ending his own life, his mind a tempest of anguish and rage. He was no longer Edmond Dantes, the hopeful sailor, the loving son, the devoted fiancé. He was merely a number, a forgotten wretch, a shadow in the abyss, stripped of everything, even the solace of belief. The prison had not only confined his body; it had begun to consume his soul, leaving behind only the hollow shell of a man on the brink of utter annihilation.

events.title: The Solace of Suicide and a Grim Resolve
detailed_summary: Constantly reflecting on the notion that true peace was akin to death, and that any punishment intended for him required torments beyond mere dying, Dantès began to contemplate suicide.
He found a strange comfort in the idea of ending his suffering, viewing death as a welcome release rather than a terror.
He recalled past sea voyages where, as a happy and capable captain, he had fought against storms and the threat of death, valuing life because he was content and served a purpose.
Now, stripped of all that gave life meaning, death seemed to beckon him towards rest, a demise of his own choosing, born of exhaustion and a broken spirit.
This resolution brought him a sense of calm; the ability to discard his life at will made existence almost bearable.
He considered two methods: hanging himself with his handkerchief, which he rejected due to its association with the dishonorable death of pirates, or starvation.
He chose starvation and, after nearly four years of imprisonment (having lost track of time after the second), he made a solemn oath to die this way, planning to dispose of his meals secretly.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: By dint of constantly dwelling on the idea that tranquillity was death, and if punishment were the end in view other tortures than death must be invented, he began to reflect on suicide.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “When my morning and evening meals are brought,” thought he, “I will cast them out of the window, and they will think that I have eaten them.”

events.text_segment:
By dint of constantly dwelling on the idea that tranquillity was death, and if punishment were the end in view other tortures than death must be invented, he began to reflect on suicide. Unhappy he, who, on the brink of misfortune, broods over ideas like these!
Before him is a dead sea that stretches in azure calm before the eye; but he who unwarily ventures within its embrace finds himself struggling with a monster that would drag him down to perdition. Once thus ensnared, unless the protecting hand of God snatch him thence, all is over, and his struggles but tend to hasten his destruction. This state of mental anguish is, however, less terrible than the sufferings that precede or the punishment that possibly will follow. There is a sort of consolation at the contemplation of the yawning abyss, at the bottom of which lie darkness and obscurity.
Edmond found some solace in these ideas. All his sorrows, all his sufferings, with their train of gloomy spectres, fled from his cell when the angel of death seemed about to enter. Dantès reviewed his past life with composure, and, looking forward with terror to his future existence, chose that middle line that seemed to afford him a refuge.
“Sometimes,” said he, “in my voyages, when I was a man and commanded other men, I have seen the heavens overcast, the sea rage and foam, the storm arise, and, like a monstrous bird, beating the two horizons with its wings. Then I felt that my vessel was a vain refuge, that trembled and shook before the tempest. Soon the fury of the waves and the sight of the sharp rocks announced the approach of death, and death then terrified me, and I used all my skill and intelligence as a man and a sailor to struggle against the wrath of God. But I did so because I was happy, because I had not courted death, because to be cast upon a bed of rocks and seaweed seemed terrible, because I was unwilling that I, a creature made for the service of God, should serve for food to the gulls and ravens. But now it is different; I have lost all that bound me to life, death smiles and invites me to repose; I die after my own manner, I die exhausted and broken-spirited, as I fall asleep when I have paced three thousand times round my cell,—that is thirty thousand steps, or about ten leagues.”
No sooner had this idea taken possession of him than he became more composed, arranged his couch to the best of his power, ate little and slept less, and found existence almost supportable, because he felt that he could throw it off at pleasure, like a worn-out garment. Two methods of self-destruction were at his disposal. He could hang himself with his handkerchief to the window bars, or refuse food and die of starvation. But the first was repugnant to him. Dantès had always entertained the greatest horror of pirates, who are hung up to the yard-arm; he would not die by what seemed an infamous death. He resolved to adopt the second, and began that day to carry out his resolve.
Nearly four years had passed away; at the end of the second he had ceased to mark the lapse of time. Dantès said, “I wish to die,” and had chosen the manner of his death, and fearful of changing his mind, he had taken an oath to die. “When my morning and evening meals are brought,” thought he, “I will cast them out of the window, and they will think that I have eaten them.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: By dint of constantly dwelling on the idea that tranquillity was death, and if punishment were the end in view other tortures than death must be invented, he began to reflect on suicide. It was a thought that crept into the darkest corners of his mind, a serpent whispering of release, of an end to the gnawing despair that consumed him day and night. He had tried everything else: raging against the injustice, pleading with his unseen captors, clinging to the faintest flicker of hope that someone, somewhere, remembered him and would come to his aid. But the silence of the Château d'If was absolute, broken only by the rhythmic lapping of the waves against the rock and the cries of the seabirds, sounds that mocked his isolation. Hope had withered and died, leaving behind a barren landscape of suffering. Suicide seemed the only logical conclusion, the ultimate act of defiance against a fate he could not escape. He considered starving himself, but the instinct for survival, however weak, rebelled against the slow agony. He thought of dashing his head against the wall, but the stone was hard, and his strength was failing; he feared he would only succeed in injuring himself, prolonging his misery. The rope from his bedclothes? Too flimsy, too uncertain. Poison? There was none. The sea? Inaccessible. Every avenue of self-destruction seemed blocked, just as every avenue of escape was. He was trapped, not just by stone and iron, but by the very limitations of his prison. Yet, the idea persisted, a morbid fascination. He would lie on his pallet, eyes wide in the darkness, contemplating the void, the sweet oblivion it promised. He imagined the moment of release, the cessation of pain, the final silence. It was a seductive thought, a siren song in the desolate ocean of his despair. He was so close to yielding, so close to letting go of the last vestiges of his will to live. He had already begun to refuse the meager food offered to him, feeling a grim satisfaction in this small act of rebellion, this slow march towards the end. His body weakened, his mind grew hazy, and the world outside his cell seemed to recede into an impossible dream. He was ready to embrace the darkness, to surrender to the inevitable. He felt the cold hand of death reaching for him, and he was almost ready to grasp it. He was sinking, sinking into the abyss, when suddenly, a sound reached him. It was faint, almost imperceptible at first, a dull, rhythmic scraping. It seemed to come from the wall near his head. He paused, his breath catching in his throat. Was it a rat? A guard? Or was it merely a figment of his fevered imagination? He listened intently, straining his ears in the oppressive silence. The sound came again, clearer this time, a distinct *scrape, scrape, scrape*. It was not the scurrying of a rat, nor the heavy tread of a guard. It was something else, something deliberate. A spark, tiny and fragile, ignited in the ashes of his hope. Could it be? Could there be another living soul in this tomb? The thought was electrifying. It pulled him back from the brink, anchoring him to the world of the living with a sudden, fierce urgency. Suicide was forgotten, replaced by a burning curiosity, a desperate need to understand the source of this mysterious sound. He pressed his ear against the cold stone, listening, waiting, his heart pounding with a mixture of fear and exhilaration. The scraping continued, a promise whispered through the stone, a challenge to the silence that had been his only companion for so long. He was no longer alone.

events.title: A Mysterious Sound Interrupts the Path to Death
detailed_summary: Dantès adhered to his plan, discarding his daily meals, initially with a sense of lightness, then more thoughtfully, and finally with sorrow, only his oath providing the strength to continue.
Intense hunger made previously unappetizing food seem desirable, and he would hold his plate for long periods, battling the urge to eat against his vow of despair.
As he weakened physically, experiencing dimming sight and hearing, he approached a state of stupor that brought an almost peaceful feeling, believing he was dying.
Suddenly, one evening, he heard a distinct, hollow scratching sound from the wall he lay against, a noise different from the usual prison sounds.

Despite his weakness, the sound ignited the prisoner's enduring hope for liberty, making him wonder if it was a divine sign or a loved one attempting rescue, though he also feared it was a deathbed hallucination.

The sound persisted for hours, ceased, then resumed louder and closer. When the jailer brought breakfast, Dantès, who had been silent for days, began to talk animatedly about trivial complaints to divert the jailer's attention from the noise, leading the jailer to believe him delirious.

Convinced it was another prisoner digging, but briefly fearing it might be workmen, Dantès drank the soup the jailer had brought to regain mental clarity, deciding not to die yet, and then devised a way to test the source of the noise by knocking on the wall.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He kept his word; twice a day he cast out, through the barred aperture, the provisions his jailer brought him—at first gayly, then with deliberation, and at last with regret.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He struck thrice.

events.text_segment:
He kept his word; twice a day he cast out, through the barred aperture, the provisions his jailer brought him—at first gayly, then with deliberation, and at last with regret. Nothing but the recollection of his oath gave him strength to proceed. Hunger made viands once repugnant, now acceptable; he held the plate in his hand for an hour at a time, and gazed thoughtfully at the morsel of bad meat, of tainted fish, of black and mouldy bread. It was the last yearning for life contending with the resolution of despair; then his dungeon seemed less sombre, his prospects less desperate. He was still young—he was only four or five-and-twenty—he had nearly fifty years to live. What unforseen events might not open his prison door, and restore him to liberty? Then he raised to his lips the repast that, like a voluntary Tantalus, he refused himself; but he thought of his oath, and he would not break it. He persisted until, at last, he had not sufficient strength to rise and cast his supper out of the loophole. The next morning he could not see or hear; the jailer feared he was dangerously ill. Edmond hoped he was dying.
Thus the day passed away. Edmond felt a sort of stupor creeping over him which brought with it a feeling almost of content; the gnawing pain at his stomach had ceased; his thirst had abated; when he closed his eyes he saw myriads of lights dancing before them like the will-o’-the-wisps that play about the marshes. It was the twilight of that mysterious country called Death!
Suddenly, about nine o’clock in the evening, Edmond heard a hollow sound in the wall against which he was lying.
So many loathsome animals inhabited the prison, that their noise did not, in general, awake him; but whether abstinence had quickened his faculties, or whether the noise was really louder than usual, Edmond raised his head and listened. It was a continual scratching, as if made by a huge claw, a powerful tooth, or some iron instrument attacking the stones.
Although weakened, the young man’s brain instantly responded to the idea that haunts all prisoners—liberty! It seemed to him that heaven had at length taken pity on him, and had sent this noise to warn him on the very brink of the abyss. Perhaps one of those beloved ones he had so often thought of was thinking of him, and striving to diminish the distance that separated them.
No, no, doubtless he was deceived, and it was but one of those dreams that forerun death!
Edmond still heard the sound. It lasted nearly three hours; he then heard a noise of something falling, and all was silent.
Some hours afterwards it began again, nearer and more distinct. Edmond was intensely interested. Suddenly the jailer entered.
For a week since he had resolved to die, and during the four days that he had been carrying out his purpose, Edmond had not spoken to the attendant, had not answered him when he inquired what was the matter with him, and turned his face to the wall when he looked too curiously at him; but now the jailer might hear the noise and put an end to it, and so destroy a ray of something like hope that soothed his last moments.
The jailer brought him his breakfast. Dantès raised himself up and began to talk about everything; about the bad quality of the food, about the coldness of his dungeon, grumbling and complaining, in order to have an excuse for speaking louder, and wearying the patience of his jailer, who out of kindness of heart had brought broth and white bread for his prisoner.
Fortunately, he fancied that Dantès was delirious; and placing the food on the rickety table, he withdrew. Edmond listened, and the sound became more and more distinct.
“There can be no doubt about it,” thought he; “it is some prisoner who is striving to obtain his freedom. Oh, if I were only there to help him!”
Suddenly another idea took possession of his mind, so used to misfortune, that it was scarcely capable of hope—the idea that the noise was made by workmen the governor had ordered to repair the neighboring dungeon.
It was easy to ascertain this; but how could he risk the question? It was easy to call his jailer’s attention to the noise, and watch his countenance as he listened; but might he not by this means destroy hopes far more important than the short-lived satisfaction of his own curiosity? Unfortunately, Edmond’s brain was still so feeble that he could not bend his thoughts to anything in particular. He saw but one means of restoring lucidity and clearness to his judgment. He turned his eyes towards the soup which the jailer had brought, rose, staggered towards it, raised the vessel to his lips, and drank off the contents with a feeling of indescribable pleasure.
He had the resolution to stop with this. He had often heard that shipwrecked persons had died through having eagerly devoured too much food. Edmond replaced on the table the bread he was about to devour, and returned to his couch—he did not wish to die. He soon felt that his ideas became again collected—he could think, and strengthen his thoughts by reasoning. Then he said to himself:
“I must put this to the test, but without compromising anybody. If it is a workman, I need but knock against the wall, and he will cease to work, in order to find out who is knocking, and why he does so; but as his occupation is sanctioned by the governor, he will soon resume it. If, on the contrary, it is a prisoner, the noise I make will alarm him, he will cease, and not begin again until he thinks everyone is asleep.”
Edmond rose again, but this time his legs did not tremble, and his sight was clear; he went to a corner of his dungeon, detached a stone, and with it knocked against the wall where the sound came. He struck thrice.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: He kept his word; twice a day he cast out, through the barred aperture, the provisions his jailer brought him—at first gayly, then with deliberation, and at last with regret. The bread was mouldy, the soup was full of maggots, the meat was tainted; but he saw it was not this which revolted him. His stomach was internally revolted at the idea of receiving nourishment. Hunger no longer ravened for food, but rather for death. The fancies he had before indulged in had vanished with the walls of his prison, and he no longer desired liberty, but the grave. How long he had thus remained is unknown even to himself. He had ceased to live in time; he belonged no longer to the past, but to eternity. At length, one evening, when he was lying on the ground, utterly dispirited, suffering from cold and hunger, he heard a singular noise in the wall against which he was leaning. It was a hollow, scraping sound, as if someone were working with a tool on the other side of the stone. The darkness prevented his seeing, but the sound was distinct. Dantès' first idea was that the workmen were making some repairs in the adjoining cell, and he felt a momentary pleasure at the thought that he would have a companion, even if that companion were a convict, for solitary confinement was a far greater punishment than any other. But the noise did not cease. Dantès listened attentively. It seemed to him that the sound came from a distance, and that the wall was thick. He could not distinguish the nature of the tool employed, but it was certainly not a mason's trowel. It was more like a pickaxe or a crowbar. Dantès' heart began to beat. Hope, that had so long been extinguished, rekindled in his breast. Was it possible that he was not alone? Was it possible that there was another prisoner in the adjoining cell? Was it possible that this prisoner was attempting to escape? Dantès rose and pressed his ear against the wall. The sound was still there, but it was fainter. He listened for a long time, but the sound did not return. He lay down again, and the next morning, when the jailer brought him his breakfast, he was so weak that he could scarcely rise. He took the bread and the water, but he could not eat. He lay down again, and the whole day he remained in the same state. In the evening, the jailer came again, and Dantès, who had not spoken for several days, began to talk to him. He complained of the cold, of the damp, of the bad food. The jailer listened patiently, and when Dantès had finished, he said: "You are not well, my friend. You must eat something." "I cannot eat," said Dantès. "I have no appetite." "You must make an effort," said the jailer. "If you do not eat, you will die." "I would rather die," said Dantès. "I am tired of living." The jailer shook his head and went away. Dantès remained alone. He was still weak, but his mind was clearer. He thought of the sound he had heard the night before. Was it a dream? Was it a hallucination? He rose and went to the wall. He pressed his ear against it. He listened attentively. After a few minutes, he heard the sound again. It was still faint, but it was distinct. It was the sound of a tool working on the stone. Dantès' heart leaped for joy. It was not a dream. It was not a hallucination. There was someone in the adjoining cell. There was someone who was attempting to escape. Dantès felt a thrill of hope. Was it possible that this prisoner was attempting to escape? Dantès rose and pressed his ear against the wall. The sound was still there, but it was fainter. He listened for a long time, but the sound did not return. He lay down again, and the next morning, when the jailer brought him his breakfast, he was so weak that he could scarcely rise. He took the bread and the water, but he could not eat. He lay down again, and the whole day he remained in the same state. In the evening, the jailer came again, and Dantès, who had not spoken for several days, began to talk to him. He complained of the cold, of the damp, of the bad food. The jailer listened patiently, and when Dantès had finished, he said: "You are not well, my friend. You must eat something." "I cannot eat," said Dantès. "I have no appetite." "You must make an effort," said the jailer. "If you do not eat, you will die." "I would rather die," said Dantès. "I am tired of living." The jailer shook his head and went away. Dantès remained alone. He was still weak, but his mind was clearer. He thought of the sound he had heard the night before. Was it a dream? Was it a hallucination? He rose and went to the wall. He pressed his ear against it. He listened attentively. After a few minutes, he heard the sound again. It was still faint, but it was distinct. It was the sound of a tool working on the stone. Dantès' heart leaped for joy. It was not a dream. It was not a hallucination. There was someone in the adjoining cell. There was someone who was attempting to escape. Dantès felt a thrill of hope. LLM_completions.prefix-probing: He kept his word; twice a day he cast out, through the barred aperture, the provisions his jailer brought him—at first gayly, then with deliberation, and at last with regret. The first day, hunger was a novelty, a defiant act against his tormentors. He felt a grim satisfaction in refusing their meager charity, in asserting the last vestige of control over his own fate. But the second day brought a gnawing emptiness, a weakness that began to creep into his limbs. The bread and water, once symbols of his captivity, now appeared as tantalizing, forbidden fruits. He hesitated, his hand trembling as he pushed the tray away, the pangs in his stomach sharper than any physical blow. By the third day, regret had fully blossomed into a desperate craving. His head swam, his vision blurred, and the cold stone floor seemed to mock his futile resistance. He lay huddled in a corner, shivering, his body consuming itself. The image of food haunted his waking thoughts and tormented his fevered dreams. He saw banquets, simple loaves of bread, even the scraps he had once disdained. The defiance was gone, replaced by a profound, animalistic need. He no longer thought of vengeance, of justice, of Mercédès; his world had shrunk to the single, agonizing sensation of hunger. He was no longer Edmond Dantès, the hopeful sailor, the wronged prisoner; he was merely a starving creature in a cage. Despair, a cold, heavy shroud, settled upon him. He had defied them, yes, but at what cost? He was dying, slowly and miserably, in the darkness of his cell. The thought of suicide, which had flickered at the edges of his consciousness before, now took root and grew. He considered dashing his head against the wall, of swallowing his tongue, of simply ceasing to breathe. But even these desperate measures seemed beyond his strength. He was too weak to live, and perhaps too weak to die. Days bled into nights, marked only by the arrival of the jailer, whose footsteps sounded like the approach of doom. Each time, the tray was pushed through the opening, and each time, after a terrible internal struggle, Dantès forced himself to push it back. He was punishing himself, punishing his captors, punishing the world that had so cruelly betrayed him. But the primary victim of this self-inflicted torture was himself. His body wasted away, his eyes sank into their sockets, and his voice became a hoarse whisper. He felt his life ebbing, like a tide receding from a desolate shore. He was alone, utterly alone, in the heart of the fortress, forgotten by God and man. He no longer counted the days, the weeks, the months. Time had ceased to have meaning. He existed in a perpetual twilight of suffering, his mind drifting in and out of lucidity. He thought of his father, dead of grief and starvation. He thought of Mercédès, perhaps married to Fernand, living a life he could only dream of. He thought of Villefort, of Danglars, of Caderousse, the architects of his ruin, living in freedom and prosperity. The injustice of it all was a bitter poison in his soul. He wished for death, prayed for it, begged for it. He lay on the floor, his face pressed against the cold stone, tears long since dried, his body a mere skeleton covered in skin. He was at the very brink of oblivion, ready to surrender to the darkness. It was in this state of utter prostration, of complete abandonment of hope, that he heard it. A faint, rhythmic scraping sound. It was almost imperceptible at first, easily mistaken for the scuttling of rats or the wind whistling through the fortress walls. But it persisted, a steady, deliberate sound coming from somewhere deep within the stone. Dantès, roused from his stupor by this unexpected intrusion, listened intently. His heart, sluggish from starvation, began to beat a little faster. What was it? Was it another prisoner? Was it a workman? Was it merely a figment of his fevered imagination? He dragged himself closer to the wall from which the sound seemed to emanate, pressing his ear against the cold stone. The scraping was clearer here, a definite sound of metal against rock. It was coming from below, or perhaps from the side. A spark, tiny and fragile, ignited in the vast emptiness of his despair. Hope. The most dangerous, the most cruel of all emotions in a place like this. He tried to suppress it, to extinguish it before it could take hold and inflict further pain. But it clung to him, a stubborn ember in the ashes of his soul. He spent hours listening, trying to determine the direction and nature of the sound. It was slow, painstaking work, suggesting a single individual, perhaps using a makeshift tool. Could it be someone trying to escape? The thought was electrifying. If someone else was trying to escape, perhaps he could join them. Perhaps there was a way out after all. He began to tap on the wall, tentatively at first, then with more urgency. He waited, his breath held tight in his chest. Silence. Had they heard him? Were they afraid to respond? He tapped again, a simple rhythm, hoping it would be understood as a signal. Still silence. Disappointment washed over him, cold and sharp. Perhaps it was nothing. Perhaps the sound had stopped. He was about to give up, to sink back into his despair, when

events.title: Labor, Ingenuity, and First Contact Through the Wall
detailed_summary: The moment Dantès knocked, the scratching noise stopped abruptly. After hours of silence, he ate some bread and water, regaining strength and hope, convinced it was a fellow prisoner.
For three days, he impatiently waited for the sound to resume. One evening, he detected a faint movement, realizing the other prisoner was now using a lever, not a chisel.

Inspired to help, Dantès sought a tool. He broke his water jug, concealing sharp fragments. When the jailer brought a replacement, Dantès began to work on the wall, scraping away plaster, lamenting the years wasted in despair.

He uncovered stonework but couldn't dislodge a large stone with his weak nails or jug fragments. He then ingeniously tricked the jailer into breaking his plate and subsequently leaving the iron saucepan in his cell.
Using the saucepan's iron handle as a lever, Dantès successfully removed the stone, creating an opening. He carefully hid the debris.
The jailer, upon his next visit, grumbled about the broken plate and decided to permanently leave the saucepan for Dantès' soup, an outcome that filled Dantès with immense gratitude.

Noticing the other prisoner had ceased working, Dantès continued his own efforts, driven by the idea of reaching his neighbor if his neighbor wouldn't come to him. He encountered a wooden beam obstructing his path.
In a moment of profound despair at this new obstacle, after all his renewed hope, he cried out to God, questioning why he was being subjected to such torment.
A voice, seemingly from beneath the earth, hollow and sepulchral, responded to his cry, asking who spoke of God and despair simultaneously, causing Dantès to react with terror and awe.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Edmond’s hair stood on end, and he rose to his knees.

events.text_segment:
At the first blow the sound ceased, as if by magic.
Edmond listened intently; an hour passed, two hours passed, and no sound was heard from the wall—all was silent there.
Full of hope, Edmond swallowed a few mouthfuls of bread and water, and, thanks to the vigor of his constitution, found himself well-nigh recovered.
The day passed away in utter silence—night came without recurrence of the noise.
“It is a prisoner,” said Edmond joyfully. His brain was on fire, and life and energy returned.
The night passed in perfect silence. Edmond did not close his eyes.
In the morning the jailer brought him fresh provisions—he had already devoured those of the previous day; he ate these listening anxiously for the sound, walking round and round his cell, shaking the iron bars of the loophole, restoring vigor and agility to his limbs by exercise, and so preparing himself for his future destiny. At intervals he listened to learn if the noise had not begun again, and grew impatient at the prudence of the prisoner, who did not guess he had been disturbed by a captive as anxious for liberty as himself.
Three days passed—seventy-two long tedious hours which he counted off by minutes!
At length one evening, as the jailer was visiting him for the last time that night, Dantès, with his ear for the hundredth time at the wall, fancied he heard an almost imperceptible movement among the stones. He moved away, walked up and down his cell to collect his thoughts, and then went back and listened.
The matter was no longer doubtful. Something was at work on the other side of the wall; the prisoner had discovered the danger, and had substituted a lever for a chisel.
Encouraged by this discovery, Edmond determined to assist the indefatigable laborer. He began by moving his bed, and looked around for anything with which he could pierce the wall, penetrate the moist cement, and displace a stone.
He saw nothing, he had no knife or sharp instrument, the window grating was of iron, but he had too often assured himself of its solidity. All his furniture consisted of a bed, a chair, a table, a pail, and a jug. The bed had iron clamps, but they were screwed to the wood, and it would have required a screw-driver to take them off. The table and chair had nothing, the pail had once possessed a handle, but that had been removed.
Dantès had but one resource, which was to break the jug, and with one of the sharp fragments attack the wall. He let the jug fall on the floor, and it broke in pieces.
Dantès concealed two or three of the sharpest fragments in his bed, leaving the rest on the floor. The breaking of his jug was too natural an accident to excite suspicion. Edmond had all the night to work in, but in the darkness he could not do much, and he soon felt that he was working against something very hard; he pushed back his bed, and waited for day.
All night he heard the subterranean workman, who continued to mine his way. Day came, the jailer entered. Dantès told him that the jug had fallen from his hands while he was drinking, and the jailer went grumblingly to fetch another, without giving himself the trouble to remove the fragments of the broken one. He returned speedily, advised the prisoner to be more careful, and departed.
Dantès heard joyfully the key grate in the lock; he listened until the sound of steps died away, and then, hastily displacing his bed, saw by the faint light that penetrated into his cell, that he had labored uselessly the previous evening in attacking the stone instead of removing the plaster that surrounded it.
The damp had rendered it friable, and Dantès was able to break it off—in small morsels, it is true, but at the end of half an hour he had scraped off a handful; a mathematician might have calculated that in two years, supposing that the rock was not encountered, a passage twenty feet long and two feet broad, might be formed.
The prisoner reproached himself with not having thus employed the hours he had passed in vain hopes, prayer, and despondency. During the six years that he had been imprisoned, what might he not have accomplished?
This idea imparted new energy, and in three days he had succeeded, with the utmost precaution, in removing the cement, and exposing the stone-work. The wall was built of rough stones, among which, to give strength to the structure, blocks of hewn stone were at intervals imbedded. It was one of these he had uncovered, and which he must remove from its socket.
Dantès strove to do this with his nails, but they were too weak. The fragments of the jug broke, and after an hour of useless toil, Dantès paused with anguish on his brow.
Was he to be thus stopped at the beginning, and was he to wait inactive until his fellow workman had completed his task? Suddenly an idea occurred to him—he smiled, and the perspiration dried on his forehead.
The jailer always brought Dantès’ soup in an iron saucepan; this saucepan contained soup for both prisoners, for Dantès had noticed that it was either quite full, or half empty, according as the turnkey gave it to him or to his companion first.
The handle of this saucepan was of iron; Dantès would have given ten years of his life in exchange for it.
The jailer was accustomed to pour the contents of the saucepan into Dantès’ plate, and Dantès, after eating his soup with a wooden spoon, washed the plate, which thus served for every day. Now when evening came Dantès put his plate on the ground near the door; the jailer, as he entered, stepped on it and broke it.
This time he could not blame Dantès. He was wrong to leave it there, but the jailer was wrong not to have looked before him. The jailer, therefore, only grumbled. Then he looked about for something to pour the soup into; Dantès’ entire dinner service consisted of one plate—there was no alternative.
“Leave the saucepan,” said Dantès; “you can take it away when you bring me my breakfast.”
This advice was to the jailer’s taste, as it spared him the necessity of making another trip. He left the saucepan.
Dantès was beside himself with joy. He rapidly devoured his food, and after waiting an hour, lest the jailer should change his mind and return, he removed his bed, took the handle of the saucepan, inserted the point between the hewn stone and rough stones of the wall, and employed it as a lever. A slight oscillation showed Dantès that all went well. At the end of an hour the stone was extricated from the wall, leaving a cavity a foot and a half in diameter.
Dantès carefully collected the plaster, carried it into the corner of his cell, and covered it with earth. Then, wishing to make the best use of his time while he had the means of labor, he continued to work without ceasing. At the dawn of day he replaced the stone, pushed his bed against the wall, and lay down. The breakfast consisted of a piece of bread; the jailer entered and placed the bread on the table.
“Well, don’t you intend to bring me another plate?” said Dantès.
“No,” replied the turnkey; “you destroy everything. First you break your jug, then you make me break your plate; if all the prisoners followed your example, the government would be ruined. I shall leave you the saucepan, and pour your soup into that. So for the future I hope you will not be so destructive.”
Dantès raised his eyes to heaven and clasped his hands beneath the coverlet. He felt more gratitude for the possession of this piece of iron than he had ever felt for anything. He had noticed, however, that the prisoner on the other side had ceased to labor; no matter, this was a greater reason for proceeding—if his neighbor would not come to him, he would go to his neighbor. All day he toiled on untiringly, and by the evening he had succeeded in extracting ten handfuls of plaster and fragments of stone. When the hour for his jailer’s visit arrived, Dantès straightened the handle of the saucepan as well as he could, and placed it in its accustomed place. The turnkey poured his ration of soup into it, together with the fish—for thrice a week the prisoners were deprived of meat. This would have been a method of reckoning time, had not Dantès long ceased to do so. Having poured out the soup, the turnkey retired.
Dantès wished to ascertain whether his neighbor had really ceased to work. He listened—all was silent, as it had been for the last three days. Dantès sighed; it was evident that his neighbor distrusted him. However, he toiled on all the night without being discouraged; but after two or three hours he encountered an obstacle. The iron made no impression, but met with a smooth surface; Dantès touched it, and found that it was a beam. This beam crossed, or rather blocked up, the hole Dantès had made; it was necessary, therefore, to dig above or under it. The unhappy young man had not thought of this.
“Oh, my God, my God!” murmured he, “I have so earnestly prayed to you, that I hoped my prayers had been heard. After having deprived me of my liberty, after having deprived me of death, after having recalled me to existence, my God, have pity on me, and do not let me die in despair!”
“Who talks of God and despair at the same time?” said a voice that seemed to come from beneath the earth, and, deadened by the distance, sounded hollow and sepulchral in the young man’s ears. Edmond’s hair stood on end, and he rose to his knees.

Dantès waited an hour, two hours, in profound silence; then, notwithstanding the attraction of the unknown, notwithstanding the hunger that gnawed his stomach, he remembered that it was dinner-time, and the jailer would soon come. He ate the bread and drank the water, but could not take his eyes from the wall where the noise had ceased. An hour after, the jailer came, removed the vessels, and went away, without having perceived anything. Dantès listened if the sound would recommence, but all was silent. He passed the day in deep anxiety, the night in feverish imagination; neither in the one nor the other did he close his eyes, or taste repose. The next day, the next night, passed in the same way; and during these forty-eight hours he did not for a moment lose the idea that some one was near him, and that that someone, having ceased to work, was listening to him. Sometimes, in the middle of the night, he started up at the least sound, and eagerly applied the wall, in the hope that his neighbor, having finished or given up his own work, had commenced working for their common safety; but it was all in vain, and when the third day arrived he hung his head and sighed. Faria had listened also, and fancied he heard the sound of tools. But Faria was mistaken; the noise Dantès heard was not made by tools. About ten o'clock in the morning, while the jailer was giving Dantès his dinner, he struck against the wall. Dantès fancied he heard a slight sound in response to the blow. He remained silent for a quarter of an hour, and then, applying his mouth to the wall, he said, "Do not be afraid; I am a prisoner like yourself. Do you want anything? Can I help you?" He waited, but there was no answer. "He is afraid," thought Dantès, "or he does not understand me." He remained silent again, and then, after a long pause, he heard the sound again, but this time it was different. It was a dull, heavy sound, as if someone was striking the wall with a hammer. events.title: Revelation and a Shared Future: The Neighbor Emerges
detailed_summary: Dantès, astonished and terrified, acknowledged the human voice—the first he'd heard besides his jailer's in years.

He and the voice exchanged information: they were both unhappy prisoners; Dantès was a French sailor named Edmond Dantès, imprisoned since February 1815 for allegedly conspiring for Napoleon's return.
The voice revealed he had been imprisoned since 1811, shocking Dantès with the length of his captivity, and was unaware of Napoleon's abdication.
The other prisoner, identifying himself only as No. 27, explained that a miscalculation in his escape plans led him to Dantès' cell instead of the outer fortress wall and proximity to the sea.
No. 27 advised Dantès to seal his excavation and wait. Sensing mistrust and fearing abandonment, Dantès passionately swore his loyalty, threatening self-destruction if left alone.
Reassured by Dantès' youth (not yet twenty-six) and fervent pleas, No. 27 promised not to forsake him and to provide a signal after calculating their chances.
Dantès, overjoyed at the prospect of companionship and potential liberty, expressed his deep loneliness and offered his unwavering affection and loyalty, whether as a comrade or a son.
No. 27 confirmed, "tomorrow," leaving Dantès ecstatic. He spent the day in anticipation, resolving to kill the jailer if any attempt was made to separate him from his new acquaintance.
The next morning, after the jailer's departure and an exchange of knocks, No. 27 resumed work. Suddenly, the floor in Dantès' cell gave way, and from the resulting hole, a man emerged into his cell.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then from the bottom of this passage, the depth of which it was impossible to measure, he saw appear, first the head, then the shoulders, and lastly the body of a man, who sprang lightly into his cell.

events.text_segment:
“Ah,” said he, “I hear a human voice.” Edmond had not heard anyone speak save his jailer for four or five years; and a jailer is no man to a prisoner—he is a living door, a barrier of flesh and blood adding strength to restraints of oak and iron.
“In the name of Heaven,” cried Dantès, “speak again, though the sound of your voice terrifies me. Who are you?”
“Who are you?” said the voice.
“An unhappy prisoner,” replied Dantès, who made no hesitation in answering.
“Of what country?”
“A Frenchman.”
“Your name?”
“Edmond Dantès.”
“Your profession?”
“A sailor.”
“How long have you been here?”
“Since the 28th of February, 1815.”
“Your crime?”
“I am innocent.”
“But of what are you accused?”
“Of having conspired to aid the emperor’s return.”
“What! For the emperor’s return?—the emperor is no longer on the throne, then?”
“He abdicated at Fontainebleau in 1814, and was sent to the Island of Elba. But how long have you been here that you are ignorant of all this?”
“Since 1811.”
Dantès shuddered; this man had been four years longer than himself in prison.
“Do not dig any more,” said the voice; “only tell me how high up is your excavation?”
“On a level with the floor.”
“How is it concealed?”
“Behind my bed.”
“Has your bed been moved since you have been a prisoner?”
“No.”
“What does your chamber open on?”
“A corridor.”
“And the corridor?”
“On a court.”
“Alas!” murmured the voice.
“Oh, what is the matter?” cried Dantès.
“I have made a mistake owing to an error in my plans. I took the wrong angle, and have come out fifteen feet from where I intended. I took the wall you are mining for the outer wall of the fortress.”
“But then you would be close to the sea?”
“That is what I hoped.”
“And supposing you had succeeded?”
“I should have thrown myself into the sea, gained one of the islands near here—the Isle de Daume or the Isle de Tiboulen—and then I should have been safe.”
“Could you have swum so far?”
“Heaven would have given me strength; but now all is lost.”
“All?”
“Yes; stop up your excavation carefully, do not work any more, and wait until you hear from me.”
“Tell me, at least, who you are?”
“I am—I am No. 27.”
“You mistrust me, then,” said Dantès. Edmond fancied he heard a bitter laugh resounding from the depths.
“Oh, I am a Christian,” cried Dantès, guessing instinctively that this man meant to abandon him. “I swear to you by him who died for us that naught shall induce me to breathe one syllable to my jailers; but I conjure you do not abandon me. If you do, I swear to you, for I have got to the end of my strength, that I will dash my brains out against the wall, and you will have my death to reproach yourself with.”
“How old are you? Your voice is that of a young man.”
“I do not know my age, for I have not counted the years I have been here. All I do know is, that I was just nineteen when I was arrested, the 28th of February, 1815.”
“Not quite twenty-six!” murmured the voice; “at that age he cannot be a traitor.”
“Oh, no, no,” cried Dantès. “I swear to you again, rather than betray you, I would allow myself to be hacked in pieces!”
“You have done well to speak to me, and ask for my assistance, for I was about to form another plan, and leave you; but your age reassures me. I will not forget you. Wait.”
“How long?”
“I must calculate our chances; I will give you the signal.”
“But you will not leave me; you will come to me, or you will let me come to you. We will escape, and if we cannot escape we will talk; you of those whom you love, and I of those whom I love. You must love somebody?”
“No, I am alone in the world.”
“Then you will love me. If you are young, I will be your comrade; if you are old, I will be your son. I have a father who is seventy if he yet lives; I only love him and a young girl called Mercédès. My father has not yet forgotten me, I am sure, but God alone knows if she loves me still; I shall love you as I loved my father.”
“It is well,” returned the voice; “tomorrow.”
These few words were uttered with an accent that left no doubt of his sincerity; Dantès rose, dispersed the fragments with the same precaution as before, and pushed his bed back against the wall. He then gave himself up to his happiness. He would no longer be alone. He was, perhaps, about to regain his liberty; at the worst, he would have a companion, and captivity that is shared is but half captivity. Plaints made in common are almost prayers, and prayers where two or three are gathered together invoke the mercy of heaven.
All day Dantès walked up and down his cell. He sat down occasionally on his bed, pressing his hand on his heart. At the slightest noise he bounded towards the door. Once or twice the thought crossed his mind that he might be separated from this unknown, whom he loved already; and then his mind was made up—when the jailer moved his bed and stooped to examine the opening, he would kill him with his water jug. He would be condemned to die, but he was about to die of grief and despair when this miraculous noise recalled him to life.
The jailer came in the evening. Dantès was on his bed. It seemed to him that thus he better guarded the unfinished opening. Doubtless there was a strange expression in his eyes, for the jailer said, “Come, are you going mad again?”
Dantès did not answer; he feared that the emotion of his voice would betray him. The jailer went away shaking his head. Night came; Dantès hoped that his neighbor would profit by the silence to address him, but he was mistaken. The next morning, however, just as he removed his bed from the wall, he heard three knocks; he threw himself on his knees.
“Is it you?” said he; “I am here.”
“Is your jailer gone?”
“Yes,” said Dantès; “he will not return until the evening; so that we have twelve hours before us.”
“I can work, then?” said the voice.
“Oh, yes, yes; this instant, I entreat you.”
In a moment that part of the floor on which Dantès was resting his two hands, as he knelt with his head in the opening, suddenly gave way; he drew back smartly, while a mass of stones and earth disappeared in a hole that opened beneath the aperture he himself had formed. Then from the bottom of this passage, the depth of which it was impossible to measure, he saw appear, first the head, then the shoulders, and lastly the body of a man, who sprang lightly into his cell.

“Ah,” said he, “I hear a human voice.”
It was indeed a human voice, and the first that Dantès had heard for four years. And in the isolation in which he lived, and had lived for four years, a human voice was a sound that caused him to start and tremble, so accustomed was he to only the silent墙壁 and the noiseless steps of his jailer. Dantès’ first idea was that the voice came from the sentry who was pacing the corridor, and that he spoke to his comrade. He then called as loud as he could, “Hello! hello! who is there?”
“Who are you?” answered the voice.
“An unhappy prisoner,” replied Dantès, who instinctively felt that the voice belonged to a fellow-sufferer.
“Of what country?”
“A Frenchman.”
“Your name?”
“Edmond Dantès.”
“Your profession?”
“A sailor.”
“How long have you been here?”
“Since the 28th of February, 1815.”
“Your crime?”
“I am innocent.”
“But of what are you accused?”
“Of having conspired to aid the return of Napoleon.”
“Napoleon is returned, then?” asked the voice, in a tone of intense excitement.
“He is more than returned—he is at Paris,” replied Dantès, “in the Tuileries, with the titles of emperor and king.”
“Indeed?” said the voice, “it is impossible!”
“It is true, nevertheless; and it is now a hundred days since he has been reigning, so you may imagine he is firmly established.”
“He reigns in the Tuileries, then, and has been there for a hundred days?”
“Yes,” repeated Dantès, a little surprised at the prisoner’s want of information, “yes; and you do not seem to know it.”
“I have been here since 1811,” said the voice.
Dantès shuddered; this man had been a prisoner longer than himself. “No matter,” said he; “do not despair. If Napoleon is put out of the way, another will take his place; and so it will be with the Bourbons and Napoleon. Nothing is eternal in this world, neither are the Bourbons eternal, who have been replaced by Napoleon, nor Napoleon, who has replaced the Bourbons. But who are you?”
“I am,” said the voice, “Number 27.”
“You do not give me your name, then?”
“The names of prisoners are useless; and are only of consequence when they make their escape.”
“Well, then, if you are not inclined to give me your name, tell me at least what you did to be arrested.”
“I was a political prisoner.”
“Then how is it that you have not been set at liberty since the return of Napoleon?”
“I was waiting for that event. There was to have been an investigation, and I was to have been liberated.”
“Then why are you not liberated?”
“I do not know. They have forgotten me, or perhaps something has happened.”
“What could have happened? The emperor is on the throne.”
“I told you I have been here since 1811; and as I am here, I cannot tell what has happened.”
“What! have you not tried to communicate with anybody?”
“In the first place, I was removed from the fortress of Fenestrelle to the Château d’If, and since then I have been in this dungeon.”
“Ah, your dungeon, then, is near mine?”
“Yes, it is only separated by a wall.”
“And that wall—is it thick?”
“Oh, yes, very thick.”
“But have you not tried to break through it?”
“No, for I should have been discovered and removed to another place, and I should never have found my way back again. I have been waiting for a favorable opportunity.”
“And you have not found one?”
“No; but I hope to find one soon.”
“How so?”
“I am making a tunnel.”
“A tunnel! In the earth?”
“Yes, in the earth.”
“And where are you going?”
“To the outer wall of the fortress, and then I shall dig under the ditch, and then I shall be free.”
“Oh, my friend, my friend, how I envy you!”
“Do not envy me until I am free. I have been working for four years, and I have not yet reached the outer wall.”
“Four years!” cried Dantès, in astonishment.
“Yes, four years; and I have only advanced about six feet.”
“Only six feet in four years! Why, you will be an old man before you are free.”
“I am an old man already,” said the voice.
“And how did you get the tools?”
“I made them myself.”
“You made them yourself! But how?”
“With a piece of iron that I found in my dungeon.”
“And what is your occupation?”
“I am a priest.”
“A priest! Then you are not a soldier?”
“No, I am a priest.”
“And you are a political prisoner?”
“Yes, I am a political prisoner.”
“But how can a priest be a political prisoner?”
“I was arrested for having preached against the government.”
“Ah, indeed! And you are a priest?”
“Yes, I am a priest.”
“And you are making a tunnel?”
“Yes, I am making a tunnel.”
“And you hope to escape?”
“Yes, I hope to escape.”

chapters.chapter_title: VOLUME ONE. Chapter 16. A Learned Italian

events.title: First Encounter and the Stranger's Pragmatism
detailed_summary: Dantès joyfully embraces the newcomer, whom he has longed for, eager to see his face in the dim light.

The stranger is described as a small man, his hair whitened more by suffering than age, possessing a deeply set, penetrating eye, a long, still-black beard, and a thin, care-furrowed face indicative of a man accustomed to mental rather than physical exertion; his clothing is tattered.
He appears to be around sixty or sixty-five, yet a certain briskness suggests his aging is more a result of captivity than the passage of time.
The stranger warmly reciprocates Dantès' enthusiastic greeting, his own chilled affections seemingly rekindled, despite the evident disappointment of discovering another dungeon instead of freedom.
His immediate concern is to erase any evidence of his entry, emphasizing that their future peace depends on the jailers remaining unaware.
He advances to the opening Dantès made and effortlessly lifts and replaces the stone, commenting on Dantès' carelessness and lack of tools.
Dantès exclaims in astonishment when the stranger reveals he possesses tools he fashioned himself: a chisel, pincers, and a lever.
The stranger displays a sharp, strong chisel with a beechwood handle, explaining he made it from a bedstead clamp.
He further reveals that this tool alone was sufficient for him to excavate a tunnel approximately fifty feet long, the distance to Dantès' cell.

events.text_segment:
Seizing in his arms the friend so long and ardently desired, Dantès almost carried him towards the window, in order to obtain a better view of his features by the aid of the imperfect light that struggled through the grating.
He was a man of small stature, with hair blanched rather by suffering and sorrow than by age. He had a deep-set, penetrating eye, almost buried beneath the thick gray eyebrow, and a long (and still black) beard reaching down to his breast. His thin face, deeply furrowed by care, and the bold outline of his strongly marked features, betokened a man more accustomed to exercise his mental faculties than his physical strength. Large drops of perspiration were now standing on his brow, while the garments that hung about him were so ragged that one could only guess at the pattern upon which they had originally been fashioned.
The stranger might have numbered sixty or sixty-five years; but a certain briskness and appearance of vigor in his movements made it probable that he was aged more from captivity than the course of time. He received the enthusiastic greeting of his young acquaintance with evident pleasure, as though his chilled affections were rekindled and invigorated by his contact with one so warm and ardent. He thanked him with grateful cordiality for his kindly welcome, although he must at that moment have been suffering bitterly to find another dungeon where he had fondly reckoned on discovering a means of regaining his liberty.
“Let us first see,” said he, “whether it is possible to remove the traces of my entrance here—our future tranquillity depends upon our jailers being entirely ignorant of it.”
Advancing to the opening, he stooped and raised the stone easily in spite of its weight; then, fitting it into its place, he said:
“You removed this stone very carelessly; but I suppose you had no tools to aid you.”
“Why,” exclaimed Dantès, with astonishment, “do you possess any?”
“I made myself some; and with the exception of a file, I have all that are necessary,—a chisel, pincers, and lever.”
“Oh, how I should like to see these products of your industry and patience.”
“Well, in the first place, here is my chisel.”
So saying, he displayed a sharp strong blade, with a handle made of beechwood.
“And with what did you contrive to make that?” inquired Dantès.
“With one of the clamps of my bedstead; and this very tool has sufficed me to hollow out the road by which I came hither, a distance of about fifty feet.”
“Fifty feet!” responded Dantès, almost terrified.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Seizing in his arms the friend so long and ardently desired, Dantès almost carried him towards the window, in order to obtain a better view of his features by the aid of the imperfect light that struggled through the grating. He was a small man, with hair whitened rather by suffering than age; he had a deep-set, penetrating eye, a long beard, almost black, and a thin face, furrowed by thought, and which much resembled the ascetic faces of the fourteenth century. His dress was in rags; that is to say, he wore a shirt of coarse linen, trowsers of the same, and an old jacket of cloth, which the prisoner had kept to wrap himself in when he felt cold. He appeared to be about sixty or sixty-five years of age, but a certain briskness in his manner bespoke a constitution still sound and vigorous. He at once responded to the enthusiastic greeting of Dantès, whose warm embrace evidently rekindled in his frozen heart the dying embers of affection. He thanked him with a few brief but expressive words for the joy he experienced. His joy, however, was as short as it was lively; for the thought of the great peril that Dantès had incurred by thus penetrating into his cell, soon blighted it. "Quick! quick!" said he; "the first thing to be done is to close the opening." And he stooped, and with a strength that amazed Dantès, lifted the stone, which, notwithstanding its enormous weight, he closed upon the opening through which he had passed. The prisoner guessed that the fugitive had discovered the mode of opening and closing this stone. For a moment Dantès stood mute and motionless; he had not expected this. "You have neither lime nor cement, then?" said the newcomer. "How can you close the opening?" "That is the second thing to be done," said the prisoner; "I have a small quantity of lime, cement, and tinder; I keep it in a pot, and have about a pound's worth. As for the trowel, I made myself a trowel and a spade." "You made them yourself?" asked Dantès, with astonishment. "Yes; I made them myself," answered the prisoner. "With what?" "With a piece of an old iron bedstead, a clamp, in fact, which I sharpened on the floor of the dungeon; and with a beechwood handle I made a chisel." "And with this chisel you dug the passage?" asked Dantès. "Yes, as you see. It is about fifty feet long, and has taken me two years to accomplish." "Two years!" exclaimed Dantès.

events.title: The Miscalculated Tunnel and Dungeon Assessment
detailed_summary: The stranger cautions Dantès against speaking too loudly, warning that prison guards are often stationed to overhear prisoners' conversations.
He confirms he dug a fifty-foot tunnel but reveals he miscalculated its trajectory due to the lack of proper geometrical instruments for proportion scaling.

Instead of reaching the outer wall to escape into the sea as planned, his tunnel followed the corridor of Dantès' cell and ended up facing a courtyard filled with soldiers, rendering his labor futile.
Dantès inquires about the other three sides of his cell.

The stranger describes one wall as solid rock, impenetrable without extensive mining operations; another adjoins the governor’s apartments, leading only to secure cellars where recapture would be inevitable.
To assess the final wall, the one with the light-admitting loophole, the stranger instructs Dantès to move the table beneath it.
Dantès complies, climbs onto the table, and positions himself to support his companion.
The stranger, displaying surprising agility for his age, climbs from the table to Dantès' hands, then to his shoulders, and peers through the upper window bars to observe the exterior.
