events.title: Unraveling the Conspiracy: Dantès' Betrayers Identified
detailed_summary: Faria notices Dantès' deep abstraction and Dantès admits he was reflecting on Faria's immense intelligence and what he might have achieved if free.
Faria philosophizes that misfortune often cultivates intellectual treasures, comparing it to compression needed for gunpowder or collision of clouds for electricity.
Dantès confesses his own ignorance and acknowledges Faria's profound knowledge.
Dantès reveals his second thought: Faria is unaware of his personal history.
He expresses his deep desire to identify the human source of his suffering to cease blaming Heaven.
Faria, after Dantès swears his innocence by his father and Mercédès, asks to hear his story.

Dantès recounts his life: voyages, the death of Captain Leclere, the mission to deliver a packet to the grand marshal, receiving a letter for Monsieur Noirtier, his return to Marseilles, his father, his love for Mercédès, the nuptial feast, his arrest, examination, and imprisonment, knowing nothing beyond that point.
Faria reflects and introduces his maxim: to find the author of a bad deed, identify who benefits from it.
Dantès initially believes his disappearance benefited no one, deeming himself insignificant.
Faria explains relativity in social hierarchy and self-interest, from kings to employees, and urges Dantès to consider his specific world.
They discuss Dantès' prospects: captaincy of the Pharaon and marriage to Mercédès.

Faria questions who had an interest in preventing the captaincy. Dantès recalls only one crew member with ill-will, Danglars, with whom he had quarreled and whose accounts were inaccurate. Dantès would not have kept him as supercargo.

Faria asks if anyone was present during Dantès' last conversation with Captain Leclere; Dantès initially says no, but then remembers Danglars passing by as he received the packet for the grand marshal.
Faria confirms Danglars saw Dantès with the letter upon his return to the Pharaon from Porto-Ferrajo.
Dantès recites the denunciation letter verbatim, accusing him of carrying a packet from Murat to the usurper and a letter from the usurper to a Bonapartist Club.
Faria finds the accusation clear, noting Dantès' trusting nature.

He compares Danglars' handsome, running handwriting with the backhanded script of the anonymous letter, which Faria demonstrates as easily disguised by writing with the left hand, a script often uniform across individuals.
Dantès is astonished by the resemblance of Faria's left-handed writing to the accusation.
Faria then probes about who would want to prevent Dantès' marriage to Mercédès.
Dantès names Fernand, a Catalan who loved her, but initially dismisses him as the letter writer, believing Fernand would prefer direct violence and wouldn't know the letter's details.

Faria asks if Danglars knew Fernand. Dantès then vividly recalls seeing Danglars and Fernand in earnest conversation, with a drunk Caderousse, at Père Pamphile's the evening before his wedding, with pens, ink, and paper on their table.
The realization of their collective treachery horrifies Dantès.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: What are you thinking of?” asked the abbé smilingly, imputing the deep abstraction in which his visitor was plunged to the excess of his awe and wonder.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Oh, the heartless, treacherous scoundrels!” exclaimed Dantès, pressing his hand to his throbbing brows.

events.text_segment:
What are you thinking of?” asked the abbé smilingly, imputing the deep abstraction in which his visitor was plunged to the excess of his awe and wonder.
“I was reflecting, in the first place,” replied Dantès, “upon the enormous degree of intelligence and ability you must have employed to reach the high perfection to which you have attained. What would you not have accomplished if you had been free?”
“Possibly nothing at all; the overflow of my brain would probably, in a state of freedom, have evaporated in a thousand follies; misfortune is needed to bring to light the treasures of the human intellect. Compression is needed to explode gunpowder. Captivity has brought my mental faculties to a focus; and you are well aware that from the collision of clouds electricity is produced—from electricity, lightning, from lightning, illumination.”
“No,” replied Dantès. “I know nothing. Some of your words are to me quite empty of meaning. You must be blessed indeed to possess the knowledge you have.”
The abbé smiled. “Well,” said he, “but you had another subject for your thoughts; did you not say so just now?”
“I did!”
“You have told me as yet but one of them—let me hear the other.”
“It was this,—that while you had related to me all the particulars of your past life, you were perfectly unacquainted with mine.”
“Your life, my young friend, has not been of sufficient length to admit of your having passed through any very important events.”
“It has been long enough to inflict on me a great and undeserved misfortune. I would fain fix the source of it on man that I may no longer vent reproaches upon Heaven.”
“Then you profess ignorance of the crime with which you are charged?”
“I do, indeed; and this I swear by the two beings most dear to me upon earth,—my father and Mercédès.”
“Come,” said the abbé, closing his hiding-place, and pushing the bed back to its original situation, “let me hear your story.”
Dantès obeyed, and commenced what he called his history, but which consisted only of the account of a voyage to India, and two or three voyages to the Levant, until he arrived at the recital of his last cruise, with the death of Captain Leclere, and the receipt of a packet to be delivered by himself to the grand marshal; his interview with that personage, and his receiving, in place of the packet brought, a letter addressed to a Monsieur Noirtier—his arrival at Marseilles, and interview with his father—his affection for Mercédès, and their nuptual feast—his arrest and subsequent examination, his temporary detention at the Palais de Justice, and his final imprisonment in the Château d’If. From this point everything was a blank to Dantès—he knew nothing more, not even the length of time he had been imprisoned. His recital finished, the abbé reflected long and earnestly.
“There is,” said he, at the end of his meditations, “a clever maxim, which bears upon what I was saying to you some little while ago, and that is, that unless wicked ideas take root in a naturally depraved mind, human nature, in a right and wholesome state, revolts at crime. Still, from an artificial civilization have originated wants, vices, and false tastes, which occasionally become so powerful as to stifle within us all good feelings, and ultimately to lead us into guilt and wickedness. From this view of things, then, comes the axiom that if you visit to discover the author of any bad action, seek first to discover the person to whom the perpetration of that bad action could be in any way advantageous. Now, to apply it in your case,—to whom could your disappearance have been serviceable?”
“To no one, by Heaven! I was a very insignificant person.”
“Do not speak thus, for your reply evinces neither logic nor philosophy; everything is relative, my dear young friend, from the king who stands in the way of his successor, to the employee who keeps his rival out of a place. Now, in the event of the king’s death, his successor inherits a crown,—when the employee dies, the supernumerary steps into his shoes, and receives his salary of twelve thousand livres. Well, these twelve thousand livres are his civil list, and are as essential to him as the twelve millions of a king. Everyone, from the highest to the lowest degree, has his place on the social ladder, and is beset by stormy passions and conflicting interests, as in Descartes’ theory of pressure and impulsion. But these forces increase as we go higher, so that we have a spiral which in defiance of reason rests upon the apex and not on the base. Now let us return to your particular world. You say you were on the point of being made captain of the Pharaon?”
“Yes.”
“And about to become the husband of a young and lovely girl?”
“Yes.”
“Now, could anyone have had any interest in preventing the accomplishment of these two things? But let us first settle the question as to its being the interest of anyone to hinder you from being captain of the Pharaon. What say you?”
“I cannot believe such was the case. I was generally liked on board, and had the sailors possessed the right of selecting a captain themselves, I feel convinced their choice would have fallen on me. There was only one person among the crew who had any feeling of ill-will towards me. I had quarelled with him some time previously, and had even challenged him to fight me; but he refused.”
“Now we are getting on. And what was this man’s name?”
“Danglars.”
“What rank did he hold on board?”
“He was supercargo.”
“And had you been captain, should you have retained him in his employment?”
“Not if the choice had remained with me, for I had frequently observed inaccuracies in his accounts.”
“Good again! Now then, tell me, was any person present during your last conversation with Captain Leclere?”
“No; we were quite alone.”
“Could your conversation have been overheard by anyone?”
“It might, for the cabin door was open—and—stay; now I recollect,—Danglars himself passed by just as Captain Leclere was giving me the packet for the grand marshal.”
“That’s better,” cried the abbé; “now we are on the right scent. Did you take anybody with you when you put into the port of Elba?”
“Nobody.”
“Somebody there received your packet, and gave you a letter in place of it, I think?”
“Yes; the grand marshal did.”
“And what did you do with that letter?”
“Put it into my portfolio.”
“You had your portfolio with you, then? Now, how could a sailor find room in his pocket for a portfolio large enough to contain an official letter?”
“You are right; it was left on board.”
“Then it was not till your return to the ship that you put the letter in the portfolio?”
“No.”
“And what did you do with this same letter while returning from Porto-Ferrajo to the vessel?”
“I carried it in my hand.”
“So that when you went on board the Pharaon, everybody could see that you held a letter in your hand?”
“Yes.”
“Danglars, as well as the rest?”
“Danglars, as well as others.”
“Now, listen to me, and try to recall every circumstance attending your arrest. Do you recollect the words in which the information against you was formulated?”
“Oh yes, I read it over three times, and the words sank deeply into my memory.”
“Repeat it to me.”
Dantès paused a moment, then said, “This is it, word for word: ‘The king’s attorney is informed by a friend to the throne and religion, that one Edmond Dantès, mate on board the Pharaon, this day arrived from Smyrna, after having touched at Naples and Porto-Ferrajo, has been intrusted by Murat with a packet for the usurper; again, by the usurper, with a letter for the Bonapartist Club in Paris. This proof of his guilt may be procured by his immediate arrest, as the letter will be found either about his person, at his father’s residence, or in his cabin on board the Pharaon.’”
The abbé shrugged his shoulders. “The thing is clear as day,” said he; “and you must have had a very confiding nature, as well as a good heart, not to have suspected the origin of the whole affair.”
“Do you really think so? Ah, that would indeed be infamous.”
“How did Danglars usually write?”
“In a handsome, running hand.”
“And how was the anonymous letter written?”
“Backhanded.”
Again the abbé smiled. “Disguised.”
“It was very boldly written, if disguised.”
“Stop a bit,” said the abbé, taking up what he called his pen, and, after dipping it into the ink, he wrote on a piece of prepared linen, with his left hand, the first two or three words of the accusation. Dantès drew back, and gazed on the abbé with a sensation almost amounting to terror.
“How very astonishing!” cried he at length. “Why your writing exactly resembles that of the accusation.”
“Simply because that accusation had been written with the left hand; and I have noticed that——”
“What?”
“That while the writing of different persons done with the right hand varies, that performed with the left hand is invariably uniform.”
“You have evidently seen and observed everything.”
“Let us proceed.”
“Oh, yes, yes!”
“Now as regards the second question.”
“I am listening.”
“Was there any person whose interest it was to prevent your marriage with Mercédès?”
“Yes; a young man who loved her.”
“And his name was——”
“Fernand.”
“That is a Spanish name, I think?”
“He was a Catalan.”
“You imagine him capable of writing the letter?”
“Oh, no; he would more likely have got rid of me by sticking a knife into me.”
“That is in strict accordance with the Spanish character; an assassination they will unhesitatingly commit, but an act of cowardice, never.”
“Besides,” said Dantès, “the various circumstances mentioned in the letter were wholly unknown to him.”
“You had never spoken of them yourself to anyone?”
“To no one.”
“Not even to your mistress?”
“No, not even to my betrothed.”
“Then it is Danglars.”
“I feel quite sure of it now.”
“Wait a little. Pray, was Danglars acquainted with Fernand?”
“No—yes, he was. Now I recollect——”
“What?”
“To have seen them both sitting at table together under an arbor at Père Pamphile’s the evening before the day fixed for my wedding. They were in earnest conversation. Danglars was joking in a friendly way, but Fernand looked pale and agitated.”
“Were they alone?”
“There was a third person with them whom I knew perfectly well, and who had, in all probability made their acquaintance; he was a tailor named Caderousse, but he was very drunk. Stay!—stay!—How strange that it should not have occurred to me before! Now I remember quite well, that on the table round which they were sitting were pens, ink, and paper. Oh, the heartless, treacherous scoundrels!” exclaimed Dantès, pressing his hand to his throbbing brows.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
What are you thinking of?” asked the abbé smilingly, imputing the deep abstraction in which his visitor was plunged to the excess of his awe and wonder. Dantès started, as if roused from a dream, and looked at the abbé with eyes still wide with astonishment. “I am thinking, Father,” he replied, his voice hushed, “of the difference between you and me. Of the vastness of your knowledge, which seems to encompass the world, and my own utter ignorance. I am thinking of the fate that brought us together, you, a man who knows everything, and I, a man who knew nothing but sorrow and injustice. I am thinking… I am thinking that you are more than a man; you are a living miracle.”

The abbé’s smile softened. “My son,” he said gently, “knowledge is not a miracle; it is the fruit of labor and study. And sorrow and injustice, while bitter, can also be teachers, sharpening the mind and hardening the spirit. You have learned much in this place, Edmond, perhaps more than you realize. You have learned patience, endurance, and the value of a true friend.” He paused, his gaze steady on Dantès. “But you are right; there is a great disparity in our understanding of the world. And it is that disparity I wish to address. You asked me once why I, a man of God and learning, was imprisoned here. I told you it was for political reasons, for dreaming of a united Italy. That is true, but it is not the whole truth. My imprisonment is also linked to a secret, a secret that has been my companion for years, a secret that could change your life, should you ever leave this place.”

Dantès leaned forward, his heart pounding. The abbé’s words held a gravity that transcended their prison walls. “A secret, Father? What secret could be so great?”

The abbé rose slowly, his movements deliberate despite his frailty. He walked to the corner of the cell where his tools lay hidden – the pickaxe, the lever, the fragments of stone. He picked up a small, worn book, its cover faded and its pages brittle with age. “This book, Edmond,” he said, returning to his seat, “is the key to that secret. It is a theological treatise, written in Latin, by a cardinal of the Spada family, who lived in the fifteenth century.”

Dantès looked at the book with curiosity, but saw nothing remarkable about it. “A theological treatise?” he echoed, puzzled.

“Yes,” the abbé confirmed. “But within its pages, hidden by a cunning cipher, lies the will of Cardinal Spada, one of the wealthiest men of his time. A will that was never executed, a fortune that was never claimed.”

A fortune? The word hung in the air, incongruous with their surroundings. Dantès could only stare. “A fortune? But… how?”

The abbé settled back, his eyes distant, as if looking into the past. “The Spada family was ancient and powerful, their wealth accumulated over centuries through commerce, banking, and alliances. Cardinal Cesare Spada was the last direct male heir. He lived during a turbulent time in Italy, the era of the Borgias, a time of poisonings, assassinations, and political intrigue. The Cardinal, a man of foresight and caution, foresaw the dangers. He knew that his vast wealth made him a target, and that upon his death, his fortune would likely be seized by the rapacious powers of the day, perhaps even the Pope himself, Alexander VI, a Borgia.”

He paused, allowing the historical context to sink in. “The Cardinal had a nephew, Guido Spada, whom he loved dearly and wished to inherit his wealth. But he knew that a simple will bequeathing everything to Guido would be useless; the fortune would be confiscated before Guido could claim it. So, the Cardinal devised a plan. He decided to hide his treasure, not in a bank or a vault, but in a place known only to himself, and to leave instructions for its recovery in a manner that would escape the notice of his enemies.”

The abbé tapped the old book. “He wrote his will, a legitimate document, stating that he bequeathed to his nephew Guido all his possessions, his library, his collections, save for his palace and his revenues, which were to be sold to provide masses for his soul. This will was publicly known.

events.title: The Deeper Betrayal: Villefort's Crime Uncovered and Dantès' Secret Vow
detailed_summary: Faria asks if he can help Dantès discover anything beyond his friends' villainy.
Dantès implores Faria to explain why he received no second examination, no trial, and was condemned without a sentence.
Faria acknowledges this as a more serious and mysterious matter, requiring minute information.
He questions Dantès about his examiner: the deputy prosecutor, about twenty-six or twenty-seven, old enough to be ambitious but too young for corruption.
Dantès recalls the deputy treated him with mildness.
The deputy appeared greatly disturbed upon reading the letter that incriminated Dantès, seemingly overcome by Dantès' misfortune.
As proof of sympathy, the deputy burned the letter, the sole evidence against Dantès.
Faria suggests this seemingly sympathetic man might be a greater scoundrel than imagined, remarking that two-legged tigers and crocodiles are most dangerous.
He learns the letter was addressed to M. Noirtier, Rue Coq-Héron, Paris.
Faria notes the deputy made Dantès promise never to speak of the letter and swear never to utter the name Noirtier.
Faria recalls knowing a Noirtier, a former Girondin, at the court of the Queen of Etruria.
Upon learning the deputy's name was De Villefort, Faria bursts into laughter.
He then reveals the stunning truth: Noirtier was Villefort's father.
Dantès is utterly transfixed with horror by this revelation.

A bright light of understanding dawns on Dantès, clarifying Villefort's actions during the examination: his change in demeanor, the destruction of the letter, the exacted promise, and his supplicating tones.
Overwhelmed, Dantès staggers and retreats to his own cell to contemplate this devastating truth.
During hours of profound meditation, he forms a fearful resolution and binds himself to it with a solemn oath (presumably for vengeance).
Later, Faria, having received unusual privileges due to his harmless madness, invites Dantès to share his Sunday supper of finer bread and wine.
Dantès' features are composed but his appearance reveals a fixed, desperate resolve.
Faria expresses regret for helping Dantès, perceiving that the revelations have instilled a passion for vengeance in him.
Dantès smiles and requests they speak of something else.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Dantès smiled. “Let us talk of something else,” said he.

events.text_segment:
Is there anything else I can assist you in discovering, besides the villany of your friends?” inquired the abbé with a laugh.
“Yes, yes,” replied Dantès eagerly; “I would beg of you, who see so completely to the depths of things, and to whom the greatest mystery seems but an easy riddle, to explain to me how it was that I underwent no second examination, was never brought to trial, and, above all, was condemned without ever having had sentence passed on me?”
“That is altogether a different and more serious matter,” responded the abbé. “The ways of justice are frequently too dark and mysterious to be easily penetrated. All we have hitherto done in the matter has been child’s play. If you wish me to enter upon the more difficult part of the business, you must assist me by the most minute information on every point.”
“Pray ask me whatever questions you please; for, in good truth, you see more clearly into my life than I do myself.”
“In the first place, then, who examined you,—the king’s attorney, his deputy, or a magistrate?”
“The deputy.”
“Was he young or old?”
“About six or seven-and-twenty years of age, I should say.”
“So,” answered the abbé. “Old enough to be ambitious, but too young to be corrupt. And how did he treat you?”
“With more of mildness than severity.”
“Did you tell him your whole story?”
“I did.”
“And did his conduct change at all in the course of your examination?”
“He did appear much disturbed when he read the letter that had brought me into this scrape. He seemed quite overcome by my misfortune.”
“By your misfortune?”
“Yes.”
“Then you feel quite sure that it was your misfortune he deplored?”
“He gave me one great proof of his sympathy, at any rate.”
“And that?”
“He burnt the sole evidence that could at all have criminated me.”
“What? the accusation?”
“No; the letter.”
“Are you sure?”
“I saw it done.”
“That alters the case. This man might, after all, be a greater scoundrel than you have thought possible.”
“Upon my word,” said Dantès, “you make me shudder. Is the world filled with tigers and crocodiles?”
“Yes; and remember that two-legged tigers and crocodiles are more dangerous than the others.”
“Never mind; let us go on.”
“With all my heart! You tell me he burned the letter?”
“He did; saying at the same time, ‘You see I thus destroy the only proof existing against you.’”
“This action is somewhat too sublime to be natural.”
“You think so?”
“I am sure of it. To whom was this letter addressed?”
“To M. Noirtier, Rue Coq-Héron, No. 13, Paris.”
“Now can you conceive of any interest that your heroic deputy could possibly have had in the destruction of that letter?”
“Why, it is not altogether impossible he might have had, for he made me promise several times never to speak of that letter to anyone, assuring me he so advised me for my own interest; and, more than this, he insisted on my taking a solemn oath never to utter the name mentioned in the address.”
“Noirtier!” repeated the abbé; “Noirtier!—I knew a person of that name at the court of the Queen of Etruria,—a Noirtier, who had been a Girondin during the Revolution! What was your deputy called?”
“De Villefort!” The abbé burst into a fit of laughter, while Dantès gazed on him in utter astonishment.
“What ails you?” said he at length.
“Do you see that ray of sunlight?”
“I do.”
“Well, the whole thing is more clear to me than that sunbeam is to you. Poor fellow! poor young man! And you tell me this magistrate expressed great sympathy and commiseration for you?”
“He did.”
“And the worthy man destroyed your compromising letter?”
“Yes.”
“And then made you swear never to utter the name of Noirtier?”
“Yes.”
“Why, you poor short-sighted simpleton, can you not guess who this Noirtier was, whose very name he was so careful to keep concealed? This Noirtier was his father!”
Had a thunderbolt fallen at the feet of Dantès, or hell opened its yawning gulf before him, he could not have been more completely transfixed with horror than he was at the sound of these unexpected words. Starting up, he clasped his hands around his head as though to prevent his very brain from bursting, and exclaimed, “His father! his father!”
“Yes, his father,” replied the abbé; “his right name was Noirtier de Villefort.”
At this instant a bright light shot through the mind of Dantès, and cleared up all that had been dark and obscure before. The change that had come over Villefort during the examination, the destruction of the letter, the exacted promise, the almost supplicating tones of the magistrate, who seemed rather to implore mercy than to pronounce punishment,—all returned with a stunning force to his memory. He cried out, and staggered against the wall like a drunken man, then he hurried to the opening that led from the abbé’s cell to his own, and said, “I must be alone, to think over all this.”
When he regained his dungeon, he threw himself on his bed, where the turnkey found him in the evening visit, sitting with fixed gaze and contracted features, dumb and motionless as a statue. During these hours of profound meditation, which to him had seemed only minutes, he had formed a fearful resolution, and bound himself to its fulfilment by a solemn oath.
Dantès was at length roused from his reverie by the voice of Faria, who, having also been visited by his jailer, had come to invite his fellow-sufferer to share his supper. The reputation of being out of his mind, though harmlessly and even amusingly so, had procured for the abbé unusual privileges. He was supplied with bread of a finer, whiter quality than the usual prison fare, and even regaled each Sunday with a small quantity of wine. Now this was a Sunday, and the abbé had come to ask his young companion to share the luxuries with him.
Dantès followed him; his features were no longer contracted, and now wore their usual expression, but there was that in his whole appearance that bespoke one who had come to a fixed and desperate resolve. Faria bent on him his penetrating eye.
“I regret now,” said he, “having helped you in your late inquiries, or having given you the information I did.”
“Why so?” inquired Dantès.
“Because it has instilled a new passion in your heart—that of vengeance.”
Dantès smiled. “Let us talk of something else,” said he.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Is there anything else I can assist you in discovering, besides the villany of your friends?” inquired the abbé with a laugh.
“Yes,” returned Dantès, “I was not put on my trial; I was not examined. Do you call that regular?”
“No, but that is the custom in France, and especially in Paris, where they think nothing of burying a man alive in the Bastille, the Bicêtre, or the Charenton, as they did with Latude, and many others.”
“But then the king is deceived?” said Dantès.
“Certainly he is; but what does that signify to M. de Richelieu or M. de Sartines, who are the ministers? It is a word that means nothing. Now, let us return to your examination. You say you were not examined?”
“No.”
“Not even by the deputy-procureur?”
“Yes, once, but he was very young.”
“Young, was he? about twenty-six or twenty-seven years of age?”
“About that.”
“And his name was…?”
“M. de Villefort.”
“M. de Villefort,” repeated the abbé. “I knew his father, M. de Noirtier.”
“Noirtier!” exclaimed Dantès; “then you know him?”
“Yes; I knew him well. He was a Girondin, and a very warm partisan of the Revolution. He was a member of the Convention, and voted for the death of the king. He was a very clever man, and a very dangerous one.”
“And his son?”
“His son, as you say, was deputy-procureur. He was a very ambitious young man, and a very clever one too. He was very much attached to his father, and very much afraid of him.”
“And he examined me?”
“Yes, he examined you. And what did he say?”
“He asked me my name, my age, my profession, and where I came from. He asked me if I knew M. de Noirtier, and if I had a letter for him.”
“And you said?”
“I said that I did not know M. de Noirtier, and that I had a letter for him.”
“And he read the letter?”
“Yes, he read it.”
“And what did he do with it?”
“He burned it.”
“He burned it!” exclaimed the abbé. “He burned it before your eyes?”
“Yes.”
“And what did he say?”
“He said that the letter was a very dangerous one, and that it would ruin me if it were found. He said that he would burn it, and that I must promise him never to speak of it again, and never to utter the name of Noirtier.”
“And you promised him?”
“Yes.”
“And you have kept your promise?”
“Yes, until now.”
“And you have never spoken of this letter to any one?”
“Never.”
“Not even to your father?”
“No.”
“Nor to Mercédès?”
“No.”
“Nor to Fernand?”
“No.”
“Nor to Caderousse?”
“No.”
“Nor to Danglars?”
“No.”
“Nor to any one?”
“To no one.”
“And you have never uttered the name of Noirtier?”
“Never.”
“Until now?”
“Until now.”
“Good,” said the abbé. “Now I understand. This M. de Villefort was the son of M. de Noirtier.”
“Yes.”
“And he was afraid that the letter would compromise his father?”
“Yes.”
“And he burned it to save his father?”
“Yes.”
“And he made you promise never to speak of it again, and never to utter the name of Noirtier?”
“Yes.”
“And he sent you to prison?”
“Yes.”
“Without trial, without examination, without sentence?”
“Yes.”
“Because he was afraid that you would speak?”
“Yes.”
“And he was right,” said the abbé. “You would have spoken.”
“Yes,” said Dantès, “I would have spoken.”
“And you would have ruined his father?”
“Yes.”
“And he sent you to prison to save his father?”
“Yes.”
“And he was right,” repeated the abbé. “He was right.”
“But he was a scoundrel!” exclaimed Dantès.
“No,” said the abbé, “he was not a scoundrel. He was a man who loved his father.”
“But he sacrificed me to his father!”
“Yes,” said the abbé, “he sacrificed you to his father. But that is not being a scoundrel. That is being a man.”
“But he was a villain!” cried Dantès.
“No,” said the abbé, “he was not a villain. He was a man who was afraid.”
“Afraid of what?”
“Afraid of the law. Afraid of the guillotine. Afraid of being ruined. Afraid of being dishonored.”
“But he dishonored me!” cried Dantès.
“No,” said the abbé, “he did not dishonor you. He saved his father.”
“But he was a coward!” cried Dantès.
“No,” said the abbé, “he was not a coward. He was a man who was afraid.”
“But he was a monster!” cried Dantès.
“No,” said the abbé, “he was not a monster. He was a man who was afraid.”
“But he was a murderer!” cried Dantès.
“No,” said the abbé, “he was not a murderer. He was a man who was afraid.”
“But he was a demon!” cried Dantès.
“No,” said the abbé, “he was not a demon. He was a man who was afraid.”
“But he was a devil!” cried Dantès.
“No,” said the abbé, “he was not a devil. He was a man who was afraid.”
“But he was a fiend!” cried Dantès.
“No,” said the abbé, “he was not a fiend. He was a man who was afraid.”
“But he was a monster!” cried Dantès.
“No,” said the abbé, “he was not a monster. He was a man who was afraid.”

“But he was a coward!” cried Dantès.
“No,” said the abbé, “he was not a coward. He was a man who was afraid.”
“But he was a monster!” cried Dantès.
“No,” said the abbé, “he was not a monster. He was a man who was afraid

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Is there anything else I can assist you in discovering, besides the villany of your friends?” inquired the abbé with a laugh. Dantès stared at him, his face a mask of bewildered pain. “My friends?” he repeated, the word catching in his throat like a shard of glass. “But I have no friends who would do this! You speak of betrayal, Abbé, but by whom? Who could possibly gain from my ruin?” The abbé’s smile faded, replaced by an expression of profound pity. “Alas, my son,” he said softly, “it is often those closest to us who have the most to gain from our downfall. Envy, jealousy, ambition – these are powerful motives, capable of turning affection into malice.” He paused, allowing the weight of his words to settle upon the young man. “You asked who gained. Let us consider. Who coveted your position as captain of the *Pharaon*?” Dantès’s eyes widened slightly. “Danglars,” he whispered, the name tasting bitter on his tongue. “Precisely,” the abbé affirmed. “A man consumed by professional jealousy, who saw you as an obstacle to his own advancement. He was the first link in the chain.” “Danglars…” Dantès murmured, shaking his head in disbelief. “But he was my shipmate! We sailed together!” “And who,” the abbé continued, his voice low and steady, “was consumed by jealousy of another kind? Who desired the woman you were to marry, the beautiful Mercédès?” A cold dread began to creep into Dantès’s heart. He knew the answer before the abbé spoke the name. “Fernand,” he breathed, his voice barely audible. “Fernand Mondego.” “The very same,” said the abbé. “Your rival in love, who saw your impending marriage as the end of his hopes. He was the second link.” Dantès buried his face in his hands, a low groan escaping his lips. “Fernand… my friend since childhood… Mercédès’s cousin…” The abbé waited patiently, letting the storm of realization break over him. “And finally,” the abbé said, his tone hardening slightly, “who was the instrument of your destruction? Who, in his zeal to protect his own burgeoning career and conceal a dangerous secret, seized upon the denunciation and ensured it led to your perpetual imprisonment?” Dantès looked up, his eyes red-rimmed and filled with a dawning horror. “The examining magistrate,” he said, his voice hoarse. “Monsieur de Villefort.” “Gérard de Villefort,” the abbé confirmed, his gaze piercing. “The man who sacrificed your life to secure his own future. His father, Noirtier, was a staunch Bonapartist. At a time when the Bourbons were restored, such a connection was ruinous. Your letter, intended for the emperor, was the very evidence he needed to prove his own loyalty to the crown by ruthlessly suppressing any hint of Bonapartist conspiracy. He saw your innocence, he knew the denunciation was born of malice, but he chose to bury you and the secret with you.” Dantès sprang to his feet, pacing the narrow confines of the cell like a caged animal. “Danglars! Fernand! Villefort! All three! They conspired against me! They stole my freedom, my love, my life!” His voice rose to a shout, echoing off the stone walls. “Why? Why did they hate me so much?” “Not hate, my son,” the abbé corrected gently. “Self-interest. Danglars wanted your place. Fernand wanted your bride. Villefort wanted to protect his name and career. You were simply in their way. An inconvenience to be removed.” “An inconvenience!” Dantès cried, his fists clenched. “They condemned me to this living tomb for being an ‘inconvenience’?” He stopped pacing and turned to the abbé, his eyes blazing with a terrible light. “And the letter? How did they do it? How did they ensure it reached Villefort?” The abbé gestured towards the straw pallet. “Sit, my son. Let us examine the mechanics of their treachery. Danglars, as I deduced from your account of the events leading up to your arrest, was the author of the denunciation. He wrote the words that sealed your fate. Fernand, consumed by jealousy, was the one who undertook to deliver it, or ensure its delivery, to the authorities. He was the hand that carried the poison.” “Fernand delivered it?” Dantès repeated, his voice filled with anguish. “My friend… my brother…” “And Villefort,” the abbé continued, ignoring Dantès’s cry of pain, “was the judge, jury, and executioner. He received the letter, recognized its potential to implicate his own family, and instead of investigating its malicious origins, he destroyed it and you along with it. He saw the name ‘Noirtier’ in the address on the letter you carried, and his fate was sealed the moment he read it. He could not let that letter, or you, reach Paris.”

events.title: The Pact of Education and Dantès' Intellectual Transformation
detailed_summary: Faria, respecting Dantès' wish, changes the subject, his conversation rich with useful hints and sound information, never alluding to his own sorrows.
Dantès listens with admiration, finding some remarks corresponded with his existing nautical knowledge, while others opened new intellectual vistas.
He asks Faria to teach him, partly to prevent Faria from growing weary of his ignorance, and promises never again to mention escape.
Faria smiles and agrees, stating that human knowledge is limited and he can teach Dantès mathematics, physics, history, and several modern languages within about two years.
Dantès is amazed at the short timeframe.

Faria clarifies he can teach principles, not their application; memory makes learners, while philosophy makes the learned, and philosophy itself cannot be taught but is the application of sciences to truth.
Dantès, eager to begin, asks what Faria will teach him first.
Faria replies, "Everything," and that evening they sketch an educational plan.
Dantès possesses a prodigious memory and quick conception; his mathematical aptitude and poetic feelings aid his learning.
Already knowing Italian and some Romaic, he quickly comprehends other languages, speaking Spanish, English, and German within six months.
True to his promise, Dantès never mentions escape, possibly due to the delight of his studies or his keen sense of honor regarding his pledge.
Days and months pass rapidly in instructive pursuits, and at the end of a year, Dantès is transformed.

events.text_segment:
Again the abbé looked at him, then mournfully shook his head; but in accordance with Dantès’ request, he began to speak of other matters. The elder prisoner was one of those persons whose conversation, like that of all who have experienced many trials, contained many useful and important hints as well as sound information; but it was never egotistical, for the unfortunate man never alluded to his own sorrows. Dantès listened with admiring attention to all he said; some of his remarks corresponded with what he already knew, or applied to the sort of knowledge his nautical life had enabled him to acquire. A part of the good abbé’s words, however, were wholly incomprehensible to him; but, like the aurora which guides the navigator in northern latitudes, opened new vistas to the inquiring mind of the listener, and gave fantastic glimpses of new horizons, enabling him justly to estimate the delight an intellectual mind would have in following one so richly gifted as Faria along the heights of truth, where he was so much at home.
“You must teach me a small part of what you know,” said Dantès, “if only to prevent your growing weary of me. I can well believe that so learned a person as yourself would prefer absolute solitude to being tormented with the company of one as ignorant and uninformed as myself. If you will only agree to my request, I promise you never to mention another word about escaping.”
The abbé smiled.
“Alas, my boy,” said he, “human knowledge is confined within very narrow limits; and when I have taught you mathematics, physics, history, and the three or four modern languages with which I am acquainted, you will know as much as I do myself. Now, it will scarcely require two years for me to communicate to you the stock of learning I possess.”
“Two years!” exclaimed Dantès; “do you really believe I can acquire all these things in so short a time?”
“Not their application, certainly, but their principles you may; to learn is not to know; there are the learners and the learned. Memory makes the one, philosophy the other.”
“But cannot one learn philosophy?”
“Philosophy cannot be taught; it is the application of the sciences to truth; it is like the golden cloud in which the Messiah went up into heaven.”
“Well, then,” said Dantès, “What shall you teach me first? I am in a hurry to begin. I want to learn.”
“Everything,” said the abbé. And that very evening the prisoners sketched a plan of education, to be entered upon the following day. Dantès possessed a prodigious memory, combined with an astonishing quickness and readiness of conception; the mathematical turn of his mind rendered him apt at all kinds of calculation, while his naturally poetical feelings threw a light and pleasing veil over the dry reality of arithmetical computation, or the rigid severity of geometry. He already knew Italian, and had also picked up a little of the Romaic dialect during voyages to the East; and by the aid of these two languages he easily comprehended the construction of all the others, so that at the end of six months he began to speak Spanish, English, and German.
In strict accordance with the promise made to the abbé, Dantès spoke no more of escape. Perhaps the delight his studies afforded him left no room for such thoughts; perhaps the recollection that he had pledged his word (on which his sense of honor was keen) kept him from referring in any way to the possibilities of flight. Days, even months, passed by unheeded in one rapid and instructive course. At the end of a year Dantès was a new man.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Again the abbé looked at him, then mournfully shook his head; but in accordance with Dantès’ request, he began to speak of other matters. He spoke of his country, of the Campagna of Rome, of Florence, of Pisa, of the Tuscan coast, of the Archipelago, of Asia Minor, of Constantinople, of Egypt, of the all he knew, and all he had seen; and as he spoke, his conversation was rich with those delightful details that are found only in the recollections of travellers. He related the history of the illustrious unfortunates who have languished in prison, in chains, or in dungeons. He knew the histories of Pope Alexander VI. and his daughter Lucrezia Borgia; of Pope Clement VII. and the horrible massacre of Rome in 1527, when 28,000 of his people were murdered before his eyes; of the Duke de Guise, who was murdered by forty-five blows of a poniard; of the Chevalier de Saint-Méry, who was slowly tortured to death; of Urbain Grandier, who was burned at the stake with his manuscript; of Galileo, who was imprisoned for astronomical observations from which he recanted publicly, but who whispered, nevertheless, as he rose from his knees, “E pur si muove” (and yet it moves). He recounted the sufferings of Louis XI. at the Château de Loches, where he made Saint Francis de Paule come from Calabria to his assistance; of Edward II., smothered in the Castle of Berkeley; of Casimir V., who voluntarily renounced the crown; of Charles I., beheaded at Whitehall. As the abbé spoke, the pale face of Dantès brightened; he had found a companion in misfortune, but this companion was also a guide. He had found a man who, like himself, had suffered greatly, but who, instead of being crushed by his misfortunes, had surmounted them and turned them to account. He listened with admiration, and from time to time he interrupted him with a question. Some of the abbé’s remarks corresponded with the nautical knowledge which Dantès had acquired, and with the geographical descriptions given by Dantès’ father, and which had made him so anxious to go to sea; others related to science, and opened to Dantès new intellectual vistas. He had a desire to learn, which daily became more ardent. He had often heard of the Abbé Faria, and the high estimation in which he was held; but his admiration was greatly increased when he saw the man himself, and was enabled to judge of the vast extent of his acquirements. “You like history, do you not?” asked the abbé. “Oh, yes, very much,” replied Dantès; “you have made me like it better than ever.” “Well, then, I will teach it to you,” said the abbé; “and not only history, but mathematics, physics, and all I know myself, excepting, of course, the art of escaping, which you have already renounced.” Dantès smiled. “I will teach you all this,” continued the abbé, “in about two years.” “Two years!” exclaimed Dantès. “Yes; it is a short time, is it not?” asked the abbé. “I thought it would take ten,” replied Dantès. “Human knowledge is limited,” said Faria; “and when I have taught you mathematics, physics, history, and four or five modern languages, you will know nearly as much as I do. Memory makes learners, while philosophy makes the learned. Philosophy itself cannot be taught; it is the application of sciences to truth; it is the application of all knowledge to the well-being of humanity. It is the result of all knowledge, and it is this result which I will teach you.” Dantès was eager to begin. “What shall I learn first?” he asked. “Everything,” replied the abbé, and that evening they sketched a plan of education. Dantès possessed a prodigious memory and a quick conception; his mathematical aptitude and his poetic feelings aided his learning. He already knew Italian and some Romaic, and he quickly comprehended other languages, so that in six months he spoke Spanish, English, and German. True to his promise, Dantès never again mentioned escape; perhaps he had forgotten it in the delight of his studies, or perhaps his keen sense of honor regarding his pledge prevented him. Days and months passed rapidly in these instructive pursuits, and at the end of a year Dantès was a transformed man.

events.title: A New Escape Plan Hatched and Years of Arduous Labor
detailed_summary: Despite the companionship, Faria grows sadder, preoccupied by a persistent thought.
One day, Faria exclaims, "Ah, if there were no sentinel!"
Dantès, understanding Faria's thoughts, suggests the sentinel need not be an obstacle.
Faria reiterates his aversion to bloodshed, though Dantès argues it would be self-preservation.
Faria admits to incessantly thinking about it and reveals he has a plan if they could place a 'deaf and blind' sentinel in the gallery.
Dantès' determined reply, "He shall be both blind and deaf," makes Faria shudder and refuse further discussion.
After three months, Faria questions Dantès' strength; Dantès demonstrates by bending and straightening a chisel.
Faria makes Dantès promise not to harm the sentry except as a last resort.
With this assurance, Faria declares they can execute their design, estimating it will take at least a year.
Dantès laments the past year as wasted, but Faria reassures him.

Faria then reveals his plan: to dig a tunnel from the passage connecting their cells, extending beneath the sentinel's gallery. They would then excavate so a flagstone would collapse under the sentinel, who, stunned, would be bound and gagged by Dantès. They would then escape through a gallery window using Faria's ladder.
Dantès is overjoyed by the simple yet promising plan.
They begin their mining labor immediately with renewed vigor and hope.
Their work progresses, interrupted only by the need to return to their cells for turnkey visits, whose footsteps they learn to distinguish.
Excavated earth is pulverized and discreetly thrown from their windows at night.
More than a year is consumed in this undertaking, using only a chisel, a knife, and a wooden lever.
Throughout this period, Faria continues to instruct Dantès in various languages and subjects, imparting worldly knowledge and refinement.
After fifteen months, the tunnel and excavation under the gallery are complete; they can hear the sentinel pacing above.
They await a sufficiently dark night for their attempt, their main fear being the loosened stone giving way prematurely, which they try to prevent with a small wooden beam.
As Dantès arranges this beam, Faria, who was in Edmond's cell cutting a peg for the ladder, calls out in a tone of great suffering.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Dantès observed, however, that Faria, in spite of the relief his society afforded, daily grew sadder; one thought seemed incessantly to harass and distract his mind.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Dantès was occupied in arranging this piece of wood when he heard Faria, who had remained in Edmond’s cell for the purpose of cutting a peg to secure their rope-ladder, call to him in a tone indicative of great suffering.

events.text_segment:
Dantès observed, however, that Faria, in spite of the relief his society afforded, daily grew sadder; one thought seemed incessantly to harass and distract his mind. Sometimes he would fall into long reveries, sigh heavily and involuntarily, then suddenly rise, and, with folded arms, begin pacing the confined space of his dungeon. One day he stopped all at once, and exclaimed:
“Ah, if there were no sentinel!”
“There shall not be one a minute longer than you please,” said Dantès, who had followed the working of his thoughts as accurately as though his brain were enclosed in crystal so clear as to display its minutest operations.
“I have already told you,” answered the abbé, “that I loathe the idea of shedding blood.”
“And yet the murder, if you choose to call it so, would be simply a measure of self-preservation.”
“No matter! I could never agree to it.”
“Still, you have thought of it?”
“Incessantly, alas!” cried the abbé.
“And you have discovered a means of regaining our freedom, have you not?” asked Dantès eagerly.
“I have; if it were only possible to place a deaf and blind sentinel in the gallery beyond us.”
“He shall be both blind and deaf,” replied the young man, with an air of determination that made his companion shudder.
“No, no,” cried the abbé; “impossible!”
Dantès endeavored to renew the subject; the abbé shook his head in token of disapproval, and refused to make any further response. Three months passed away.
“Are you strong?” the abbé asked one day of Dantès. The young man, in reply, took up the chisel, bent it into the form of a horseshoe, and then as readily straightened it.
“And will you engage not to do any harm to the sentry, except as a last resort?”
“I promise on my honor.”
“Then,” said the abbé, “we may hope to put our design into execution.”
“And how long shall we be in accomplishing the necessary work?”
“At least a year.”
“And shall we begin at once?”
“At once.”
“We have lost a year to no purpose!” cried Dantès.
“Do you consider the last twelve months to have been wasted?” asked the abbé.
“Forgive me!” cried Edmond, blushing deeply.
“Tut, tut!” answered the abbé, “man is but man after all, and you are about the best specimen of the genus I have ever known. Come, let me show you my plan.”
The abbé then showed Dantès the sketch he had made for their escape. It consisted of a plan of his own cell and that of Dantès, with the passage which united them. In this passage he proposed to drive a level as they do in mines; this level would bring the two prisoners immediately beneath the gallery where the sentry kept watch; once there, a large excavation would be made, and one of the flag-stones with which the gallery was paved be so completely loosened that at the desired moment it would give way beneath the feet of the soldier, who, stunned by his fall, would be immediately bound and gagged by Dantès before he had power to offer any resistance. The prisoners were then to make their way through one of the gallery windows, and to let themselves down from the outer walls by means of the abbé’s ladder of cords.
Dantès’ eyes sparkled with joy, and he rubbed his hands with delight at the idea of a plan so simple, yet apparently so certain to succeed. That very day the miners began their labors, with a vigor and alacrity proportionate to their long rest from fatigue and their hopes of ultimate success. Nothing interrupted the progress of the work except the necessity that each was under of returning to his cell in anticipation of the turnkey’s visits. They had learned to distinguish the almost imperceptible sound of his footsteps as he descended towards their dungeons, and happily, never failed of being prepared for his coming. The fresh earth excavated during their present work, and which would have entirely blocked up the old passage, was thrown, by degrees and with the utmost precaution, out of the window in either Faria’s or Dantès’ cell, the rubbish being first pulverized so finely that the night wind carried it far away without permitting the smallest trace to remain.
More than a year had been consumed in this undertaking, the only tools for which had been a chisel, a knife, and a wooden lever; Faria still continuing to instruct Dantès by conversing with him, sometimes in one language, sometimes in another; at others, relating to him the history of nations and great men who from time to time have risen to fame and trodden the path of glory. The abbé was a man of the world, and had, moreover, mixed in the first society of the day; he wore an air of melancholy dignity which Dantès, thanks to the imitative powers bestowed on him by nature, easily acquired, as well as that outward polish and politeness he had before been wanting in, and which is seldom possessed except by those who have been placed in constant intercourse with persons of high birth and breeding.
At the end of fifteen months the level was finished, and the excavation completed beneath the gallery, and the two workmen could distinctly hear the measured tread of the sentinel as he paced to and fro over their heads. Compelled, as they were, to await a night sufficiently dark to favor their flight, they were obliged to defer their final attempt till that auspicious moment should arrive; their greatest dread now was lest the stone through which the sentry was doomed to fall should give way before its right time, and this they had in some measure provided against by propping it up with a small beam which they had discovered in the walls through which they had worked their way. Dantès was occupied in arranging this piece of wood when he heard Faria, who had remained in Edmond’s cell for the purpose of cutting a peg to secure their rope-ladder, call to him in a tone indicative of great suffering.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Dantès observed, however, that Faria, in spite of the relief his society afforded, daily grew sadder; one thought seemed incessantly to harass and distract his mind. Sometimes, in the middle of their conversation, he would stop, and his eyes would become fixed and vacant, and then he would heave a deep sigh. Dantès quickly perceived that Faria concealed something from him. One day he ventured to question him on the subject; but the abbé merely shook his head, and replied that the thing he thought of was of too serious a nature to be discussed by mere words. That night Dantès did not sleep. As he had done before he knew the abbé, he remained awake, listening to every sound, and fancying he heard the abbé sighing. The next day, when he went into the abbé’s chamber, he found him sitting with his head bent down, and his whole frame in a state of extreme depression. He did not notice Dantès’ entrance. The latter stood for a moment, hesitating whether to speak to him or not; but, seeing that his presence was unnoticed, and that Faria was so deeply engaged in the subject of his thoughts, he coughed. Faria raised his head, and, with a bitter smile, which was painful to see, held out his hand to Dantès. “As you see, my son,” said he, “the iron has entered into my soul.” Dantès sat down beside him. “It is a sad thing to feel that one’s will is powerless,” continued Faria. “There is one thing of which I am always thinking.” “Tell me what it is,” said Dantès, “and perhaps I may be able to assist you.” The abbé shook his head. “No,” said he, “it is a matter that concerns me alone, and in which no one can assist me.” “Is it anything connected with your escape?” asked Dantès. “Perhaps.” “Can I do anything to forward it?” “Yes; but you must have patience.” “I have patience,” said Dantès. “But tell me what it is.” Faria remained silent for a moment, and then, looking at Dantès with a searching glance, he said, “Edmond, if there were no sentinel!” “Ah,” said Dantès, “I understand you. You think that the sentinel is an insurmountable obstacle.” “He is,” said Faria. “But,” said Dantès, “the sentinel is a man like ourselves.” “Yes,” said Faria, “but he is armed, and we are not.” “But,” said Dantès, “we might disarm him.” “No,” said Faria, “I will not consent to bloodshed.” “But,” said Dantès, “it would be in self-defence.” “No,” said Faria, “I have an aversion to bloodshed.” Dantès was silent. He saw that the abbé was determined on this point. “But,” said Faria, after a moment’s silence, “if we could place a sentinel in the gallery who was deaf and blind, then I should have a plan.” “He shall be both blind and deaf,” replied Dantès, with a determined tone. Faria shuddered. “No,” said he, “I will not hear of it.” And he refused to say another word on the subject. Dantès saw that it was useless to press him further, and he left him. Three months passed away. During this time, Faria seemed to be constantly thinking of the same thing. One day, when Dantès was with him, he said, “Edmond, are you strong?” “I think so,” said Dantès. “Try,” said Faria, holding out a chisel. Dantès took the chisel, and, with a slight effort, bent it. “Good,” said Faria. “Now straighten it.” Dantès straightened the chisel. “You are strong enough,” said Faria. “Now, listen to me. I have a plan. But you must promise me one thing.” “What is it?” asked Dantès. “You must promise me that you will not harm the sentinel, unless it is absolutely necessary for your own preservation.” “I promise,” said Dantès. “Then,” said Faria, “we can execute our design. It will take at least a year.” “A year!” exclaimed Dantès. “Another year lost!” “No,” said Faria, “not lost. You have learned much during the past year.” “But,” said Dantès, “a year is a long time.” “It is,” said Faria, “but we must have patience.” “Tell me your plan,” said Dantès. “Listen,” said Faria. “We will dig a tunnel from the passage that connects our cells, and extend it beneath the gallery where the sentinel walks. We will then excavate the earth beneath one of the flagstones of the gallery, so that it will give way when the sentinel steps upon it. He will fall, and be stunned. You will then rush out, bind and gag him, and we will escape through the window of the gallery, using my ladder.” Dantès listened with intense interest. The plan was so simple, and yet so promising, that he could scarcely believe it. “And the sentinel?” he asked. “We will take his clothes, and leave him bound and gagged in the tunnel,” said Faria. “He will be found in the morning, and it will be supposed that he has been attacked by some of the prisoners.” “It is a bold plan,” said Dantès. “It is the only one that offers any chance of success,” said Faria. “Are you willing to undertake it?” “I am,” said Dantès. “Then,” said Faria, “let us begin at once.” They set to work immediately. Their labor was severe, but they worked with renewed vigor and hope. They dug the tunnel, and excavated the earth beneath the gallery. They were obliged to work in the greatest secrecy, and to return to their cells whenever they heard the footsteps of the turnkeys. They soon learned to distinguish the footsteps of each turnkey, and to know when they were approaching. They pulverized the excavated earth, and threw it out of their windows at night. More than a year was consumed in this undertaking. They had only a chisel, a knife, and a wooden lever to work with. During all this time, Faria continued to instruct Dantès in various languages, and in history, geography, and mathematics. He also taught him much concerning the manners and customs of different countries, and the laws and institutions of different governments. He imparted to him all the knowledge he had acquired during his long and studious life. Dantès made rapid progress, and became a man of extensive information and refined manners. After fifteen months, the tunnel and the excavation beneath the gallery were completed. They could hear the sentinel pacing above their heads. They now only awaited a sufficiently dark night for their attempt. Their principal fear was that the loosened stone might give way prematurely. To prevent this, they supported it with a small wooden beam. One day, as Dantès was arranging this beam, Faria, who was in Edmond’s cell cutting a peg for the ladder, called out in a tone of great suffering.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Dantès observed, however, that Faria, in spite of the relief his society afforded, daily grew sadder; one thought seemed incessantly to harass and distract his mind. It was evident that some secret sorrow, deeper than the loss of liberty, gnawed at his heart. Dantès, who had come to regard the old man with filial affection, could not bear to see him thus afflicted. He ventured, one day, to question him gently on the subject.

“My dear Abbé,” he said, “you have taught me so much, given me so much hope and strength. Yet, I see you are troubled. Is there something I can do? Some burden I can share?”

Faria sighed, a deep, weary sound that seemed to come from the very depths of his soul. He looked at Dantès with eyes that held a profound sadness, yet also a flicker of something else – a strange, feverish light.

“Ah, my son,” he replied, his voice low and hesitant, “you are kind, too kind. But this is a burden I have carried for many years, and it is one that grows heavier with each passing day of my captivity.”

“But what is it?” Dantès pressed, his concern growing. “Is it your past? Your enemies? The injustice of your imprisonment?”

“All that, yes,” Faria admitted, “but there is something more. A secret. A terrible, magnificent secret that consumes me.”

He paused, as if weighing whether to speak further. Dantès waited patiently, his heart pounding with a mixture of curiosity and apprehension.

Finally, Faria seemed to make a decision. He leaned closer, his voice dropping to a conspiratorial whisper, though there was no one to overhear them but the rats and the echoes of the dungeon.

“Dantès,” he began, “you know that I was once the secretary and friend of Cardinal Spada?”

“You have told me, Abbé.”

“And you know that Cardinal Spada was one of the wealthiest and most powerful princes of the Church in his time?”

“Yes.”

“What you do not know,” Faria continued, his eyes fixed on Dantès, “is the source of that immense wealth. It was not entirely derived from his benefices or his family’s ancient fortune. Much of it came from a hidden source, a treasure.”

Dantès stared, half-disbelieving. “A treasure?”

“Yes, a treasure,” Faria affirmed, his voice gaining a strange intensity. “Hidden by one of his ancestors, a man named Cesare Spada, in the year 1498. Cesare, fearing that Pope Alexander VI and his son Cesare Borgia would confiscate his vast riches, decided to conceal them.”

Faria then recounted how, upon the death of Cardinal Spada, his library and possessions had passed through several hands before being acquired by Cardinal Rospigliosi, in whose service Faria had been. It was while cataloguing the old cardinal’s library that Faria made his astonishing discovery.

“Among the books,” Faria explained, his eyes gleaming with the memory, “was an old breviary. It seemed unremarkable, but as I examined it closely, I noticed that some pages were stuck together. With great care, I separated them, and there, between the leaves, I found a piece of paper. It was yellowed with age, written in a cipher.”

Faria described the painstaking process of deciphering the code, a task that took him months of patient work. He had suspected it might be a political document or a family secret, but the reality was far more extraordinary.

“The message,” Faria said, his voice trembling slightly, “was a will. Not a legal will, but a testament from Cesare Spada to his descendants, revealing the location of his hidden fortune. It read: ‘I, Cesare Spada, having been warned that Pope Alexander VI is about to poison me, and fearing that my property will be confiscated by the Borgias, declare that I have hidden in the island of Monte Cristo, in the most remote cave, all my treasures, consisting of two million Roman crowns in gold and silver ingots, and a vast collection of jewels and precious stones

events.title: Faria's Sudden Catastrophic Illness and Dantès' Devoted Care
detailed_summary: Dantès rushes to Faria and finds him deathly pale, sweating, and with clenched hands.
Faria urgently explains he is seized by a terrible, possibly mortal illness, a recurring malady for which there is only one remedy.
He instructs Dantès to go to his cell, find a small phial half-filled with a red fluid hidden in a hollowed bedpost, and bring it to him.
Realizing he might be found, Faria asks Dantès to help him back to his own cell while he still has strength.
Despite the devastating blow to their escape hopes, Dantès maintains his presence of mind and helps Faria back to his bed.
Faria, shivering, explains he is about to have a cataleptic fit. He might lie still as if dead, or suffer violent convulsions and cry out.
He implores Dantès to ensure his cries are not heard, as discovery would lead to their permanent separation.
Faria instructs Dantès that only when he becomes completely motionless, cold, and rigid, should Dantès force open his teeth and administer eight to ten drops of the liquid, which might revive him.
Dantès exclaims in grief at the uncertainty.
Faria cries out that he is dying before a sudden, violent fit overtakes him, preventing him from finishing his sentence.
His body convulses, eyes bulge, mouth distorts, and he utters dreadful cries, which Dantès muffles with a blanket.
The fit lasts two hours, after which Faria falls back, colder and paler than marble, crushed and rigid as a corpse.
Edmond waits until Faria appears lifeless, then with difficulty pries open his jaws and administers the prescribed drops, anxiously awaiting the outcome.
After an hour with no sign of life, Dantès fears he delayed too long.
At length, a slight color returns to Faria's cheeks, consciousness to his eyes, a faint sigh escapes him, and he makes a feeble movement.
Dantès cries out in delight, "He is saved!"
Faria, unable to speak, anxiously points towards the door; Dantès hears the approaching jailer.
It is nearly seven o'clock; Dantès springs to the passage, closes the stone opening, and rushes to his cell, appearing seated on his bed just as the jailer enters.
Almost immediately after the jailer leaves, Dantès, foregoing his food, returns to Faria's chamber.
Faria has fully regained consciousness but remains helpless and exhausted on his bed.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Faria had now fully regained his consciousness, but he still lay helpless and exhausted on his miserable bed.

events.text_segment:
Dantès hastened to his dungeon, where he found him standing in the middle of the room, pale as death, his forehead streaming with perspiration, and his hands clenched tightly together.
“Gracious heavens!” exclaimed Dantès, “what is the matter? what has happened?”
“Quick! quick!” returned the abbé, “listen to what I have to say.”
Dantès looked in fear and wonder at the livid countenance of Faria, whose eyes, already dull and sunken, were surrounded by purple circles, while his lips were white as those of a corpse, and his very hair seemed to stand on end.
“Tell me, I beseech you, what ails you?” cried Dantès, letting his chisel fall to the floor.
“Alas,” faltered out the abbé, “all is over with me. I am seized with a terrible, perhaps mortal illness; I can feel that the paroxysm is fast approaching. I had a similar attack the year previous to my imprisonment. This malady admits but of one remedy; I will tell you what that is. Go into my cell as quickly as you can; draw out one of the feet that support the bed; you will find it has been hollowed out for the purpose of containing a small phial you will see there half-filled with a red-looking fluid. Bring it to me—or rather—no, no!—I may be found here, therefore help me back to my room while I have the strength to drag myself along. Who knows what may happen, or how long the attack may last?”
In spite of the magnitude of the misfortune which thus suddenly frustrated his hopes, Dantès did not lose his presence of mind, but descended into the passage, dragging his unfortunate companion with him; then, half-carrying, half-supporting him, he managed to reach the abbé’s chamber, when he immediately laid the sufferer on his bed.
“Thanks,” said the poor abbé, shivering as though his veins were filled with ice. “I am about to be seized with a fit of catalepsy; when it comes to its height I shall probably lie still and motionless as though dead, uttering neither sigh nor groan. On the other hand, the symptoms may be much more violent, and cause me to fall into fearful convulsions, foam at the mouth, and cry out loudly. Take care my cries are not heard, for if they are it is more than probable I should be removed to another part of the prison, and we be separated forever. When I become quite motionless, cold, and rigid as a corpse, then, and not before,—be careful about this,—force open my teeth with the knife, pour from eight to ten drops of the liquor contained in the phial down my throat, and I may perhaps revive.”
“Perhaps!” exclaimed Dantès in grief-stricken tones.
“Help! help!” cried the abbé, “I—I—die—I——”
So sudden and violent was the fit that the unfortunate prisoner was unable to complete the sentence; a violent convulsion shook his whole frame, his eyes started from their sockets, his mouth was drawn on one side, his cheeks became purple, he struggled, foamed, dashed himself about, and uttered the most dreadful cries, which, however, Dantès prevented from being heard by covering his head with the blanket. The fit lasted two hours; then, more helpless than an infant, and colder and paler than marble, more crushed and broken than a reed trampled under foot, he fell back, doubled up in one last convulsion, and became as rigid as a corpse.
Edmond waited till life seemed extinct in the body of his friend, then, taking up the knife, he with difficulty forced open the closely fixed jaws, carefully administered the appointed number of drops, and anxiously awaited the result. An hour passed away and the old man gave no sign of returning animation. Dantès began to fear he had delayed too long ere he administered the remedy, and, thrusting his hands into his hair, continued gazing on the lifeless features of his friend. At length a slight color tinged the livid cheeks, consciousness returned to the dull, open eyeballs, a faint sigh issued from the lips, and the sufferer made a feeble effort to move.
“He is saved! he is saved!” cried Dantès in a paroxysm of delight.
The sick man was not yet able to speak, but he pointed with evident anxiety towards the door. Dantès listened, and plainly distinguished the approaching steps of the jailer. It was therefore near seven o’clock; but Edmond’s anxiety had put all thoughts of time out of his head.
The young man sprang to the entrance, darted through it, carefully drawing the stone over the opening, and hurried to his cell. He had scarcely done so before the door opened, and the jailer saw the prisoner seated as usual on the side of his bed. Almost before the key had turned in the lock, and before the departing steps of the jailer had died away in the long corridor he had to traverse, Dantès, whose restless anxiety concerning his friend left him no desire to touch the food brought him, hurried back to the abbé’s chamber, and raising the stone by pressing his head against it, was soon beside the sick man’s couch. Faria had now fully regained his consciousness, but he still lay helpless and exhausted on his miserable bed.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Dantès hastened to his dungeon, where he found him standing in the middle of the room, pale as death, his forehead streaming with perspiration, and his hands clenched tightly together. He had been seized by one of those terrible attacks to which we have before alluded, and which frequently endangered his life. "Ah, my dear friend," said the abbé, with a look of inexpressible anguish, "you see I am dying; and not only that, but I am dying without seeing you again!" "Oh, no, no!" cried Dantès, "you will not die! What is this? Is it the same illness?" "The same, and yet more terrible; and if God does not permit me to find a remedy, I cannot long survive it." "A remedy!" exclaimed Dantès; "has this illness, then, a remedy?" "Yes, a remedy; a single one, a sovereign one; a remedy that has saved me when I have been ten times as ill as I am now; and if I had it by my side, I should be saved in ten minutes." "A remedy! and you have not this remedy?" cried Dantès in despair. "No, for I have lost it. The attack seized me when I was in the act of removing my bed to pass into your chamber; and I had not time to get my phial." "A phial! is your remedy, then, contained in a phial?" "Yes," answered the abbé, "in a small phial, of the kind you use for smelling-salts, of which I always have two or three about me." "And where is this phial?" "I have it not, I tell you; it is in my chamber, in the pocket of my frock, which is hanging on the wall." "Quick! quick!" cried Dantès; "tell me what is to be done." "You must go to my chamber," said the abbé; "take my frock from the wall, pass your hand into the pocket, and you will find the phial I spoke of; bring it to me, and if I have strength enough left to open it, or if you do it for me, and pour ten drops in a glass, I shall be saved." "But go to your chamber!" said Dantès; "how can I? The passage is blocked up." "It is not," cried Faria; "I removed the stones before I was attacked." "Oh, why did you not call me? why did you not call me?" cried Dantès. "A fit of giddiness came over me, and when it passed, I had scarcely strength to drag myself to the opening. Make haste, then, my dear friend; my life depends on your haste." "I will go directly," said Dantès, "but you?" "Oh, I will wait for you; I will pray to God to spare me till you return. Make haste!" Dantès waited not for a second bidding; he sprang into the passage, and in a moment arrived at the opening; the stones were removed, and the passage was free. He entered the abbé's chamber, went straight to the wall, and felt the frock; the phial was there. He seized it, and returned with the speed of lightning. He found the abbé in the same position, but his face was fearfully pale, and his features convulsed. "You are saved! you are saved!" cried Dantès, holding up the phial. "Give it to me! give it to me!" cried the abbé. "Quick! quick!" He seized the phial with a convulsive hand, raised it to his lips, and swallowed the contents. "It is past!" said he, falling back on his bed; "I am saved!" Dantès saw that he was indeed saved; the color returned to his cheeks, his eyes lost their wild expression, and he spoke with a firm voice. "But," said Dantès, "what was this terrible illness?" "It is a catalepsy," answered the abbé; "it is an attack that seizes me at intervals; it is a kind of lethargy, during which I lie as if dead, without sense or motion. I have been subject to it from my youth; it is a hereditary disease, and my father died of it." "And this remedy?" "It is a powerful stimulant, which restores me to life. I have always a supply of it about me, and it is the only thing that can save me." "But," said Dantès, "if you had not been able to remove the stones, and I had not been able to come to you?" "Then I should have died," answered the abbé. "But God has willed it otherwise, and he has sent you to save me." Dantès remained with the abbé all night; he watched over him with the tenderness of a son, and the abbé, who had recovered his strength, conversed with him on the subject of his illness. "This attack," said he, "is a warning from God; it tells me that I have not long to live. I must therefore make haste to communicate to you the secret I have so long guarded." "Oh, my dear friend," said Dantès, "do not speak of dying; you will live, and we shall be free." "No," said the abbé, "my hour is come; I feel it. But I will not die without revealing to you the secret of the treasure of the Spada family."
