events.title: Faria's Grim Prognosis and Dantès' Unwavering Oath of Loyalty
detailed_summary: Faria weakly tells Dantès he didn't expect to see him again, thinking Dantès might have escaped alone as all was ready.
Dantès is indignant at the suggestion that he would abandon Faria.
Faria acknowledges he was wrong and expresses his extreme exhaustion and debilitation from the attack.
Dantès tries to reassure him that his strength will return.

Faria reveals a grim reality: he can move neither his right arm nor leg, indicating a suffusion of blood on the brain. He states the third such attack will either kill him or leave him paralyzed for life.
He explains this is a family inheritance; his father and grandfather died from it in their third attack, and the physician Cabanis, who prepared the remedy, predicted a similar end for him.
Dantès’ hopeful suggestion that he could carry Faria while swimming is dismissed by Faria as impossible for a sailor.
Faria urges Dantès to cease false hopes and fly alone, releasing him from his promise to stay.
Dantès declares he will also remain.
Rising with solemnity, he extends his hand over Faria's head and swears by the blood of Christ never to leave him while he lives.
Faria, deeply moved by Dantès' devotion, accepts his oath.

He tells Dantès that since neither can or will leave, they must fill up the excavation under the gallery to prevent discovery from the hollow sound of the sentinel's footsteps, which would lead to their separation.

Faria instructs Dantès to undertake this work alone, all night if necessary, and not to return until after the jailer's visit the next day, as he will have something of greatest importance to communicate.
Dantès affectionately presses Faria's hand, and Faria smiles encouragingly as Dantès retires to his task with obedience and respect.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I did not expect to see you again,” said he feebly, to Dantès.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Faria smiled encouragingly on him, and the young man retired to his task, in the spirit of obedience and respect which he had sworn to show towards his aged friend.

events.text_segment:
I did not expect to see you again,” said he feebly, to Dantès.
“And why not?” asked the young man. “Did you fancy yourself dying?”
“No, I had no such idea; but, knowing that all was ready for flight, I thought you might have made your escape.”
The deep glow of indignation suffused the cheeks of Dantès.
“Without you? Did you really think me capable of that?”
“At least,” said the abbé, “I now see how wrong such an opinion would have been. Alas, alas! I am fearfully exhausted and debilitated by this attack.”
“Be of good cheer,” replied Dantès; “your strength will return.” And as he spoke he seated himself near the bed beside Faria, and took his hands. The abbé shook his head.
“The last attack I had,” said he, “lasted but half an hour, and after it I was hungry, and got up without help; now I can move neither my right arm nor leg, and my head seems uncomfortable, which shows that there has been a suffusion of blood on the brain. The third attack will either carry me off, or leave me paralyzed for life.”
“No, no,” cried Dantès; “you are mistaken—you will not die! And your third attack (if, indeed, you should have another) will find you at liberty. We shall save you another time, as we have done this, only with a better chance of success, because we shall be able to command every requisite assistance.”
“My good Edmond,” answered the abbé, “be not deceived. The attack which has just passed away, condemns me forever to the walls of a prison. None can fly from a dungeon who cannot walk.”
“Well, we will wait,—a week, a month, two months, if need be,—and meanwhile your strength will return. Everything is in readiness for our flight, and we can select any time we choose. As soon as you feel able to swim we will go.”
“I shall never swim again,” replied Faria. “This arm is paralyzed; not for a time, but forever. Lift it, and judge if I am mistaken.”
The young man raised the arm, which fell back by its own weight, perfectly inanimate and helpless. A sigh escaped him.
“You are convinced now, Edmond, are you not?” asked the abbé. “Depend upon it, I know what I say. Since the first attack I experienced of this malady, I have continually reflected on it. Indeed, I expected it, for it is a family inheritance; both my father and grandfather died of it in a third attack. The physician who prepared for me the remedy I have twice successfully taken, was no other than the celebrated Cabanis, and he predicted a similar end for me.”
“The physician may be mistaken!” exclaimed Dantès. “And as for your poor arm, what difference will that make? I can take you on my shoulders, and swim for both of us.”
“My son,” said the abbé, “you, who are a sailor and a swimmer, must know as well as I do that a man so loaded would sink before he had done fifty strokes. Cease, then, to allow yourself to be duped by vain hopes, that even your own excellent heart refuses to believe in. Here I shall remain till the hour of my deliverance arrives, and that, in all human probability, will be the hour of my death. As for you, who are young and active, delay not on my account, but fly—go—I give you back your promise.”
“It is well,” said Dantès. “Then I shall also remain.” Then, rising and extending his hand with an air of solemnity over the old man’s head, he slowly added, “By the blood of Christ I swear never to leave you while you live.”
Faria gazed fondly on his noble-minded, single-hearted, high-principled young friend, and read in his countenance ample confirmation of the sincerity of his devotion and the loyalty of his purpose.
“Thanks,” murmured the invalid, extending one hand. “I accept. You may one of these days reap the reward of your disinterested devotion. But as I cannot, and you will not, quit this place, it becomes necessary to fill up the excavation beneath the soldier’s gallery; he might, by chance, hear the hollow sound of his footsteps, and call the attention of his officer to the circumstance. That would bring about a discovery which would inevitably lead to our being separated. Go, then, and set about this work, in which, unhappily, I can offer you no assistance; keep at it all night, if necessary, and do not return here tomorrow till after the jailer has visited me. I shall have something of the greatest importance to communicate to you.”
Dantès took the hand of the abbé in his, and affectionately pressed it. Faria smiled encouragingly on him, and the young man retired to his task, in the spirit of obedience and respect which he had sworn to show towards his aged friend.

I did not expect to see you again,” said he feebly, to Dantès. “I had thought that you were already far away.”
“You did me an injustice, then,” replied Edmond, “and the proof is, that I am here.”
“That is true; and it is I who am punished for my fault, as I feel my self dying.”
“Oh, no, my friend,” said Dantès, “you will not die. We are free, and we have youth on our side.”
“Alas,” said Faria, “my dear friend, it is not youth that can save me; it is the physician. I feel that all is over. My first attack lasted but half an hour, and left me only a great weakness; the second deprived me for a short time of sight, and then my sight returned, but I had lost the use of my limbs. This third attack will either carry me off, or leave me paralyzed for life. So you see, my dear friend, the use of our freedom is over for me. Fly, fly then, yourself. You are young, and have hitherto been happy; stay not with me, a poor, paralytic, and despairing old man, with whom the jailer will leave you to die of hunger, or will perhaps think proper to bury you alive. That would be a double murder. Go, I repeat, go!”
“No, my friend,” said Dantès, “you shall not die. I will take care of you, and I shall save you, as you have saved me. We will escape together, and when we are free, I will be your son, your companion, your friend. We will never part till death separates us.”
“It is useless,” said the abbé. “My dear friend, you cannot carry me; the tunnel is small, and I am a heavy burden. I should only impede your flight, and they would recapture us both. No, no; fly alone. You are young, active, and strong, and you have the world before you.”
“But what will become of you?”
“What matters it? If I die here, I shall at least die in your arms. If you remain, you will be taken, and you will die in a dungeon. No, no; I tell you again, fly, and leave me to my fate.”
“It is in vain,” said Edmond. “I have sworn to remain with you, and I will keep my oath. If you die, I will die with you. If you are buried, I will be buried with you.”
“My friend, my friend,” said the abbé, “you are a noble heart. I thank you. But I must tell you, that I have no hope of recovery. I feel that the end is near. My father and my grandfather died of the same disease, and the physician Cabanis, who attended them, told me that I should probably die of it also, and that the third attack would be fatal. So you see, my dear friend, there is no hope for me.”
“But we will escape,” said Edmond, with a feverish energy. “We will escape, and we will find a physician who will cure you.”
“It is impossible,” said the abbé. “I can no longer move my right arm or my right leg. I am paralyzed on one side. How can I escape?”
“I will carry you,” said Edmond.
“You cannot. The passage is too narrow, and you are not strong enough.”
“But I will try.”
“It is useless, I tell you. Do not deceive yourself with false hopes. Fly, fly alone, and leave me to die in peace.”
“No,” said Edmond, firmly. “I will not leave you. I will stay with you, and I will take care of you.”
“Then,” said the abbé, “since you are determined to remain, we must fill up the excavation under the gallery. The sentinel passes there, and if he hears the hollow sound of his footsteps, he will suspect something, and we shall be discovered and separated. You must do it alone, for I cannot help you. You must work all night, if necessary, and you must not return till after the jailer has been here to-morrow morning. I shall have something of the greatest importance to communicate to you.”
Edmond pressed the abbé’s hand affectionately, and the abbé smiled on him with an expression of paternal tenderness. Edmond then retired to his chamber, and began to work with obedience and respect.

His eyes, usually so bright with the fire of intellect, were dimmed and sunken, fixed upon Dantès with a look of profound weariness, yet tinged with a flicker of recognition and perhaps, relief. Dantès rushed to his side, kneeling beside the pallet of straw that served as the old man’s bed. “Abbé! You are ill! What has happened?” he cried, his heart constricting with fear. He had grown to love this extraordinary man, his mentor, his only companion in this living tomb. Faria smiled faintly, a mere ghost of his former vibrant expression. “Nothing, my son, that time and this accursed place do not inflict upon us all. Another attack, that is all. Dantès gently raised his head, offering him a little water from the earthen jug. Faria drank slowly, his hand trembling. “Thank you, Edmond,” he murmured. “You are a good son. chapters.chapter_title: VOLUME ONE. Chapter 18. The Treasure

events.title: Faria's Revelation of the Treasure and Dantès's Skepticism
detailed_summary: Faria, appearing calm, showed Dantès a partially burned sheet of paper.
Dantès identified it as old, bearing Gothic script in a strange ink.
Faria announced this paper was his treasure and, due to Dantès's proven loyalty, offered him half.
Dantès became anxious, recalling Faria's past declarations about a treasure, which he had dismissed as madness.
He had consciously avoided the subject, and Faria's previous silence had led him to believe the Abbé had regained his senses.
Faria's current words ignited Dantès's fear that his companion was suffering a severe relapse into mental delusion.
Faria attempted to soothe Dantès, insisting on his own sanity and the treasure's reality, prophesying that Dantès would eventually possess it.
He suggested that while others dismissed him as mad, Dantès, knowing him better, should believe him.
Dantès, privately despairing at what he perceived as Faria's relapse, proposed that Faria rest and discuss the matter later.
Faria countered that the matter was urgent, fearing another cataleptic attack might prevent him from revealing the secret.

He confessed a past, vengeful satisfaction in the thought that his persecutors would never find the riches, but expressed that his affection for Dantès now motivated him to ensure Dantès acquired the wealth.
Dantès sighed, expressing his continued disbelief.
Observing Dantès's skepticism, Faria urged him to examine the paper, which he claimed to have never shown to anyone else.
To placate Faria, Dantès consented to read it, though he still wished to defer the conversation.
He read the cryptic, fragmented message, which mentioned a treasure and a date.
Dantès commented that he could only discern broken phrases and illegible words damaged by fire.
Faria asserted that while unclear to Dantès, he had meticulously deciphered its meaning through long study.
Just as Dantès questioned if Faria had truly uncovered the hidden meaning, they were interrupted by approaching footsteps.
Dantès seized the opportunity to depart, relieved to avoid further discussion that he feared would confirm Faria's instability, while Faria hastily concealed their passage.

events.text_segment:
When Dantès returned next morning to the chamber of his companion in captivity, he found Faria seated and looking composed. In the ray of light which entered by the narrow window of his cell, he held open in his left hand, of which alone, it will be recollected, he retained the use, a sheet of paper, which, from being constantly rolled into a small compass, had the form of a cylinder, and was not easily kept open. He did not speak, but showed the paper to Dantès.
“What is that?” he inquired.
“Look at it,” said the abbé with a smile.
“I have looked at it with all possible attention,” said Dantès, “and I only see a half-burnt paper, on which are traces of Gothic characters inscribed with a peculiar kind of ink.”
“This paper, my friend,” said Faria, “I may now avow to you, since I have the proof of your fidelity—this paper is my treasure, of which, from this day forth, one-half belongs to you.”
The sweat started forth on Dantès’ brow. Until this day and for how long a time!—he had refrained from talking of the treasure, which had brought upon the abbé the accusation of madness. With his instinctive delicacy Edmond had preferred avoiding any touch on this painful chord, and Faria had been equally silent. He had taken the silence of the old man for a return to reason; and now these few words uttered by Faria, after so painful a crisis, seemed to indicate a serious relapse into mental alienation.
“Your treasure?” stammered Dantès. Faria smiled.
“Yes,” said he. “You have, indeed, a noble nature, Edmond, and I see by your paleness and agitation what is passing in your heart at this moment. No, be assured, I am not mad. This treasure exists, Dantès, and if I have not been allowed to possess it, you will. Yes—you. No one would listen or believe me, because everyone thought me mad; but you, who must know that I am not, listen to me, and believe me so afterwards if you will.”
“Alas,” murmured Edmond to himself, “this is a terrible relapse! There was only this blow wanting.” Then he said aloud, “My dear friend, your attack has, perhaps, fatigued you; had you not better repose awhile? Tomorrow, if you will, I will hear your narrative; but today I wish to nurse you carefully. Besides,” he said, “a treasure is not a thing we need hurry about.”
“On the contrary, it is a matter of the utmost importance, Edmond!” replied the old man. “Who knows if tomorrow, or the next day after, the third attack may not come on? and then must not all be over? Yes, indeed, I have often thought with a bitter joy that these riches, which would make the wealth of a dozen families, will be forever lost to those men who persecute me. This idea was one of vengeance to me, and I tasted it slowly in the night of my dungeon and the despair of my captivity. But now I have forgiven the world for the love of you; now that I see you, young and with a promising future,—now that I think of all that may result to you in the good fortune of such a disclosure, I shudder at any delay, and tremble lest I should not assure to one as worthy as yourself the possession of so vast an amount of hidden wealth.”
Edmond turned away his head with a sigh.
“You persist in your incredulity, Edmond,” continued Faria. “My words have not convinced you. I see you require proofs. Well, then, read this paper, which I have never shown to anyone.”
“Tomorrow, my dear friend,” said Edmond, desirous of not yielding to the old man’s madness. “I thought it was understood that we should not talk of that until tomorrow.”
“Then we will not talk of it until tomorrow; but read this paper today.”
“I will not irritate him,” thought Edmond, and taking the paper, of which half was wanting,—having been burnt, no doubt, by some accident,—he read:
“this treasure, which may amount to two...
of Roman crowns in the most distant a...
of the second opening wh...
declare to belong to him alo...
heir.
                    “25th April, 149’”
“Well!” said Faria, when the young man had finished reading it.
“Why,” replied Dantès, “I see nothing but broken lines and unconnected words, which are rendered illegible by fire.”
“Yes, to you, my friend, who read them for the first time; but not for me, who have grown pale over them by many nights’ study, and have reconstructed every phrase, completed every thought.”
“And do you believe you have discovered the hidden meaning?”
“I am sure I have, and you shall judge for yourself; but first listen to the history of this paper.”
“Silence!” exclaimed Dantès. “Steps approach—I go—adieu!”
And Dantès, happy to escape the history and explanation which would be sure to confirm his belief in his friend’s mental instability, glided like a snake along the narrow passage; while Faria, restored by his alarm to a certain amount of activity, pushed the stone into place with his foot, and covered it with a mat in order the more effectually to avoid discovery.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: When Dantès returned next morning to the chamber of his companion in captivity, he found Faria seated and looking composed. In his left hand he held a sheet of paper, which he was carefully examining. ‘Look,’ said he to Dantès, ‘I have found it.’ Dantès took the paper, which was covered with Gothic writing, and over which a thick line had been traced. ‘This paper,’ said Faria, ‘I found in a portfolio I inherited from my great-uncle, the Abbé Faria, who lived in the time of Cæsar Borgia, and who was chaplain to Pope Alexander VI. This portfolio has been in the family from that period. It was not till the other day that I thought of examining the papers it contained, when I discovered this.’ ‘And what is this?’ asked Dantès. ‘Read it,’ replied Faria. ‘It is difficult to read, the writing is so old,’ said Dantès. ‘I have studied it so long that I know it by heart,’ said Faria. ‘I will assist you. That first line is in Latin, and means, “Seek in the fifth of the grottos of the island of Monte Cristo.”’ ‘What island is that?’ asked Dantès. ‘The island of Monte Cristo, near Pianosa,’ replied Faria, ‘a desert island, which has been uninhabited since the time of the pirates. It is there that the Cardinal Spada concealed his treasure, and I have no doubt that this is the paper which will enable you to discover it.’ ‘And what is this treasure?’ asked Dantès. ‘A treasure of two millions of Roman crowns, which are worth nearly thirteen millions of our money,’ replied Faria. ‘And this paper?’ asked Dantès. ‘This paper,’ said Faria, ‘is a will made by the Cardinal Spada, who, fearing that Cæsar Borgia would seize his wealth, concealed it in the island of Monte Cristo, and left this paper to his family, that they might be able to find it after his death. But the paper was lost, and the treasure remained concealed. It was not till the other day that I found this paper, and I have no doubt that it is the one which will enable you to discover the treasure.’ Dantès was struck with astonishment. He had often heard of the immense wealth of the Cardinal Spada, but he had never believed that it was still in existence. ‘And you say that this paper will enable me to discover it?’ asked he. ‘Yes,’ replied Faria, ‘if you follow the directions it contains. But it is necessary that you should be able to read it, and it is written in a cipher which is very difficult to understand.’ ‘But you have understood it?’ said Dantès. ‘Yes,’ replied Faria, ‘after studying it for many years. And I have no doubt that I have discovered the secret.’ ‘And you say that this treasure is worth thirteen millions?’ asked Dantès. ‘Yes,’ replied Faria, ‘and it is all in gold and jewels.’ Dantès was lost in thought. He had often dreamed of wealth, but he had never imagined that it was possible to acquire such a sum. ‘And you say that this paper belongs to you?’ asked he. ‘Yes,’ replied Faria, ‘it belongs to me, and I give it to you.’ ‘To me?’ cried Dantès. ‘Yes, to you,’ replied Faria. ‘You have been a faithful companion to me, and I wish to give you a proof of my gratitude.’ ‘But why do you give it to me?’ asked Dantès. ‘Because,’ replied Faria, ‘I have no need of it. I am old and infirm, and I have not long to live. And I wish to give you a proof of my affection.’ ‘But why do you not keep it for yourself?’ asked Dantès. ‘Because,’ replied Faria, ‘I have no family, and I wish to give it to you, who are like a son to me.’ ‘But why do you not give it to your family?’ asked Dantès. ‘Because,’ replied Faria, ‘I have no family, and I wish to give it to you, who are like a son to me.’ Dantès was deeply moved. He had never expected such a proof of affection from his companion. ‘But why do you not keep it for yourself?’ asked he. ‘Because,’ replied Faria, ‘I have no family, and I wish to give it to you, who are like a son to me.’ Dantès was deeply moved. LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
When Dantès returned next morning to the chamber of his companion in captivity, he found Faria seated and looking composed. Dantès, on the other hand, was overwhelmed with shame and disappointment. His face was pale, his eyes downcast, and his movements slow and heavy. He felt like a child who had boasted of a great feat only to fail miserably in the attempt. The brief flicker of hope that had sustained him through the arduous night had been brutally extinguished, leaving behind only the cold, hard reality of his prison walls, thicker and more impenetrable than he had ever imagined.

He sank onto his stool, unable to meet the old man's gaze. He expected reproach, perhaps even pity, which would have been almost as unbearable. But Faria said nothing for a moment, merely observing him with a gentle, understanding expression. The silence stretched, filled only by the distant sounds of the fortress and the quiet rustling of Faria's papers.

Finally, Faria spoke, his voice calm and steady, devoid of any trace of judgment. "So," he said softly, "you have learned that stone is harder than hope?" His tone was not mocking, but rather that of someone who had long ago come to terms with such harsh lessons.

Dantès winced. "It was useless, Abbé," he murmured, his voice thick with despair. "All that work... all that hope... for nothing. The wall... it is too thick. I dug for hours, and made scarcely any impression. It is impossible. We are buried alive."

Faria nodded slowly. "Impossible is a word invented by those who find it easier to live in the world as it is given to them, rather than explore the power they have to change it. However," he added, a faint smile touching his lips, "even the greatest power has its limits. You encountered one such limit last night. The rock of the Château d'If is renowned for its density and depth. It is not merely a wall, but the very foundation of the island itself, plunging deep into the sea."

"Then there is no hope," Dantès said, the words a bitter taste in his mouth.

"Hope is a different matter," Faria replied. "Hope is the sun that warms us, the light that guides us. It is not a tool for breaking stone. You confused the desire for freedom with the means to achieve it. Your hope was valid, Edmond, but your method, while brave and determined, was insufficient against such an obstacle. You attacked the mountain with a pickaxe, when perhaps a different approach is needed."

Dantès looked up, a flicker of curiosity piercing his gloom. "A different approach? What other approach can there be? We are in a dungeon, Abbé, with only these tools and our hands."

Faria leaned forward slightly. "Knowledge, Edmond. Knowledge is the most powerful tool of all. You have strength, courage, and determination. These are admirable qualities, but they must be guided by understanding. You attempted to overcome a physical barrier with physical force alone. But perhaps the barrier is not solely physical. Perhaps there are other ways around it, or through it, that do not involve brute strength."

Dantès listened intently, his despair momentarily forgotten in the face of Faria's quiet confidence. "What do you mean?" he asked.

"I mean that every problem has multiple solutions," Faria explained. "And the best solution is often not the most obvious one. You have learned the limits of one path. Now, we must consider others. Your attempt was not a failure, Edmond. It was a valuable experiment. It taught us the nature of the obstacle. Now we know precisely what we are up against. This knowledge is power."

He paused, allowing his words to sink in. Dantès felt a faint stirring within him, a tiny ember of the hope that had been so cruelly extinguished. Faria was not dismissing his pain or his effort; he was reframing the experience, turning a crushing defeat into a lesson learned.

"But what other way is there?" Dantès repeated, still struggling to grasp the concept.

"That is what we must discover

events.title: The Governor's Visit and Dantès's Lingering Doubts
detailed_summary: The prison governor visited Faria personally after being informed of his illness by the jailer.
Faria, upon receiving him, carefully hid the extent of his paralysis, fearing that pity might lead the governor to move him to better quarters, thereby separating him from Dantès.
The governor, who harbored a degree of fondness for the man he considered a harmless lunatic, left under the impression that Faria was suffering only a minor ailment.
Meanwhile, Dantès, isolated in his own cell, grappled with conflicting thoughts.
He reflected on Faria's consistent intelligence and sound judgment on all other matters, finding it difficult to reconcile these qualities with the apparent obsession about the treasure.
Dantès found himself questioning whether Faria was genuinely deluded regarding the treasure, or if the rest of the world was mistaken about Faria's sanity.
He chose to stay in his cell for the remainder of the day, avoiding Faria to postpone what he believed would be the heartbreaking confirmation of his friend's madness.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was the governor, who, hearing of Faria’s illness from the jailer, had come in person to see him.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Dantès remained in his cell all day, not daring to return to his friend, thinking thus to defer the moment when he should be convinced, once for all, that the abbé was mad—such a conviction would be so terrible!

events.text_segment:
It was the governor, who, hearing of Faria’s illness from the jailer, had come in person to see him.
Faria sat up to receive him, avoiding all gestures in order that he might conceal from the governor the paralysis that had already half stricken him with death. His fear was lest the governor, touched with pity, might order him to be removed to better quarters, and thus separate him from his young companion. But fortunately this was not the case, and the governor left him, convinced that the poor madman, for whom in his heart he felt a kind of affection, was only troubled with a slight indisposition.
During this time, Edmond, seated on his bed with his head in his hands, tried to collect his scattered thoughts. Faria, since their first acquaintance, had been on all points so rational and logical, so wonderfully sagacious, in fact, that he could not understand how so much wisdom on all points could be allied with madness. Was Faria deceived as to his treasure, or was all the world deceived as to Faria?
Dantès remained in his cell all day, not daring to return to his friend, thinking thus to defer the moment when he should be convinced, once for all, that the abbé was mad—such a conviction would be so terrible!

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: It was the governor, who, hearing of Faria’s illness from the jailer, had come in person to see him. Faria received him, and knowing that the least complaint might lead to his being removed to the infirmary, and consequently separated from Dantès, he concealed the paralysis which had already made such fearful progress; he only complained of a slight indisposition, and by a singular effort of willpower, even avoided making use of gestures, lest the governor should suspect the extent of his physical prostration. The governor, who felt a sort of affection for this old man, who was neither violent nor dangerous, and whose madness was rather an amiable delusion than a frightful mania, left under the impression that Faria was only slightly indisposed. Meanwhile, Dantès remained in his cell, and this time he did not go to Faria. He could not reconcile himself to the idea of a mind so powerful, so clear-sighted, and so intelligent, being deranged on one point. However reasonable the abbé had been on all other subjects, on this his reason failed him; it was a sort of monomania, which had its source in the recollection of the dungeon, and had grown into a fixed idea from his long captivity. And the unfortunate young man passed the day in his cell, with his head in his hands, trying to understand how so much wisdom and reason could be allied with such folly. Was Faria really deluded as to this treasure, or was all the world mistaken as to Faria? He remained, therefore, in his cell all day, that he might not be compelled to witness the sad spectacle of his friend’s madness.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: It was the governor, who, hearing of Faria’s illness from the jailer, had come in person to see him. Dantes stood by, a silent, anxious observer, as the portly official entered the cell, his face a mask of professional concern. The governor approached the pallet where the old man lay, his features drawn and pale, one side of his body tragically still. He spoke a few perfunctory words, asking about the symptoms, his gaze sweeping over the meager furnishings and the prisoner himself with a practiced, detached air. Faria, with difficulty, articulated his condition, his voice weak but retaining a flicker of his former intellect. The governor listened, nodded, and then, after a brief, clinical examination of the afflicted limb, straightened up. There was no real hope offered, only a promise of such poor medical attention as the prison afforded – a mere formality for a man clearly beyond recovery in this desolate place. With a final, dismissive glance that seemed to consign the brilliant Abbé to his inevitable end, the governor turned and left, his heavy footsteps echoing down the corridor, leaving Dantes alone once more with his dying friend and the crushing weight of their shared captivity.

events.title: Faria's Determined Pursuit and the Beginning of the Spada Chronicle
detailed_summary: As evening approached and Dantès had not visited, Faria, despite his physical limitations, made a strenuous effort to reach Dantès's cell.
Dantès was distressed to hear the sounds of the old man arduously dragging himself, his leg and one arm being useless.
Feeling compelled to help, Dantès assisted Faria in navigating the small opening into his chamber.
Faria, smiling kindly, remarked on his own relentless pursuit, suggesting Dantès could not evade his intended generosity.
Dantès, seeing no way to avoid the conversation further, helped Faria onto his bed and sat beside him, prepared to listen.
Faria commenced his story, explaining his past role as the secretary and confidant of Cardinal Spada, the last of that noble family.
He credited this worthy lord with all the happiness he had ever experienced, noting that despite the family's proverbial wealth, the Cardinal himself was not affluent.
Faria described the Cardinal's palace as his personal paradise and spoke of his deep devotion to the Cardinal, especially after tutoring his nephews who had since passed away.
He recalled frequently observing his patron engrossed in annotating ancient books and searching through dusty family manuscripts.

Faria then recounted an incident where, after he had gently chided the Cardinal for his seemingly futile research and the subsequent mental exhaustion, the Cardinal responded with a bitter smile and opened a book on the history of Rome.
He directed Dantès's attention to particular lines within the twentieth chapter concerning the life of Pope Alexander VI, lines Faria claimed he would never forget.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There, in the twentieth chapter of the Life of Pope Alexander VI., were the following lines, which I can never forget:—

events.text_segment:
But, towards the evening after the hour for the customary visit had gone by, Faria, not seeing the young man appear, tried to move and get over the distance which separated them. Edmond shuddered when he heard the painful efforts which the old man made to drag himself along; his leg was inert, and he could no longer make use of one arm. Edmond was obliged to assist him, for otherwise he would not have been able to enter by the small aperture which led to Dantès’ chamber.
“Here I am, pursuing you remorselessly,” he said with a benignant smile. “You thought to escape my munificence, but it is in vain. Listen to me.”
Edmond saw there was no escape, and placing the old man on his bed, he seated himself on the stool beside him.
“You know,” said the abbé, “that I was the secretary and intimate friend of Cardinal Spada, the last of the princes of that name. I owe to this worthy lord all the happiness I ever knew. He was not rich, although the wealth of his family had passed into a proverb, and I heard the phrase very often, ‘As rich as a Spada.’ But he, like public rumor, lived on this reputation for wealth; his palace was my paradise. I was tutor to his nephews, who are dead; and when he was alone in the world, I tried by absolute devotion to his will, to make up to him all he had done for me during ten years of unremitting kindness. The cardinal’s house had no secrets for me. I had often seen my noble patron annotating ancient volumes, and eagerly searching amongst dusty family manuscripts. One day when I was reproaching him for his unavailing searches, and deploring the prostration of mind that followed them, he looked at me, and, smiling bitterly, opened a volume relating to the History of the City of Rome. There, in the twentieth chapter of the Life of Pope Alexander VI., were the following lines, which I can never forget:—

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: But, towards the evening after the hour for the customary visit had gone by, Faria, not seeing the young man appear, tried to move and get over the distance which separated them. He dragged himself along, with the help of his hands and the one leg which was still serviceable, and Dantès heard the groaning sound of the old man's struggle. He was distressed to the last degree, and directly the opening was made, he sprang to meet him. "Oh, my dear friend!" said Dantès, "how could you be so imprudent? Why did you not call me, and I would have come?" "A call might have betrayed us," returned Faria, "and as my leg would not carry me, I have brought it with me." And he smiled on the young man, who saw that he still held the leg of the bed with which he had so often drilled the wall. "Come, come," said Faria, when he had entered, "do not concern yourself about me, but think only of yourself. If you are tired, go to sleep, and leave me to watch." "No, no," said Dantès, "I am not in the least tired; but, after the joy of this morning, I am rather overcome." "Sit down, then, and listen to me," said Faria. Dantès drew the stool to the side of the bed, and seated himself. "I have had a most delightful day," said Faria, "and you must let me finish it after my own fashion. Listen." Dantès gave the most profound attention. "You know that I was the secretary and friend of Cardinal Spada, the last of the princes of that name. I owe to this worthy lord all the happiness I ever enjoyed. He was a man of great capacity and profound knowledge, but was more especially remarkable for his immense fortune, which he had himself considerably increased since his accession to the rank of cardinal, by speculation in different banks, both at Rome and Paris. His income was considered at that time to be about four million livres; and he possessed two of the most splendid palaces in Rome, one magnificent residence at Florence, and ten estates in different parts of Italy, besides which he had pictures, statues, gold plate, and diamonds of immense value. He never married, but was intended for the Church from his earliest youth. His affections, therefore, centred on his two nephews, the sole heirs of his immense possessions. The first was the Duke della Spada, the other the Count Cesare Spada. The cardinal loved them both dearly, but it was no easy matter to please him, for he was very capricious. He received a large number of visitors, and maintained a princely establishment, and it was one of the most striking things to observe the contrast between the luxury of the palace and the frugality of the patron. As I had said before, I was the secretary of the cardinal, and this is how I gained his confidence. He was an enlightened man, and was very fond of antiquities, and we often passed whole days in examining the ruins of the old city, of which he knew every stone. He was not so fond of modern history, but was perfectly acquainted with that of the Middle Ages. As, however, his fortune was so immense, and he was justly supposed to be still more wealthy, he was very much sought after by all the popes, and was required to give them large sums, which he did willingly, knowing that it is the policy of the Church to ask constantly from those who are rich, and to give occasionally to those who are poor. Upon his accession, Urban VI found himself in great pecuniary distress, and as he knew that the cardinal had large possessions, he applied to him for a loan of a hundred thousand crowns. The cardinal gave them to him, and when he was in the act of signing the receipt, Urban VI said to him, smiling, 'I thank you, my dear cardinal; it is a great service that you render me, and I shall never forget it.' The cardinal smiled in his turn, and said, 'Holy Father, I am always happy to be able to render any service to your holiness.' 'Yes,' replied the pope, 'but this is a great service

events.title: The Borgia Conspiracy and the Fatal Banquet
detailed_summary: Faria narrated from the historical account, explaining that after the Romagna wars, Cæsar Borgia required funds to secure his Italian conquests, and Pope Alexander VI also needed money to deal with King Louis XII of France.
The Pope conceived a plan to create two new cardinals from wealthy Roman personages.
This scheme involved selling the prestigious offices these men already held, selling the two new cardinal hats, and a third, more sinister objective.
The chosen individuals were Giovanni Rospigliosi and Cæsar Spada, both men of high standing and considerable wealth.
They paid for the cardinal positions, and others paid for their vacated offices, enriching the papal coffers by eight hundred thousand crowns.
Faria then detailed the final phase: the Pope and Cæsar Borgia invited the new cardinals to dinner.
Cæsar Borgia had initially proposed using one of his signature assassination devices – a poisoned key or a ring with a lion's head that delivered a fatal bite.
However, Pope Alexander VI preferred poisoning them at dinner, arguing it produced more immediate results than the delayed effects of a prick or bite.
The dinner was arranged at a vineyard retreat familiar to the cardinals. Rospigliosi attended with enthusiasm.
Cardinal Spada, however, being a prudent man deeply attached to his nephew, wrote his will and attempted to warn his nephew to meet him near the vineyard, but the message seemingly never reached him.
Spada recognized such invitations as thinly veiled death sentences, a modern refinement on older, cruder methods of dispatch.
Upon arriving, Spada was dismayed to see his nephew already present and being flattered by Cæsar Borgia, realizing the trap was set.
During the meal, Spada confirmed his nephew had not received his warning; it was already too late, as the nephew had consumed wine specially poured for him.
Spada himself was pressured to drink from another bottle. An hour later, a physician pronounced both men poisoned by mushrooms.
Spada died at the vineyard's entrance, while his nephew expired at his own home, making desperate, unintelligible signs to his wife.
Cæsar Borgia and the Pope quickly moved to claim the Spada inheritance, ostensibly to search for the deceased's papers.
They found only a note bequeathing coffers, books, and a gold-cornered breviary to Spada's nephew.
The official heirs searched diligently but found no significant treasure, only the library and laboratories, leading to astonishment that the reputedly wealthy Spada was so poor.
Before dying, the nephew urged his wife to look among his uncle's papers for a will.
The family's subsequent search was even more thorough but equally fruitless; the family's palaces and vineyard were of little value at the time.
Time passed. Pope Alexander VI eventually died from accidental poisoning. Cæsar Borgia, also poisoned but surviving with disfigurement, later met an obscure death in a skirmish.

The Spada family never recovered its former affluence, and public rumor suggested Cæsar Borgia had outmaneuvered his father and seized the fortunes of both cardinals, as Rospigliosi, having taken no precautions, was entirely stripped of his assets.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “‘The great wars of Romagna had ended; Cæsar Borgia, who had completed his conquest, had need of money to purchase all Italy.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I say the two, because Cardinal Rospigliosi, who had not taken any precaution, was completely despoiled.

events.text_segment:
“‘The great wars of Romagna had ended; Cæsar Borgia, who had completed his conquest, had need of money to purchase all Italy. The pope had also need of money to bring matters to an end with Louis XII. King of France, who was formidable still in spite of his recent reverses; and it was necessary, therefore, to have recourse to some profitable scheme, which was a matter of great difficulty in the impoverished condition of exhausted Italy. His holiness had an idea. He determined to make two cardinals.’
“By choosing two of the greatest personages of Rome, especially rich men—this was the return the Holy Father looked for. In the first place, he could sell the great appointments and splendid offices which the cardinals already held; and then he had the two hats to sell besides. There was a third point in view, which will appear hereafter.
“The pope and Cæsar Borgia first found the two future cardinals; they were Giovanni Rospigliosi, who held four of the highest dignities of the Holy See, and Cæsar Spada, one of the noblest and richest of the Roman nobility; both felt the high honor of such a favor from the pope. They were ambitious, and Cæsar Borgia soon found purchasers for their appointments. The result was, that Rospigliosi and Spada paid for being cardinals, and eight other persons paid for the offices the cardinals held before their elevation, and thus eight hundred thousand crowns entered into the coffers of the speculators.
“It is time now to proceed to the last part of the speculation. The pope heaped attentions upon Rospigliosi and Spada, conferred upon them the insignia of the cardinalate, and induced them to arrange their affairs and take up their residence at Rome. Then the pope and Cæsar Borgia invited the two cardinals to dinner. This was a matter of dispute between the Holy Father and his son. Cæsar thought they could make use of one of the means which he always had ready for his friends, that is to say, in the first place, the famous key which was given to certain persons with the request that they go and open a designated cupboard. This key was furnished with a small iron point,—a negligence on the part of the locksmith. When this was pressed to effect the opening of the cupboard, of which the lock was difficult, the person was pricked by this small point, and died next day. Then there was the ring with the lion’s head, which Cæsar wore when he wanted to greet his friends with a clasp of the hand. The lion bit the hand thus favored, and at the end of twenty-four hours, the bite was mortal.
“Cæsar proposed to his father, that they should either ask the cardinals to open the cupboard, or shake hands with them; but Alexander VI. replied: ‘Now as to the worthy cardinals, Spada and Rospigliosi, let us ask both of them to dinner, something tells me that we shall get that money back. Besides, you forget, Cæsar, an indigestion declares itself immediately, while a prick or a bite occasions a delay of a day or two.’ Cæsar gave way before such cogent reasoning, and the cardinals were consequently invited to dinner.
“The table was laid in a vineyard belonging to the pope, near San Pierdarena, a charming retreat which the cardinals knew very well by report. Rospigliosi, quite set up with his new dignities, went with a good appetite and his most ingratiating manner. Spada, a prudent man, and greatly attached to his only nephew, a young captain of the highest promise, took paper and pen, and made his will. He then sent word to his nephew to wait for him near the vineyard; but it appeared the servant did not find him.
“Spada knew what these invitations meant; since Christianity, so eminently civilizing, had made progress in Rome, it was no longer a centurion who came from the tyrant with a message, ‘Cæsar wills that you die.’ but it was a legate à latere, who came with a smile on his lips to say from the pope, ‘His holiness requests you to dine with him.’
“Spada set out about two o’clock to San Pierdarena. The pope awaited him. The first sight that attracted the eyes of Spada was that of his nephew, in full costume, and Cæsar Borgia paying him most marked attentions. Spada turned pale, as Cæsar looked at him with an ironical air, which proved that he had anticipated all, and that the snare was well spread.
“They began dinner and Spada was only able to inquire of his nephew if he had received his message. The nephew replied no; perfectly comprehending the meaning of the question. It was too late, for he had already drunk a glass of excellent wine, placed for him expressly by the pope’s butler. Spada at the same moment saw another bottle approach him, which he was pressed to taste. An hour afterwards a physician declared they were both poisoned through eating mushrooms. Spada died on the threshold of the vineyard; the nephew expired at his own door, making signs which his wife could not comprehend.
“Then Cæsar and the pope hastened to lay hands on the heritage, under pretense of seeking for the papers of the dead man. But the inheritance consisted in this only, a scrap of paper on which Spada had written:—‘I bequeath to my beloved nephew my coffers, my books, and, amongst others, my breviary with the gold corners, which I beg he will preserve in remembrance of his affectionate uncle.’
“The heirs sought everywhere, admired the breviary, laid hands on the furniture, and were greatly astonished that Spada, the rich man, was really the most miserable of uncles—no treasures—unless they were those of science, contained in the library and laboratories. That was all. Cæsar and his father searched, examined, scrutinized, but found nothing, or at least very little; not exceeding a few thousand crowns in plate, and about the same in ready money; but the nephew had time to say to his wife before he expired: ‘Look well among my uncle’s papers; there is a will.’
“They sought even more thoroughly than the august heirs had done, but it was fruitless. There were two palaces and a vineyard behind the Palatine Hill; but in these days landed property had not much value, and the two palaces and the vineyard remained to the family since they were beneath the rapacity of the pope and his son. Months and years rolled on. Alexander VI. died, poisoned,—you know by what mistake. Cæsar, poisoned at the same time, escaped by shedding his skin like a snake; but the new skin was spotted by the poison till it looked like a tiger’s. Then, compelled to quit Rome, he went and got himself obscurely killed in a night skirmish, scarcely noticed in history.
“After the pope’s death and his son’s exile, it was supposed that the Spada family would resume the splendid position they had held before the cardinal’s time; but this was not the case. The Spadas remained in doubtful ease, a mystery hung over this dark affair, and the public rumor was, that Cæsar, a better politician than his father, had carried off from the pope the fortune of the two cardinals. I say the two, because Cardinal Rospigliosi, who had not taken any precaution, was completely despoiled.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: ‘The great wars of Romagna had ended; Cæsar Borgia, who had completed his conquest, had need of money to purchase all Italy. Pope Alexander VI, his father, was as avaricious as his son was ambitious, and he also required money to forward his schemes. He cast his eyes on two wealthy personages who had lately arrived in Rome; the one was Giovanni Rospigliosi, the other Cæsar Spada, both of them men of immense wealth. The Pope and Cæsar Borgia sent for them, and proposed, in the first instance, to make them cardinals. This was a great honour, but it cost them two hundred thousand crowns each. They agreed to the terms, and paid the money. The Pope and Cæsar Borgia then proposed to them to resign their offices, which were to be sold to the highest bidder, and the proceeds to be divided between the Pope and his son. They consented to this also, and gave up their offices, which were sold for five hundred thousand crowns. The Pope and Cæsar Borgia then invited the two cardinals to dinner. Cæsar Borgia had at first proposed to use one of his ingenious devices, a key or a ring, which he always carried about him, and which he called his ‘little key’ and his ‘little ring.’ The key, which was a master-key, opened all locks; and the ring, which had a lion’s head on it, contained a small needle, which, on being pressed, injected a subtle poison into the person it touched. But Pope Alexander VI preferred poisoning them at dinner, arguing that it produced more immediate results than the delayed effects of a prick or a bite. The dinner was arranged at a vineyard retreat familiar to the cardinals. Rospigliosi attended with enthusiasm. Cardinal Spada, however, being a prudent man deeply attached to his nephew, wrote his will and attempted to warn his nephew to meet him near the vineyard, but the message seemingly never reached him. Spada recognized such invitations as thinly veiled death sentences, a modern refinement on older, cruder methods of dispatch. Upon arriving, Spada was dismayed to see his nephew already present and being flattered by Cæsar Borgia, realizing the trap was set. During the meal, Spada confirmed his nephew had not received his warning; it was already too late, as the nephew had consumed wine specially poured for him. Spada himself was pressured to drink from another bottle. An hour later, a physician pronounced both men poisoned by mushrooms. Spada died at the vineyard’s entrance, while his nephew expired at his own home, making desperate, unintelligible signs to his wife. Cæsar Borgia and the Pope quickly moved to claim the Spada inheritance, ostensibly to search for the deceased’s papers. They found only a note bequeathing coffers, books, and a gold-cornered breviary to Spada’s nephew. The official heirs searched diligently but found no significant treasure, only the library and laboratories, leading to astonishment that the reputedly wealthy Spada was so poor. Before dying, the nephew urged his wife to look among his uncle’s papers for a will. The family’s subsequent search was even more thorough but equally fruitless; the family’s palaces and vineyard were of little value at the time. Time passed. Pope Alexander VI eventually died from accidental poisoning. Cæsar Borgia, also poisoned but surviving with disfigurement, later met an obscure death in a skirmish. The Spada family never recovered its former affluence, and public rumour suggested Cæsar Borgia had outmanœuvred his father and seized the fortunes of both cardinals, as Rospigliosi, having taken no precautions, was entirely stripped of his assets.’

events.title: Faria's Decades-Long Search and the Breviary's Secret
detailed_summary: Faria paused his narrative to ask Dantès if the story thus far seemed pointless.
Dantès, however, expressed that he found the account exceptionally engaging and urged Faria to proceed.
Faria continued, explaining that the Spada family gradually adapted to their diminished fortunes over subsequent generations, with descendants pursuing various careers.

He then focused on the last Count of Spada, whom he served as secretary. This Count often lamented the mismatch between his noble rank and his modest wealth, and Faria advised him to convert his assets into an annuity, thereby doubling his income.

The renowned family breviary, passed down through the family and regarded as a sacred relic due to a peculiar clause in the only discovered will, remained in the Count's possession. It was described as an illuminated manuscript, heavily adorned with gold.
Faria, like numerous predecessors, painstakingly examined the extensive family archives and documents dating back to the poisoned Cardinal, but found no clues to the lost wealth.

He had even authored a detailed history of the Borgia family specifically to ascertain if their fortunes had notably increased following Cardinal Cæsar Spada's death, but could only confirm their acquisition of Cardinal Rospigliosi's property.
Faria grew convinced that the Spada inheritance had benefited neither the Borgias nor the family and remained undiscovered, like a treasure from the Arabian Nights, hidden within the earth.
He meticulously researched, analyzed, and calculated three centuries of the family's finances, all to no avail, leaving him in ignorance and the Count of Spada in relative poverty.

Upon his patron's death, Faria inherited the family papers, a library of five thousand volumes, and the famous breviary, along with a sum of money, conditioned upon arranging memorial masses and compiling a genealogical history of the Spada house, all of which he diligently performed.
Faria assured Dantès that the climax of the story was approaching.

He recounted events from December 1807, a month prior to his arrest and shortly after the Count of Spada's demise. While organizing papers for the thousandth time, in preparation for a move from Rome to Florence, he felt weary after a heavy meal.
He fell asleep around three in the afternoon and awoke at six in complete darkness.
Unable to summon anyone for a light, he decided to procure one himself. His matchbox was empty.

He needed paper to light a candle from the embers. Hesitant to use any valuable document, he recalled an old, yellowed piece of paper that had served as a bookmark in the breviary for centuries, kept there at the request of the heirs.
He located this paper, twisted it, and ignited it in the dying flames of the fireplace.
As the paper began to burn, yellowish characters miraculously appeared on its surface, revealed by the heat.
Faria, with great urgency, extinguished the flame, lit his candle directly from the fire, and unfolded the crumpled paper with profound emotion.
He realized the characters had been written in a sympathetic, or invisible, ink, becoming visible only when exposed to heat. Nearly a third of the paper had been consumed by the fire.
Faria identified this as the same paper he had shown Dantès earlier and instructed him to read it once more, after which he would fill in the missing words and clarify the fragmented meaning.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was that paper you read this morning; read it again, Dantès, and then I will complete for you the incomplete words and unconnected sense.”

events.text_segment:
“Up to this point,” said Faria, interrupting the thread of his narrative, “this seems to you very meaningless, no doubt, eh?”
“Oh, my friend,” cried Dantès, “on the contrary, it seems as if I were reading a most interesting narrative; go on, I beg of you.”
“I will. The family began to get accustomed to their obscurity. Years rolled on, and amongst the descendants some were soldiers, others diplomatists; some churchmen, some bankers; some grew rich, and some were ruined. I come now to the last of the family, whose secretary I was—the Count of Spada. I had often heard him complain of the disproportion of his rank with his fortune; and I advised him to invest all he had in an annuity. He did so, and thus doubled his income. The celebrated breviary remained in the family, and was in the count’s possession. It had been handed down from father to son; for the singular clause of the only will that had been found, had caused it to be regarded as a genuine relic, preserved in the family with superstitious veneration. It was an illuminated book, with beautiful Gothic characters, and so weighty with gold, that a servant always carried it before the cardinal on days of great solemnity.
“At the sight of papers of all sorts,—titles, contracts, parchments, which were kept in the archives of the family, all descending from the poisoned cardinal, I in my turn examined the immense bundles of documents, like twenty servitors, stewards, secretaries before me; but in spite of the most exhaustive researches, I found—nothing. Yet I had read, I had even written a precise history of the Borgia family, for the sole purpose of assuring myself whether any increase of fortune had occurred to them on the death of the Cardinal Cæsar Spada; but could only trace the acquisition of the property of the Cardinal Rospigliosi, his companion in misfortune.
“I was then almost assured that the inheritance had neither profited the Borgias nor the family, but had remained unpossessed like the treasures of the Arabian Nights, which slept in the bosom of the earth under the eyes of the genie. I searched, ransacked, counted, calculated a thousand and a thousand times the income and expenditure of the family for three hundred years. It was useless. I remained in my ignorance, and the Count of Spada in his poverty.
“My patron died. He had reserved from his annuity his family papers, his library, composed of five thousand volumes, and his famous breviary. All these he bequeathed to me, with a thousand Roman crowns, which he had in ready money, on condition that I would have anniversary masses said for the repose of his soul, and that I would draw up a genealogical tree and history of his house. All this I did scrupulously. Be easy, my dear Edmond, we are near the conclusion.
“In 1807, a month before I was arrested, and a fortnight after the death of the Count of Spada, on the 25th of December (you will see presently how the date became fixed in my memory), I was reading, for the thousandth time, the papers I was arranging, for the palace was sold to a stranger, and I was going to leave Rome and settle at Florence, intending to take with me twelve thousand francs I possessed, my library, and the famous breviary, when, tired with my constant labor at the same thing, and overcome by a heavy dinner I had eaten, my head dropped on my hands, and I fell asleep about three o’clock in the afternoon.
“I awoke as the clock was striking six. I raised my head; I was in utter darkness. I rang for a light, but, as no one came, I determined to find one for myself. It was indeed but anticipating the simple manners which I should soon be under the necessity of adopting. I took a wax-candle in one hand, and with the other groped about for a piece of paper (my match-box being empty), with which I proposed to get a light from the small flame still playing on the embers. Fearing, however, to make use of any valuable piece of paper, I hesitated for a moment, then recollected that I had seen in the famous breviary, which was on the table beside me, an old paper quite yellow with age, and which had served as a marker for centuries, kept there by the request of the heirs. I felt for it, found it, twisted it up together, and putting it into the expiring flame, set light to it.
“But beneath my fingers, as if by magic, in proportion as the fire ascended, I saw yellowish characters appear on the paper. I grasped it in my hand, put out the flame as quickly as I could, lighted my taper in the fire itself, and opened the crumpled paper with inexpressible emotion, recognizing, when I had done so, that these characters had been traced in mysterious and sympathetic ink, only appearing when exposed to the fire; nearly one-third of the paper had been consumed by the flame. It was that paper you read this morning; read it again, Dantès, and then I will complete for you the incomplete words and unconnected sense.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: “Up to this point,” said Faria, interrupting the thread of his narrative, “this seems to you very meaningless, no doubt, eh?”“Oh, my father!” cried Dantès, “on the contrary, it is deeply interesting to me, for I can easily imagine this Count of Spada, reduced to poverty, yet keeping up his rank, and your own position with him, in that noble pride which looks at the past in default of the future. Go on, I entreat you!”“Well, then, the Abbé Spada,” resumed Faria, “suffered the same fate as his brother, the Cardinal; and this was the fate of all the younger branches of the family, who were successively poisoned, and died in the space of a year. Then the Pope, enriched by the spoils, seized the property, and armed with this legal right, dispossessed the last of the family, a nephew of the two victims, who had never made profession of faith, and whom he confined in the Castle of Saint Angelo, where he soon died of despair. I say of despair, because the gentleman, when I was secretary to his descendant, who told me the story as I tell it you, added this remark: ‘He was so rich, and we are so poor.’ The Pope appropriated the whole of the inheritance, and then, fearing lest some unexpected claim should be raised, and knowing that the Spada family were of a tenacious temper, and very inveterate in their hatreds, he sought by every means to exterminate them, and so there remained none but a single descendant, a child, whom he could not get into his power, and who was saved by the care of his mother, and fled to Spain. Now,” said Faria, turning towards Dantès, “you understand the words, ‘He was so rich, and we are so poor.’ The family, however, in the branch that fled to Spain, preserved its pride and its title, but was so reduced in fortune, that the last scion of the house, who was called by courtesy Count de Spada, lived in a small house in the Trastevere. It was with this nobleman that I was connected. I had been for a long time his secretary. I was engaged in arranging his papers when I discovered the singular clause of which I have told you, and which was contained in a will made by the Cardinal Cæsar Spada, and which I found among some papers bearing the date of 1498. This will was in favor of his nephew, a young man of eighteen, and was made in anticipation of the dangers which the Cardinal foresaw he would incur from the cupidity of Pope Alexander VI. The Cardinal had, therefore, not made a will, but a simple declaration, in which he stated that, not daring to make a public will, fearing that his intentions would be frustrated by the Pope, he deposited in a safe place his will, written by his own hand, and to which he confided the care of his nephew. This is the clause I mean, and which had baffled all the researches of the Spada family, who, though they suspected a treasure, had never been able to find it. I had examined, like them, a thousand documents, calculated a thousand combinations, and, like them, had abandoned the hope of ever finding anything. I had, however, in my researches, discovered many curious particulars relative to the Cardinal, and the singular life he led. He was a man of great learning, and of a very original turn of mind. He was a profound alchemist, and a great believer in the occult sciences. He had a laboratory in his palace, where he passed the greater part of his time. He was also a great lover of books, and had a magnificent library. It was in this library that I passed my days, arranging and classifying the books and papers. One day, I was examining a very old breviary, which had belonged to the Cardinal, and which was considered as a relic in the family. It was a magnificent manuscript, illuminated with the most beautiful miniatures, and bound in velvet, with clasps of gold. I had often admired it, and had even copied some of the miniatures. As I was turning over the leaves, I found a paper, which had been inserted as a bookmark. It was a very old paper, yellow with age, and which had been folded in four. I opened it, and saw that it was covered with writing. The writing was in a very peculiar character, and I could not at first make it out. I thought it was some cabalistic formula, or some alchemistical receipt. I was about to throw it aside, when my eye fell upon a word which I recognized. It was the name of Cæsar Spada. This struck me, and I examined the paper more attentively. I saw that it was a will, or rather a codicil, written by the hand of the Cardinal. I read it, and found that it contained the secret of the treasure. The paper was very old, and the ink had faded, so that it was very difficult to read. I spent several days in deciphering it, and at last succeeded in making out the whole. This is what I read: ‘I, Cæsar Spada, Cardinal, being about to die, and having no time to make a will, declare that I have deposited in a safe place, in the island of Monte Cristo, in the grotto of the same name, a treasure of two millions of Roman crowns, which I have accumulated during my life, and which I bequeath to my nephew, Guido Spada, and his heirs after him. This treasure is contained in six chests, and is buried at the foot of the cross which is erected at the entrance of the grotto. I have also deposited with the treasure a will, written by my hand, and which contains my last wishes. I recommend my nephew to be prudent, and not to reveal this secret to any one. Done this 25th of April, 1498.’ You see,” said Faria, “that this paper was a codicil, and that it contained the secret of the treasure. Now,” continued he, “you understand why the Spada family were so poor, and why the Pope was so rich. The treasure had remained hidden for three centuries, and no one had ever suspected its existence. I was the first to discover it, and I was about to reveal it to the Count, when I was arrested.”“And this paper,” said Dantès, “is it still in existence?”“No,” said Faria, “I have it no longer. I had it with me when I was arrested, and it was taken from me by the police. But I have it all in my memory, and I can repeat it to you word for word.”“And this treasure,” said Dantès, “does it still exist?”“Yes,” said Faria, “it still exists. It is in the island of Monte Cristo, in the grotto of the same name. It is buried at the foot of the cross which is erected at the entrance of the grotto. It is a treasure of two millions of Roman crowns, contained in six chests.”“And you

simple_agent_extraction_refined_2.text: “Up to this point,” said Faria, interrupting the thread of his narrative, “this seems to you very meaningless, no doubt, eh?”“Oh, my father!” cried Dantès, “on the contrary, it is deeply interesting to me, for I can easily imagine this Count of Spada, reduced to poverty, yet keeping up his rank, and your own position with him, in that noble pride which looks at the past in default of the future. Go on, I entreat you!”“Well, then, the Spada family,” resumed Faria, “went on from generation to generation, adapting themselves to their altered fortunes, and pursuing some of them the career of the church, others the profession of arms, and others the administration of public affairs. All these, according to their several abilities, sought to augment the family fortune, but all in vain. Some grew rich, others were ruined, and still the family remained poor. The last of the family was a Count, the grandson of the one I have mentioned, with whom I was connected as secretary. I advised him to convert the whole of his property into an annuity, as he had no children, and thus to double his income. He consented, and I was charged with the negotiation. It was a difficult matter to find any one who would consent to lend money upon the life of a man of eighty-five, and that man a Roman count, but I succeeded, and the Count was thus assured of a large income, and was enabled to maintain his rank with becoming dignity. The celebrated breviary, which had been handed down from father to son for centuries, and which was regarded as a sacred relic, owing to a peculiar clause in the only will that had been discovered, remained in the Count’s possession. It was an illuminated manuscript, adorned with the most beautiful miniatures, and bound in velvet, with clasps of gold. It was very heavy, and was used on solemn occasions. I, like many others, had examined the immense archives of the family, and the documents which dated back to the time of the poisoned Cardinal, but I had found nothing. I had even written a history of the Borgia family, with the view of ascertaining whether their fortunes had increased in a remarkable manner after the death of Cardinal Cæsar Spada, but I had only been able to ascertain that they had acquired the property of Cardinal Rospigliosi, and that was all. I became convinced that the inheritance had profited neither the Borgias nor the Spada family, and that it was still undiscovered, like a treasure from the Arabian Nights, hidden in the bowels of the earth. I had examined, analyzed, and calculated, during three centuries, the finances of the family, and I had arrived at the conviction that the whole of the inheritance had disappeared. I was in ignorance, and the Count of Spada was in poverty. Upon the death of my patron, I inherited his papers, a library of five thousand volumes, and the famous breviary, with a sum of money, on condition that I should arrange for the celebration of a number of masses for the repose of his soul, and that I should compile a genealogical history of the house of Spada, all of which I performed with the greatest exactitude. But,” said Faria, “I am coming to the point. Listen to me. It was in the month of December, 1807, a month before my arrest, and shortly after the death of the Count of Spada. The palace was sold, and I was preparing to remove to Florence with my possessions. I was arranging his papers for the thousandth time, when, after a heavy meal, I felt weary, and fell asleep about three o’clock in the afternoon. I awoke at six, and was in complete darkness. I could not ring for a light, as I had dismissed my servant. I groped about for a match, but could find none. I knew there were some embers in the fireplace, and I resolved to light a candle from them. I needed a piece of paper to twist up and light at the fire. I hesitated to use any valuable document, and then I recollected that there was an old, yellowed piece of paper, which had served as a bookmark in the breviary for centuries, and which had been kept there at the request of the heirs. I found this paper, twisted it up, and put it into the dying embers. As the paper began to burn, yellowish characters appeared upon it, as if by magic. I extinguished the flame with haste, lit my candle directly from the fire, and unfolded the crumpled paper with profound emotion. I saw that the characters were written in sympathetic ink, and that they had become visible by the action of the heat. Nearly a third of the paper was consumed. This,” said Faria, “is the paper I showed you just now. Read it once more, and I will fill up the missing words, and you will understand the fragmented meaning.”

events.title: The Deciphered Will, the Treasure of Monte Cristo, and Faria's Testament
detailed_summary: With a triumphant demeanor, Faria handed the scorched paper to Dantès, who now read words written in a reddish, rust-colored ink.

Dantès read the message, which, though more complete, was still fragmented. It spoke of Cardinal Spada's actions on April 25, 1498, his fear of Pope Alexander VI, and a treasure concealed on the Island of Monte Cristo.
Faria then produced a second piece of paper containing additional fragments, which Dantès also read.
At Faria's direction, Dantès combined the two fragments.
The joined pieces formed a complete declaration by Cardinal Cæsar Spada, revealing his anxieties about Pope Alexander VI and Cæsar Borgia.

The document stated that Cardinal Spada had buried his entire fortune—ingots, gold, currency, jewels, and gems—in the caves of the small Island of Monte Cristo, a location familiar to his nephew, Guido Spada.

The will specified the treasure's value at nearly two million Roman crowns and provided precise instructions for its retrieval: by lifting the twentieth rock from the small eastern creek in a direct line, leading to two openings in caves, with the treasure located in the farthest angle of the second opening.
The Cardinal bequeathed this entire treasure to his nephew Guido Spada as his sole heir, the document dated April 25, 1498.
Faria inquired if Dantès now understood the significance of the document.
Dantès, though still tinged with incredulity, acknowledged it as Cardinal Spada's long-lost declaration and will.

Faria affirmed this with great enthusiasm, explaining that he had deciphered the complete message by deducing the missing portions based on the surviving text, the length of the lines, and the overall context, much like navigating a cavern by a faint ray of light.

He revealed that he had resolved to pursue the treasure immediately upon this discovery, while also carrying his treatise on the unification of Italy, but was apprehended by imperial police in Piombino, their suspicions aroused by his unexplained, hasty departure.
Addressing Dantès with paternal warmth, Faria stated that Dantès now possessed all the knowledge he himself had.
He then made a solemn promise: if they were to escape prison together, half of the treasure would belong to Dantès; if Dantès escaped alone, the entire fortune would be his.
Dantès hesitated, questioning whether there might be a more rightful living heir to the treasure.

Faria reassured him, stating the Spada family line was extinct. Moreover, the last Count of Spada had made Faria his heir, bequeathing him the symbolic breviary and all it contained, thus ensuring they could claim the fortune without moral reservations.
Faria disclosed the treasure's estimated value: two million Roman crowns, equivalent to nearly thirteen million francs in their contemporary currency.
Dantès, overwhelmed by the immense sum, exclaimed that it was impossible.

Faria countered by explaining that such vast accumulations of wealth were not uncommon for powerful fifteenth-century families who lacked modern investment opportunities, citing current Roman families impoverished despite possessing entailed, inaccessible fortunes in jewels.
Edmond felt as though he were dreaming, caught between disbelief and burgeoning joy.

Faria explained his delay in revealing the secret: he wished first to test Dantès's character and then to surprise him. He lamented that had they escaped before his paralytic attack, he would have guided Dantès to Monte Cristo; now, he said with a sigh, Dantès would be the one to guide him.
Faria gently chided Dantès for not yet expressing gratitude.
Dantès responded that the treasure rightfully belonged to Faria alone, as he, Dantès, had no claim to it and was no relation.

Faria, deeply moved, exclaimed that Dantès was his son, the child of his captivity, sent by Providence to comfort him, fulfilling both the role of a father he could never be and a companion in imprisonment.
With this declaration, Faria extended his one functional arm towards Dantès, who, overcome with emotion, embraced him and wept.

events.text_segment:
Faria, with an air of triumph, offered the paper to Dantès, who this time read the following words, traced with an ink of a reddish color resembling rust:
“This 25th day of April, 1498, be...
