creek to the east in a right line. Two open...
in these caves; the treasure is in the furthest a...
which treasure I bequeath and leave en...
as my sole heir.
“25th April, 1498.
“Cæs...
“And now,” said the abbé, “read this other paper;” and he presented to Dantès a second leaf with fragments of lines written on it, which Edmond read as follows:
“...ing invited to dine by his Holiness
...content with making me pay for my hat,
...serves for me the fate of Cardinals Caprara
...I declare to my nephew, Guido Spada
...ried in a place he knows
...the caves of the small
...essed of ingots, gold, money,
...know of the existence of this treasure, which
...lions of Roman crowns, and which he
...ck from the small
...ings have been made
...ngle in the second;
...tire to him
...ar † Spada.”
Faria followed him with an excited look.
“And now,” he said, when he saw that Dantès had read the last line, “put the two fragments together, and judge for yourself.” Dantès obeyed, and the conjointed pieces gave the following:
“This 25th day of April, 1498, be...ing invited to dine by his Holiness Alexander VI., and fearing that not...content with making me pay for my hat, he may desire to become my heir, and re...serves for me the fate of Cardinals Caprara and Bentivoglio, who were poisoned,...I declare to my nephew, Guido Spada, my sole heir, that I have bu...ried in a place he knows and has visited with me, that is, in...the caves of the small Island of Monte Cristo, all I poss...essed of ingots, gold, money, jewels, diamonds, gems; that I alone...know of the existence of this treasure, which may amount to nearly two mil...lions of Roman crowns, and which he will find on raising the twentieth ro...ck from the small creek to the east in a right line. Two open...ings have been made in these caves; the treasure is in the furthest a...ngle in the second; which treasure I bequeath and leave en...tire to him as my sole heir. “25th April, 1498. “Cæs...ar † Spada.”
“Well, do you comprehend now?” inquired Faria.
“It is the declaration of Cardinal Spada, and the will so long sought for,” replied Edmond, still incredulous.
“Yes; a thousand times, yes!”
“And who completed it as it now is?”
“I did. Aided by the remaining fragment, I guessed the rest; measuring the length of the lines by those of the paper, and divining the hidden meaning by means of what was in part revealed, as we are guided in a cavern by the small ray of light above us.”
“And what did you do when you arrived at this conclusion?”
“I resolved to set out, and did set out at that very instant, carrying with me the beginning of my great work, the unity of the Italian kingdom; but for some time the imperial police (who at this period, quite contrary to what Napoleon desired so soon as he had a son born to him, wished for a partition of provinces) had their eyes on me; and my hasty departure, the cause of which they were unable to guess, having aroused their suspicions, I was arrested at the very moment I was leaving Piombino.
“Now,” continued Faria, addressing Dantès with an almost paternal expression, “now, my dear fellow, you know as much as I do myself. If we ever escape together, half this treasure is yours; if I die here, and you escape alone, the whole belongs to you.”
“But,” inquired Dantès hesitating, “has this treasure no more legitimate possessor in the world than ourselves?”
“No, no, be easy on that score; the family is extinct. The last Count of Spada, moreover, made me his heir, bequeathing to me this symbolic breviary, he bequeathed to me all it contained; no, no, make your mind satisfied on that point. If we lay hands on this fortune, we may enjoy it without remorse.”
“And you say this treasure amounts to——”
“Two millions of Roman crowns; nearly thirteen millions of our money.”
“Impossible!” said Dantès, staggered at the enormous amount.
“Impossible? and why?” asked the old man. “The Spada family was one of the oldest and most powerful families of the fifteenth century; and in those times, when other opportunities for investment were wanting, such accumulations of gold and jewels were by no means rare; there are at this day Roman families perishing of hunger, though possessed of nearly a million in diamonds and jewels, handed down by entail, and which they cannot touch.”
Edmond thought he was in a dream—he wavered between incredulity and joy.
“I have only kept this secret so long from you,” continued Faria, “that I might test your character, and then surprise you. Had we escaped before my attack of catalepsy, I should have conducted you to Monte Cristo; now,” he added, with a sigh, “it is you who will conduct me thither. Well, Dantès, you do not thank me?”
“This treasure belongs to you, my dear friend,” replied Dantès, “and to you only. I have no right to it. I am no relation of yours.”
“You are my son, Dantès,” exclaimed the old man. “You are the child of my captivity. My profession condemns me to celibacy. God has sent you to me to console, at one and the same time, the man who could not be a father, and the prisoner who could not get free.”
And Faria extended the arm of which alone the use remained to him to the young man, who threw himself upon his neck and wept.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Faria, with an air of triumph, offered the paper to Dantès, who this time read the following words, traced with an ink of a reddish color resembling rust: "This fifth day of June, 1498, finding myself unable to combat longer with the enemies whom the Pope Alexander VI has raised up against me, and fearing that, after my death, my property will be pillaged by the Church, I confide to my nephew, Guido Spada, my sole heir, the whole of my treasures, amounting to the sum of one hundred thousand scudi in gold, and contained in a grotto situated in the island of Monte Cristo. This grotto is entered by a second opening, which I have had made for the purpose, and which is concealed by the twenty-fourth rock from the small creek to the east. This paper will be found in the will of my secretary, Canon Spada, who alone knows the secret." Dantès read and re-read these lines, his heart pounding with a mixture of awe and disbelief. The words seemed to leap from the page, carrying the weight of centuries and the promise of unimaginable wealth. He looked up at Faria, his eyes wide with wonder. "Is this... is this real?" he stammered. Faria smiled, a triumphant, knowing smile. "As real as the chains that bind us, my friend. I told you I had discovered a treasure, did I not? This is it." He took the paper back gently. "For years, I puzzled over the various documents in the cardinal's library. His will, his correspondence, his account books. They were all there, brought to the Chateau d'If with him, overlooked by those who sought only political secrets. I noticed discrepancies, missing sums, references to wealth that did not appear in the official inventories. Then, I found this codicil, hidden within the binding of a theological treatise. But it was written in a cipher, a complex substitution cipher that took me years to unravel." Faria's eyes gleamed with the pride of his intellectual victory. "Imagine, Dantès! A cardinal of the Church, one of the wealthiest men of his time, fearing the avarice of the Borgia Pope, hides his immense fortune. Not in Rome, where it might be found, but on a remote, uninhabited island. He entrusts the secret to his nephew, Guido, and leaves this codicil, hoping it will one day be discovered by his rightful heir." "But... Monte Cristo?" Dantès breathed the name, a name he knew only as a distant island in the Tuscan Archipelago. "An island, yes," Faria confirmed. "Uninhabited, rocky, a perfect hiding place. The cardinal was a man of foresight. He knew that such a treasure, if discovered by the Church or the state, would be confiscated. By hiding it, he preserved it for his family." "And the sum... one hundred thousand scudi?" Dantès could barely comprehend the figure. "In gold, yes," Faria corrected. "And that was in 1498. Consider the value today, with the increase in the price of gold, not to mention the interest it would have accrued had it been invested, though of course, it was not. But more than that, the document mentions 'the whole of my treasures'. One hundred thousand scudi in gold was likely just the liquid cash. There would be jewels, precious metals, works of art, perhaps. The true value is incalculable, certainly several millions of francs in modern currency, perhaps ten, twenty, fifty million!" Dantès felt dizzy. Millions. He, Edmond Dantès, a prisoner, had before him the key to a fortune that could buy kingdoms. "And you deciphered this... here? In this prison?" "Every day, for years," Faria affirmed. "The cipher was devilishly clever, based on a complex system of key words and numerical shifts. But patience and intellect prevail. I reconstructed the key, letter by letter, number by number, until the words revealed themselves. It was a moment of triumph, Edmond, a moment that repaid years of toil and frustration." He tapped the paper. "This is our hope, Edmond. This is our means of escape, not just from these walls, but from the fate that was forced upon us. With this treasure, we can buy our freedom, we can exact justice, we can live lives of power and influence." Dantès stared at the document, then at Faria, then back at the document. The reddish ink seemed to glow with a malevolent promise. "But how?" he asked, his voice hoarse. "How do we get to Monte Cristo? We are prisoners." "Ah, that is the next problem," Faria said, his expression becoming more serious. "But a problem that can be solved. We have time, Edmond. We have intellect. And now, we have the motive. We will find a way. We will escape, and we will claim this treasure. It is our destiny." He carefully folded the paper and placed it back in its hiding place within the book. "Now, Edmond," he said, his voice lower, more conspiratorial, "we must plan. We must prepare. Our work is far from over. We have a fortune to claim, and a world to conquer." Dantès nodded, still reeling from the revelation. The darkness of the prison cell seemed less

chapters.chapter_title: VOLUME ONE. Chapter 19. The Third Attack

events.title: Treasure's Dual Significance and Escape Route Blocked
detailed_summary: Abbé Faria frequently spoke about the immense good Dantès could achieve with the treasure, making it seem even more valuable to him.
In stark contrast, Dantès privately contemplated the significant harm he could inflict upon his adversaries with such wealth, his thoughts colored by his vow of vengeance.
Faria was unacquainted with the Island of Monte Cristo, prompting Dantès, who knew its location and had once landed there, to sketch a map for the abbé.
Faria provided Dantès with guidance on the methods to employ for recovering the hidden riches.
Dantès, though convinced of Faria's sanity and admiring his intellect, harbored strong doubts about whether the treasure, if it ever truly existed, would still be there.
Their hopes for escape suffered a severe blow when a new misfortune occurred: the gallery on the sea side, which they had considered as a potential escape path, was completely repaired.

The hole Dantès had partially filled in was now sealed with large stones, a development that, ironically, prevented their earlier escape attempts from being discovered due to Faria's prior precautionary advice to Dantès, which would have led to their certain separation.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Now that this treasure, which had so long been the object of the abbé’s meditations, could insure the future happiness of him whom Faria really loved as a son, it had doubled its value in his eyes, and every day he expatiated on the amount, explaining to Dantès all the good which, with thirteen or fourteen millions of francs, a man could do in these days to his friends; and then Dantès’ countenance became gloomy, for the oath of vengeance he had taken recurred to his memory, and he reflected how much ill, in these times, a man with thirteen or fourteen millions could do to his enemies.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Thus a new, a stronger, and more inexorable barrier was interposed to cut off the realization of their hopes.

events.text_segment:
Now that this treasure, which had so long been the object of the abbé’s meditations, could insure the future happiness of him whom Faria really loved as a son, it had doubled its value in his eyes, and every day he expatiated on the amount, explaining to Dantès all the good which, with thirteen or fourteen millions of francs, a man could do in these days to his friends; and then Dantès’ countenance became gloomy, for the oath of vengeance he had taken recurred to his memory, and he reflected how much ill, in these times, a man with thirteen or fourteen millions could do to his enemies.
The abbé did not know the Island of Monte Cristo; but Dantès knew it, and had often passed it, situated twenty-five miles from Pianosa, between Corsica and the Island of Elba, and had once touched there. This island was, always had been, and still is, completely deserted. It is a rock of almost conical form, which looks as though it had been thrust up by volcanic force from the depth to the surface of the ocean. Dantès drew a plan of the island for Faria, and Faria gave Dantès advice as to the means he should employ to recover the treasure. But Dantès was far from being as enthusiastic and confident as the old man. It was past a question now that Faria was not a lunatic, and the way in which he had achieved the discovery, which had given rise to the suspicion of his madness, increased Edmond’s admiration of him; but at the same time Dantès could not believe that the deposit, supposing it had ever existed, still existed; and though he considered the treasure as by no means chimerical, he yet believed it was no longer there.
However, as if fate resolved on depriving the prisoners of their last chance, and making them understand that they were condemned to perpetual imprisonment, a new misfortune befell them; the gallery on the sea side, which had long been in ruins, was rebuilt. They had repaired it completely, and stopped up with vast masses of stone the hole Dantès had partly filled in. But for this precaution, which, it will be remembered, the abbé had made to Edmond, the misfortune would have been still greater, for their attempt to escape would have been detected, and they would undoubtedly have been separated. Thus a new, a stronger, and more inexorable barrier was interposed to cut off the realization of their hopes.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Now that this treasure, which had so long been the object of the abbé’s meditations, could insure the future happiness of him whom Faria really loved as a son, it had doubled its value in his eyes, and every day he expatiated on the amount, explaining to Dantès all the good which, with thirteen or fourteen millions of francs, a man could do in these days to his friends; and then Dantès’ countenance became gloomy, for the oath of vengeance he had taken recurred to his memory, and he reflected how much ill, in these times, a man with thirteen or fourteen millions could do to his enemies. Faria was a man of probity, and he thought the best way of making Dantès happy was to enrich him, and Dantès was a man of honour, and he thought his adversaries deserved punishment. These two men, thus opposite in feeling, resembled each other in mental superiority, and they understood each other in a half-word. So that Dantès, as we have said, while he prided himself on his sagacity, while he admired the vast knowledge of his friend, did not the less continue to doubt the existence of this treasure, but, as he wisely thought, it was better to employ his strength in digging than in discussing. Faria, on his part, was for ever drawing fresh plans, and devising new means of discovery, sometimes he thought the treasure was under the tree, and at others in the grottoes; then again, under the rocks, and then in the earth, and each time he calculated the space to be cleared, and the time to be occupied in the work, and Dantès worked with a zeal which increased his corporeal strength. At length, one day, Faria stopped him, and appeared thoughtful. “We have worked long enough, Dantès,” he said, “and you have been very patient, and now I am going to put your strength, and still more, your intelligence, to the test. Listen to me.” Dantès ceased digging, and leaned on his pickaxe. “You know the Island of Monte Cristo, Dantès?” “Yes, your reverence, I have been all round it, and landed on it once.” “Could you draw me a plan of it?” “With the greatest ease.” “Do so, then.” Faria placed in his hands a portion of the linen on which he wrote his manuscript, and Dantès drew the plan desired with a charcoal fish. “Excellent!” said Faria, “now show me the landing-places, the grottoes, the rocks, and the creeks, and the small bays.” Dantès pointed them all out. “Now show me the spot where you landed.” “Here, in this creek.” “Can you give me any details of the coast?” “Yes, it is a granite rock, white and shining.” “And the trees that are on the island?” “There are only pines, and two evergreen oaks, in the western part.” “That will do,” said Faria, “now tell me, did you ever penetrate into the island?” “No, I only remained there an hour, and that was to gather provisions.” “In what part did you procure them?” “In the same where I landed.” Faria mused for a few moments, and then, with a smile, he said, “Now, Dantès, you must be no longer a digger, but an archaeologist.” “An archaeologist, your reverence, what is that?” “A man who seeks for hidden antiquities; and as the grottos of Monte Cristo may have been inhabited by smugglers, that is to say, by robbers, not of men, but of honest goods, we may find some traces of their occupation.” “And how shall we discover them?” “By examining the grottoes, and by sounding the earth; for instance, all the earth that sounds hollow gives reason to suppose that there may be some cavity beneath, and we will search for those cavities.” “I understand,” said Dantès, “and I will work with a pickaxe and a sounding-rod.” “That is it,” said Faria, “and now, my friend, as we are prohibited natural death, we must seek violent death.” Dantès started. “What do you mean, your reverence?” “I mean,” replied Faria, “that we must not suffer ourselves to be suffocated by the want of air, or die of hunger, unless we wish to undergo the fate of the unfortunate wretch in the Château d’If.” “Ah,” said Dantès, “I understand, we will dig till we come to the sea, and then we will escape.” “That is it.” “But if we are discovered?” “We shall be killed, and that is all,” said F

events.title: Dantès' True Treasure and Faria's Legacy Preparations
detailed_summary: Dantès, with a sense of sorrowful resignation, conveyed to Faria his belief that divine will was making it impossible for him to break his promise of staying, thereby removing any merit from his devotion.

He proclaimed that his genuine treasure was not the gold on Monte Cristo, but Faria's companionship, the intellectual awakening Faria had sparked, the languages implanted in his mind, and the sciences made accessible.
Dantès asserted that these intellectual and spiritual gains had enriched him and brought him happiness, dispelling the despair that had once consumed him, valuing them more than any material fortune.
Faria, now incapacitated with paralysis in his right arm and left leg, abandoned any hope of personally enjoying the treasure and instead focused on devising escape strategies for Dantès.

To ensure the secret of the treasure's location remained secure, Faria compelled Dantès to commit the contents of the letter to memory, after which Faria destroyed the second, more vulnerable part of the document.

Faria dedicated many hours to giving Dantès meticulous instructions for his actions once he regained his liberty, emphasizing the need to reach Monte Cristo, find a pretext to remain there alone, and then locate the treasure in the specified cavern.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “You see,” said the young man, with an air of sorrowful resignation, to Faria, “that God deems it right to take from me any claim to merit for what you call my devotion to you.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then, once free, from the day and hour and moment when he was so, he could have but one only thought, which was, to gain Monte Cristo by some means, and remain there alone under some pretext which would arouse no suspicions; and once there, to endeavor to find the wonderful caverns, and search in the appointed spot,—the appointed spot, be it remembered, being the farthest angle in the second opening.

events.text_segment:
“You see,” said the young man, with an air of sorrowful resignation, to Faria, “that God deems it right to take from me any claim to merit for what you call my devotion to you. I have promised to remain forever with you, and now I could not break my promise if I would. The treasure will be no more mine than yours, and neither of us will quit this prison. But my real treasure is not that, my dear friend, which awaits me beneath the sombre rocks of Monte Cristo, it is your presence, our living together five or six hours a day, in spite of our jailers; it is the rays of intelligence you have elicited from my brain, the languages you have implanted in my memory, and which have taken root there with all their philological ramifications. These different sciences that you have made so easy to me by the depth of the knowledge you possess of them, and the clearness of the principles to which you have reduced them—this is my treasure, my beloved friend, and with this you have made me rich and happy. Believe me, and take comfort, this is better for me than tons of gold and cases of diamonds, even were they not as problematical as the clouds we see in the morning floating over the sea, which we take for terra firma, and which evaporate and vanish as we draw near to them. To have you as long as possible near me, to hear your eloquent speech,—which embellishes my mind, strengthens my soul, and makes my whole frame capable of great and terrible things, if I should ever be free,—so fills my whole existence, that the despair to which I was just on the point of yielding when I knew you, has no longer any hold over me; and this—this is my fortune—not chimerical, but actual. I owe you my real good, my present happiness; and all the sovereigns of the earth, even Cæsar Borgia himself, could not deprive me of this.”
Thus, if not actually happy, yet the days these two unfortunates passed together went quickly. Faria, who for so long a time had kept silence as to the treasure, now perpetually talked of it. As he had prophesied would be the case, he remained paralyzed in the right arm and the left leg, and had given up all hope of ever enjoying it himself. But he was continually thinking over some means of escape for his young companion, and anticipating the pleasure he would enjoy. For fear the letter might be some day lost or stolen, he compelled Dantès to learn it by heart; and Dantès knew it from the first to the last word. Then he destroyed the second portion, assured that if the first were seized, no one would be able to discover its real meaning. Whole hours sometimes passed while Faria was giving instructions to Dantès,—instructions which were to serve him when he was at liberty. Then, once free, from the day and hour and moment when he was so, he could have but one only thought, which was, to gain Monte Cristo by some means, and remain there alone under some pretext which would arouse no suspicions; and once there, to endeavor to find the wonderful caverns, and search in the appointed spot,—the appointed spot, be it remembered, being the farthest angle in the second opening.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“You see,” said the young man, with an air of sorrowful resignation, to Faria, “that God deems it right to take from me any claim to merit for what you call my devotion to you. I was about to break my vow; I was about to leave you, whose society has become so indispensable to me.”

“Yes, I know it,” said Faria; “but your devotion will be no less real, no less fervent, because it is now compulsory. It is as if God, seeing your hesitation, has sent his angel to retain you.”

“Oh, no!” said Dantès; “it is not an angel! it is the demon of despair who is come to conduct me to the tomb.”

“My child,” said Faria, in a voice of paternal tenderness, “you are deceived. God has sent me to you to console the man who, next to me, has suffered most. It is not the treasure, which you will not have, that I regret, but the knowledge which I have given you, which you will not use. It is not the gold of Monte Cristo that is my treasure,” added the old man, “but it is that you will be free and happy. Yes, my child, here is my treasure; it is not the gold which is on Monte Cristo, which is at the bottom of the sea, or buried in the earth, but the knowledge which I have given you, the languages which I have implanted in your mind, the sciences which I have made accessible to you. These are the things which have made you rich and happy. These are the things which have dispelled the despair which once consumed you. These are the things which I value more than any material fortune.”

Faria was now paralyzed in his right arm and left leg. He had given up all hope of ever enjoying the treasure himself, and his whole thoughts were now directed to devising some means of escape for Dantès. He made Dantès repeat the contents of the letter over and over again, until he was sure that he knew it by heart. Then he took the second part of the document, which was the most vulnerable, and destroyed it. He spent many hours in giving Dantès the most minute instructions as to what he was to do when he regained his liberty. He was to go to Monte Cristo, find some pretext for remaining there alone, and then search for the treasure in the cavern which was indicated.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: “You see,” said the young man, with an air of sorrowful resignation, to Faria, “that God deems it right to take from me any claim to merit for what you call my devotion to you. It is not devotion, my dear Abbé, it is necessity. What else have I in this tomb but you? What other purpose can I have but to aid you, to listen to you, to learn from you? My life outside these walls is a memory, a phantom that haunts me but no longer belongs to me. The Edmond Dantès who loved Mercédès, who was loved by his father, who was destined for happiness and a captaincy – that man is dead. He died the moment these stones closed upon him. The wretch who breathes this foul air, who eats this wretched food, who sees no sun and hears no human voice but yours, is a different being entirely. He is a creature of this dungeon, and you are its only light, its only reason for existence. To help you is not a virtue; it is self-preservation. If you were not here, I would have succumbed to despair long ago. I would have dashed my head against the walls, or simply ceased to breathe. You have given me back a semblance of life, a purpose, however small. You teach me, you speak to me of the world I have lost, you fill the dreadful silence with your knowledge and your stories. You are my link to humanity, my only companion, my father, my friend, my teacher. Every stroke of the pickaxe, every handful of earth I remove, every hour I spend listening to your wisdom – these are not sacrifices, they are the very fabric of my existence now. They are what prevent me from dissolving into the nothingness that surrounds me. Do you think I have any hope left for myself? Do you imagine I still dream of escape for my own sake? No, Abbé. My dreams are your dreams. My hope, if any flickers, is for your freedom, that you might see the sun again, that you might share your incredible mind with a world that deserves it more than this stone cell. If I work, it is for you. If I learn, it is to understand you better, to be a more worthy listener to your profound thoughts. If I endure, it is because you endure, and your strength gives me strength. Do not speak of merit, then. There is no merit in a drowning man clinging to the only spar in the ocean. There is no devotion in a plant turning towards the only ray of light that penetrates its prison. You are that spar, that ray of light. My actions are merely the instinctive movements of a soul desperate not to perish entirely. You have saved me, Abbé, not by freeing my body, but by saving my mind from madness and my spirit from utter annihilation. My gratitude is boundless, but it is a passive state, a feeling of profound indebtedness, not an active virtue. I do what I do because I cannot do otherwise and continue to exist in any meaningful way. You are my world, Faria, and tending to my world is not devotion; it is simply living within it.”

events.title: Prison Routine and Onset of Faria's Final Illness
detailed_summary: The passage of time in prison was bearable for Dantès and Faria, largely due to Faria's continuous efforts to educate his young companion, helping them both cope with their imprisonment.
Faria immersed himself in teaching to avoid dwelling on his advancing age, while Dantès used the intellectual engagement to push away the fading, painful memories of his past.
Beneath this superficial tranquility, both men harbored deep, unexpressed longings and sorrows that surfaced when they were alone in their cells.
One night, Dantès was suddenly awakened, thinking he heard someone calling his name.
He discerned the faint, plaintive voice attempting to utter his name was coming from Faria's cell.
Sitting up with a cold sweat, Dantès feared the worst and, after moving his bed and the stone, hurried through the passage to Faria's side.
He found Faria pale but upright, clinging to his bedstead, his face contorted by the dreadful and familiar symptoms of his recurring illness, which had previously caused Dantès great alarm.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: In the meanwhile the hours passed, if not rapidly, at least tolerably.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: His features were writhing with those horrible symptoms which he already knew, and which had so seriously alarmed him when he saw them for the first time.

events.text_segment:
In the meanwhile the hours passed, if not rapidly, at least tolerably. Faria, as we have said, without having recovered the use of his hand and foot, had regained all the clearness of his understanding, and had gradually, besides the moral instructions we have detailed, taught his youthful companion the patient and sublime duty of a prisoner, who learns to make something from nothing. They were thus perpetually employed,—Faria, that he might not see himself grow old; Dantès, for fear of recalling the almost extinct past which now only floated in his memory like a distant light wandering in the night. So life went on for them as it does for those who are not victims of misfortune and whose activities glide along mechanically and tranquilly beneath the eye of Providence.
But beneath this superficial calm there were in the heart of the young man, and perhaps in that of the old man, many repressed desires, many stifled sighs, which found vent when Faria was left alone, and when Edmond returned to his cell.
One night Edmond awoke suddenly, believing that he heard someone calling him. He opened his eyes upon utter darkness. His name, or rather a plaintive voice which essayed to pronounce his name, reached him. He sat up in bed and a cold sweat broke out upon his brow. Undoubtedly the call came from Faria’s dungeon.
“Alas,” murmured Edmond; “can it be?”
He moved his bed, drew up the stone, rushed into the passage, and reached the opposite extremity; the secret entrance was open. By the light of the wretched and wavering lamp, of which we have spoken, Dantès saw the old man, pale, but yet erect, clinging to the bedstead. His features were writhing with those horrible symptoms which he already knew, and which had so seriously alarmed him when he saw them for the first time.

events.title: Faria's Farewell and Dantès' Desperate Attempt to Save Him
detailed_summary: Faria, speaking with resignation, indicated to Dantès that he understood the fatal nature of his current attack and that no explanation was necessary.
Overcome with anguish, Dantès cried out and started towards the door to call for help, but Faria, with his remaining strength, stopped him, warning that discovery would jeopardize Dantès' future.
Faria urged Dantès to focus on his own survival and eventual escape, suggesting that his death might actually benefit Dantès by removing a hindrance and that Providence was perhaps intervening.
Dantès, refusing to accept defeat and remembering his previous success in reviving Faria, declared he would save him again and retrieved the phial with the red liquid.

Though expressing no personal hope for recovery, Faria instructed Dantès on how to administer the medicine, advising a larger dose of twelve drops, and then the remainder if he did not improve, acknowledging man's inherent desire to preserve life.

Faria then delivered his final wishes, blessing Dantès as a son, expressing gratitude for his companionship, and solemnly reaffirming the existence of the Spada treasure, urging Dantès to find it upon his escape.
A severe convulsion seized Faria; his eyes became bloodshot, and he clasped Dantès' hand, murmuring a final farewell.
Summoning his last reserves of strength, Faria uttered his final words: “Monte Cristo, forget not Monte Cristo!” before falling back onto the bed.
Dantès witnessed the horrifying physical changes as Faria’s body became rigid and contorted, a stark contrast to the intellectual being he had been.
Waiting for what he judged the opportune moment, Dantès administered twelve drops of the potion, and after a tense wait with no change, he poured the entire remaining contents down Faria’s throat.

events.text_segment:
“Alas, my dear friend,” said Faria in a resigned tone, “you understand, do you not, and I need not attempt to explain to you?”
Edmond uttered a cry of agony, and, quite out of his senses, rushed towards the door, exclaiming, “Help, help!”
Faria had just sufficient strength to restrain him.
“Silence,” he said, “or you are lost. We must now only think of you, my dear friend, and so act as to render your captivity supportable or your flight possible. It would require years to do again what I have done here, and the results would be instantly destroyed if our jailers knew we had communicated with each other. Besides, be assured, my dear Edmond, the dungeon I am about to leave will not long remain empty; some other unfortunate being will soon take my place, and to him you will appear like an angel of salvation. Perhaps he will be young, strong, and enduring, like yourself, and will aid you in your escape, while I have been but a hindrance. You will no longer have half a dead body tied to you as a drag to all your movements. At length Providence has done something for you; he restores to you more than he takes away, and it was time I should die.”
Edmond could only clasp his hands and exclaim, “Oh, my friend, my friend, speak not thus!” and then resuming all his presence of mind, which had for a moment staggered under this blow, and his strength, which had failed at the words of the old man, he said, “Oh, I have saved you once, and I will save you a second time!” And raising the foot of the bed, he drew out the phial, still a third filled with the red liquor.
“See,” he exclaimed, “there remains still some of the magic draught. Quick, quick! tell me what I must do this time; are there any fresh instructions? Speak, my friend; I listen.”
“There is not a hope,” replied Faria, shaking his head, “but no matter; God wills it that man whom he has created, and in whose heart he has so profoundly rooted the love of life, should do all in his power to preserve that existence, which, however painful it may be, is yet always so dear.”
“Oh, yes, yes!” exclaimed Dantès; “and I tell you that I will save you yet.”
“Well, then, try. The cold gains upon me. I feel the blood flowing towards my brain. These horrible chills, which make my teeth chatter and seem to dislocate my bones, begin to pervade my whole frame; in five minutes the malady will reach its height, and in a quarter of an hour there will be nothing left of me but a corpse.”
“Oh!” exclaimed Dantès, his heart wrung with anguish.
“Do as you did before, only do not wait so long, all the springs of life are now exhausted in me, and death,” he continued, looking at his paralyzed arm and leg, “has but half its work to do. If, after having made me swallow twelve drops instead of ten, you see that I do not recover, then pour the rest down my throat. Now lift me on my bed, for I can no longer support myself.”
Edmond took the old man in his arms, and laid him on the bed.
“And now, my dear friend,” said Faria, “sole consolation of my wretched existence,—you whom Heaven gave me somewhat late, but still gave me, a priceless gift, and for which I am most grateful,—at the moment of separating from you forever, I wish you all the happiness and all the prosperity you so well deserve. My son, I bless thee!”
The young man cast himself on his knees, leaning his head against the old man’s bed.
“Listen, now, to what I say in this my dying moment. The treasure of the Spadas exists. God grants me the boon of vision unrestricted by time or space. I see it in the depths of the inner cavern. My eyes pierce the inmost recesses of the earth, and are dazzled at the sight of so much riches. If you do escape, remember that the poor abbé, whom all the world called mad, was not so. Hasten to Monte Cristo—avail yourself of the fortune—for you have indeed suffered long enough.”
A violent convulsion attacked the old man. Dantès raised his head and saw Faria’s eyes injected with blood. It seemed as if a flow of blood had ascended from the chest to the head.
“Adieu, adieu!” murmured the old man, clasping Edmond’s hand convulsively—“adieu!”
“Oh, no,—no, not yet,” he cried; “do not forsake me! Oh, succor him! Help—help—help!”
“Hush! hush!” murmured the dying man, “that they may not separate us if you save me!”
“You are right. Oh, yes, yes; be assured I shall save you! Besides, although you suffer much, you do not seem to be in such agony as you were before.”
“Do not mistake! I suffer less because there is in me less strength to endure. At your age we have faith in life; it is the privilege of youth to believe and hope, but old men see death more clearly. Oh, ’tis here—’tis here—’tis over—my sight is gone—my senses fail! Your hand, Dantès! Adieu! adieu!”
And raising himself by a final effort, in which he summoned all his faculties, he said,—“Monte Cristo, forget not Monte Cristo!” And he fell back on the bed.
The crisis was terrible, and a rigid form with twisted limbs, swollen eyelids, and lips flecked with bloody foam, lay on the bed of torture, in place of the intellectual being who so lately rested there.
Dantès took the lamp, placed it on a projecting stone above the bed, whence its tremulous light fell with strange and fantastic ray on the distorted countenance and motionless, stiffened body. With steady gaze he awaited confidently the moment for administering the restorative.
When he believed that the right moment had arrived, he took the knife, pried open the teeth, which offered less resistance than before, counted one after the other twelve drops, and watched; the phial contained, perhaps, twice as much more. He waited ten minutes, a quarter of an hour, half an hour,—no change took place. Trembling, his hair erect, his brow bathed with perspiration, he counted the seconds by the beating of his heart. Then he thought it was time to make the last trial, and he put the phial to the purple lips of Faria, and without having occasion to force open his jaws, which had remained extended, he poured the whole of the liquid down his throat.
The draught produced a galvanic effect, a violent trembling pervaded the old man’s limbs, his eyes opened until it was fearful to gaze upon them, he heaved a sigh which resembled a shriek, and then his convulsed body returned gradually to its former immobility, the eyes remaining open.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“Alas, my dear friend,” said Faria in a resigned tone, “you understand, do you not, and I need not attempt to explain to you?”

Dantès uttered a cry of anguish, and, starting up, rushed towards the door, exclaiming, “Oh, my friend! help! help!”

“Silence!” cried Faria, collecting all his strength; “do not condemn me to hear the cries of my gaoler. It is useless, I tell you; my hour is come. I have been saved once by the most extraordinary chance; but a second time there is no hope. Do not disturb yourself, do not distress yourself, my dear Dantès; it is the will of God!”

“No! no!” cried Dantès; “you will not die! I will save you! I have saved you once, and I will save you again!”

“No,” said Faria; “let me die in peace. Do not call any one; do not denounce my death to the gaoler. My death would perhaps procure you that liberty which I in vain sought for myself. God wills that I should die here; who knows? perhaps the ever-watchful Providence is even now opening the gates of my prison, and preparing to lead me forth by a passage unknown to the gaolers.”

“Oh, do not speak thus, my friend! I will not let you die! Oh, I will so watch over you, and if I see you in danger, I will again give you the remedy which has already succeeded so well.”

“My child,” said Faria, “that remedy was successfully applied to a new disease, the progress of which it checked; but this one is fatal, and was caused by the effort I made.”

“Is there no hope, then?” asked Dantès, in a trembling voice.

“None, my dear friend, none,” answered Faria; “but it matters little; do not grieve yourself, it is better to die than to suffer as I do.”

Dantès fell on his knees beside the bed, and seized the hand of the dying man, who smiled sweetly at him.

“See,” said he, “I had finished my work; I had just completed the history of the House of Spada, to which I devoted the last ten years of my life. I have also written this, which I commend to your care; it is the Private History of the Cabinet of Alexander VI., and this, which is a memorial of the Captivity of Pius VII. at Fontainebleau. The first is in Latin, and the others in Italian. If you ever escape, you can get them published; but there is a passage in the history of the House of Spada which can be rendered useful to you.”

Dantès pressed the hand of the abbé to his lips.

“Listen,” continued he; “you are an intelligent young man, and have comprehended all that I have taught you. Do not abandon my papers to the gaolers, for they would make a jest of them; but if you are ever permitted to leave this prison, have them copied, and publish them. But, above all, do not forget the passage I mentioned; it may be to you of the greatest importance.”

“I will not forget anything, my friend,” said Dantès; “but tell me, I beseech you, what is this passage?”

“Listen,” said Faria; “it is in the twenty-ninth chapter of the history of the House of Spada. It is there written that the Cardinal Cesare Spada, my ancestor, in the year 1498, fearing that Alexander VI. would poison him, made a will by which he declared that he had buried in a certain part of the island of Monte Cristo, which he named, a treasure of two millions of Roman crowns, consisting of gold, ingots, jewels, and diamonds. This treasure he bequeathed to his only son, Guido; but as he feared that the pope would seize upon it, he added that if Guido died without issue, the treasure should revert to the nearest relative of the family, who should be able to discover it. Guido died without issue, and I am the nearest relative. Now, you understand, do you not?”

“Yes, my friend, I understand,” said Dantès; “and if I ever escape, I will seek for this treasure.”

“Yes, my child, do so,” said Faria; “and if you find it, remember that it is the fruit of my labours, and that I have bequeathed it to you.”

“I will remember it, my friend,” said Dantès; “and if I find it, I will share it with you.”

“No,” said Faria; “you are my son, and I give it all to you. But now,” added he, “my strength fails me; my eyes grow dim; I feel that I am dying. Give me the phial.”

Dantès hastened to the corner where the phial was deposited, and brought it to the abbé.

“Now,” said Faria, “listen to me. If I do not recover from this attack, which is more violent than the others, pour twelve drops into a glass of water, and make me drink it. If I do not revive, then pour the remainder down my throat. It is a powerful remedy, and may perhaps restore me.”

“Yes, my friend, yes,” said Dantès; “I will do as you desire.”

“Now,” said Faria, “bless you, my dear child; bless you for having softened the rigours of my captivity, and for having restored me to life, for I was dead when you found me. Bless you for having given me hope, and for having taught me that there is still a God in heaven who watches over the innocent.”

Dantès wept aloud, and pressed the hand of the abbé to his heart.

“Do not weep, my child,” said Faria; “it is the will of God. And now, farewell. Remember the treasure of Monte Cristo.”

He had scarcely uttered these words when a violent convulsion seized him; his eyes became bloodshot, his face purple, and his limbs rigid. He clasped the hand of Dantès with a strength that made him cry out, and, with a last effort, he murmured, “Monte Cristo, forget not Monte Cristo!”

Then, with a sigh, which seemed to tear his very soul from his body, he fell back on the bed, a lifeless corpse.

Dantès remained for a moment stupified, then, seeing that the eyes of the abbé were fixed and glassy, that his face was livid, and that his limbs were cold and rigid, he felt a thrill of horror run through his veins. He had never before seen death, and the sight of that motionless body, with its distorted features and its glazed eyes, filled him with a dread which he could not overcome.

He waited for a moment, then, remembering the instructions of the abbé, he poured twelve drops of the liquid into a glass of water, and made him drink it. He waited again, but there was no sign of life. Then, with a trembling hand, he poured the remainder down his throat. Still there was no change. The abbé was dead.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“Alas, my dear friend,” said Faria in a resigned tone, “you understand, do you not, and I need not attempt to explain to you?”

Dantès knelt beside the pallet, his heart heavy with a sorrow he had not known since the death of his father. The Abbé’s face, usually animated by the fire of his intellect, was now pale and drawn, marked by the recent, more violent attack of catalepsy. His breathing was shallow, his voice weak, barely a whisper. “Yes, Father,” Dantès murmured, his voice thick with emotion, “I understand. It is the third attack.”

Faria smiled faintly, a smile of profound peace that seemed to emanate from a soul already detaching itself from the confines of the body. “The third,” he confirmed. “And as I told you, the third is fatal. The lamp is extinguished, Edmond. The oil is consumed.”

Dantès seized the Abbé’s hand, pressing it to his lips. “No, Father, do not say that! You are strong, you will recover! We will yet escape together!”

Faria gently squeezed his hand. “My son, hope is a good thing, perhaps the best of things, and no good thing ever dies. But hope for me now lies beyond these walls, in a different realm. My work here is done. I have given you all I could – knowledge, counsel, and the key to a fortune that will make you powerful. Use it wisely, Edmond. Avenge us, but do not become like them. Be just.”

A tear rolled down Dantès’s cheek. “But what will I do without you? You are my father, my teacher, my only friend!”

“You are no longer the simple sailor who was cast into this abyss,” Faria said, his voice gaining a fleeting strength. “You are a man forged in suffering, tempered by knowledge. You are ready. The world awaits you, Edmond. Go, live, remember.” His eyes, which had held such piercing intelligence, began to glaze over. His grip on Dantès’s hand weakened.

“Father! Father!” Dantès cried, but the Abbé did not respond. His breathing became fainter, almost imperceptible. Dantès watched, helpless, as the last spark of life flickered and died in the eyes of the man who had saved him from despair, who had given him a new life within the tomb. The silence that followed was more profound than any Dantès had ever known, a silence that screamed of loss and finality.

He remained kneeling there for a long time, holding the cold hand, the weight of his grief crushing him. The cell, which had seemed a place of learning and hope when Faria was alive, now reverted to being a mere stone box, a tomb for two – one dead, one living. Despair, the old enemy, began to creep back into the corners of his mind.

But then, as he looked at the lifeless form of his friend, an idea, born of desperation and the Abbé’s own teachings on resourcefulness, began to form. It was a wild, audacious, terrifying idea, but it was an idea of escape. Faria had often spoken of the custom of burying the dead of the Château d’If in the sea, weighted down in sacks. What if… what if he could take Faria’s place?

The thought sent a shiver down his spine, a mixture of horror and desperate hope. It was a gruesome plan, a desecration of sorts, but the alternative was to remain buried alive himself. He looked at the body again. It was thin, emaciated by years of captivity and illness. He was larger, stronger, but perhaps… perhaps it was possible.

He rose, his movements stiff. He had to act quickly before the guards discovered the Abbé’s death. He dragged Faria’s body from the pallet and carried it to his own bed, laying it carefully. Then, with trembling hands, he began to undress the corpse, exchanging its clothes for his own. It was a macabre task, one that tested his resolve, but the burning desire for freedom, for vengeance, for life, drove him on.

He dressed himself in the Abbé’s simple, worn garments. They were too small, but that could not be helped. He then took the sheet from his bed and wrapped it around Faria’s body, securing it as best he could. He carried the wrapped body back to the Abbé’s pallet and laid it there, arranging it to look as though the Abbé were merely sleeping.

He then returned to his own cell, taking with him the Abbé’s knife and the small store of tools they had fashioned over the years. He waited, every nerve taut, listening for the sound of the guards. The silence of the prison seemed heavier than usual, punctuated only by the distant lapping of waves against the rocks below.

Hours seemed to pass. The initial shock and grief began to give way to a cold, focused determination. He thought of Mercédès, of his father, of Danglars, Fernand, and Villefort. He would not die here. He would live, and he would make them pay.

Finally, he heard footsteps approaching, heavier than usual, and the j

events.title: Faria's Death and Dantès' Solitary Vigil
detailed_summary: Following the administration of the full dose of medicine, Faria's body experienced a brief, violent tremor, and his eyes opened alarmingly wide before he sighed deeply and his convulsed form returned to stillness, eyes remaining open.

For an agonizing period lasting an hour and a half, Dantès remained by Faria's side, hand on his chest, feeling the life ebb away as the body grew colder and the heartbeat fainter, until it stopped entirely.
The arrival of dawn brought its dim light into the dungeon, paling the lamp and confirming the stark reality: Faria was dead, and Dantès was alone with his corpse.

An overwhelming and extreme terror seized Dantès; he found himself unable to touch Faria’s lifeless hand or gaze into his fixed, vacant eyes, which repeatedly opened despite his attempts to close them.
Dantès extinguished the lamp, carefully hid it, and then, closing the passage stone as best he could, retreated to his own cell.
His return coincided with the arrival of the jailer, who began his morning rounds at Dantès' cell before proceeding to Faria's with breakfast, showing no awareness of the night's tragic events.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Half an hour, an hour, an hour and a half elapsed, and during this period of anguish, Edmond leaned over his friend, his hand applied to his heart, and felt the body gradually grow cold, and the heart’s pulsation become more and more deep and dull, until at length it stopped; the last movement of the heart ceased, the face became livid, the eyes remained open, but the eyeballs were glazed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He went on his way.

events.text_segment:
Half an hour, an hour, an hour and a half elapsed, and during this period of anguish, Edmond leaned over his friend, his hand applied to his heart, and felt the body gradually grow cold, and the heart’s pulsation become more and more deep and dull, until at length it stopped; the last movement of the heart ceased, the face became livid, the eyes remained open, but the eyeballs were glazed.
It was six o’clock in the morning, the dawn was just breaking, and its feeble ray came into the dungeon, and paled the ineffectual light of the lamp. Strange shadows passed over the countenance of the dead man, and at times gave it the appearance of life. While the struggle between day and night lasted, Dantès still doubted; but as soon as the daylight gained the pre-eminence, he saw that he was alone with a corpse. Then an invincible and extreme terror seized upon him, and he dared not again press the hand that hung out of bed, he dared no longer to gaze on those fixed and vacant eyes, which he tried many times to close, but in vain—they opened again as soon as shut. He extinguished the lamp, carefully concealed it, and then went away, closing as well as he could the entrance to the secret passage by the large stone as he descended.
It was time, for the jailer was coming. On this occasion he began his rounds at Dantès’ cell, and on leaving him he went on to Faria’s dungeon, taking thither breakfast and some linen. Nothing betokened that the man knew anything of what had occurred. He went on his way.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Half an hour, an hour, an hour and a half elapsed, and during this period of anguish, Edmond leaned over his friend, his hand applied to his heart, and felt the body gradually grow cold, and the heart’s pulsation become more and more deep and dull, until at length it stopped; the last movement of the heart ceased, the face became livid, the eyes remained open, but the eyeballs were glazed. At this moment the lamp went out, and the dawn of day appeared through the narrow window of the cell, and with the dawn appeared the pallid face of the Abbé, upon which the dim light shed a ghastly hue. The eyes, which remained open, gazed with a frightful expression at the window, and seemed to be starting from their sockets. Edmond had never beheld death under so hideous an aspect; it was so ghastly he dared not touch the dead body, and drew back from the spectacle with horror. And yet he had seen revolting sights in the hospital at Marseilles, and in the galleys. At the galleys he had seen the execution of the unfortunate Sebastian, who had been condemned as the associate of Pepino and Rocca Priori; but never had the hideous features of a corpse presented themselves to his view with the ghastliness that now struck him. Seated on his stool in the corner of the dungeon, Edmond could only gaze on the terrible countenance, the open eyes, the distorted features, the lips drawn back so as to show the white teeth; it was fearful. There was not a sound in the dungeon, save the almost inaudible respiration of Edmond, who sat motionless in his fear. It seemed to him as if the dead man was about to rise, and walk, and speak. It was in vain that he told himself that Faria was dead, that he was utterly powerless; he could not remove the horrible impression which the open eyes produced upon him. He tried to close them, but as soon as he left the lids, they opened again with a frightful stare. He rose in despair, and turned to the door, intending to call the sentry, and point out the fact that his companion was dead; but the thought of the consequences that might ensue restrained him. They would remove Faria’s body, and in doing so discover the tunnel, and prevent the completion of his own. Then in the place of the wise and good Abbé, they would perchance send him a companion who would frustrate all his plans, or else leave him alone. Alone! the word created an indescribable terror. He recollected the horrors he had endured during the first four years of his captivity; the frightful solitude, the silence, the darkness; and he recoiled from the idea of being thus abandoned for ever, with the dead body of his companion before him. His blood ran cold. He seated himself again in his corner, and resolved not to stir from it. The day passed on thus. Edmond remained in his corner, and the Abbé’s corpse lay upon the bed. At the accustomed hour, the jailer came, and, without disturbing the ordinary routine, brought Edmond’s breakfast, and then Faria’s. “Come, father,” said he, when he perceived the latter did not move, “take your breakfast—the sun is up.” But the sun was more than up. Its rays, shining through the upper bars of the window, reached the bed, and gave to the lifeless face of the Abbé a horrible paleness, and to his glazed eyes a frightful expression. The jailer gazed at him for a moment, then, approaching the bed, he drew back the sheet. “Ah! ah!” said he, with a horrid smile, which displayed his uneven teeth, “he is dead!” Edmond did not answer. “Yes, he is dead,” continued the jailer; “he is dead, and this time it is for good. Well, father, go and tell the governor, that he may send the masons, and have the wall built up. It is all over.” “Yes,” said Edmond, “it is all over!” “Well, and what are you doing there, sitting in the corner?” said the jailer; “why do you not come and help me?” Edmond rose, and approached the bed, while the jailer went out. The dead body was cold. Edmond drew the sheet over the face. “Alas!” said he, “he is dead, and I am alone again! I am alone again, to struggle with my sorrow and despair!” The jailer returned, accompanied by the governor. The governor was a man of mild character, who had been a soldier, and was accustomed to the sight of death. He ordered the body to be removed, and the cell to be cleaned. Edmond remained in his corner, and did not speak. The body was placed in a sack, and carried away. The cell was cleaned, and the wall was built up. Edmond was alone again. He remained in his corner, and did not move

events.title: Discovery of Faria's Body and Eavesdropping on Jailers
detailed_summary: An intense urge compelled Dantès to find out what was transpiring in Faria's dungeon, so he returned via the secret passage.
He arrived just as the turnkey discovered Faria's lifeless body and cried out for help.
Soon, other turnkeys joined, followed by the sounds of soldiers arriving, and ultimately, the governor of the château.
Dantès listened as they moved the corpse, and heard the governor instruct them to throw water on Faria's face in an attempt to revive him.
Upon seeing that Faria did not respond, they sent for the doctor.
After the governor temporarily departed, Dantès overheard the remaining men expressing a mixture of pity and brutal laughter concerning Faria.

He listened to their callous remarks about the abbé's supposed madness, his treasure quest, and the inexpensive nature of burials at the Château d'If, before the governor returned with the doctor and formal inquiries began.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Dantès was then seized with an indescribable desire to know what was going on in the dungeon of his unfortunate friend.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The inquiries soon commenced.

events.text_segment:
Dantès was then seized with an indescribable desire to know what was going on in the dungeon of his unfortunate friend. He therefore returned by the subterraneous gallery, and arrived in time to hear the exclamations of the turnkey, who called out for help. Other turnkeys came, and then was heard the regular tramp of soldiers. Last of all came the governor.
Edmond heard the creaking of the bed as they moved the corpse, heard the voice of the governor, who asked them to throw water on the dead man’s face; and seeing that, in spite of this application, the prisoner did not recover, they sent for the doctor. The governor then went out, and words of pity fell on Dantès’ listening ears, mingled with brutal laughter.
“Well, well,” said one, “the madman has gone to look after his treasure. Good journey to him!”
“With all his millions, he will not have enough to pay for his shroud!” said another.
“Oh,” added a third voice, “the shrouds of the Château d’If are not dear!”
“Perhaps,” said one of the previous speakers, “as he was a churchman, they may go to some expense in his behalf.”
“They may give him the honors of the sack.”
Edmond did not lose a word, but comprehended very little of what was said. The voices soon ceased, and it seemed to him as if everyone had left the cell. Still he dared not to enter, as they might have left some turnkey to watch the dead. He remained, therefore, mute and motionless, hardly venturing to breathe. At the end of an hour, he heard a faint noise, which increased. It was the governor who returned, followed by the doctor and other attendants. There was a moment’s silence,—it was evident that the doctor was examining the dead body. The inquiries soon commenced.

Other turnkeys hastened to the spot, and then was heard the sound of soldiers’ steps. The governor of the château arrived, and Dantès could distinguish his stern voice. He ordered the door to be opened. Dantès did not lose a word, and comprehended everything. They took the corpse on the bed, and Dantès heard one of the turnkeys laugh brutally. “Well, well,” said he, “the madman has gone to search for his treasure. He told me the other day that he was going, but I did not believe him.” “Ah, that’s rich,” said another, “what a pity he did not confide his secret to us; we would have helped him in the search.” “No,” said a third, with a sigh, “the best of us all is gone. Father Faria was a good man, and I am sure he is gone to heaven. Throw water on his face, and we shall see if he will not return to us.” “Ah, bah, he is dead enough,” said the first turnkey; “I saw him as stiff as a poker. The abbé was a learned man, and besides, he had a treasure.” “That is true,” said the governor, “he was a learned man; and, had he not been a madman, he would have been a great man.” “Come, come,” said the first turnkey, “let us not stand here all day; we have other prisoners to attend to. Let us carry him to the cemetery.” “To the cemetery!” exclaimed the governor, “why, he is not dead yet.” “Yes, yes,” said the turnkey, “he is dead enough; I tell you I saw him as stiff as a poker.” “Well, well,” said the governor, “let us carry him to the cemetery, and we shall see.” Dantès heard them lift the body, and then the sound of their steps as they carried it away. events.title: Official Confirmation of Death and Callous Remarks
detailed_summary: The doctor examined Faria, identified the symptoms of the illness that led to his death, and formally pronounced him deceased.
The subsequent conversation among the officials was conducted with a nonchalance that outraged Dantès, who felt Faria deserved profound love and respect from everyone.
The governor expressed a superficial regret, noting that Faria had been a quiet, unproblematic prisoner whose perceived madness made him easy to manage.
A turnkey affirmed this, stating Faria would have remained imprisoned for decades without attempting to escape.
Despite the doctor’s clear diagnosis, the governor, citing official duty, insisted on further measures to unequivocally confirm the death.
An order was given to heat irons, a directive that caused Dantès to shudder with horror as he listened.
Dantès heard the sounds of hurried movements and subsequently smelled the nauseating odor of burning flesh, which made him feel faint.
The doctor then declared Faria definitively dead, citing the burn mark on the heel as conclusive, and remarked that the 'poor fool' was now cured of his folly and freed from captivity.
The officials briefly discussed Faria's name, his notable erudition, and what the doctor termed his 'monomania' regarding the treasure.
The jailer responsible for Faria's care attested to his good behavior, mentioning his entertaining stories and a time Faria had given a successful medical prescription for the jailer's sick wife.
The doctor made a lighthearted comment about this medical 'rivalry' and expressed hope that the governor would ensure Faria received due respect.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The doctor analyzed the symptoms of the malady to which the prisoner had succumbed, and declared that he was dead.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Ah, ah!” said the doctor, “I did not know that I had a rival; but I hope, governor, that you will show him all proper respect in consequence.”

events.text_segment:
The doctor analyzed the symptoms of the malady to which the prisoner had succumbed, and declared that he was dead. Questions and answers followed in a nonchalant manner that made Dantès indignant, for he felt that all the world should have for the poor abbé a love and respect equal to his own.
“I am very sorry for what you tell me,” said the governor, replying to the assurance of the doctor, “that the old man is really dead; for he was a quiet, inoffensive prisoner, happy in his folly, and required no watching.”
“Ah,” added the turnkey, “there was no occasion for watching him; he would have stayed here fifty years, I’ll answer for it, without any attempt to escape.”
“Still,” said the governor, “I believe it will be requisite, notwithstanding your certainty, and not that I doubt your science, but in discharge of my official duty, that we should be perfectly assured that the prisoner is dead.”
There was a moment of complete silence, during which Dantès, still listening, knew that the doctor was examining the corpse a second time.
“You may make your mind easy,” said the doctor; “he is dead. I will answer for that.”
“You know, sir,” said the governor, persisting, “that we are not content in such cases as this with such a simple examination. In spite of all appearances, be so kind, therefore, as to finish your duty by fulfilling the formalities described by law.”
“Let the irons be heated,” said the doctor; “but really it is a useless precaution.”
This order to heat the irons made Dantès shudder. He heard hasty steps, the creaking of a door, people going and coming, and some minutes afterwards a turnkey entered, saying:
“Here is the brazier, lighted.”
There was a moment’s silence, and then was heard the crackling of burning flesh, of which the peculiar and nauseous smell penetrated even behind the wall where Dantès was listening in horror. The perspiration poured forth upon the young man’s brow, and he felt as if he should faint.
“You see, sir, he is really dead,” said the doctor; “this burn in the heel is decisive. The poor fool is cured of his folly, and delivered from his captivity.”
“Wasn’t his name Faria?” inquired one of the officers who accompanied the governor.
“Yes, sir; and, as he said, it was an ancient name. He was, too, very learned, and rational enough on all points which did not relate to his treasure; but on that, indeed, he was intractable.”
“It is the sort of malady which we call monomania,” said the doctor.
“You had never anything to complain of?” said the governor to the jailer who had charge of the abbé.
“Never, sir,” replied the jailer, “never; on the contrary, he sometimes amused me very much by telling me stories. One day, too, when my wife was ill, he gave me a prescription which cured her.”
“Ah, ah!” said the doctor, “I did not know that I had a rival; but I hope, governor, that you will show him all proper respect in consequence.”

A silence, heavy and profound, fell upon the cell, broken only by the distant murmur of the sea against the rocks of the Château d'If.  The guards, accustomed to such scenes, went about their grim duty with practiced efficiency.  They fetched a coarse sack, the kind used for transporting provisions, and began the process of preparing the body for burial.  Dantès, in his adjacent cell, heard the muffled sounds through the thick stone wall – the shuffling of feet, the rustle of the sack, the low, guttural voices of the men.  He knew instantly what was happening.  His heart, which had been numb with grief only moments before, now began to pound with a frantic, terrible hope.  Abbé Faria was dead, but his death offered a possibility, a desperate, audacious chance for escape that had never existed before.  He remembered Faria's words, his lessons on patience, on seizing opportunity.  This was the ultimate, the most perilous opportunity.  He had to act, and act quickly, before the body was removed.  Waiting until the guards had finished their task, he listened intently.  The sounds ceased.  They had sewn the body into the sack.  Now was the moment.  With trembling hands, he began to work at the loose stone behind his bed, the one Faria had helped him loosen so many years ago.  The stone yielded, revealing the narrow passage.  He squeezed through, his body scraping against the rough-hewn rock, and emerged into Faria's cell.  It was dark, save for a sliver of moonlight filtering through the high window.  He saw the sack lying on the floor, a dark, inert shape.  He approached it, his breath catching in his throat.  He had to be quick, silent.  He knelt beside the sack, his fingers fumbling with the coarse material.  He found the opening where the head had been placed before being sewn shut.  Working swiftly, he managed to tear the stitches loose just enough to create an opening.  He then reached inside and, with a supreme effort, pulled the body of the old man from the sack.  It was cold, stiff, and surprisingly heavy.  He laid it gently on the floor beside the sack.  Now came the most terrifying part.  He had to take its place.  He slipped into the sack, pulling the rough fabric up around him.  He curled his body into the fetal position, mimicking the shape of the corpse.  He pulled the torn edges of the sack together as best he could, hoping the darkness and the haste of the guards would conceal the imperfection.  He lay there, heart hammering against his ribs, listening.  Every second stretched into an eternity.  Then he heard them – the heavy footsteps approaching the cell door.  The key turned in the lock with a loud, grating sound.  The door creaked open, letting in a faint light from the corridor.  He heard the guards enter, their voices low.  They approached the sack.  He felt hands grasp the material, lifting him.  He was hoisted onto their shoulders, carried out of the cell, down the corridor, and towards the outer courtyard. events.title: Burial Arrangements and Dantès' Emergence into Faria's Cell
detailed_summary: The governor sarcastically assured the doctor that Faria would receive a 'decent' burial in the best sack available, questioning if that would satisfy him.
A turnkey inquired if the governor needed to be present for the final preparations, to which the governor affirmed, urging them to hurry as he couldn't stay all day.

Dantès heard the distinct sounds of a canvas sack rustling, the bed creaking as Faria's body was handled, and the heavy tread of someone lifting a weight, followed by the bed creaking again as the body was placed in the sack.
The governor announced that the burial would take place that evening.
When asked about the time, he specified it would be around ten or eleven o'clock.

In response to a question about a mass, the governor stated it was impossible as the château's chaplain was away on leave, cynically remarking that Faria might have had a requiem if he hadn't been in such a hurry to die.
The doctor contributed a typically impious joke for his profession, suggesting God would respect Faria's clerical status and not trouble the devil with him, which was met with laughter.
Once the body was sacked, the governor instructed them to simply shut the dungeon as if Faria were still alive, deeming a watch unnecessary.
After the sounds of footsteps and voices faded, and the door was secured, an oppressive silence of death filled the space, chilling Dantès to his core.
Cautiously, Dantès lifted the stone covering the passage with his head, looked around Faria's now-empty chamber, and then stepped out of the tunnel.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Yes, yes, make your mind easy, he shall be decently interred in the newest sack we can find.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was empty, and Dantès emerged from the tunnel.

events.text_segment:
“Yes, yes, make your mind easy, he shall be decently interred in the newest sack we can find. Will that satisfy you?”
“Must this last formality take place in your presence, sir?” inquired a turnkey.
“Certainly. But make haste—I cannot stay here all day.” Other footsteps, going and coming, were now heard, and a moment afterwards the noise of rustling canvas reached Dantès’ ears, the bed creaked, and the heavy footfall of a man who lifts a weight sounded on the floor; then the bed again creaked under the weight deposited upon it.
“This evening,” said the governor.
“Will there be any mass?” asked one of the attendants.
“That is impossible,” replied the governor. “The chaplain of the château came to me yesterday to beg for leave of absence, in order to take a trip to Hyères for a week. I told him I would attend to the prisoners in his absence. If the poor abbé had not been in such a hurry, he might have had his requiem.”
“Pooh, pooh;” said the doctor, with the impiety usual in persons of his profession; “he is a churchman. God will respect his profession, and not give the devil the wicked delight of sending him a priest.” A shout of laughter followed this brutal jest. Meanwhile the operation of putting the body in the sack was going on.
“This evening,” said the governor, when the task was ended.
“At what hour?” inquired a turnkey.
“Why, about ten or eleven o’clock.”
“Shall we watch by the corpse?”
“Of what use would it be? Shut the dungeon as if he were alive—that is all.”
Then the steps retreated, and the voices died away in the distance; the noise of the door, with its creaking hinges and bolts ceased, and a silence more sombre than that of solitude ensued,—the silence of death, which was all-pervasive, and struck its icy chill to the very soul of Dantès.
Then he raised the flag-stone cautiously with his head, and looked carefully around the chamber. It was empty, and Dantès emerged from the tunnel.

```python
“Perfectly,” replied the doctor.

“Yes, yes, make haste; I cannot remain here all day.”

Dantès heard the rasping sound of the canvas sack which the attendants brought, the creaking of the bed as they lifted the body, and the heavy tread of the men who carried it to the sack, and the creaking of the bed again as they placed it in.

“The burial will take place this evening,” said the governor.

“At what hour?” asked the turnkey.

“About ten or eleven o’clock.”

“Shall we have a mass?” inquired the turnkey.

“That is impossible,” replied the governor; “the chaplain of the château is on leave of absence. Had the poor Abbé Faria been in less haste, he might have had a requiem; but it is thus with all our prisoners, they are always in a hurry,” added he, with a laugh.

“Never mind,” replied the doctor, with a smile; “God will respect him as a churchman, and will not trouble the devil with him.”

They all laughed.

“Well, when you have put him in the sack,” said the governor, “you need not sew it up; just shut the dungeon door, and that is all. There is no need of watching him, he will not escape.”

The footsteps and voices died away; the door was secured. The silence which followed was dreadful. Dantès felt the chill of death penetrate his very soul. Cautiously, he raised the stone with his head, looked around the chamber, now empty, and then stepped out of the tunnel.
"""

print(generated_text_segment)
```
