I have forgotten him!” “You loved him, then?” said the abbé, whose gaze became more fixed and satisfied as he observed the growing depression of the innkeeper. “You loved him?” “As a brother,” replied Caderousse, with a choking voice. “He was a noble heart, a brave young man. And how did he die? Of what did he die?” “He died,” replied the abbé, “as young and strong men die in prison, when they have been long there, and have lost all hope; he died of imprisonment, of despair, of a broken heart.” Caderousse groaned. “Poor Edmond!” he repeated. “And I—I who was his friend—I who loved him so well—I have done nothing for him!” “You say you were his friend?” said the abbé. “Yes, his friend,” replied Caderousse; “we were children together, we were sailors together, we were friends together.” “And yet,” said the abbé, “when he was arrested, you did nothing for him.” “I was afraid,” replied Caderousse; “I was a coward. But I loved him, nevertheless.” “And he,” continued the abbé, “even in his dying moments, swore to me that he was ignorant of the cause of his detention. He implored me, by the most sacred ties, to clear his memory of any stain, and to investigate the mystery of his fate. And I—I have promised him that I would do so.” Caderousse listened with a haggard look. “And you believe him?” he asked. “I do,” replied the abbé. “And I am here to-day to keep my promise.” He paused for a moment, and then continued, “Edmond Dantès had a friend in prison, a rich Englishman, who was released during the second restoration. This Englishman, in gratitude for the care which Dantès had taken of him during an illness, gave him a diamond of immense value. Dantès preserved it for his future use.” Caderousse’s eyes sparkled. “A diamond of immense value!” he exclaimed. “Yes,” replied the abbé, “of immense value to a man in Edmond’s position. It was estimated at fifty thousand francs.” Caderousse uttered a cry of astonishment. “Fifty thousand francs!” he repeated. “It is impossible!” “It is true,” said the abbé. “It was not, it is true, as large as a nut, but it was a stone of the first water.” He drew from his pocket a small black shagreen box, opened it, and displayed to the dazzled eyes of Caderousse a magnificent jewel, set in a ring. “Look at it,” he said. “It is a diamond of the first water, and it is worth fifty thousand francs.” Caderousse was breathless with admiration. “It is true,” he murmured, “it is true. It is a magnificent stone.” “And the setting is also valuable,” added the abbé, as he closed the box and replaced it in his pocket. Caderousse remained fascinated.

events.title: Dantès's Will: A Diamond to be Shared Among Friends
characters: Abbé Faria (disguised, referred to as 'the abbé')
detailed_summary: Caderousse, still captivated by the diamond, asks the abbé how he came to possess it, wondering if Edmond had made him his heir.
The abbé clarifies that he is merely Dantès's testamentary executor.

He recounts Dantès's dying words, stating he had four dear and faithful friends, plus his betrothed, who he was convinced grieved his loss. He names one of these friends as Caderousse, causing the innkeeper to shiver.
The abbé continues, naming another friend as Danglars, and a third, Fernand, who despite being a rival, supposedly held sincere affection for Dantès.
A fiendish smile appears on Caderousse's face as Fernand is mentioned, and he is about to interrupt, but the abbé gestures for him to wait.
The abbé then mentions Dantès's betrothed, momentarily pausing as if he has forgotten her name. Caderousse eagerly supplies, “Mercédès.”
With a stifled sigh, the abbé confirms, “Mercédès it was,” and after Caderousse urges him to continue, the abbé requests a carafe of water.
Caderousse quickly fetches the water. After drinking slowly and regaining his composure, the abbé resumes.
He explains Dantès's instructions: the diamond was to be sold, and the money divided into five equal parts to be given to these good friends, the only people Dantès felt had loved him on earth.

Caderousse asks why there are five parts when only four individuals (Caderousse, Danglars, Fernand, Mercédès) have been mentioned in this context by the Abbé. The Abbé clarifies that the fifth share was intended for Edmond's own father.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “But how comes the diamond in your possession, sir? Did Edmond make you his heir?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Because the fifth is dead, as I hear. The fifth sharer in Edmond’s bequest, was his own father.”

events.text_segment:
“But how comes the diamond in your possession, sir? Did Edmond make you his heir?”
“No, merely his testamentary executor. ‘I once possessed four dear and faithful friends, besides the maiden to whom I was betrothed’ he said; ‘and I feel convinced they have all unfeignedly grieved over my loss. The name of one of the four friends is Caderousse.’” The innkeeper shivered.
“‘Another of the number,’” continued the abbé, without seeming to notice the emotion of Caderousse, “‘is called Danglars; and the third, in spite of being my rival, entertained a very sincere affection for me.’”
A fiendish smile played over the features of Caderousse, who was about to break in upon the abbé’s speech, when the latter, waving his hand, said, “Allow me to finish first, and then if you have any observations to make, you can do so afterwards. ‘The third of my friends, although my rival, was much attached to me,—his name was Fernand; that of my betrothed was’—Stay, stay,” continued the abbé, “I have forgotten what he called her.”
“Mercédès,” said Caderousse eagerly.
“True,” said the abbé, with a stifled sigh, “Mercédès it was.”
“Go on,” urged Caderousse.
“Bring me a carafe of water,” said the abbé.
Caderousse quickly performed the stranger’s bidding; and after pouring some into a glass, and slowly swallowing its contents, the abbé, resuming his usual placidity of manner, said, as he placed his empty glass on the table:
“Where did we leave off?”
“The name of Edmond’s betrothed was Mercédès.”
“To be sure. ‘You will go to Marseilles,’ said Dantès,—for you understand, I repeat his words just as he uttered them. Do you understand?”
“Perfectly.”
“‘You will sell this diamond; you will divide the money into five equal parts, and give an equal portion to these good friends, the only persons who have loved me upon earth.’”
“But why into five parts?” asked Caderousse; “you only mentioned four persons.”
“Because the fifth is dead, as I hear. The fifth sharer in Edmond’s bequest, was his own father.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“But how comes the diamond in your possession, sir? Did Edmond make you his heir?”
“No, not his heir; I am only the testamentary executor of his last wishes, and his dying words were, that he had four dear and faithful friends, plus his betrothed, and that he was convinced they grieved for his loss. He charged me to convey to them his last farewell, and, as a proof of his affection, to distribute among them the little he had possessed.”
“The names of these four friends, sir?” asked Caderousse.
“Gaspard Caderousse, tailor, at Marseilles; Danglars, clerk in the house of Morrel & Son; Fernand, a Catalan fisherman; and Mercédès, a Catalan.”
“Ah, yes,” said Caderousse, becoming pale, and letting the glass he held fall from his hand, “these were the true friends.”
“Not a doubt of it,” replied the abbé; “and as I was charged with his dying wishes, I have come to discharge my trust to them. This diamond was to be sold, and the money divided into five equal parts, and I have come to bring you your share, and to convey to the others what belongs to them.”
“Why, there were only four,” said Caderousse; “you named only four—Caderousse, Danglars, Fernand, and Mercédès.”
“Yes, but Dantès added that the fifth share belonged to his father.”

events.title: The Starvation of Dantès's Father and La Carconte's Suspicious Intervention
characters: Abbé Faria (disguised, referred to as 'the abbé')
detailed_summary: Caderousse, visibly agitated by conflicting emotions, confirms that Dantès's father indeed died. He states he learned this in Marseilles but couldn't get details due to the time elapsed.
The abbé, trying to appear indifferent, asks Caderousse if he can provide more information about the elder Dantès's end.
Caderousse asserts his ability to provide details, having lived near the old man, and confirms his death occurred about a year after his son's disappearance.
When the abbé inquires about the cause of death, Caderousse mentions that doctors called it gastro-enteritis and acquaintances attributed it to grief.
After a dramatic pause, Caderousse reveals his own belief, as someone who saw the old man in his dying moments: he died of
he says, before being prompted by the priest,
of downright starvation.”

The abbé springs from his seat in horror, exclaiming that such a death is worse than that suffered by the vilest animals and that it is impossible for a Christian to perish of hunger amidst fellow Christians.
Caderousse simply states, “What I have said, I have said.”
Suddenly, a voice from the top of the stairs, belonging to La Carconte, interjects, calling Caderousse a fool for meddling and questioning why he involves himself in matters not concerning him.
La Carconte, sickly and peering between the balusters, had feebly descended the stairs, attracted by the voices, and had been listening to the conversation.
Caderousse sharply tells his wife to mind her own business, stating that common politeness requires him to answer the gentleman's questions.
La Carconte scoffs at his notion of politeness, advocating for common prudence and questioning the stranger's motives for extracting information.
The abbé assures La Carconte that his intentions are good and that her husband risks nothing by answering candidly.
She remains skeptical, warning that fair promises are often forgotten once information is divulged, leading to unforeseen trouble and misery for those who speak too freely.
The abbé solemnly promises that whatever evils may befall them, they will not be caused by his instrumentality.

La Carconte mutters inarticulately, lets her head drop to her knees, and succumbs to a fit of ague, though remaining within earshot. The abbé, visibly shaken by the revelations and confrontation, drinks more water to compose himself.

events.text_segment:
“Too true, too true!” ejaculated Caderousse, almost suffocated by the contending passions which assailed him, “the poor old man did die.”
“I learned so much at Marseilles,” replied the abbé, making a strong effort to appear indifferent; “but from the length of time that has elapsed since the death of the elder Dantès, I was unable to obtain any particulars of his end. Can you enlighten me on that point?”
“I do not know who could if I could not,” said Caderousse. “Why, I lived almost on the same floor with the poor old man. Ah, yes, about a year after the disappearance of his son the poor old man died.”
“Of what did he die?”
“Why, the doctors called his complaint gastro-enteritis, I believe; his acquaintances say he died of grief; but I, who saw him in his dying moments, I say he died of——”
Caderousse paused.
“Of what?” asked the priest, anxiously and eagerly.
“Why, of downright starvation.”
“Starvation!” exclaimed the abbé, springing from his seat. “Why, the vilest animals are not suffered to die by such a death as that. The very dogs that wander houseless and homeless in the streets find some pitying hand to cast them a mouthful of bread; and that a man, a Christian, should be allowed to perish of hunger in the midst of other men who call themselves Christians, is too horrible for belief. Oh, it is impossible!—utterly impossible!”
“What I have said, I have said,” answered Caderousse.
“And you are a fool for having said anything about it,” said a voice from the top of the stairs. “Why should you meddle with what does not concern you?”
The two men turned quickly, and saw the sickly countenance of La Carconte peering between the baluster rails; attracted by the sound of voices, she had feebly dragged herself down the stairs, and, seated on the lower step, head on knees, she had listened to the foregoing conversation.
“Mind your own business, wife,” replied Caderousse sharply. “This gentleman asks me for information, which common politeness will not permit me to refuse.”
“Politeness, you simpleton!” retorted La Carconte. “What have you to do with politeness, I should like to know? Better study a little common prudence. How do you know the motives that person may have for trying to extract all he can from you?”
“I pledge you my word, madam,” said the abbé, “that my intentions are good; and that your husband can incur no risk, provided he answers me candidly.”
“Ah, that’s all very fine,” retorted the woman. “Nothing is easier than to begin with fair promises and assurances of nothing to fear; but when poor, silly folks, like my husband there, have been persuaded to tell all they know, the promises and assurances of safety are quickly forgotten; and at some moment when nobody is expecting it, behold trouble and misery, and all sorts of persecutions, are heaped on the unfortunate wretches, who cannot even see whence all their afflictions come.”
“Nay, nay, my good woman, make yourself perfectly easy, I beg of you. Whatever evils may befall you, they will not be occasioned by my instrumentality, that I solemnly promise you.”
La Carconte muttered a few inarticulate words, then let her head again drop upon her knees, and went into a fit of ague, leaving the two speakers to resume the conversation, but remaining so as to be able to hear every word they uttered. Again the abbé had been obliged to swallow a draught of water to calm the emotions that threatened to overpower him.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“Too true, too true!” ejaculated Caderousse, almost suffocated by the contending passions which assailed him, “the poor old man did die.”
“I heard so,” replied the abbé; “and I was even told that he died of grief.”
“That is true, monsieur, and yet it is not the whole truth.”
“Not the whole truth, monsieur?”
“No; the whole truth is, that he died—of hunger.”
“Of hunger?” cried the abbé, springing from his seat. “Why, the vilest animals are not suffered to die of hunger. The very dogs that wander houseless and homeless in the streets find some one to cast them a morsel of bread, and your father, a man well known, well liked, and respected, died of hunger in the midst of a Christian city! Impossible! impossible!”
“What I have said, I have said,” replied Caderousse, dogmatically.
“And you said right, Caderousse,” said a voice from the top of the stairs. “He did die of hunger.”
The two men turned, and saw the sickly, cadaverous face of La Carconte peering between the balusters; attracted by the sound of voices, she had feebly descended the stairs, and, unperceived, had been listening to the conversation.
“Why do you meddle with what does not concern you?” said Caderousse to his wife; “come down, and do the honours of the house, or go to bed.”
“Let her stay,” said the abbé; “my conversation is with you, and does not regard madame.”
“But it does regard me,” said La Carconte; “for since you question him about the dead, why should you not question him about the living? And since he has told you that Edmond’s father died of hunger, tell him that his wife was near dying of hunger too.”
“Silence, La Carconte! silence!” said Caderousse; “monsieur does not come here to listen to all our complaints. And besides, it will do no good.”
“That is as it may be,” said La Carconte; “but I know that I, for my part, have not seen a sou of the money, and that I have suffered enough to be dead ten times over.”
“Do you hear?” said Caderousse; “do you hear the woman? She is always like that when she has the ague. It is a fever that carries off everything.”
“It is not the ague,” said La Carconte; “it is the truth. And if he has told you that Edmond’s father died of hunger, tell him also that Edmond’s father was abandoned by everybody, and that you, Caderousse, you, who were his neighbour, and who knew him well, you let him die like a dog, without giving him a crust of bread, or a glass of water, or a word of comfort! Ah, you may well turn away your head, and blush for shame!”
“Hold your tongue, I tell you!” cried Caderousse; “or I will make you hold your tongue!”
“No, no,” said La Carconte; “you cannot make me hold my tongue. I have suffered too much. I have seen too much. I have heard too much. And I will speak. I will tell him that you were all false friends, all traitors, all cowards! I will tell him that you were all afraid of the police, and that you left the poor old man to die alone, in his misery, in his despair, in his hunger!”
“Silence, I say!” repeated Caderousse, raising his hand.
“No, no,” said La Carconte, with a wild laugh; “you cannot silence me. I am not afraid of you. I am not afraid of the police. I am not afraid of anything. I am only afraid of God, and I know that God will punish you for your wickedness!”
And with these words, she fell back, exhausted, on the stairs, and remained there, groaning and trembling.
“You see,” said Caderousse, “she is mad. It is the fever.”
“No,” said the abbé, who had listened to this scene with profound emotion; “she is not mad, she is only unhappy.”
And, turning to Caderousse, he said, “You have heard what your wife has said. Is it true?”
“It is true,” said Caderousse, in a low voice; “it is true that I was a coward, and that I abandoned the poor old man. But I was afraid. I was afraid of the police. I was afraid of being arrested.”
“And you were not afraid of letting a man die of hunger?”
“I was afraid of everything,” said Caderousse; “I was afraid of myself.”
He paused for a moment, and then added, “But it is not my fault. It is the fault of fate.”
“No, Caderousse,” said the abbé, “it is not the fault of fate, it is the fault of men. And you are one of those men.”
Caderousse bowed his head, and did not reply.
“And now,” said the abbé, “tell me, what became of the money that Edmond had left with his father?”
“The money?” said Caderousse, raising his head; “there was no money.”

“Too true, too true!” ejaculated Caderousse, almost suffocated by the contending passions which assailed him, “the poor old man did die.” He wiped his brow with a trembling hand, his eyes darting nervously around the small room, as if seeking an escape from the piercing gaze of the Abbé Busoni. “He died,” Caderousse repeated, his voice hoarse, “of grief, they said. And… and hunger.”

“Hunger?” the Abbé’s voice was low, devoid of emotion, yet it seemed to vibrate with an intensity that made Caderousse flinch. “A man dies of hunger in the heart of Marseille? A man whose son had just been promised a fortune, a captaincy, a life of ease?”

“Ah, but that was the cruelest part, wasn’t it?” Caderousse burst out, a bitter, self-pitying laugh escaping him. “The old man waited. He waited for Edmond to come back, to bring him the happiness he’d promised. But Edmond never came. And the old man… he just faded away. He wouldn’t eat. He said he couldn’t swallow when his boy was in trouble. He just sat there, day after day, in that little room, his eyes fixed on the door, hoping.”

“And you, Caderousse?” the Abbé prompted, his gaze unwavering. “You were his neighbour. You saw his suffering. Did you offer him bread? Did you offer him comfort?”

Caderousse squirmed. “I… I was poor myself, Abbé. Things were hard. And… and Danglars, he said it was no business of ours. He said Dantès was a Bonapartist, a traitor, and his father would get what he deserved.” He paused, a flicker of genuine shame crossing his face before being replaced by a defensive scowl. “Besides, the old man was proud. He wouldn’t take charity easily.”

“Charity?” The Abbé’s tone sharpened slightly. “Was it charity to help the father of a man who had shared his last coin with you? A man who had considered you a friend?”

Caderousse’s face paled. “He… he did leave some money, didn’t he? Before he sailed on the Pharaon. A few louis, for his father.”

“Precisely,” said the Abbé. “A sum intended to keep the old man comfortable until his return. What became of that money, Caderousse?”

Caderousse hesitated, licking his dry lips. The memory was clearly painful, not from remorse, but from the fear of consequences. “It… it was there. In a little purse. The old man kept it. But he wouldn’t touch it. He said it was Edmond’s money, and he was saving it for him.”

“So, the money was there, and the man died of hunger?” the Abbé’s voice was dangerously quiet. “And you, his neighbour, knowing of the money, knowing of his need, did nothing?”

“What could I do?” Caderousse whined. “He wouldn’t eat! He just wasted away. And after he died… well, the landlord took some of the money for the rent he was owed. And the rest… it just disappeared. Things get lost, you know, in times like that.”

events.title: Unveiling Treachery: Caderousse Hesitates, The Abbé Dangles the Bait
characters: Abbé Faria (disguised, referred to as 'the abbé')
detailed_summary: After composing himself, the abbé suggests that the elder Dantès must have been forsaken by everyone to have perished so dreadfully.

Caderousse clarifies that Mercédès the Catalan and Monsieur Morrel were kind to him, but the old man had developed a profound hatred for Fernand—the very person the abbé had named as one of Dantès's faithful friends.
La Carconte, from her seat on the stairs, murmurs a warning to her husband to mind what he is saying.

Ignoring her, though annoyed, Caderousse questions Fernand's faithfulness, implying treachery related to Dantès's wife, and states Dantès was too honorable and trusting, cruelly deceived. He adds he fears the malediction of the dead more than the hatred of the living.
La Carconte exclaims, “Imbecile!”
The abbé then directly asks Caderousse if he knows how Fernand injured Dantès. Caderousse claims no one knows better.
When the abbé urges him to speak, La Carconte cries out, telling Gaspard he is master but advising him to hold his tongue. Caderousse momentarily concedes his wife might be right.

The abbé asks if he will therefore say nothing. Caderousse questions the utility of revealing the truth, since Dantès is dead and beyond feelings of hatred or revenge, suggesting such matters be buried with him.
The abbé subtly challenges this, asking if Caderousse prefers that he bestow the reward intended for faithful friendship upon men Caderousse himself deems false and treacherous.

Caderousse acknowledges the truth in this, agreeing that Edmond's gift was not meant for traitors like Fernand and Danglars, and adds that such a sum would mean little to them anyway given their current wealth.
La Carconte chimes in, reminding her husband that those two men could crush him at a single blow.
The abbé feigns ignorance of their power and history, inviting Caderousse to relate it. After a moment's reflection, Caderousse declines, saying it would take too much time.

The abbé, with an air of utter indifference, states Caderousse is free to speak or be silent and that he respects his scruples. He declares his intention to proceed with his duty and dispose of the diamond.
As he says this, the abbé again draws out the small box, opens it, and skillfully holds the diamond so that its brilliant flash catches Caderousse's dazzled gaze.

events.text_segment:
When he had sufficiently recovered himself, he said, “It appears, then, that the miserable old man you were telling me of was forsaken by everyone. Surely, had not such been the case, he would not have perished by so dreadful a death.”
“Why, he was not altogether forsaken,” continued Caderousse, “for Mercédès the Catalan and Monsieur Morrel were very kind to him; but somehow the poor old man had contracted a profound hatred for Fernand—the very person,” added Caderousse with a bitter smile, “that you named just now as being one of Dantès’ faithful and attached friends.”
“And was he not so?” asked the abbé.
“Gaspard, Gaspard!” murmured the woman, from her seat on the stairs, “mind what you are saying!”
Caderousse made no reply to these words, though evidently irritated and annoyed by the interruption, but, addressing the abbé, said, “Can a man be faithful to another whose wife he covets and desires for himself? But Dantès was so honorable and true in his own nature, that he believed everybody’s professions of friendship. Poor Edmond, he was cruelly deceived; but it was fortunate that he never knew, or he might have found it more difficult, when on his deathbed, to pardon his enemies. And, whatever people may say,” continued Caderousse, in his native language, which was not altogether devoid of rude poetry, “I cannot help being more frightened at the idea of the malediction of the dead than the hatred of the living.”
“Imbecile!” exclaimed La Carconte.
“Do you, then, know in what manner Fernand injured Dantès?” inquired the abbé of Caderousse.
“Do I? No one better.”
“Speak out then, say what it was!”
“Gaspard!” cried La Carconte, “do as you will; you are master—but if you take my advice you’ll hold your tongue.”
“Well, wife,” replied Caderousse, “I don’t know but what you’re right!”
“So you will say nothing?” asked the abbé.
“Why, what good would it do?” asked Caderousse. “If the poor lad were living, and came to me and begged that I would candidly tell which were his true and which his false friends, why, perhaps, I should not hesitate. But you tell me he is no more, and therefore can have nothing to do with hatred or revenge, so let all such feeling be buried with him.”
“You prefer, then,” said the abbé, “that I should bestow on men you say are false and treacherous, the reward intended for faithful friendship?”
“That is true enough,” returned Caderousse. “You say truly, the gift of poor Edmond was not meant for such traitors as Fernand and Danglars; besides, what would it be to them? no more than a drop of water in the ocean.”
“Remember,” chimed in La Carconte, “those two could crush you at a single blow!”
“How so?” inquired the abbé. “Are these persons, then, so rich and powerful?”
“Do you not know their history?”
“I do not. Pray relate it to me!”
Caderousse seemed to reflect for a few moments, then said, “No, truly, it would take up too much time.”
“Well, my good friend,” returned the abbé, in a tone that indicated utter indifference on his part, “you are at liberty, either to speak or be silent, just as you please; for my own part, I respect your scruples and admire your sentiments; so let the matter end. I shall do my duty as conscientiously as I can, and fulfil my promise to the dying man. My first business will be to dispose of this diamond.”
So saying, the abbé again drew the small box from his pocket, opened it, and contrived to hold it in such a light, that a bright flash of brilliant hues passed before the dazzled gaze of Caderousse.

events.title: Temptation's Triumph: Caderousse Decides to Reveal All
characters: Abbé Faria (disguised, referred to as 'the abbé')
detailed_summary: Visibly tempted by the re-displayed diamond, Caderousse hoarsely calls his wife to come downstairs.

La Carconte descends with a relatively firm step, asking about the diamond. Caderousse explains it's a beautiful jewel left by Edmond Dantès, to be sold and the money divided among his father, Mercédès, Fernand, Danglars, and himself, worth at least fifty thousand francs.
The woman exclaims at the magnificent jewel. Caderousse then asks if a fifth of the profits belongs to them.

The abbé confirms this, adding that they would also receive an equal division of the elder Dantès's share, as he feels at liberty to divide it among the four survivors, assuming they are the friends Edmond esteemed most faithful.

La Carconte murmurs that she doesn't consider those who betray and ruin you as friends. Caderousse quickly agrees, stating he had just observed to the gentleman that it's sacrilegious to reward treachery, perhaps crime.

The abbé calmly replaces the jewel in his pocket, stating it is Caderousse's fault, not his, if he proceeds without full information. He then asks for the addresses of Fernand and Danglars to execute Edmond's wishes.
Caderousse becomes extremely agitated. As the abbé rises and moves towards the door, as if to check on his horse, Caderousse and his wife exchange looks of deep meaning.
Caderousse tells his wife that the splendid diamond might all be theirs if they chose. When she questions if he believes it, he asserts that a man of holy profession wouldn't deceive them.

La Carconte replies for him to do as he likes, stating she washes her hands of the affair. She climbs the stairs to her chamber, body convulsed with chills despite the heat, and from the top stair, warns her husband to consider well what he is about to do.
Caderousse replies that he has both reflected and decided. La Carconte enters her chamber.
The abbé returns and asks Caderousse what he has decided. Caderousse replies, “To tell you all I know.”
The priest commends his decision, not for his own desire to learn, but so the legacy might be distributed according to the testator's wishes.
Caderousse, his face flushed with cupidity, hopes it may be so. He asks for a moment, stating they might be interrupted and that the visit should remain secret.
He stealthily closes and bolts the door. During this, the abbé chooses a seat in a shadowed corner, ensuring the light falls on Caderousse.
La Carconte's trembling voice is heard from upstairs, as if witnessing the scene, saying, “Remember, this is no affair of mine.”
Caderousse dismisses her, stating he will take all consequences upon himself, and then begins his story.

events.text_segment:
“Wife, wife!” cried he in a hoarse voice, “come here!”
“Diamond!” exclaimed La Carconte, rising and descending to the chamber with a tolerably firm step; “what diamond are you talking about?”
“Why, did you not hear all we said?” inquired Caderousse. “It is a beautiful diamond left by poor Edmond Dantès, to be sold, and the money divided between his father, Mercédès, his betrothed bride, Fernand, Danglars, and myself. The jewel is worth at least fifty thousand francs.”
“Oh, what a magnificent jewel!” cried the astonished woman.
“The fifth part of the profits from this stone belongs to us then, does it not?” asked Caderousse.
“It does,” replied the abbé; “with the addition of an equal division of that part intended for the elder Dantès, which I believe myself at liberty to divide equally with the four survivors.”
“And why among us four?” inquired Caderousse.
“As being the friends Edmond esteemed most faithful and devoted to him.”
“I don’t call those friends who betray and ruin you,” murmured the wife in her turn, in a low, muttering voice.
“Of course not!” rejoined Caderousse quickly; “no more do I, and that was what I was observing to this gentleman just now. I said I looked upon it as a sacrilegious profanation to reward treachery, perhaps crime.”
“Remember,” answered the abbé calmly, as he replaced the jewel and its case in the pocket of his cassock, “it is your fault, not mine, that I do so. You will have the goodness to furnish me with the address of both Fernand and Danglars, in order that I may execute Edmond’s last wishes.”
The agitation of Caderousse became extreme, and large drops of perspiration rolled from his heated brow. As he saw the abbé rise from his seat and go towards the door, as though to ascertain if his horse were sufficiently refreshed to continue his journey, Caderousse and his wife exchanged looks of deep meaning.
“There, you see, wife,” said the former, “this splendid diamond might all be ours, if we chose!”
“Do you believe it?”
“Why, surely a man of his holy profession would not deceive us!”
“Well,” replied La Carconte, “do as you like. For my part, I wash my hands of the affair.”
So saying, she once more climbed the staircase leading to her chamber, her body convulsed with chills, and her teeth rattling in her head, in spite of the intense heat of the weather. Arrived at the top stair, she turned round, and called out, in a warning tone, to her husband, “Gaspard, consider well what you are about to do!”
“I have both reflected and decided,” answered he.
La Carconte then entered her chamber, the flooring of which creaked beneath her heavy, uncertain tread, as she proceeded towards her armchair, into which she fell as though exhausted.
“Well,” asked the abbé, as he returned to the apartment below, “what have you made up your mind to do?”
“To tell you all I know,” was the reply.
“I certainly think you act wisely in so doing,” said the priest. “Not because I have the least desire to learn anything you may please to conceal from me, but simply that if, through your assistance, I could distribute the legacy according to the wishes of the testator, why, so much the better, that is all.”
“I hope it may be so,” replied Caderousse, his face flushed with cupidity.
“I am all attention,” said the abbé.
“Stop a minute,” answered Caderousse; “we might be interrupted in the most interesting part of my story, which would be a pity; and it is as well that your visit hither should be made known only to ourselves.”
With these words he went stealthily to the door, which he closed, and, by way of still greater precaution, bolted and barred it, as he was accustomed to do at night.
During this time the abbé had chosen his place for listening at his ease. He removed his seat into a corner of the room, where he himself would be in deep shadow, while the light would be fully thrown on the narrator; then, with head bent down and hands clasped, or rather clenched together, he prepared to give his whole attention to Caderousse, who seated himself on the little stool, exactly opposite to him.
“Remember, this is no affair of mine,” said the trembling voice of La Carconte, as though through the flooring of her chamber she viewed the scene that was enacting below.
“Enough, enough!” replied Caderousse; “say no more about it; I will take all the consequences upon myself.”
And he began his story.

“Wife, wife!” cried he in a hoarse voice, “come here!”
La Carconte, who, attracted by the sight of the diamond, had followed the abbé with her eyes, and had been standing on the first step of the stairs, descended with a tolerably firm step, and came towards her husband.
“What do you want, Caderousse?” asked she.
“Come here,” said Caderousse; “look!”
The woman looked in the direction indicated, and saw the diamond which the abbé had just replaced in his pocket.
“The diamond!” exclaimed she; “how magnificent it is!”
“I was going to tell you,” said Caderousse; “it is a beautiful jewel, left with me by Edmond Dantès.”
“By Edmond Dantès!” repeated La Carconte; “he is dead, then, is he not?”
“I believe so,” replied Caderousse; “it is, at least, a year since this gentleman came to me, and said, ‘Edmond Dantès is dead, and before he died he charged me to sell this diamond, and divide the money amongst his father, Mercédès, Fernand, Danglars, and myself. The diamond is worth fifty thousand francs.’”
“Fifty thousand francs!” exclaimed La Carconte; “why, it is a fortune, Caderousse!”
“A fifth part of the profits belongs to us, then?” asked Caderousse, his face flushed with cupidity.
“Yes,” said the abbé; “and, as I was going to observe to you, with the fifth part of the sum arising from the sale of the jewel, you may contrive to make a little fortune, in addition to the two hundred francs I was going to give you.”
“Ah, sir,” said Caderousse, with an air of dissatisfaction, “we are very unfortunate.”
“Unfortunate, why so?” asked the abbé.
“Because he has not left us the whole, since he knew we were the most necessitous.”
“And because he has left the others anything at all,” said La Carconte, speaking in a hoarse voice, and with a constrained smile.
“Who are the others?” asked La Carconte.
“His father, Mercédès, Fernand, and Danglars.”
“His father is dead,” said La Carconte; “so that you would have had his share.”
“That is not certain,” replied Caderousse; “the gentleman said he was to divide it amongst us four.”
“He said amongst the five,” returned La Carconte.
“Yes, but as the father is dead, it will be divided amongst the four survivors.”
“You see, then, that your share is increased,” said the abbé; “and it is so much the better, as this will be an encouragement for you to relate to me the details I have asked for, as to the lives of these four persons since the disappearance of Edmond Dantès.”
“Of these four persons!” cried Caderousse, in a tone of still greater cupidity.
“Certainly, for the testator, having informed me of his desire to distribute this part of his effects amongst the four persons who had been his most faithful friends, it is my duty to ascertain if his wishes have been complied with; and it is for that reason I address myself to you, who have been his neighbour, and one of his most intimate companions.”
“And who have never injured him,” added Caderousse, hastily.
“And who did not betray him,” said La Carconte, with a gloomy air.
“That is what I was going to say, my dear Carconte,” returned Caderousse; “and I have made that remark to the gentleman, who can tell you the same thing. I said to him, ‘Depend upon it, sir, Edmond had no friends but his father, Mercédès, and myself, and I may add, that he ought to have remembered us before anyone else.’”
“And why,” asked the abbé, without changing his voice, “did he charge me to divide this property amongst Fernand and Danglars also?”
“Because he was deceived by the false protestations of friendship of those two hypocrites, who have both gained largely by his arrest, and still more by his disappearance.”
“Indeed!” said the abbé; “explain that to me, for I am ignorant of the whole affair.”
“Ah, sir,” said Caderousse, “if M. Dantès had confided in me as he did in you, he would not have been where he is;

“I was going to tell you,” said Caderousse; “it is a beautiful jewel, left with me by Edmond Dantès.”
“By Edmond Dantès!” repeated La Carconte; “he is dead, then, is he not?”
“I believe so,” replied Caderousse; “it is, at least, a year since this gentleman came to me, and said, ‘Edmond Dantès is dead, and before he died he charged me to sell this diamond, and divide the money amongst his father, Mercédès, Fernand, Danglars, and myself. The diamond is worth fifty thousand francs.’”
“Fifty thousand francs!” exclaimed La Carconte; “why, it is a fortune, Caderousse!”
“A fifth part of the profits belongs to us, then?” asked Caderousse, his face flushed with cupidity.
“Yes,” said the abbé; “and, as I was going to observe to you, with the fifth part of the sum arising from the sale of the jewel, you may contrive to make a little fortune, in addition to the two hundred francs I was going to give you.”
“Ah, sir,” said Caderousse, with an air of dissatisfaction, “we are very unfortunate.”
“Unfortunate, why so?” asked the abbé.
“Because he has not left us the whole, since he knew we were the most necessitous.”
“And because he has left the others anything at all,” said La Carconte, speaking in a hoarse voice, and with a constrained smile.
“Who are the others?” asked La Carconte.
“His father, Mercédès, Fernand, and Danglars.”
“His father is dead,” said La Carconte; “so that you would have had his share.”
“That is not certain,” replied Caderousse; “the gentleman said he was to divide it amongst us four.”
“He said amongst the five,” returned La Carconte.
“Yes, but as the father is dead, it will be divided amongst the four survivors.”
“You see, then, that your share is increased,” said the abbé; “and it is so much the better, as this will be an encouragement for you to relate to me the details I have asked for, as to the lives of these four persons since the disappearance of Edmond Dantès.”
“Of these four persons!” cried Caderousse, in a tone of still greater cupidity.
“Certainly, for the testator, having informed me of his desire to distribute this part of his effects amongst the four persons who had been his most faithful friends, it is my duty to ascertain if his wishes have been complied with; and it is for that reason I address myself to you, who have been his neighbour, and one of his most intimate companions.”
“And who have never injured him,” added Caderousse, hastily.
“And who did not betray him,” said La Carconte, with a gloomy air.
“That is what I was going to say, my dear Carconte,” returned Caderousse; “and I have made that remark to the gentleman, who can tell you the same thing. I said to him, ‘Depend upon it, sir, Edmond had no friends but his father, Mercédès, and myself, and I may add, that he ought to have remembered us before anyone else.’”
“And why,” asked the abbé, without changing his voice, “did he charge me to divide this property amongst Fernand and Danglars also?”
“Because he was deceived by the false protestations of friendship of those two hypocrites, who have both gained largely by his arrest, and still more by his disappearance.”
“Indeed!” said the abbé; “explain that to me, for I am ignorant of the whole affair.”
“Ah, sir,” said Caderousse, “if M. Dantès had confided in me as he did in you, he would not have been where he is;

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“Wife, wife!” cried he in a hoarse voice, “come here!”

Madame Danglars, who had been reclining on a sofa in the adjoining drawing-room, engaged in the perusal of a fashionable novel, rose with a sigh of impatience. Her husband’s voice, usually so resonant with authority or smooth with calculation, was now fractured, raw, and edged with a terror she had rarely heard, even in the most volatile moments of their shared financial ventures. She smoothed her dress, adjusted a stray curl, and entered the study, a room that had always seemed to her the very heart of his power, lined with ledgers and strongboxes, smelling faintly of paper and success.

But the room was not as she remembered it. Papers were scattered across the floor, not in neat piles, but as if thrown in a fit of madness. The large oak desk was a chaos of overturned inkwells, crumpled documents, and a single, half-empty decanter. And her husband… Danglars, the Baron Danglars, the man who had built an empire on numbers and nerve, stood by the window, his back to her, his shoulders slumped, his hands clenched into fists that trembled visibly. His usually immaculate attire was dishevelled, his face, when he finally turned, was a mask of grey, drawn skin, wild eyes, and a mouth twisted in a silent scream.

“What is it, Baron?” she asked, her voice cool, though a prickle of unease began to crawl up her spine. “You sound… unwell.”

He laughed, a sound devoid of mirth, a dry, rattling cough. “Unwell? Oh, I am perfectly well, Madame. Never better! I am merely… ruined.”

He spat the word out as if it were poison. Ruined. The word hung in the air, heavy and suffocating. Madame Danglars felt the blood drain from her face. Ruined? Danglars? The richest banker in Paris? It was impossible.

“What nonsense is this?” she demanded, stepping closer, trying to see the ledgers, the papers that told this impossible tale. “Explain yourself!”

“Explain?” He turned fully now, gesturing wildly at the room, at the scattered papers. “It is all here! The explanation! The Spanish funds… vanished! Cavalcanti… a fraud, his millions a phantom! The investments I made… worthless! Every venture I touched in the last month… turned to dust! There was a run on the bank today, Madame! A run! And there was nothing… nothing to meet it!”

His voice rose to a frantic pitch. “Millions! Gone! Vanished into thin air! My fortune, your fortune, the fortunes of half of Paris entrusted to me… all gone!” He stumbled towards his desk, sweeping more papers onto the floor. “Look! These are the accounts! Lies! All lies! The figures don’t add up! They never did! Someone… someone has been manipulating everything!”

Madame Danglars stared at him, her mind reeling. Ruined. Not just a setback, not a temporary difficulty, but utter, complete ruin. The luxurious life she had built, the social standing she had fought for, the independence her own financial dealings had afforded her… all built on the foundation of his wealth, which was now crumbling into dust.

“But… how?” she whispered, her voice barely audible. “How could this happen? You are the Baron Danglars! You control everything!”

“I controlled nothing!” he roared, his despair turning to fury

events.title: Caderousse's Condition for Revealing the Truth
detailed_summary: Caderousse insists that the Abbé must promise never to reveal him as the source of the information he is about to share.
He explains his fear, stating that the individuals involved are rich and powerful and could easily destroy him.
The Abbé provides reassurance, citing his role as a priest to whom confessions are sacred, his Italian nationality, his devotion to God rather than men, and his imminent return to his convent.
He emphasizes that their shared goal is to honor the last wishes of their deceased friend, Edmond Dantès.
This assurance appears to bolster Caderousse's courage to speak.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: First, sir,” said Caderousse, “you must make me a promise.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: This positive assurance seemed to give Caderousse a little courage.

events.text_segment:
First, sir,” said Caderousse, “you must make me a promise.”
“What is that?” inquired the abbé.
“Why, if you ever make use of the details I am about to give you, that you will never let anyone know that it was I who supplied them; for the persons of whom I am about to talk are rich and powerful, and if they only laid the tips of their fingers on me, I should break to pieces like glass.”
“Make yourself easy, my friend,” replied the abbé. “I am a priest, and confessions die in my breast. Recollect, our only desire is to carry out, in a fitting manner, the last wishes of our friend. Speak, then, without reserve, as without hatred; tell the truth, the whole truth; I do not know, never may know, the persons of whom you are about to speak; besides, I am an Italian, and not a Frenchman, and belong to God, and not to man, and I shall shortly retire to my convent, which I have only quitted to fulfil the last wishes of a dying man.”
This positive assurance seemed to give Caderousse a little courage.

events.title: The Tragic Decline and Death of Old Dantès
detailed_summary: Caderousse agrees to disclose the truth about Edmond's supposed friends, beginning with Edmond's father, whom Edmond loved deeply.
He recounts how, after Edmond's arrest during his betrothal feast at La Réserve, Monsieur Morrel sought details while old Dantès returned home alone, heartbroken.
Old Dantès tearfully packed away his wedding suit and paced his room all night, his grief deeply unsettling Caderousse, who lived below and heard his every step.
The following day, Mercédès unsuccessfully sought help from M. de Villefort and then visited old Dantès, finding him sleepless and without food.
She urged him to come live with her so she could care for him, but he refused, insisting he must remain in his house for Edmond's return, as his son loved him above all else.
Caderousse overheard this exchange, having wished Mercédès would succeed, as the old man's constant footsteps gave him no rest.
Caderousse admits he rarely tried to console old Dantès, who seemed to dislike his presence.

One night, however, hearing the old man's sobs, Caderousse felt compelled to go to him, but found him praying with such eloquence and fervor that Caderousse, despite his own irreligious nature, was profoundly moved and reflected on the unbearable depth of a father's grief.
Old Dantès became increasingly solitary, closing his door even to M. Morrel and Mercédès, convinced Edmond was dead and awaiting him.
As people stopped visiting, Caderousse observed strangers leaving old Dantès's apartment with bundles, realizing he was selling his possessions to survive.
Eventually, destitute and owing three quarters' rent, old Dantès was granted a final week before eviction.
After three days of hearing him walk, Caderousse heard silence on the fourth day and, looking through the keyhole, saw old Dantès pale and ill.

He alerted M. Morrel and Mercédès; Morrel brought a doctor who diagnosed an intestinal inflammation and prescribed a limited diet, a prescription the old man seemed to accept with a faint smile, as it provided an excuse not to eat.
Mercédès, alarmed by his deterioration, wished to move him to her home, a desire shared by M. Morrel, but the old man resisted so vehemently they relented.
Mercédès stayed by his bedside, while M. Morrel left his purse on the chimney-piece before departing.

Adhering to the doctor's orders (or using them as a pretext), old Dantès refused all sustenance and, after nine days of despair and fasting, died, cursing those who caused his misery and asking Mercédès to tell Edmond, if she ever saw him again, that he died blessing him.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘If you ever see my Edmond again, tell him I die blessing him.’”

events.text_segment:
“Well, then, under these circumstances,” said Caderousse, “I will, I even believe I ought to undeceive you as to the friendship which poor Edmond thought so sincere and unquestionable.”
“Begin with his father, if you please.” said the abbé; “Edmond talked to me a great deal about the old man for whom he had the deepest love.”
“The history is a sad one, sir,” said Caderousse, shaking his head; “perhaps you know all the earlier part of it?”
“Yes.” answered the abbé; “Edmond related to me everything until the moment when he was arrested in a small cabaret close to Marseilles.”
“At La Réserve! Oh, yes; I can see it all before me this moment.”
“Was it not his betrothal feast?”
“It was and the feast that began so gayly had a very sorrowful ending; a police commissary, followed by four soldiers, entered, and Dantès was arrested.”
“Yes, and up to this point I know all,” said the priest. “Dantès himself only knew that which personally concerned him, for he never beheld again the five persons I have named to you, or heard mention of anyone of them.”
“Well, when Dantès was arrested, Monsieur Morrel hastened to obtain the particulars, and they were very sad. The old man returned alone to his home, folded up his wedding suit with tears in his eyes, and paced up and down his chamber the whole day, and would not go to bed at all, for I was underneath him and heard him walking the whole night; and for myself, I assure you I could not sleep either, for the grief of the poor father gave me great uneasiness, and every step he took went to my heart as really as if his foot had pressed against my breast.
“The next day Mercédès came to implore the protection of M. de Villefort; she did not obtain it, however, and went to visit the old man; when she saw him so miserable and heart-broken, having passed a sleepless night, and not touched food since the previous day, she wished him to go with her that she might take care of him; but the old man would not consent. ‘No,’ was the old man’s reply, ‘I will not leave this house, for my poor dear boy loves me better than anything in the world; and if he gets out of prison he will come and see me the first thing, and what would he think if I did not wait here for him?’ I heard all this from the window, for I was anxious that Mercédès should persuade the old man to accompany her, for his footsteps over my head night and day did not leave me a moment’s repose.”
“But did you not go upstairs and try to console the poor old man?” asked the abbé.
“Ah, sir,” replied Caderousse, “we cannot console those who will not be consoled, and he was one of these; besides, I know not why, but he seemed to dislike seeing me. One night, however, I heard his sobs, and I could not resist my desire to go up to him, but when I reached his door he was no longer weeping but praying. I cannot now repeat to you, sir, all the eloquent words and imploring language he made use of; it was more than piety, it was more than grief, and I, who am no canter, and hate the Jesuits, said then to myself, ‘It is really well, and I am very glad that I have not any children; for if I were a father and felt such excessive grief as the old man does, and did not find in my memory or heart all he is now saying, I should throw myself into the sea at once, for I could not bear it.’”
“Poor father!” murmured the priest.
“From day to day he lived on alone, and more and more solitary. M. Morrel and Mercédès came to see him, but his door was closed; and, although I was certain he was at home, he would not make any answer. One day, when, contrary to his custom, he had admitted Mercédès, and the poor girl, in spite of her own grief and despair, endeavored to console him, he said to her,—‘Be assured, my dear daughter, he is dead; and instead of expecting him, it is he who is awaiting us; I am quite happy, for I am the oldest, and of course shall see him first.’
“However well disposed a person may be, why, you see we leave off after a time seeing persons who are in sorrow, they make one melancholy; and so at last old Dantès was left all to himself, and I only saw from time to time strangers go up to him and come down again with some bundle they tried to hide; but I guessed what these bundles were, and that he sold by degrees what he had to pay for his subsistence. At length the poor old fellow reached the end of all he had; he owed three quarters’ rent, and they threatened to turn him out; he begged for another week, which was granted to him. I know this, because the landlord came into my apartment when he left his.
“For the first three days I heard him walking about as usual, but, on the fourth I heard nothing. I then resolved to go up to him at all risks. The door was closed, but I looked through the keyhole, and saw him so pale and haggard, that believing him very ill, I went and told M. Morrel and then ran on to Mercédès. They both came immediately, M. Morrel bringing a doctor, and the doctor said it was inflammation of the bowels, and ordered him a limited diet. I was there, too, and I never shall forget the old man’s smile at this prescription.
“From that time he received all who came; he had an excuse for not eating any more; the doctor had put him on a diet.”
The abbé uttered a kind of groan.
“The story interests you, does it not, sir?” inquired Caderousse.
“Yes,” replied the abbé, “it is very affecting.”
“Mercédès came again, and she found him so altered that she was even more anxious than before to have him taken to her own home. This was M. Morrel’s wish also, who would fain have conveyed the old man against his consent; but the old man resisted, and cried so that they were actually frightened. Mercédès remained, therefore, by his bedside, and M. Morrel went away, making a sign to the Catalan that he had left his purse on the chimney-piece; but, availing himself of the doctor’s order, the old man would not take any sustenance; at length (after nine days of despair and fasting), the old man died, cursing those who had caused his misery, and saying to Mercédès, ‘If you ever see my Edmond again, tell him I die blessing him.’”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“Well, then, under these circumstances,” said Caderousse, “I will, I even believe I ought to undeceive you as to the friendship which poor Edmond thought so sincere and unquestionable. And first, as concerns his father, whom Edmond loved so dearly, and who returned his affection with equal warmth, the poor old man—well, you know the rest.”
“No, I do not know the rest,” answered the abbé; “the little I do know has been gathered from vague reports. Edmond never talked to me about his father’s death.”
“So much the better; it will the more affect you. After the arrest of Edmond, and just at the moment when M. Morrel was leaving the house to obtain information, old Dantès, whom we had left in the company of Mercédès, must have been anticipating the speedy return of his son, since from the place where he was, he could see the vessel which was bringing him back, and since that vessel was the Pharaon, of which Edmond was the mate, and which was entering the port of Marseilles in full sail. Old Dantès remained all day waiting for his son, and at night was compelled to acknowledge to himself that Edmond would not return home. Then he went to bed, but the old man did not sleep; he had been perfectly well the day before, but the next morning he was pale and haggard; and the next day, and the next, he grew worse and worse. M. Morrel came once or twice, and offered to persuade the old man to remove to his house, and in fact to live with him; so did Mercédès, who would have given up her own chamber to him; but the old man positively refused. Caderousse, who was present, will tell you that he would not take anything. ‘No,’ said he, ‘so long as my son is not here, I will not quit this house; because,’ added he, with a smile that grieved me to the heart, ‘if he should return, he would not know where to find me.’ And yet every day he grew weaker and weaker. Caderousse and I endeavoured, but in vain, to prevail upon him to eat something. Mercédès did more than we did; she cooked him broth, made him custards, brought him sweetmeats; but the poor old man did not even thank her. At last, one morning, he felt so ill that Mercédès sent for a doctor. Caderousse went for him. It was M. de Boville, who had been an intimate friend of Dantès’s and who attended him gratuitously. I was there. I saw the doctor feel his pulse, and then shake his head, and go away, recommending him to be kept very quiet. I went up to the old man’s bedside, and said, ‘Father Dantès, do you want anything?’ He looked at me with eyes that spoke at once his answer—‘I want my son.’ ‘But,’ said I, ‘your son cannot return just yet; in the meantime, is there anything I can do for you?’ ‘No,’ said he; ‘nothing.’ He motioned me away, and I left the room, my heart filled with such grief as I had never before experienced. But when I reached the outside of the house, I met Mercédès, who was coming in, and who said to me, ‘Caderousse, how is he?’ I could only answer by tears; and she, understanding me, covered her face with her hands, and fled towards the city. I returned to the old man. He was calmer, but his eyes were fixed on the door. It was evident that he was still expecting his son. He remained in this state for two days, and on the third, at about ten o’clock in the morning, he died. He died,’ continued Caderousse, his voice trembling with emotion, ‘of grief, of despair, of a broken heart. Ah, M. l’Abbé, if you had seen him die, you would have said, ‘It is not God who has done this, but man!’”
“And you say that he refused food?” asked the abbé.
“Yes, he did; and I am sure it was not from want of appetite, for I saw him look at the food Mercédès brought him with a longing eye; but he seemed to have a repugnance to eat, as if it would prolong a life of suffering. He died, as I told you, on the third day, and on the fourth we buried him. M. Morrel and Mercédès alone followed him to the grave. Caderousse and I were there too, but we were not invited. We went of our own accord. We had not seen each other for some time, and we met at the funeral. We shook hands, and that was all. We did not speak. We had nothing to say to each other. When the funeral was over, M. Morrel gave me a hundred francs, and said, ‘Caderousse, this is for you and your wife; and this,’ added he, giving me another hundred francs, ‘is for the expenses of the funeral.’ So you see, M. l’Abbé, that M. Morrel is a worthy man.”
“And what became of Mercédès?” asked the abbé.
“Mercédès returned to the Catalans, and has remained there ever since. She lives in the same house, and in the same room. She has never quitted it. She has never forgotten Edmond. She has never ceased to mourn for him. She has never ceased to hope for his return. She has never ceased to love him.”
“And you say that old Dantès died of grief?”
“Yes, M. l’Abbé, of grief. I am as sure of it as I am that I am speaking to you. He died because he had lost all hope. He died because he had lost his son.”
“And you say that he refused food?”
“Yes, he did. He would not eat. He would not drink. He would not live.”
“And you say that he died on the third day?”
“Yes, on the third day, at ten o’clock in the morning.”
“And you say that M. Morrel and Mercédès alone followed him to the grave?”
“Yes, they alone. Caderousse and I were there too, but we were not invited.”
“And you say that M. Morrel gave you a hundred francs for yourself and your wife, and another hundred francs for the expenses of the funeral?”
“Yes, he did. M. Morrel is a worthy man.”
“And you say that Mercédès has remained at the Catalans ever since?”
“Yes, she has. She lives in the same house, and in the same room. She has never quitted it. She has never forgotten Edmond. She has never ceased to mourn for him. She has never ceased to hope for his return. She has never ceased to love him.”
“And you say that she has never ceased to love him?”
“Yes, M. l’Abbé, she has never ceased to love him.”
“And you say that she has never ceased to hope for his return?”
“Yes, M. l’Abbé, she has never ceased to hope for his return.”
“And you say that she has never ceased to mourn for him?”
“Yes, M. l’Abbé, she has never ceased to mourn for him.”
“And you say that she has never forgotten him?”
“Yes, M. l’Abbé, she has never forgotten him.”
“And you say that she has never quitted the house?”
“Yes, M. l’Abbé, she has never quitted the house.”

He died, as I told you, on the third day, and on the fourth we buried him. M. Morrel and Mercédès alone followed him to the grave. Caderousse and I were there too, but we were not invited. We went of our own accord. We had not seen each other for some time, and we met at the funeral. We shook hands, and that was all. We did not speak. We had nothing to say to each other. When the funeral was over, M. Morrel gave me a hundred francs, and said, ‘Caderousse, this is for you and your wife; and this,’ added he, giving me another hundred francs, ‘is for the expenses of the funeral.’ So you see, M. l’Abbé, that M. Morrel is a worthy man.”
“And what became of Mercédès?” asked the abbé.
“Mercédès returned to the Catalans, and has remained there ever since. She lives in the same house, and in the same room. She has never quitted it. She has never forgotten Edmond. She has never ceased to mourn for him. She has never ceased to hope for his return. She has never ceased to love him.”
“And you say that old Dantès died of grief?”
“Yes, M. l’Abbé, of grief. I am as sure of it as I am that I am speaking to you. He died because he had lost all hope. He died because he had lost his son.”
“And you say that he refused food?”
“Yes, he did. He would not eat. He would not drink. He would not live.”
“And you say that he died on the third day?”
“Yes, on the third day, at ten o’clock in the morning.”
“And you say that M. Morrel and Mercédès alone followed him to the grave?”
“Yes, they alone. Caderousse and I were there too, but we were not invited.”
“And you say that M. Morrel gave you a hundred francs for yourself and your wife, and another hundred francs for the expenses of the funeral?”
“Yes, he did. M. Morrel is a worthy man.”
“And you say that Mercédès has remained at the Catalans ever since?”
“Yes, she has. She lives in the same house, and in the same room. She has never quitted it. She has never forgotten Edmond. She has never ceased to mourn for him. She has never ceased to hope for his return. She has never ceased to love him.”
“And you say that she has never ceased to love him?”
“Yes, M. l’Abbé, she has never ceased to love him.”
“And you say that she has never ceased to hope for his return?”
“Yes, M. l’Abbé, she has never ceased to hope for his return.”
“And you say that she has never ceased to mourn for him?”
“Yes, M. l’Abbé, she has never ceased to mourn for him.”
“And you say that she has never forgotten him?”
“Yes, M. l’Abbé, she has never forgotten him.”
“And you say that she has never quitted the house?”
“Yes, M. l’Abbé, she has never quitted the house.”

events.title: Confirmation of Death by Hunger and Identification of Dantès's Betrayers
detailed_summary: The Abbé, visibly agitated by the account of old Dantès's death, rises and paces before questioning Caderousse about the specific cause.
Caderousse confirms unequivocally that old Dantès died of hunger, stating he is as certain of it as he is that they are both Christians.
Deeply moved, the Abbé drinks some water, his eyes red and cheeks pale, and describes the event as horrific.
Caderousse emphasizes that this tragedy was the result of human actions, not divine will.

The Abbé, in an almost menacing tone, demands to know the identities of these men, reminding Caderousse of his promise to reveal everything about those who caused the son's despair and the father's starvation.
Caderousse identifies two men driven by jealousy: Fernand, motivated by love for Mercédès, and Danglars, motivated by ambition.
He explains their jealousy manifested in denouncing Edmond as a Bonapartist agent.
When pressed on who was the primary culprit, Caderousse states both were involved: one conceived and wrote the letter, the other delivered it to the post.
This letter, he specifies, was written at La Réserve the day before the betrothal feast.
The Abbé murmurs to himself, recognizing the accuracy of Faria's judgments about men and events.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The abbé rose from his chair, made two turns round the chamber, and pressed his trembling hand against his parched throat.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Oh, Faria, Faria, how well did you judge men and things!”

events.text_segment:
The abbé rose from his chair, made two turns round the chamber, and pressed his trembling hand against his parched throat.
“And you believe he died——”
“Of hunger, sir, of hunger,” said Caderousse. “I am as certain of it as that we two are Christians.”
The abbé, with a shaking hand, seized a glass of water that was standing by him half-full, swallowed it at one gulp, and then resumed his seat, with red eyes and pale cheeks.
“This was, indeed, a horrid event,” said he in a hoarse voice.
“The more so, sir, as it was men’s and not God’s doing.”
“Tell me of those men,” said the abbé, “and remember too,” he added in an almost menacing tone, “you have promised to tell me everything. Tell me, therefore, who are these men who killed the son with despair, and the father with famine?”
“Two men jealous of him, sir; one from love, and the other from ambition,—Fernand and Danglars.”
“How was this jealousy manifested? Speak on.”
“They denounced Edmond as a Bonapartist agent.”
“Which of the two denounced him? Which was the real delinquent?”
“Both, sir; one with a letter, and the other put it in the post.”
“And where was this letter written?”
“At La Réserve, the day before the betrothal feast.”
“’Twas so, then—’twas so, then,” murmured the abbé. “Oh, Faria, Faria, how well did you judge men and things!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The abbé rose from his chair, made two turns round the chamber, and pressed his trembling hand against his parched throat. "And you say he died of hunger?" he asked.
"Of hunger, yes, sir; and I am as certain of it as I am that we are both Christians." The abbé uttered a kind of groan, and his eyes, which he raised to heaven, were red and inflamed. "This, then, was the result of their crime!" he muttered. "Poor old man! to die of hunger!" "Yes, sir," resumed Caderousse, "of hunger. Ah! if you had seen him, as I did, two days before he died, the father of a son like his, who was about to marry a beautiful girl, and to be captain of a vessel, if you had seen him, sir, two days before he died, sitting in his arm-chair, and waiting for his son, and constantly saying, 'Edmond will be here directly; he is on his way from Marseilles; and then they will not let him want for anything, for he is a good son;' ah, sir, it was a piteous sight!" "And you did not go to his help?" said the abbé, in a tone of reproach.
"Yes, sir, I did, and I proposed to him that he should share my portion of bread, and offered him the half of my bed; but he would not. This was on the morning of the day he died. The night before, he had eaten a morsel of bread which I had carried to him, and he said to me, 'Very well, Caderousse, now I am better; to-morrow I shall see Edmond.'" "So that he died the next day?" said the abbé.
"Yes, sir; and I can say that he died happy, for he had no longer any ill-will against any one; and in his last moments he forgave everybody, only he charged me to tell Edmond, if ever I saw him, that he died blessing him." The abbé pressed his hands together, and raised them to heaven. "Oh, my God!" he cried, "forgive me if I have ever cursed you!" "And this was all?" asked the abbé, with a searching look at Caderousse.
"Yes, sir," replied Caderousse, "it was all; and, believe me, it was a great deal." "But you told me that this misfortune was caused by human agency?" "Yes." "And you said that two men were the cause of it?" "Yes." "And these two men were?" "One, Fernand Mondego; the other, Danglars." "And their motive?" "Jealousy; Fernand was jealous of Edmond, and Danglars was jealous of the success which Edmond had obtained in the service of M. Morrel, and which would procure him a post which Danglars had solicited for himself." "So that these two men, from motives of personal interest, conspired against Edmond?" "Yes." "And they denounced him as a Bonapartist agent?" "Yes." "And the denunciation was?" "Written by Danglars, and delivered by Fernand." "To whom?" "To the procureur du roi." "And when was this denunciation made?" "The day before the betrothal feast, at La Réserve." "Ah!" murmured the abbé, "Faria was right; it was at La Réserve that the plot was formed."

1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:

- The completion omits the original's concise exchange about the cause of death and the immediate emotional reaction of the abbé, instead expanding into a prolonged account of the father's suffering and Caderousse's involvement.

events.title: Caderousse's Confession of Complicity and Remorse
detailed_summary: When Caderousse inquires about the Abbé's muttered words, the priest dismisses the question and urges him to continue his account.
Caderousse elaborates that Danglars wrote the denunciation with his left hand to disguise his script, and Fernand posted the letter.
The Abbé suddenly exclaims that Caderousse himself must have been present, a remark that startles Caderousse.
Quickly recovering, the Abbé rationalizes that such detailed knowledge implies Caderousse was an eyewitness.
Caderousse, his voice choked with emotion, confirms his presence at the scene.
The Abbé challenges him, asking if he protested against such a vile act, implying that his silence made him an accomplice.
Caderousse defends himself by claiming that Danglars and Fernand had plied him with so much alcohol that his perception was severely impaired, and he only vaguely understood what was happening.
He asserts that he said what little he could in his intoxicated state, but they assured him it was merely a harmless prank.
The Abbé presses further, pointing out that Caderousse must have understood the gravity of their actions the next day when Dantès was arrested, yet he remained silent despite being present.

Caderousse admits he was there and wanted to speak out but was restrained by Danglars, who warned that if Dantès were found genuinely guilty with a Bonapartist letter, anyone who supported him would be considered an accomplice.
He confesses that fear, given the volatile political situation at the time, compelled him to stay quiet, an act he now deems cowardly but not criminal.
The Abbé observes that Caderousse simply allowed events to run their course.

Caderousse agrees, adding that remorse has tormented him ever since, and he frequently begs God for forgiveness, believing this single moment of selfishness is the root of his current wretched condition, a sentiment he often expresses to his wife, La Carconte, when she complains.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “What did you please to say, sir?” asked Caderousse.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And Caderousse bowed his head with every sign of real repentance.

events.text_segment:
“What did you please to say, sir?” asked Caderousse.
“Nothing, nothing,” replied the priest; “go on.”
“It was Danglars who wrote the denunciation with his left hand, that his writing might not be recognized, and Fernand who put it in the post.”
“But,” exclaimed the abbé suddenly, “you were there yourself.”
“I!” said Caderousse, astonished; “who told you I was there?”
The abbé saw he had overshot the mark, and he added quickly,—“No one; but in order to have known everything so well, you must have been an eye-witness.”
“True, true!” said Caderousse in a choking voice, “I was there.”
“And did you not remonstrate against such infamy?” asked the abbé; “if not, you were an accomplice.”
“Sir,” replied Caderousse, “they had made me drink to such an excess that I nearly lost all perception. I had only an indistinct understanding of what was passing around me. I said all that a man in such a state could say; but they both assured me that it was a jest they were carrying on, and perfectly harmless.”
“Next day—next day, sir, you must have seen plain enough what they had been doing, yet you said nothing, though you were present when Dantès was arrested.”
“Yes, sir, I was there, and very anxious to speak; but Danglars restrained me. ‘If he should really be guilty,’ said he, ‘and did really put in to the Island of Elba; if he is really charged with a letter for the Bonapartist committee at Paris, and if they find this letter upon him, those who have supported him will pass for his accomplices.’ I confess I had my fears, in the state in which politics then were, and I held my tongue. It was cowardly, I confess, but it was not criminal.”
“I understand—you allowed matters to take their course, that was all.”
“Yes, sir,” answered Caderousse; “and remorse preys on me night and day. I often ask pardon of God, I swear to you, because this action, the only one with which I have seriously to reproach myself in all my life, is no doubt the cause of my abject condition. I am expiating a moment of selfishness, and so I always say to La Carconte, when she complains, ‘Hold your tongue, woman; it is the will of God.’” And Caderousse bowed his head with every sign of real repentance.

The Abbé smiled, but with a strange expression. “Nothing, nothing,” said he; “go on.” “Danglars wrote the denunciation with his left hand, that his writing might not be known, and Fernand posted it.” “So that,” said the Abbé, “you were there yourself, since you knew all these details?” “Ah, sir,” replied Caderousse, his voice choked with emotion, “if you had seen me at that moment, you would have pitied me. I was like a man in a dream; I saw it all, but I could not believe it. I was so drunk that I could not stand; I could only stammer out a few words, and they laughed at me. They told me it was a joke, a harmless trick to frighten Dantès, and that they would release him the next day. I believed them, sir, I believed them!” “So that,” said the Abbé, “when Dantès was arrested the next day, you were present?” “Yes, sir, I was there. I saw him arrested, and I wanted to speak, but Danglars held me back. He told me that if Dantès was really guilty, and if they found a Bonapartist letter upon him, all those who had supported him would be considered as accomplices. I was afraid, sir, I was afraid! It was a time of terror, you know, and I held my tongue. It was cowardly, I know, but it was not criminal.” “Yes,” said the Abbé, “you allowed events to take their course.” “Alas, sir,” replied Caderousse, “remorse has tormented me ever since. I have never had a moment's peace. I have often begged God to forgive me, and I believe that this single moment of selfishness is the cause of all my misfortunes. I often say so to La Carconte when she complains.”
