events.title: The Misfortunes of the Virtuous Monsieur Morrel
detailed_summary: The Abbé acknowledges Caderousse's unreserved confession, suggesting that such self-accusation merits pardon.
Caderousse expresses sorrow that Edmond died without forgiving him, though the Abbé notes Edmond was unaware; Caderousse counters that the dead supposedly know everything.
After a thoughtful silence, the Abbé inquires about Monsieur Morrel, identified by Caderousse as the owner of the Pharaon and Dantès's patron.
Caderousse praises Morrel as an honest, brave, and genuinely caring man who repeatedly interceded for Edmond.
Morrel's efforts were so energetic that he faced persecution as a Bonapartist during the Second Restoration.

He frequently visited Dantès’s father, offered him lodging, and, shortly before the old man's death, left his purse on the mantelpiece, which paid for debts and a decent burial. Caderousse reveals he still has this red silk purse.
The Abbé assumes such a virtuous man must be blessed by God, rich, and happy.
Caderousse smiles bitterly, stating Morrel is as happy as himself—meaning, deeply unhappy.
He explains that Morrel is nearly ruined and facing dishonor after twenty-five years of hard work and an honorable reputation.

Morrel has lost five ships in two years, suffered from the bankruptcies of three major firms, and his only remaining hope is the Pharaon, the ship Dantès once commanded, which is currently en route from the Indies.
Morrel's distress is compounded by his family: a devoted wife, a daughter whose marriage prospects are ruined by his financial state, and a son serving as a lieutenant in the army.
Caderousse believes that if Morrel were alone, he would take his own life.
The priest exclaims that this situation is horrible.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Well, sir,” said the abbé, “you have spoken unreservedly; and thus to accuse yourself is to deserve pardon.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Horrible!” ejaculated the priest.

events.text_segment:
“Well, sir,” said the abbé, “you have spoken unreservedly; and thus to accuse yourself is to deserve pardon.”
“Unfortunately, Edmond is dead, and has not pardoned me.”
“He did not know,” said the abbé.
“But he knows it all now,” interrupted Caderousse; “they say the dead know everything.”
There was a brief silence; the abbé rose and paced up and down pensively, and then resumed his seat.
“You have two or three times mentioned a M. Morrel,” he said; “who was he?”
“The owner of the Pharaon and patron of Dantès.”
“And what part did he play in this sad drama?” inquired the abbé.
“The part of an honest man, full of courage and real regard. Twenty times he interceded for Edmond. When the emperor returned, he wrote, implored, threatened, and so energetically, that on the second restoration he was persecuted as a Bonapartist. Ten times, as I told you, he came to see Dantès’ father, and offered to receive him in his own house; and the night or two before his death, as I have already said, he left his purse on the mantelpiece, with which they paid the old man’s debts, and buried him decently; and so Edmond’s father died, as he had lived, without doing harm to anyone. I have the purse still by me—a large one, made of red silk.”
“And,” asked the abbé, “is M. Morrel still alive?”
“Yes,” replied Caderousse.
“In that case,” replied the abbé, “he should be a man blessed of God, rich, happy.”
Caderousse smiled bitterly. “Yes, happy as myself,” said he.
“What! M. Morrel unhappy?” exclaimed the abbé.
“He is reduced almost to the last extremity—nay, he is almost at the point of dishonor.”
“How?”
“Yes,” continued Caderousse, “so it is; after five-and-twenty years of labor, after having acquired a most honorable name in the trade of Marseilles, M. Morrel is utterly ruined; he has lost five ships in two years, has suffered by the bankruptcy of three large houses, and his only hope now is in that very Pharaon which poor Dantès commanded, and which is expected from the Indies with a cargo of cochineal and indigo. If this ship founders, like the others, he is a ruined man.”
“And has the unfortunate man wife or children?” inquired the abbé.
“Yes, he has a wife, who through everything has behaved like an angel; he has a daughter, who was about to marry the man she loved, but whose family now will not allow him to wed the daughter of a ruined man; he has, besides, a son, a lieutenant in the army; and, as you may suppose, all this, instead of lessening, only augments his sorrows. If he were alone in the world he would blow out his brains, and there would be an end.”
“Horrible!” ejaculated the priest.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“Well, sir,” said the abbé, “you have spoken unreservedly; and thus to accuse yourself is to deserve pardon.”

“Alas!” said Caderousse, “Edmond is dead, and has not forgiven me!”

“You have heard of the death of Edmond Dantès, then?”

“Yes, in the prison, after the second restoration. A man from Marseilles was there, who knew him, and who told me of it.”

“The dead know nothing of this world’s affairs,” said the abbé.

“You think so?” said Caderousse. “It may be; but I have my own ideas about it.”

“And why should Edmond Dantès, since he is dead, forgive you?”

“Because I have been a coward, a traitor, and a villain,” said Caderousse; “and, as he was a man of noble heart, he would, perhaps, have forgiven me.”

“And this M. Morrel, of whom you spoke, what has become of him?”

“M. Morrel?”

“Yes; he was, I think, your employer, was he not?”

“No, sir, I was a simple workman in the employ of M. Morrel the shipowner, and I had been in that employ for twenty years when Edmond was arrested. Ah, sir, M. Morrel is a worthy, an honest, a brave man. He loved Edmond dearly, and Edmond loved him. Ah, if M. Morrel had been there, that would not have happened.”

“So that M. Morrel was not at Marseilles at the time of this arrest?”

“No; he was at Paris, on business. And when he returned, he was in despair. He did all he could to save Edmond. He went to the governor of the prison, to the procureur du roi, to the prefect. But the door was everywhere closed against him. During the Hundred Days, M. Morrel was accused of being a Bonapartist, and only escaped with his life by a miracle. And since the second restoration, he has been suspected. They say he is a liberal. The consequence is, that he has lost his best customers, and is nearly ruined.”

“Nearly ruined!” exclaimed the abbé.

“Yes; he has had losses, one after another. Five ships lost in two years, three bankruptcies of houses he was connected with, and so on. Ah, sir, M. Morrel is an unfortunate man.”

“And his family?”

“He has a wife, a daughter, and a son. His wife is a most estimable woman, who has been a great comfort to him in his misfortunes. His daughter is a charming girl, who was to have been married to a young man she loved, but the marriage is broken off on account of her father’s losses. His son is a lieutenant in the army, and is a brave young man, but he can do nothing for his father.”

“And what is M. Morrel doing now?”

“He is struggling against his misfortunes. He has only one ship left, the Pharaon, the very ship that Edmond commanded. It is expected from the Indies every day. If it arrives safe, and makes a good voyage, he may yet retrieve his affairs. But if it is lost, he is ruined past redemption.”

“And if he is ruined?”

“Then he will do as many others do in such a case.”

“What will he do?”

“He will blow his brains out,” said Caderousse, coolly.

“Good heavens!” exclaimed the abbé.

“And what is more,” continued Caderousse, “he has not a sou to bless himself with. He has sold all he had, except his house and his warehouse. And even those are mortgaged.”

“And did he do nothing for Dantès’s father?”

“Yes, indeed he did. He went to see him every day, and offered him money, and tried to persuade him to come and live with him. But the old man would not. He said he would not leave his house until Edmond returned. And he died of grief, the poor old man. And M. Morrel paid for his funeral, and for the doctor, and for everything. And he left a purse full of money on the mantelpiece, and told me to take care of the old man, and to use the money for him. But the old man died the next day. And I have the purse still. It is a red silk purse.”

“And you have kept it?”

“Yes,” said Caderousse, “I have kept it. It is the only thing I have that belonged to M. Morrel.”

“And you say that M. Morrel is an honest man?”

Morrel is a worthy, an honest, a brave man. He loved Edmond dearly, and Edmond loved him. Ah, if M. Morrel had been there, that would not have happened.”

events.title: The Ill-Gotten Success of Danglars and Fernand
detailed_summary: Caderousse laments that this is how heaven repays virtue, contrasting his own destitution and his wife's illness with the immense wealth of Fernand and Danglars, whose fortunes he attributes to their wicked deeds.
When the Abbé inquires about Danglars, the instigator, Caderousse recounts his rise: Danglars left Marseilles and, on M. Morrel's unknowing recommendation, became a cashier at a Spanish bank.
During the war with Spain, Danglars served in the French army's commissariat, amassing a fortune.

He then speculated in funds, multiplying his capital, married his banker's daughter, and after her death, married Madame de Nargonne, a widow connected to the king's chamberlain and high court circles.
Now Baron Danglars, he is a millionaire with a grand Parisian residence, numerous horses, servants, and vast wealth.
The Abbé remarks with a peculiar tone that Danglars is happy, to which Caderousse retorts that true happiness is a secret, but if wealth equates to happiness, Danglars possesses it.

Turning to Fernand, Caderousse states his story is much the same, despite his humble origins as an uneducated Catalan fisher-boy, a fact that Caderousse admits baffles everyone, suggesting a hidden secret in Fernand's life.

Detailing Fernand's ascent, Caderousse explains he was drafted into the army. After the Battle of Ligny, while serving as a sentry, he deserted his post to accompany a general who was defecting to the enemy.
This act, which would have led to a court-martial under Napoleon, was rewarded by the Bourbons upon their return. Fernand re-entered France as a sub-lieutenant.
With the general's high-level protection, he became a captain by 1823, during the Spanish war, where Danglars was making his fortune.

Being Spanish himself, Fernand was sent to Spain, where he reconnected with Danglars, gained royalist support, and used his local knowledge to guide his regiment, rendering services that led to his promotion to colonel, the title of Count, and the Cross of an Officer of the Legion of Honor after the taking of Trocadero.
When the end of the Spanish war stalled his career, Fernand, leveraging the fashionable support for Greek independence, obtained leave to serve in Greece while remaining on the army roll.
He entered the service of Ali Pasha as an instructor-general. Before Ali Pasha was killed, he rewarded Fernand with a considerable sum of money.
Fernand returned to France and was gazetted lieutenant-general, now owning a magnificent house in Paris at No. 27, Rue du Helder.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “And it is thus heaven recompenses virtue, sir,” added Caderousse.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “So that now,” continued Caderousse, “he owns a magnificent house—No. 27, Rue du Helder, Paris.”

events.text_segment:
“And it is thus heaven recompenses virtue, sir,” added Caderousse. “You see, I, who never did a bad action but that I have told you of—am in destitution, with my poor wife dying of fever before my very eyes, and I unable to do anything in the world for her; I shall die of hunger, as old Dantès did, while Fernand and Danglars are rolling in wealth.”
“How is that?”
“Because their deeds have brought them good fortune, while honest men have been reduced to misery.”
“What has become of Danglars, the instigator, and therefore the most guilty?”
“What has become of him? Why, he left Marseilles, and was taken, on the recommendation of M. Morrel, who did not know his crime, as cashier into a Spanish bank. During the war with Spain he was employed in the commissariat of the French army, and made a fortune; then with that money he speculated in the funds, and trebled or quadrupled his capital; and, having first married his banker’s daughter, who left him a widower, he has married a second time, a widow, a Madame de Nargonne, daughter of M. de Servieux, the king’s chamberlain, who is in high favor at court. He is a millionaire, and they have made him a baron, and now he is the Baron Danglars, with a fine residence in the Rue du Mont-Blanc, with ten horses in his stables, six footmen in his antechamber, and I know not how many millions in his strongbox.”
“Ah!” said the abbé, in a peculiar tone, “he is happy.”
“Happy? Who can answer for that? Happiness or unhappiness is the secret known but to one’s self and the walls—walls have ears but no tongue; but if a large fortune produces happiness, Danglars is happy.”
“And Fernand?”
“Fernand? Why, much the same story.”
“But how could a poor Catalan fisher-boy, without education or resources, make a fortune? I confess this staggers me.”
“And it has staggered everybody. There must have been in his life some strange secret that no one knows.”
“But, then, by what visible steps has he attained this high fortune or high position?”
“Both, sir—he has both fortune and position—both.”
“This must be impossible!”
“It would seem so; but listen, and you will understand. Some days before the return of the emperor, Fernand was drafted. The Bourbons left him quietly enough at the Catalans, but Napoleon returned, a special levy was made, and Fernand was compelled to join. I went too; but as I was older than Fernand, and had just married my poor wife, I was only sent to the coast. Fernand was enrolled in the active army, went to the frontier with his regiment, and was at the battle of Ligny. The night after that battle he was sentry at the door of a general who carried on a secret correspondence with the enemy. That same night the general was to go over to the English. He proposed to Fernand to accompany him; Fernand agreed to do so, deserted his post, and followed the general.
“Fernand would have been court-martialed if Napoleon had remained on the throne, but his action was rewarded by the Bourbons. He returned to France with the epaulet of sub-lieutenant, and as the protection of the general, who is in the highest favor, was accorded to him, he was a captain in 1823, during the Spanish war—that is to say, at the time when Danglars made his early speculations. Fernand was a Spaniard, and being sent to Spain to ascertain the feeling of his fellow-countrymen, found Danglars there, got on very intimate terms with him, won over the support of the royalists at the capital and in the provinces, received promises and made pledges on his own part, guided his regiment by paths known to himself alone through the mountain gorges which were held by the royalists, and, in fact, rendered such services in this brief campaign that, after the taking of Trocadero, he was made colonel, and received the title of count and the cross of an officer of the Legion of Honor.”
“Destiny! destiny!” murmured the abbé.
“Yes, but listen: this was not all. The war with Spain being ended, Fernand’s career was checked by the long peace which seemed likely to endure throughout Europe. Greece only had risen against Turkey, and had begun her war of independence; all eyes were turned towards Athens—it was the fashion to pity and support the Greeks. The French government, without protecting them openly, as you know, gave countenance to volunteer assistance. Fernand sought and obtained leave to go and serve in Greece, still having his name kept on the army roll.
Some time after, it was stated that the Comte de Morcerf (this was the name he bore) had entered the service of Ali Pasha with the rank of instructor-general. Ali Pasha was killed, as you know, but before he died he recompensed the services of Fernand by leaving him a considerable sum, with which he returned to France, when he was gazetted lieutenant-general.”
“So that now——?” inquired the abbé.
“So that now,” continued Caderousse, “he owns a magnificent house—No. 27, Rue du Helder, Paris.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“And it is thus heaven recompenses virtue, sir,” added Caderousse, completing the history of the two friends, and arriving at the period when the two fortunes were made, “and I am an honest man, and in the deepest misery, while these two men are millionaires, and the tools of Providence!”
“And Danglars, the instigator, the most guilty, do you know what has become of him?”
“Yes, sir; he left Marseilles, and obtained a situation in the house of a Spanish merchant established at Cadiz. During the war with Spain, M. Morrel, who had kept up some connection with him, recommended him to the French commissary, who was making immense purchases. His accounts were found correct, and he was made purveyor to the army. Then he speculated with his funds, and even with the funds of the army, and made a fortune. Then he became a stockbroker, and the Spanish government, having need of money, applied to him, and he supplied them with ten millions of reals, for which he received a splendid commission. He then proposed to make a loan of twenty millions, but kept it for himself, and by a clever manœuvre thus gained thirty millions, upon which he founded his fortune. He then married the daughter of the banker of whom he had obtained the loan, and who died shortly afterwards, leaving him half her fortune. He then married a second time, a widow, a Madame de Nargonne, daughter of Baron de Salvieux, who was in the king’s service, and belonged to the court. She is a woman of high fashion. Danglars, now a baron, lives in a magnificent hotel in the Rue de la Chaussée d’Antin, and gives grand dinners, to which I should die of hunger if I waited for an invitation. He has millions, horses, servants, and in fact, everything. He is a millionaire ten times over, and his wife has two millions in her own right besides.”
“Ah!” said the abbé, with a peculiar tone, “he is happy, then.”
“Happy? Who can say? Happiness is a secret between God and himself. But if wealth be happiness, Danglars is happy.”
“And Fernand?” asked the abbé.
“Fernand? His story is still more extraordinary.”
“Indeed?”
“Yes. You know, or rather you do not know, sir, that Fernand was a Catalan, a poor fisher-boy, and that the foundation of his fortune was the four hundred francs he received from M. Morrel, and which he had not earned. This money was the beginning of his fortune, as the four hundred francs of the marriage portion of Mercédès was the origin of mine. But you shall see. Fernand was a soldier, and as there was a war in Spain, he was sent with the army. The battle of Ligny had taken place, and the emperor was expected at Paris, when Fernand was on guard at the Tuileries. He was a sentry, and was ordered not to allow any one to pass. A general presented himself, and wished to pass. Fernand refused. The general insisted, and Fernand threatened to run him through with his bayonet. The general, seeing that he had to deal with a determined man, drew back, and Fernand remained at his post. The next day, the general, who was a great friend of the emperor, related the affair to him, and the emperor, who was a great admirer of courage, sent for Fernand, and promoted him to the rank of sub-lieutenant. This was the beginning of his fortune. He was sent to Spain, and as he was a Catalan, he knew the country well. He rendered great services, and was promoted to the rank of captain. He was at the siege of Cadiz, and distinguished himself by his bravery. He was made a colonel, and then a general. He was created a count by the king of Spain, and received the cross of the Legion of Honor from the king of France. He is now a lieutenant-general, and lives in a magnificent hotel in the Rue du Helder, No. 27.”
“So that,” said the abbé, “these two men, who were the cause of the ruin of the poor sailor, have raised themselves, the one to the rank of a millionaire, the other to that of a general?”
“And this is what I call the justice of heaven!” said Caderousse.

events.title: Mercédès's Transformation, Marriage, and Underlying Unhappiness
detailed_summary: The Abbé, after a moment of hesitation and self-control, inquires about Mercédès, whom he heard had disappeared.
Caderousse corrects him, saying she disappeared like the sun, only to reappear with greater splendor, and is now one of Paris's most prominent ladies.
The Abbé, finding the tale dreamlike yet plausible given his own extraordinary experiences, prompts Caderousse to continue.
Caderousse describes Mercédès's initial profound despair over losing Edmond, her attempts to appeal to M. de Villefort, and her devotion to old Dantès.
A new sorrow befell her with the departure of Fernand, whom she regarded as a brother, ignorant of his crime.
After three months of weeping, with no news of Edmond or Fernand and only the dying old Dantès for companionship, Fernand returned in a sub-lieutenant's uniform.
His return brought Mercédès joy not from love for him, but from relief at no longer being alone and seeing a friend after long solitude. Fernand had never been hated, merely not loved as Edmond was.
The thought of Edmond being dead, previously repelled, now took hold, reinforced by old Dantès's constant assertion of Edmond's demise.
Old Dantès's death removed a potential obstacle to her marrying another. Fernand, now a lieutenant, returned and reminded Mercédès of his love.
Mercédès requested six more months to await and mourn Edmond.
The Abbé sarcastically remarks that eighteen months is ample devotion, quoting, "Frailty, thy name is woman."
Six months later, Mercédès and Fernand married in the Church of Accoules, the very church where she was to marry Edmond.
Though outwardly calm, Mercédès nearly fainted passing La Réserve, where her betrothal to Edmond had occurred, a sign of her lingering love.
Fernand, anxious about Edmond's potential return, left Marseilles with Mercédès eight days after the wedding.
Caderousse later saw Mercédès in Perpignan during the Spanish war, where Fernand had left her; she was overseeing her son Albert's education.
The Abbé expresses surprise that Mercédès, daughter of a simple fisherman, could educate her son, as Edmond had described her as beautiful but uneducated.

Caderousse praises Mercédès's intelligence and inherent queenliness, explaining she developed alongside Fernand's growing fortune, learning drawing, music, and more, possibly to distract her mind from her heartache.
Despite her current assured position, wealth, and title as a countess, Caderousse pauses before stating he is sure she is not happy.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The abbé opened his mouth, hesitated for a moment, then, making an effort at self-control, he said, “And Mercédès—they tell me that she has disappeared?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Yet, I am sure, she is not happy,” said Caderousse.

events.text_segment:
The abbé opened his mouth, hesitated for a moment, then, making an effort at self-control, he said, “And Mercédès—they tell me that she has disappeared?”
“Disappeared,” said Caderousse, “yes, as the sun disappears, to rise the next day with still more splendor.”
“Has she made a fortune also?” inquired the abbé, with an ironical smile.
“Mercédès is at this moment one of the greatest ladies in Paris,” replied Caderousse.
“Go on,” said the abbé; “it seems as if I were listening to the story of a dream. But I have seen things so extraordinary, that what you tell me seems less astonishing than it otherwise might.”
“Mercédès was at first in the deepest despair at the blow which deprived her of Edmond. I have told you of her attempts to propitiate M. de Villefort, her devotion to the elder Dantès. In the midst of her despair, a new affliction overtook her. This was the departure of Fernand—of Fernand, whose crime she did not know, and whom she regarded as her brother. Fernand went, and Mercédès remained alone.
“Three months passed and still she wept—no news of Edmond, no news of Fernand, no companionship save that of an old man who was dying with despair. One evening, after a day of accustomed vigil at the angle of two roads leading to Marseilles from the Catalans, she returned to her home more depressed than ever. Suddenly she heard a step she knew, turned anxiously around, the door opened, and Fernand, dressed in the uniform of a sub-lieutenant, stood before her.
“It was not the one she wished for most, but it seemed as if a part of her past life had returned to her.
“Mercédès seized Fernand’s hands with a transport which he took for love, but which was only joy at being no longer alone in the world, and seeing at last a friend, after long hours of solitary sorrow. And then, it must be confessed, Fernand had never been hated—he was only not precisely loved. Another possessed all Mercédès’ heart; that other was absent, had disappeared, perhaps was dead. At this last thought Mercédès burst into a flood of tears, and wrung her hands in agony; but the thought, which she had always repelled before when it was suggested to her by another, came now in full force upon her mind; and then, too, old Dantès incessantly said to her, ‘Our Edmond is dead; if he were not, he would return to us.’
“The old man died, as I have told you; had he lived, Mercédès, perchance, had not become the wife of another, for he would have been there to reproach her infidelity. Fernand saw this, and when he learned of the old man’s death he returned. He was now a lieutenant. At his first coming he had not said a word of love to Mercédès; at the second he reminded her that he loved her.
“Mercédès begged for six months more in which to await and mourn for Edmond.”
“So that,” said the abbé, with a bitter smile, “that makes eighteen months in all. What more could the most devoted lover desire?” Then he murmured the words of the English poet, “‘Frailty, thy name is woman.’”
“Six months afterwards,” continued Caderousse, “the marriage took place in the church of Accoules.”
“The very church in which she was to have married Edmond,” murmured the priest; “there was only a change of bridegrooms.”
“Well, Mercédès was married,” proceeded Caderousse; “but although in the eyes of the world she appeared calm, she nearly fainted as she passed La Réserve, where, eighteen months before, the betrothal had been celebrated with him whom she might have known she still loved, had she looked to the bottom of her heart. Fernand, more happy, but not more at his ease—for I saw at this time he was in constant dread of Edmond’s return—Fernand was very anxious to get his wife away, and to depart himself. There were too many unpleasant possibilities associated with the Catalans, and eight days after the wedding they left Marseilles.”
“Did you ever see Mercédès again?” inquired the priest.
“Yes, during the Spanish war, at Perpignan, where Fernand had left her; she was attending to the education of her son.”
The abbé started. “Her son?” said he.
“Yes,” replied Caderousse, “little Albert.”
“But, then, to be able to instruct her child,” continued the abbé, “she must have received an education herself. I understood from Edmond that she was the daughter of a simple fisherman, beautiful but uneducated.”
“Oh,” replied Caderousse, “did he know so little of his lovely betrothed? Mercédès might have been a queen, sir, if the crown were to be placed on the heads of the loveliest and most intelligent. Fernand’s fortune was already waxing great, and she developed with his growing fortune. She learned drawing, music—everything. Besides, I believe, between ourselves, she did this in order to distract her mind, that she might forget; and she only filled her head in order to alleviate the weight on her heart. But now her position in life is assured,” continued Caderousse; “no doubt fortune and honors have comforted her; she is rich, a countess, and yet——”
Caderousse paused.
“And yet what?” asked the abbé.
“Yet, I am sure, she is not happy,” said Caderousse.

Mercédès is still at Marseilles, and is one of the grandest ladies in Paris.”“But,” said the abbé, with a slight trembling in his voice, “did you not say she was unhappy?”“Unhappy? Yes, at one time she was very unhappy.”“Since you promise me a complete recital, give it to me,” said the abbé. “A tale of woe is ever welcome to those who are themselves unfortunate.”“The poor girl wept and prayed incessantly,” continued Caderousse; “she went to M. de Villefort, who was no longer at Marseilles; she implored the protection of M. Morrel, who had always been a good friend to them, but the old man said, ‘For God’s sake, leave me in peace; have I not trouble enough of my own? It is the will of God. Believe me, it is the best way not to strive against it.’ And Mercédès did not strive against it, but prayed at the church of the Accoules, until her knees were worn. One day, as she was returning from the church of the Accoules, she met Fernand, who had just arrived from the army, and was covered with dust. Fernand saw the young girl’s grief, and it reminded him of the oath he had made to Edmond Dantès. He went to see M. Morrel, and inquired about Edmond. M. Morrel told him that he had disappeared, and that he was supposed to be dead. Fernand then went to see Mercédès. He found her in despair, and he spoke to her of Edmond, and of the oath he had made. Mercédès listened to him, and she saw that he was sincere. She told him that she would wait for Edmond for six months, and that if he did not return in that time, she would marry him. Fernand agreed to this, and he left her. Mercédès waited for six months, and Edmond did not return. She then married Fernand in the church of the Accoules, the very church where she was to have married Edmond. It was a sad wedding. Mercédès was dressed in white, but she was as pale as death. As she passed La Réserve, she nearly fainted. Fernand supported her, and they went on. Eight days after the wedding, Fernand and Mercédès left Marseilles. Fernand had been promoted to the rank of lieutenant, and he was ordered to Spain. I saw Mercédès again at Perpignan, during the Spanish war. She was with her son, a beautiful boy, about three years old. She was superintending his education.”The abbé started. “Mercédès superintending her son’s education! Why,” said he, “Edmond told me that she was a simple Catalan girl, knowing nothing, and having no education.”“That is true,” said Caderousse; “but sorrow has worked a miracle. Besides, she has had a good example in Fernand, who, since he has become rich, has had his son educated in the best schools. And Mercédès is a woman of great intelligence. She has learned drawing, music, and everything that is taught in the schools. She is a queen, sir, a queen!”“And she is happy?” asked the abbé, with a searching look.“Happy? I do not know. She is a great lady, and she has a fine son, but I do not know if she is happy. There are times when she looks very sad, and I have seen her weep. But do not tell her that I told you this. She would be very angry.”“And Fernand?” asked the abbé.“Fernand is a great man. He is a count, and he is very rich. He has a fine house in Paris, and he has a fine son. He is happy, I think. He has forgotten the past.”“And you?” asked the abbé.“I? I am still Caderousse, the innkeeper. I am not rich, but I am not unhappy. I have enough to live on, and I have my wife. We are not rich, but we are honest people.”“And Danglars?” asked the abbé.“Danglars is a great man. He is a baron, and he is very rich. He is a banker, and he has a fine house in Paris. He is happy, I think. He has forgotten the past.”“And M. Morrel?” asked the abbé.“M. Morrel is ruined. He has lost all his ships, and he is very poor. He is not happy, I think. He has not forgotten the past.”“And old Dantès?” asked the abbé.“Old Dantès is dead. He died of grief, I think. He was very unhappy.”“And you say that Mercédès is not happy?” asked the abbé.“I do not know. She is a great lady, and she has a fine son, but I do not know if she is happy. There are times when she looks very sad, and I have seen her weep. But do not tell her that I told you this. She would be very angry.”

The abbé opened his mouth, hesitated for a moment, then, making an effort at self-control, he said, “And Mercédès—they tell me that she has disappeared?”

Caderousse started, his bleary eyes widening slightly. He swallowed hard, the wine seemingly catching in his throat. “Disappeared?” he echoed, a nervous tremor in his voice. “Well, yes and no, Father. She’s not here, certainly. Not in the Catalans anymore. She… she married.”

The abbé’s face remained impassive, but his eyes, dark and piercing, seemed to bore into Caderousse’s soul. “Married?” he repeated softly, the single word hanging heavy in the air. “To whom?”

“To Fernand,” Caderousse mumbled, looking away. “Fernand Mondego. The one who was her cousin, you know. The fisherman.”

A long silence followed, broken only by the crackling fire and Caderousse’s uneasy shuffling. The abbé leaned back slightly, his hands clasped before him. “Fernand,” he mused aloud, as if tasting the name. “The one who loved her, even when she was betrothed to… to the other?”

“Aye,” Caderousse confirmed, taking another gulp of wine. “He always did. And when Edmond… when the other was taken, she waited. Oh, how she waited! For eighteen months, she did nothing but weep and pray. She swore she would die if he didn’t return. She was like a ghost, Father, a shadow of herself.” He shuddered. “It was terrible to see.”

“And then?” the abbé prompted, his voice still low, almost a whisper.

“And then… well, time passes, doesn’t it? And Fernand was always there. Always watching over her, always ready to help. He joined the army, made a name for himself, came back with money. And Mercédès… she was alone, her father was old and ailing, and the other… he never came back. Everyone said he was dead. Drowned, or killed in prison. So, eventually, she gave in. For her father’s sake, they said. Or maybe just from despair. She married Fernand about eighteen months after the arrest.”

The abbé closed his eyes for a brief second, a flicker of something unreadable crossing his features. When he opened them, they were as cold and sharp as before. “So, she is now Madame de Morcerf, I presume? Fernand having acquired a title?”

events.title: The Diamond's Gift, the Purse's Exchange, and Caderousse's Solemn Oath
detailed_summary: Caderousse explains his belief in Mercédès's unhappiness by recounting his experiences when he sought financial help from his old acquaintances.
Danglars refused to even see him.
Fernand had his valet-de-chambre give Caderousse a hundred francs, without a personal meeting.
However, as Caderousse was leaving Fernand's, Madame de Morcerf (Mercédès) saw him from a window and dropped a purse containing twenty-five louis at his feet, quickly closing the blind.
Regarding M. de Villefort, the Abbé asks about his fate and role in Edmond's misfortunes.

Caderousse states he never knew Villefort well and had nothing to ask of him, only knowing that Villefort married Mademoiselle de Saint-Méran and left Marseilles, presumably achieving wealth and status like the others.
Caderousse concludes that he alone has remained poor, wretched, and forgotten.
The Abbé counters that God's justice may seem delayed but always arrives, then presents Caderousse with a large diamond.

He explains the diamond was intended to be shared among Edmond's friends, but as Edmond had only one true friend, it cannot be divided. He urges Caderousse to take it, sell it for its worth of fifty thousand francs, and use the money to escape his misery.
Caderousse is overwhelmed and hesitant, suspecting a cruel joke.

The Abbé assures him he never jests about such profound feelings and asks, in exchange for the diamond, for the red silk purse M. Morrel left for old Dantès, which Caderousse had mentioned possessing.
Astonished, Caderousse retrieves the faded red silk purse with its copper runners and gives it to the Abbé, who in turn gives him the diamond.
Caderousse exclaims that the Abbé is a man of God for this act of honesty, as no one else knew Edmond had entrusted him with the diamond.
The Abbé mentally notes that Caderousse himself would likely have kept it under similar circumstances.

As the Abbé prepares to leave, Caderousse, to prove the veracity of his entire account, offers to swear upon a crucifix and his wife's testament, invoking his soul's salvation and Christian faith that he has told the truth as it occurred.

Convinced by Caderousse's sincerity, the Abbé accepts his oath, wishes him well with the money, and bids him adieu, expressing his desire to distance himself from men who inflict such harm on one another.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “What makes you believe this?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Adieu; I go far from men who thus so bitterly injure each other.”

events.text_segment:
“What makes you believe this?”
“Why, when I found myself utterly destitute, I thought my old friends would, perhaps, assist me. So I went to Danglars, who would not even receive me. I called on Fernand, who sent me a hundred francs by his valet-de-chambre.”
“Then you did not see either of them?”
“No, but Madame de Morcerf saw me.”
“How was that?”
“As I went away a purse fell at my feet—it contained five-and-twenty louis; I raised my head quickly, and saw Mercédès, who at once shut the blind.”
“And M. de Villefort?” asked the abbé.
“Oh, he never was a friend of mine, I did not know him, and I had nothing to ask of him.”
“Do you not know what became of him, and the share he had in Edmond’s misfortunes?”
“No; I only know that some time after Edmond’s arrest, he married Mademoiselle de Saint-Méran, and soon after left Marseilles; no doubt he has been as lucky as the rest; no doubt he is as rich as Danglars, as high in station as Fernand. I only, as you see, have remained poor, wretched, and forgotten.”
“You are mistaken, my friend,” replied the abbé; “God may seem sometimes to forget for a time, while his justice reposes, but there always comes a moment when he remembers—and behold—a proof!”
As he spoke, the abbé took the diamond from his pocket, and giving it to Caderousse, said, “Here, my friend, take this diamond, it is yours.”
“What, for me only?” cried Caderousse, “ah, sir, do not jest with me!”
“This diamond was to have been shared among his friends. Edmond had one friend only, and thus it cannot be divided. Take the diamond, then, and sell it; it is worth fifty thousand francs, and I repeat my wish that this sum may suffice to release you from your wretchedness.”
“Oh, sir,” said Caderousse, putting out one hand timidly, and with the other wiping away the perspiration which bedewed his brow,—“Oh, sir, do not make a jest of the happiness or despair of a man.”
“I know what happiness and what despair are, and I never make a jest of such feelings. Take it, then, but in exchange——”
Caderousse, who touched the diamond, withdrew his hand.
The abbé smiled.
“In exchange,” he continued, “give me the red silk purse that M. Morrel left on old Dantès’ chimney-piece, and which you tell me is still in your hands.”
Caderousse, more and more astonished, went toward a large oaken cupboard, opened it, and gave the abbé a long purse of faded red silk, round which were two copper runners that had once been gilt. The abbé took it, and in return gave Caderousse the diamond.
“Oh, you are a man of God, sir,” cried Caderousse; “for no one knew that Edmond had given you this diamond, and you might have kept it.”
“Which,” said the abbé to himself, “you would have done.” The abbé rose, took his hat and gloves. “Well,” he said, “all you have told me is perfectly true, then, and I may believe it in every particular.”
“See, sir,” replied Caderousse, “in this corner is a crucifix in holy wood—here on this shelf is my wife’s testament; open this book, and I will swear upon it with my hand on the crucifix. I will swear to you by my soul’s salvation, my faith as a Christian, I have told everything to you as it occurred, and as the recording angel will tell it to the ear of God at the day of the last judgment!”
“’Tis well,” said the abbé, convinced by his manner and tone that Caderousse spoke the truth. “’Tis well, and may this money profit you! Adieu; I go far from men who thus so bitterly injure each other.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: “What makes you believe this?” asked the abbé. “Because,” replied Caderousse, “I have been in the capital, and have asked for assistance from Danglars, who refused to see me, and from Fernand, who sent me a hundred francs by his valet-de-chambre.” “Then she did not assist you?” asked the abbé. “No, but she did better, for she saw me as I was going away, and as the valet-de-chambre shut the door, she opened the window, and threw me out a purse containing five-and-twenty louis. I picked them up, and blessed her. She is the only one who had pity on me, and I am sure she is unhappy.” “And M. de Villefort?” asked the abbé; “did he ever attain to the high station he desired?” “Yes, he is procureur du roi at Paris.” “He is married?” “Yes, to the daughter of the Count de Saint-Méran, a very rich heiress.” “So that,” remarked the abbé, “these four persons, who have been the cause of the ruin of Edmond Dantès, have elevated themselves, as it were, upon his ruin, and have gained wealth, honours, and position, while Edmond Dantès has perished in the depth of a dungeon?” “It is so,” replied Caderousse, “and I only, who had no share in their crimes, have remained poor, wretched, and forgotten.” “You are mistaken, my friend,” replied the abbé; “God may seem sometimes to forget, while his justice reposes, but there always comes a moment when he remembers, and behold! that moment has come for you, since you are poor, and I am sent to you by him.” “By whom?” asked Caderousse. “By the man you have just mentioned,—Edmond Dantès.” Caderousse gave a loud cry, and threw himself back in his chair, which cracked beneath his weight. “By Edmond Dantès? Impossible!” he cried; “since he is dead.” “He is not dead; he is living, and has sent me to you.” “He is living?” repeated Caderousse, mechanically; “then he is out of prison?” “He is out of prison, as you see, and is rich, powerful, and honoured.” “Then you are his friend?” asked Caderousse. “I am more than his friend; I am his confessor.” “And he has sent you to me?” “Yes, he has sent me to you to give you this.” The abbé took from his pocket a diamond of the size of a hazel-nut, and gave it to Caderousse. “For me?” cried Caderousse; “for me? What is it?” “It is a diamond,” replied the abbé; “it is worth fifty thousand francs.” “Fifty thousand francs!” cried Caderousse; “it is impossible! You are jesting with me.” “I never jest about such things,” replied the abbé; “this diamond is yours, sell it, and with the money buy yourself a house, a field, or whatever you please.” “But why does he give me this?” asked Caderousse; “why does he give me fifty thousand francs?” “Because,” replied the abbé, “he had a diamond which he intended to share with his friends, and as he had but one friend, he gives it to you.” “But I am not his friend,” said Caderousse; “I betrayed him.” “Yes,” replied the abbé; “you betrayed him, but you repented, and that is why he forgives you.” “He forgives me?” cried Caderousse; “he forgives me? Oh, I am unworthy of his forgiveness!” “He knows that,” replied the abbé; “but he is a Christian, and he forgives you.” “Then,” said Caderousse, “this diamond is really mine?” “Yes,” replied the abbé; “it is yours.” Caderousse was so overcome that he could not speak; he looked at the diamond, then at the abbé, then at the diamond again, and at last, with a deep sigh, he said, “But what must I do for this?” “You must do nothing,” replied the abbé; “it is a gift.” “A gift?” repeated Caderousse; “a gift of fifty thousand francs? It is impossible!” “It is true,” said the abbé. “Then,” said Caderousse, “you are a man of God.” “I am a man of God,” replied the abbé, “but I am also a man of justice.” “And what do you ask in return?” asked Caderousse. “I ask nothing in return,” replied the abbé; “but I advise you to make a good use of this money.” “Oh, I will,” said Caderousse; “I will indeed. I will buy a house, and a field, and I will work, and I will be honest.” “That is well,” said the abbé; “and now, give me the red silk purse which M. Morrel left for old Dantès, and which you have.” Caderousse was thunderstruck; he looked at the abbé with a bewildered air. “The red silk purse?” he stammered; “how do you know that?” “I know everything,” replied the abbé, with a smile. Caderousse went to a cupboard, and took out a small red silk purse, faded and worn, with copper runners. “Here it is,” he said, giving it to the abbé. “It is well,” said the abbé, taking the purse; “and now, farewell. Make a good use of the money, and be happy.” “Oh, I will,” said Caderousse; “I will indeed. You are a man of God.” “Farewell,” said the abbé, and he went out. Caderousse remained alone,

events.title: La Carconte's Suspicion and Caderousse's Hasty Resolve
detailed_summary: After the Abbé struggles to depart amidst Caderousse's effusive thanks and rides away, Caderousse turns to find his wife, La Carconte, looking paler and more trembling than ever.
She immediately questions if everything she overheard, particularly the Abbé giving them the diamond, is truly real.
Caderousse, still dazed with joy, affirms its truth and shows her the diamond.
La Carconte gazes at it, then gloomily suggests it might be false.
This idea startles Caderousse, who turns pale, muttering in disbelief why the man would give him a counterfeit diamond.
La Carconte scoffs that it would be a way to obtain his secrets without paying, calling him a blockhead.
Caderousse, momentarily aghast, quickly decides to verify its authenticity.
He announces he will go to the fair at Beaucaire, where Parisian jewelers are always present, to have the diamond appraised.
Instructing his wife to look after the house, he states he will be back in two hours and hastily departs, running in the opposite direction to the one the Abbé had taken.
Left alone, La Carconte mutters that fifty thousand francs is a significant sum but does not constitute a true fortune.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The abbé with difficulty got away from the enthusiastic thanks of Caderousse, opened the door himself, got out and mounted his horse, once more saluted the innkeeper, who kept uttering his loud farewells, and then returned by the road he had travelled in coming.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Fifty thousand francs!” muttered La Carconte when left alone; “it is a large sum of money, but it is not a fortune.”

events.text_segment:
The abbé with difficulty got away from the enthusiastic thanks of Caderousse, opened the door himself, got out and mounted his horse, once more saluted the innkeeper, who kept uttering his loud farewells, and then returned by the road he had travelled in coming.
When Caderousse turned around, he saw behind him La Carconte, paler and trembling more than ever.
“Is, then, all that I have heard really true?” she inquired.
“What? That he has given the diamond to us only?” inquired Caderousse, half bewildered with joy; “yes, nothing more true! See, here it is.”
The woman gazed at it a moment, and then said, in a gloomy voice, “Suppose it’s false?”
Caderousse started and turned pale.
“False!” he muttered. “False! Why should that man give me a false diamond?”
“To get your secret without paying for it, you blockhead!”
Caderousse remained for a moment aghast under the weight of such an idea.
“Oh!” he said, taking up his hat, which he placed on the red handkerchief tied round his head, “we will soon find out.”
“In what way?”
“Why, the fair is on at Beaucaire, there are always jewellers from Paris there, and I will show it to them. Look after the house, wife, and I shall be back in two hours,” and Caderousse left the house in haste, and ran rapidly in the direction opposite to that which the priest had taken.
“Fifty thousand francs!” muttered La Carconte when left alone; “it is a large sum of money, but it is not a fortune.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The abbé with difficulty got away from the enthusiastic thanks of Caderousse, opened the door himself, got out and mounted his horse, once more saluted the innkeeper, who kept uttering his loud farewells, and then returned by the road he had travelled in coming. Caderousse remained in a kind of ecstasy. Why should he give me a false diamond?” he asked. “To get your secret without paying for it, you blockhead!” Caderousse stood for a moment aghast at this suggestion, but he quickly recovered and smiled with a confident air. “False!” said he; “false! you cannot be serious, wife. Do you think a man would risk his life, as he did, to come and tell me that? Besides, look at it; see how it sparkles! Oh, my wife, this is a true diamond, and worth fifty thousand francs!” “Or perhaps,” said La Carconte, “it is only a lump of glass. Who knows?” “I will know,” replied Caderousse; “I will go to the fair at Beaucaire, where there are always Parisian jewellers, and I will show it to them. I will be back in two hours.” And, instructing his wife to take care of the house, he went out, and ran in the direction opposite to that which the abbé had taken. “Fifty thousand francs,” muttered La Carconte, when she was alone; “it is a large sum, but it is not a fortune.”
